content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
For those interested in this game, here are some details that are useful to know.You are a bipedal tank:--- Your torso moves separate from legs, and some Mechs have Jump Jets, which allow short flight depending on the number of JJ's equipped.This is a team game:--- Stay with the pack, especially when you first start. Don't be the only Mech the enemy sees.One Life to Live:In standard "Quick Play" game you drop in one Mech, after you die, you will have to wait until that game is finished before you can play that Mech again. In Faction Play (Clan Warfare) you get to drop with 4 Mechs.This is a "slow" paced shooter:--- Movement and turn speeds are based on the Mech you are in, not the speed you set your mouse to. Variation:---The speed difference alone between the fastest and slowest Mech is over 100kph, leading to huge variations in play style. Aside from this, Lasers, Ballistics/PPCs, Long Range Missiles (LRMs), and Short Range Missiles (SRMs) all have different methods to success.Location based damage:---  If you "spray and pray", you will get damage in, but fail to kill your opponent. Targeting vital spots is key to putting the enemy down. Let your lasers burn the whole duration into your opponent to get full damage. The opposite is true if you are getting shot, make sure to turn your torso to spread damage.Heat management is very important:--- Almost all weapons create heat on use, and if not managed will put you into a shutdown state, or if you override the shutdown, do extreme internal damage.Customization: --- Setting your Mech up with weapons and armor of your choosing is the one of the best parts of the game, but you don't get to do that until you buy your own Mech. This does not mean you have to spend real money however, as they give you large bonuses for the first 20 or so matches. Do make your first choice wisely, the forums are a good place to get suggestions.Cost:--- You can get a lot out of this game for free. The way you earn money (C-bills) to buy Mechs is by playing more matches, so I can't really consider it a grind. You do need to have Mech Bays in order to buy Mechs however, and these cost MC, which is real money currency.  If you are patient PGI does give away MC and Mech Bays during special events for participation, and task competition. Some Mechs, called Hero Mechs can only be purchased with MC, the only thing that makes them worthwhile is a bonus to C-bill earning, otherwise they are mostly just novelty paint, on a somewhat unique loadout, however never really better than what you can buy normally. If you do want to spend money, I suggest buying MC in a quantity that gets a good discount and buying Mech Bays when they go on sale. Competitive: --- The Match Maker works fairly well, though it is population dependent. If you are new, you will start at the bottom "Tier" which is 5. As you move up, not only does individual skill ramp up, but so does group cooperation.NGNG has a good youtube channel if you want to see some gameplay.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Soon I'm sure you'll see a flood of reviews, highlighting the best and worst MechWarrior and Pirrana Games has to offer. On one hand, you'll have people who have played this game for three years and have never had a problem with it. On the other, you'll have people who have felt burned, rightfully so, and still have residual resentment for it. I want to be a slightly more moderate voice, and try my best to review the game as I see it.I want to start, by saying I find the game fun, and I've been playing it on and off for three years. It's a very niche game, even if it didn't have giant stompy robots which is a niche genre all itself, it's "a thinking man's shooter" which takes a more slow, methodical approach to First Person Shooters. Because of this, it offers a very unique experience which, if you like that sort of thing like I do, it's very hard to find another game that quite scratches the same itch. The game is Free to Play in the same sort of way that Ketchup is a vegetable, it's technically accurate for some value of the term. For the most part, at it's best, the game is Pay2NotGrind and Pay4Vanity. At it's worst, however, you have things like the Stalker Hero "Misery," a $30 dollar reasonably solid 'meta' mech that is only available with cash money.Which is actually the real bulk of the problem, the pricing for the game is very, very high for very little. You can take a look for yourself at the "DLC" on this page - each of those Performance Packs are for two mechs, which - minus a boost to the earnable in-game currency - are identical to their earnable with in-game currency counterparts. I'm sure you'll hear about the $500 gold mech packages they offered a year ago, ( technically, still are offering from a year ago ) but that really is a extreme, argueably not entirely PGIs fault since they were still under IGP at the time, and I'd like to believe everyone involved has learned their lession and will never do anything like it again ( although, like I said, the offer is still available. )  The more consistant reality of it is somewhere around $20-30 for a mech, which is still fairly high.The good news is, for the most part, nearly all mechs become available with the earnable in-game currency some months after they're released to people who first "pre-ordered" the mechs in early access packs, and after they're released to people for cash money. ( Pay2NotWait? ) Usually this isn't a problem although sometimes the mechs are slightly to very OP and unbalance things, making the game unfun for anyone who didn't pre-order. The only real exception to this are "Hero" mechs which normally are slightly underpowered but gimmicky varriants of a mech, sometimes with ties into lore, but generally aren't the best version of any mech. Usually. There are exceptions. A lot of the residual resentment I mentioned earlier stems from the previous tendency to remain close-lipped about the direction the game was going, to ignore any real community feedback, and a very slow development cycle. Most of these have been improved upon since PGI got out from under IGPs thumb - Development has severely picked up pace and new things besides mech packs have been added to the game fairly frequently. PGI is much more open about what they're doing / what direction they want to move the game into. Feedback from what I've seen is still somewhat spotty, although from my understanding they decided to not go through with "ghost damage," a mechanic that was nearly universally hated - where in the past they would have just gone through and added it anyway ( looking at you 3rd Person and Ghost Heat ) - so, I suppose that too is improving. Overall, since I need to select Yes or No to "Do you recommend this game?" I have to say no.I like the game, I find it fun, but that doens't make it a good game by default. Between shaking off the ghost of IGP past, elements from three years ago which still feel unfinished ( mostly looking at Community Warfare here, which while "still in beta" has been worked on since launch ) and a high cost of premium elements ... It's just not a good game for the everyman. Added onto the fact that even if this game was perfect, it would still be kind of a niche game - and some people would just not be able to get into it - it makes those flaws even more hard to overlook when considering a binary "Yes or No" answer.I would, however, suggest that if you think you might be able to get into it - to at least give it a try and find out. Don't spend any money on it until you're sure you like it, but if you do - like I said, it's a fairly unique experience and hard to find games quite like it.Small, Edit : Everything up until this point is aimed for potential new players, not members of the prexisting userbase. I don't need to explain what's good or bad with the game to you, you already know and have your own opinions, and that's fine, you're more then welcome to make your own review or tell me what you agree or disagree about mine - conversation is good.But, this, and only this is specifically for the prexisting userbase - I understand you like this game, I understand being critical of things you enjoy can be hard, but be a little respectful, would you? If you're so concerned about one negative review turning people away then how do you think they're going to react when they read the comment section?

												Always press RTurn off arm lock and throttle decay when you learn how to walk. Press X to stop.Use arrows and right control to assign weapon groups.«CLAN» doesn't mean «unit of players» in this game, it's lore stuff, google for «Battletech clans» (you will also find out why 90% of players have Kerensky in their nicknames). Ammo can explode. Except Gauss ammo. Other equipment doesn't explode. Except Gauss rifle.You can switch ECM modes with J button.Pegular PPC doesn't deal any damage in range below 90 meters.You will get banned for mentioning Hitler. 40 years old men playing this game don't get jokes.Hold alt while entering 3rd peson mode to keep minimap active.And don't forget to add smurfy mechlab and Sarna to your bookmarks.Now you can robot.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Edit:There seem to be a lot of people who are eager to downvote reviews for no reason.I'm up for criticism, so if you find my review to be not helpful, let me know why.The Thing:Since it's release I've been coming back to this game and it will very likely remain one of my all time favoritesDon't let my relatively low play time on Steam fool you. I've been playing this game for a long time before it was on Steam. [hipster]And obviously before it was cool.[/hipster]The thing I probably like most about it is it's complexity. It is indeed a rather complex game and it requires time to learn and overcome. If you prefer a more casual approach to a game similar (similar, not the same!) to this, I'd recommend Robocraft.(EDIT: I do not recommend Robocraft anymore!)But this here is Robocraft for grown-ups, for people with fully developed breasts and beards.I'm serious. You will have to invest time into this game for it to be good. And, if you do, it's going to be really good, that much I can tell you.What to expect: Very tactical and very team-oriented games of 12 versus 12 giant robots from the future, armed to the teeth. Mostly extremely customizable mech-loadouts (depending on faction).Any mech plays differently, some of them fundamentally differently. Even a single mech can play very differently, if you just change the weapons.Do you like to let rockets rain down on your enemies from 1000 meters away? Or do you want to do sustained damage with lasers over medium distances? Maybe you like to just go in and brawl face to face with short range missiles. Maybe you feel like a supporter and want to help your mates by providing visuals on enemies for your team to lock on. The four weight classes (light, medium, heavy, assault) are very distinct from one another.Lights, for instance, are able to easily outmaneuver the rather cumbersome assault mechs. But lights also have very little armor and, of course, not as much firepower as the bigger ones.Medium mechs feel like a good allround-weight class, probably best to start with.Heavies to me are, well, heavier mediums. That's not meant to sound derogatory. After all, heavies are heavier than mediums, because they have more room for armor and weapons. They're probably as good of a weight class to start out with as mediums. Within the game itself there's both a casual approach, as well as a more competetive player base.You can drop (your mech gets deployed by a dropship) in games alone with other loners, who might play well as a team or mess up completely, because they're bad at communicating. These drops are referred to as PUG-drops (Pick Up Group). Or you can form a group of up to 12 players and drop with them.There's faction play, where units (basically the name for the guys with tags in front of their names, in other games usually called 'clans') come together to fight for star systems. They can control star systems and have to defend them against other units, or they will lose control over them.There's also a lot of people role playing, who enjoy lore-based... stuff. I mean, lore-based things, you get the idea. Duels between two mechs for instance, with important things like, I don't know, honor and♥♥♥♥♥♥ Read the books. The devs are cool and nice and react and interact and everything. They stream on Twitch on a regular basis where you can watch them work on new content and watch them just generally be in touch with their player base. The devs also reward players for playing. There's been customer appreciation reward programs. Within these you'd receive rewards varying from C-Bill-rewards (C-Bills are the ingame currency you earn by playing) just for playing the game. Plus, if you've decided to put money into the game and buy MC (the ingame currency bought for $$$) or one of their mech packs, you usually get a whole bunch of other things (including MECHS!) for free. This game has one of the most mature player bases I know. People usually are more respectful and more helpful. After all, there's a high likelihood of them having fully developed breasts and beards.You can easily drop into a game at any time, ask for new friends and what you get is people who want to marry you. There's also a looking for group function in the main menu. This way you can easily group up with strangers from all over the world. It's like OKcupid, but with giant stomping robots, war and explosions. What more could you wish for?There are a few things that shouldn't go unmentioned, though: In the beginning, meaning for your first 25 matches, you will receive very high C-Bill rewards. Same goes for completing the tutorial, which you should play in any case. You'll have a few million C-Bills after completing those first matches and the tutorial. After this, however, progress will be much slower.You have to be aware that sometimes earning C-Bills feels like grinding. Other times it's a lot of fun, because it just happens while playing. After all, there's a certain satisfaction to melting through your enemies' armor and soldering off their arms to cripple their firepower. I mean it. This is something I haven't experienced in any other game so far. It is after your 25 first matches and after the completion of the tutorial when you should start looking for which mech you want to buy first. For this you'll have to read into the meta a little, at least that's what I'd recommend. There are some helpful videos on the Tubes of You, too.Search for mechs that are good, avoid mechs that really are bad (not many, but they do exist at the moment).And if at first you don't like the mech you purchased, don't worry. It might just take some time to get used to it and figure out the way it's played best. This really does take some time with any mech, especially if you're just starting out. So take your time, don't get frustrated too easily.If after a while you still don't like your first mech, try different builds on it. If you still don't like it, try a mech of another weight class. You will have to use trial mechs for your first games. These mechs are being interchanged every now and then, so people can try out different ones.There are 4 mechs free to use in every weight class. 2 of each belong to one of the two factions: The Inner Sphere or the invading Clans. The game is not pay to win.Yes, certain mechs are only available for MC. But they are not superior. Some (few!) of them happen to be within higher tiers of the current meta, but they are surrounded and outnumbered by mechs for C-Bills. Others are only available for real $$$ over a period of time, before getting released for the purchase with C-Bills.Some of the things you can buy for MC include premium time and cosmetic items, such as paint jobs for your mech or cockpit items.By the way, there are lots of events that let you earn cosmetic items, mech bays or even mechs, simply by participating. You will need free mech bays in order to park new mechs.In the beginning you have a few free mech bays. Once they are full, you obviously need new ones. Mech bays can only be bought for MC OR have to be earned by participating in events. If you really, really don't want to invest any money whatsoever in this game, you can do so. But then you should make sure to participate in most of the events. Otherwise you won't have enough free bays to park your mechs at some point.tl;drWow. This was a long review.Unfortunately there is no way for me make this short. It is a complex game that deserves a long review. I recommend you read the whole thing.Ultimately I recommend you play the game.

												Being a mechwarrior since 1995 and MWO player since beta, with over 500hrs actual playtime on the battlefields plus around 400hrs more in the mechlab and over 500€ spent in mech packs and MC, I guess I can proudly call myself a mechwarrior veteran.Even this game has nothing much left to do with the former serie except the lore itself and its technichal gameset, I can still say that MWO is the best free-to-play game on the market, next to Planetside 2 and War Thunder.Overall it wins mostly because of its community. Really, the community is massive. You dont get that often in the F2P era...Pros:+ hundreds of different mechs+ all highly customizable+ complex loadout editor/mechlab+ multiple classes/roles to play+ events with free stuff every week+ big legit, active and nice community+ both competitive and lore friendly+ leagues+ a lot of different factions to fight for+ 4 gamemmodes+ decent amount of maps+ runs smooth and stable+ thousands of units to play with+ voice chat+ frequent updates (yes they work on it 24/7!)+ tiersCons:- tiers- time and money consuming (as all F2P titles)- steep learning curve- unforgiving gameplay- "sometimes" frustrating- minor bugs- no AI (yet!)- still no coop (but announced for 2016)- some mechs can only bought with real money (they are not better or something - NO PAY TO WIN HERE!)- too few maps imo- THE META!Pro Tips:- look at the map constantly- find allies, stick together- make friends, join a unit- don't be a♥♥♥♥♥♥ no place for Rambos- read about the lore, know the enemy- get used to die asap- get better and stronger, gg(Please dont expect a new mechwarrior game...this one is a competitive version of it! You can not compare both.)gl hf 07[DUDE]Nam Neckcrit

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
Let me preface this by saying I am still playing MWO, off and on, and will continue playing it because it does enough things right to be a worthwhile game.  If you don't care about the background skip to the pros and cons!Keep in mind when reading MWO Steam reviews that there is a huge community schism regarding MWO.  Many old players (sometimes called 'Islanders') are justifyably frustrated by PGI's handling of the game.  Others (the 'white-knights') believe that the game is finally in a good place and is getting better, and that PGI is therefore forgiven for past transgressions.  Most probably fall somewhere in-between.  I would like to imagine I fall somewhere into the third camp.Now for the bad news.  As many things as MechWarrior Online does right, there are still so many things wrong with it I cannot in good conscience recommend it to new players.  I will skip the diatribe about PGI's terrible history with community relations (I was a Legendary Founder which means I paid way too much money during alpha for a product that fell short of almost all of its design goals) and focus on the pros and cons of the game as it stands now.  Other reviews adequately cover the game's rocky history.What I like-Very graphically appealing-Sound is immersive-Combat feels visceral and intense.  Inflicting and recieving damage involves a lot of sparks, explosions and camera shake-Battlemechs have never felt stompier!-Matches are generally fast and tight-Weapons feel thematic (Lasers travel instantaneously and 'burn' for an extended duration, missiles are fired in swarms, ballistics throw sparks on impact and cause the victim's cockpit to jerk)-Is fairly simple to learn and play without lacking strategic depth -Teamwork is paramount and rewarded through play-The community can be great-A number of people have correctly pointed out that new players get a number of c-bill injections to help them outfit their first mech or two.  It's a nice touch, as long as new players are careful about what they spend this cash onWhat I don't-The grind is obscene.  There are people who will tell you otherwise.  They play a lot more than you and have the skills, equipment and chassis to rack up those c-bills.  As a new player, you won't have this luxury, so expect an uphill battle to afford even one properly equipped chassis with double heat sinks, endo-steel structure, an engine that doesn't suck and a loadout that won't overheat after one alpha this isn't entirely true anymore, new players will likely be able to afford their first chassis relatively quickly but will suffer from a rapid dropoff of income once their rookie bonus runs out-Related to the above, PGI prices content like mechs higher than any other F2P game I've ever played.  Hearthstone and League of Legends both require far less time and money to 'max out' an account on, and many complain about the grind in those games-The metagame is somewhat rigid and PGI hasn't done a great job of balancing it-There is a serious lack of variety in terms of maps and modes - while it is not as bad as it used to be pretty much there are only two things to do, competitive community warfare matches (meh) and random queue brawls (this is almost all of what you'll be doing)-Grind-New players aren't given any freebies, they have to play with garbage trial mechs that use stock configurations from the tabletop game until they can afford to invest in one of their own It has been brought to my attention this is no longer the case.  The trial mechs are far better designed than they used to be, I might even pilot a few tonight!-While the bonus cash for new accounts is nice, the falloff afterwards can be pretty staggering.  Especially since you still need to skill 3 variants of a mech in order to unlock the elite skills-Lack of variety is crippling to any long term enjoyment from this game.  You will VERY quickly memorize the map pool and even if you are one of those crazies who enjoys community warfare you'll find the only novelty in the game comes from the new overpriced chassis they churn out.-Few game modes-The community can suck-Did I mention the grind?ConclusionI usually don't review games on steam, but I felt compelled to in this case.  MWO is very close to being the great game it always had the potential to be, but PGI needs to seriously reconsider their pricing model as well as the pacing of in-game rewards if they don't want to drive away most of their new Steam players.As a prospective player, my recommendation would be that you play the game and find out for yourself.  It costs you nothing but the time it takes to download and play it, so unless you're an impulsive spender it can't really hurt to see if it appeals to you.  There isn't really anything else like it on the market.Edit: for those who don't understand why I gave this game a negative review despite its merits, there is no option between 'recommend' or 'not recommend'.  For the time being my opinion leans towards the latter.Edit 2:  I pretty much ditched this game entirely shortly after writing this review.  At least at the time PGI's energies were almost entirely spent on dishing out new chassis they could sell and the myriad problems with the game appeared to have mostly fallen by the wayside.  As such take anything I've written here with a grain of salt as it may be out of date.  Probably not though, knowing PGI.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												I have played a lot of Mechwarrior Online. To qualify that: I was one of the first 500 invited into the closed beta in 2012. I have also played community warfare (CW) with some of the best players in the game since that game mode was added over a year ago. In 2011 I bought a 60 (Canadian) dollar founders pack for this game, because I feel that is a sane and reasonable limit to spend for a quality videogame product. And, despite the thumbs down on this review, at the time I was completely happy with my purchase. That 60 dollar founders pack came with an exclusive mech, 30 days of premium time, and 20 000 MC (the paid for currency of this game).Today to buy the same collection of things in mechwarrior will cost you over 100 American dollars, and brings up the real issue I have with this game: The fun you will have is a byproduct of a gaming experience that has been designed from the ground up to take from you.If you decide to play this game, you will face an extremely punishing grind. "Mastering" a mech involves grinding out three tiers of skills with xp, which unlocks various bonuses that are straight upgrades. If you want that 7.5% faster run speed (huge) you will need to basic out all the elite skills on 3 mechs of the same chassis, essentially slightly different versions of the same mech. This is assuming that you have ground out enough cash to purchase the 3 mechs, and outfit them with good weapons, and upgrade them properly. It goes without saying that all of this takes a significant amount of time.The classic rebuttal to this is the argument that this is a free to play game, and people are free to pay to bypass the grind. That fails to denude the fact that this game will either take a lot of your time, or a lot of your money, or sometimes both (you can't buy those mastery skills but you can buy premium to help you grind faster). The carrot of mech stomping laser blasting fun lies at the top of a steep greasy hill, and the people on that hill will be firing at you the whole time you're climbing up.This is the price you are expected to pay as a new player, and it is why I cannot recommend this game to any of my friends or you."review the game play" - Man in comments sectionThe basic controls and movement in MWO are actually pretty solid, it's probably the thing this game does the best. You feel like a big heavy mech, your arm weapons can track different target than your torso weapons, you get stuck on tiny rocks a LOT. That last item was sarcasm. You will constantly be clipping up against small pieces of terrain that don't really serve a purpose and can't be destroyed or crushed like a proper mech should be able to do. Also, as a related issue, there are problems with the hitboxes on a lot of terrain. You will often see your lasers and autocanons impact a rock that is visually several feet to the side. Also, there are no targets in this game other than enemy mechs. There are no tanks, vehicles, helicopters, or infantry to give you a sense of scale to undercut how much psychotic power you should be feeling while driving a multi story killing machine. The hitboxes on mechs also suffer a lot of problems related to their geometry. You can take damage on your back armour when being shot from the front sometimes for no reason.The weapon balance in this game is atrocious, but I'm not going to be able to talk about balance in this game without incurring a LOT of vitriol from old timey mechwarrior fans who's deluded iron grip on a tabletop game that ceased to be relevant 20 years ago turns every rational discussion about balance in this game into a horde of mewling cries of "th th thats not like the tabletop!" So I expect to have a lot of fun with the comments section after this edit. The battletech tabletop game doesn't let players control which part of the enemy mech they shoot, it's decided with 2d6 instead. In the land of first person shooters, you get to decide how you want to click on the screen, which is something a lot of the diehard tabletop crew isn't very good at and doesn't understand. In MWO, the best builds are the ones that do a ton of alpha damage to a concentrated specific part of the enemy mech, usually center torso or legs. That is just objectively the fastest way to kill someone. The best weapons for this are lasers, because they are hitscan, have decent range, and also weigh much less than their counterparts, ballistic and missile weapons. For the most part, there is no reason to use anything else. On the other end of the spectrum, you have long range missiles (LRMs) which are laughably useless. They require a target lock, and then you need to wait for a long arcing travel time while maintaining that lock for the missiles to connect. They hit in a spread pattern which doesn't synergize with the whole "kill them quickly" plan. They also have a minimum range, where the missiles just impact and do nothing. Also, the expensive and costly "target deprivation" pilot module breaks target lock as soon as you break line of sight. Experienced players who know how to position themselves almost never get hit.Clan vs Inner Sphere is also a big problem. In Battletech lore, the clans are a seperate faction of militant space facists who show up halfway into the timeline so FASA could make some more money. Clan mechs run faster, carry more weapons for less weight, have improved cooling, carry more armour, and take more internal damage before being destroyed. They also have the only mechs in the game with MASC at the moment, which is basically a sprint button. The developers initially added clans into the game with the same values they had on the tabletop without really any balance considerations. Whoever had spent real money on a clan mech was god for several months. The developers tried to bring Inner Sphere mechs up to par by giving them "quirks" internal perks that are bound to specific chassis that do things like increase heat dissipation or decrease cooldown on specific types of weapons. This system works but only for a small handful inner sphere mechs out of hundreds of possible choices, the rest of them have mostly useless quirks, like increased range on anti missile systems (nobody uses these).The reality of this is mostly ignored by a huge section of the community. You will rarely see good builds, even at the highest matchmaking tier. You will also run into a lot of people who call themselves "support players" which is just another way of saying that they will be the last on your team to die hiding behind a hill because they only brought LRMs. If you ask for advice, most of the time that advice will be wrong. I can honestly say that this is one of the most fanatically ignorant gaming communities that I have ever born witness to.If you plan to play with anything less than 11 other friends this game is miserable to play from a team co-ordination perspective. Most solo queue matches involve teams milling around aimlessly until one of them is dead. If you queue up with a buddy, you will end up in the group queue with a bunch of other small un-cordinated teams usually sided against a full 12 man most of the time. If you queue up for CW by yourself things only get worse, because those games take longer, usually end up more lopsided, and have no actual matchmaking to determine who plays who.This game is basically the video game interpretation of the malebolge from Dante's Inferno.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												How can I sum up something so great as Mechwarrior Online into a short, readable review that won't sink too deep in analysing the techical aspects of the game?Let's start by explaning what this game is all about...Mechwarrior Online is set in the Battletech universe (1984), where different clans fight from planets and resources. You play 12 vs. 12 matches in various game modes and maps. Fighting, winning, and getting more money according to your combat performance has a great role in the game, but tinkering and customizing your 'Mechs is also a HUGE part of MWO (Mechwarrior Online).'MechsSo what are Mechwarriors then? Mechwarriors are the brave pilots of these huge lumbering mechanical tanks that have evolved from the basic battletank design into more efficient walking weapon platforms, 'Mechs.'Mechs are divided into different categories according to their chassis weight: Light Mechs (35 tons), Medium Mechs (55 tons), Heavy Mechs (75 tons) and Assault Mechs (100 tons).Lights are commonly used as scouts and intel 'Mechs, but they're also very efficient at taking down bigger assault mechs due to their great mobility. A pack of fast moving Light Mechs can easily swarm a bigger, slower 'Mech punching holes into the armors, tearing down weapons and limbs, eventually destroying it. And that can happen very fast if you're stranded too far from your team members.Medium and Heavy Mechs are bit bigger, slower, carry more armaments and armor and can take up more beating than Light Mechs.Assault Mechs are the biggest, slowest heavy hitters that you can see on the battlefield. A good Assault pilot will wreck everything coming it's way - but do not think that more weapons always means more success in combat. There are so many factors that you have to think during combat.


Viridian Bog - Hunchback-4P a.k.a. "Meltdown" warming up some metal. 
A Screenshot of MechWarrior Online
By: Blackloch°




'Mech LoadoutsEvery new 'Mech you buy comes with a stock loadout. Every 'Mech has 3-7 variants, which means the chassis of the 'Mech is pretty much the same, but the weapon hardpoints are different. One chassis might be more suitable for missile focused loadouts and other might have only hardpoints for energy weapons. On top of that, every chassis has Quirks, that give bonuses for movement, torso rotation speed, laser range, missile cooldowns etc. As I'm writing this review (Jan, 2016) there's been some rumours about the Quirks system going away somewhere in future, but I can't verify it at the moment. Personally I've always like the Quirk system, as it makes even the "crappiest" 'Mechs still good when compared to the best of the best Clan 'Mechs.The great thing in MWO is that you aren't limited into certain builds on every 'Mech. Once you select a 'Mech and open the loadout screen, you can fine tune pretty much everything from it and these all have advantages/disadvantages on battlefield. For example engines: you are free to tear down that small engine and replace it with a bigger, more faster engine. That'll make your 'Mech jog around faster, but bigger engine always means more weight too. More engine weight means less free tonnages available for weapon systems and other equipment. You can replace the normal STD-engines with lighter XL-engines. XL-engine weights less, but takes more space - and every 'Mech has a certain amount of free slots for equipment. On top of that the XL engine takes up space from both sides of torso too (Normal STD engine only uses center torso), so if someone punches a hole into your side torso, the engine is destroyed immediately. Destroyed engine means, blood, tears and game over.To combat the tonnage limit of every 'Mech, you can modify the chassis by replacing the stock structures with more lighter Endosteel structure. This will free up some more tonnages for armaments, but once again, takes up more space. When juggling for a balanced build for your new ultimate 'Mech, you should keep in mind that all weapons create heat too. The constant shooting of lasers for example can overheat the systems, which causes the 'Mech to shutdown. You can disable this overheat protection manually in tight spots, which basically means you can strain the system longer, keep on shooting and let your 'Mech take some punishment. If you overheat too much, it could lead into ammo explosion inside torso, which equals a wrecked 'Mech - or the weapons in your arms might explode, which usually means the losing of that arm.The possibilities are quite endless and I don't want this review turn into a full 'Mech building guide. I'm just trying to give you an idea how vast the 'Mech customizing options are. There are lots of advanced guides available in the Internet about 'Mech builds, module usage and group tactics. Some of the biggest clans also help train their pilots.Everything you do on the battlefield gains you points. This means doing damage to enemy 'Mechs, making the final killshot, assisting other with target painters, UAV drones, protecting your fellow Mechwarriors with ECM blanket etc. These points gain you pilot AND Mech experience (XP). These XP-points can be then used to unlock new modules and perks for your 'Mechs - making you better equipped and more skilled in combat. The list of the skills, modules and one-shot consumbales is quite vast, so there's no point of me listing them here.But you'll probably get the picture now. You can fine tune and micro manage alot of things in your 'Mechs. But this doesn't mean you have to. The basic loadouts are decent and there are Trial 'Mechs available for new pilots. These Trial 'Mechs change from time to time and they are a good way to give you a feeling what might work best for you.Free tipIf you're interested in the game and want to give it a spin, I'll higly recommend you first go through the tutorials. Not because "we don't like noobs in the battlefield". Well, we do hate it - but completing the tutorials give you a generous amount of starting capital for your first own 'Mech. And as a new player your get cadet bonus from your first 25 games, so if you go there with no idea how to play the game, you just probably f*ck up your first 10 games, get sucky points, gain less money and cadet bonus on top of that.Be a valuable asset to your team - get more points - earn more money - earn more Cadet Bonus. That'll be enough to give you a good amount of money to buy a decent 'Mech with a custom loadout. Oh, and don't accept every opinion you read as the only "truth". There are many ways to play this game and if some 'Mech is especially good in one thing, it doesn't mean you HAVE TO play it like that. F2P? P2WIN? C-Bill? MC?Like any other Free-To-Play game these days, MWO also has micro transactions for cosmetic stuff like colors, camo patterns, cockpit items etc. If you feel like supporting the game - or just want to save time - you can also buy 'Mech packs or MC (Mechwarrior Credits) with real money too. MC is the premium currency that you use for cosmetic purchases, but you can also unlock 'Mechs with it. On top of that, you can speed up your personal progress by buying some Premium Time, which means more XP and credits after every match. Nothing game breaking in my opinion since it still keeps the battlefield even and everything in-game can be obtained just by playing the game too. (Excluding the Hero-Mechs that offer a +30% money boost)I've been playing this game before it came into Steam around 400+hrs and that's just counting the hours in a fight. There's no telling how many hours I've been sitting in the loadout screen, fiddling with the next setup. So, it's easy to say I'm pretty addicted to this game. Mechwarrior Online is one of my long time favorites and I'll heavily recommend it to anyone who loves fictive combat simulators with a good amount of realism on the background. It takes some learning to understand the game mechanics, but it's definitely worth it!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												As a new player, I think MWO is great. And as a new player I notice that this game gets a lot of hate for the product it used to be, rather than what it is.As it stands, the game is generally very stable. I've been disconnected twice at the time of writing this and once was because of an earthquake at their server locations. It's a deep, tactical shooter with a lot of customization available. If you value positioning, constant map reassessment, tactics, and precision over snap accuracy then you should try MWO.The F2P model is reasonable enough, and the game is not P2W. Within the first couple dozen games, anyone can afford a top tier mech layout. I don't know if MWO is going to continue with the frequent events they've been doing, but with them the grind is much less noticable with things like mech credits (paid currency), c-bills (in game currency), and premium time all being given out for free. I'd actually say the rate at which you get new stuff is about right with these events, so it may be too slow without them.There is a little bit of an extra grind to get to the top which is with modules. Modules require global XP to learn the skills to use them and the modules cost a lot of c-bills (like as much as a new mech without being outfitted). Because of the ELO system in the game, Pilot Skill Rating (PSR), you won't really being playing against people with this gear in quick play. You will, however, be playing against these people in Community Warfare (CW).CW is a fun mode that's a nice alternative to quickplay as the objectives are no longer symmetrical. It's meant to act as the global scale war that fits in with the lore of MechWarrior. It's not fully fleshed out yet though, and the main benefit for participating is ranking up with the various factions which do have some unique rewards. But the feeling of making a true impact isn't there yet. It's also not completely balanced between the factions.Customer service has been good so far. I had an account issue that they resolved quickly, even with the holiday hours.Bottom line: MWO is fun to play, offers a good freemium model, and the company seems to have changed their mentality in running this game for the better.

Posted: December 31, 2016
												TL;DR: - If you do random decisions and are unwilling to learn in advance... do not even start this game. - If you are willing to read all that is below and much more about game, then it may be for you.- - - -Disclaimer:Instead of telling you all the good and bad stuff, You should decide for yourself.MechWarrior Online has: - 2 "sides": Inner Sphere, and Clans - Each side has separate modules and weapons preventing you to install "IS" weapon/module into "Clan" mech - > So study your 1st mech wisely before you buy it - There are 2 general types of mechs: Battlemechs, and Omnimechs - > Battlemech allows player to optimize Everything there is to it except types of weapon slots available on each part of mech (Including Engine power/size, armor type, inner construction material, ...) - > Omnimechs on other side comes almost allways with most of basics stuff predetermined (Fixed power/size engine, fixed armor type, inner construction, ...) - > But Omnimech offers ability to take any mechanical part from other variant of given mech (except main torso) and use that. So You can have more Laser slots as you take arm from other variant with lasers instead of rockets.Progression: - For playing matches you get reasonable amount of credits which can get you anything and everything in game - You get XP spendable directly on mech you are playing in match (Unlocks bit higher speed, cooling, rotation rate, ...) - > Mechanics: Each mech has several "Variants" of chasis with different weapon/equipment slots. 1st Tier of unlocks is available to every mech. 2nd Tier of unlocks becomes available only after you have 3 "Variants" of same mech with all Tier 1 unlocks purchased. Same goes for Tier 3. - You get tiny bit of global XP used to unlock global pilot skills/mech modules - > warning: Clan skills are not compatible with IS mechs, so if you go for Clan increased laser range, it will not fit into IS mech with lasersSize/Speed/Weaponry: - Huge "Assault" mechs are very slow to move,to turn and can't aim at their feet = Tiny mechs which get to their back up close can eat them if they are not protected. But they carry a lot of armor and often a lot of weapons. - "Heavy" Mechs are often nearly twice as fast as some Assault mechs in all ways. In some cases they can carry nearly same weaponry as Assault mechs. But always come with lower armor. - "Medium" mechs are kind of odd in most cases. Even lower armor than Heavies. Speed is often not that much better. Lower weight limit to carry weapons. - "Light" mechs on other hand are more often than not very fast and hard to hit. This benefit is paid by low armor and light short range weapons.= = = =Most important thing: - 1st steps in game: - > You read about "IS" vs Clan mechs incompatability. About Omnimechs vs Battlemechs difference. And about need to have 3 Variants of one mech Chassis to fully unlock all passive upgrades for mech. - > That means You will be stuck with your 1st choice for quite a while unless it was very bad pick and you sell that mech for some loss of credits - > So how to pick 1st mech? - = > Game offers ability to preview all mechs in "shop" and as you select them, you can go and click "View in Mechlab" where you can completely remove all there is from mech to see how many Tons you have for gear/armor/engine. - = > You can check what is locked and what is customizable. - = > You should look at other variants of same mech to confirm that they will be up to your different weaponry/play style choices (as you'll need 3 variants to unlock all 3 passive skill tiers to make your mech awesome as possible). - > How to buy 1st mech? - = > 1st 25 matches on account give you credit bonus which is quite nice and this bonus is moltiplied by premium time which You'll get 24hours of at account creation. This gives you 8~12M credits in total. - = > Basic Training completition gives you additional ~2.5M credits right at start. - = > Each completed match gives you credits based on your performance/team play and game mode selected. Usually between 0.1M and 0.25M credits. - = > So after 25 matches you'll have plenty to buy 3~5 variants of Light mech. 3~4 of Medium Mech. 2~3 Variants of Heavy mech. Or 1~2 variant of Assault mech. But that depends on your spending during those 25 matches on different weapons, engines, modules as that can be so expensive that you only got 1 mech and a lot of weapons you can't use at same time. So spend wisely. - = > Or you can buy Mech for real world money to support game. - = = > What applies here is same... Think before you pick your Mech(s)... Yes, Mechs. Because packages often contain 3 variants of selected mech = solving your problem with unlocking all passive skills. - = = > There are different packages on Steam and on game website - = = > Steam packages contain 2 different Chassis mechs = only 1 variant per mech, but those are "Premium"="Hero" Mechs giving you additional 30% boost fo earned Credits + Steam package has premium giving you +50% credits for 30 days. That's 80% boost, so it is not so hard to get those missing variants soon enough. - = = > On other side is game shop where you can buy package of 3 variants of mech of your choice + getting 30 days premium. (No "Hero" variant of mech included, so if you want that additional 30% credit boost, it is additional mech and money) - = = > or there are just "Hero" mechs available for purchase: No premium time, just unique skin, sometimes unique weapon slots and +30% credit boost while piloting this mech. Cost of hero mech is based on weight, so Light Mech Hero comes much cheaper that Heavy one... Both on steam and game's webshop. - = = > Last option for purchasing mech is not exactly for new players: You buy "Early Adopter pack for upcomming mech with a lot of bonuses, but it comes 4 months later when it is developed and put into game"= = = =Side notes/warnings: - Buying mech for Credits in game is instant. Buing for real world money from steam/webstore gets you your new mech on full hour. So buy 12:05 and you'll get your purchased mechs on 13:00. - You can own multiple "Versions" of same "Variant" of mech and they do not count towards passive skill unlock. - > This means that you have "Orion" Mech in Variant: ON1-M, ON1-K, ON1-V = 3 different Variants and allows for All passive skill unlocks. - > But if you have "Orion" Mech in Variant: ON1-M, ON1-K and you decide to buy ON1-K(C), that stands only for (C) version of ON1-K variant and therefore you have 2 Variants and one additional Version and no Passive Skill unlocks. - Key binding will not remove existing bind. So if you dislike 3 level of zooms on Mouse Wheel button and assign "Max. Zoom Toggle" to "Mouse 3", it will not work till you remove "Mouse 3" from original assignment. - Game is more limited on CPU side than on GPU, so adjusting some settings may not result in higher fps. But may result in easier gameplay. (60fps is easily achievable on average 4 years old PC.) - Game has good support team, so if you run into trouble... Contact them. (Unless 30 seconds on google reveals your solution on forums.)

content:
Posted: October 28, 2016
												Mechwarrior Online is an excellent addition to the Mechwarrior series.The game is by no means perfect, so it is not entirely surprising to see so many negative reviews, but it is sad when many are ill considered rants rather than objective assessments. My favourite was someone who played over 500 hours, saying only 'worst game ever'. Completely useless review, and clearly a lie too! Gave me a good chuckle. In all seriousness it is not a game that everyone will get in to and there are some important issues to be aware of before you start.1) Configuring a Mech is complicated. I know Battletech well, but for my friends it was daunting and can be quite a put off. My advice is to persevere, the complexity keeps the game fresh for a long time to come. 2) There are only a handful of maps to play on. This can definitely be frustrating given that some maps are biased towards particular weapons loadouts. Skill still plays a huge role though, and games are short so you don't suffer long if your loadout is completely inappropriate!3) Spend as much time as you can stand with trial Mechs before spending any C-Bills. You get money rapidly per game over the first few days, then it dwindles to a trickle. You'll find your first and second Mechs really have to last you a long time so choose wisely. My advice is a Clan Heavy OmniMech such as the TimberWolf-S. OmniMechs have the most configurability, and this is essential when buying a brand new Mech costs a small fortune!4) Although definitely not Pay-to-win, as skill and teamwork always trump any minor advantages of an individual Mech, spending money is very tempting as it can really ease the grind to get new Mechs. I don't begrudge the developer wanting to make money. Every Free-to-play game does, so don't pretend they don't. Overall I have enjoyed my Mechwarrior Online experience. The ability to customise Mechs with a range of weapons, and the small advantages and disadvantages of each Mech really help to maintain interest. The gameplay is surprisingly well balanced with skillful individuals and team maneuvering being vital to winning most of the time. I'll admit to frustration at the expense of Mechs and the push to spend money. However it truly is not necessary in order to advance through the game steadily. Matches are short and frequent enough to keep your bank account growing, and there is nothing more satisfying than saving up for a new Mech. Spend money only if you really enjoy it and want to support the developer. Games don't get made for free!P.S. I thought I should add that this is one of the least toxic games I've played. After playing Dota 2 for so long, and putting up with swearing and childish tantrums, it's been a breath of fresh air to have a game where 99% of the time people talking are positive and helpful!

content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												As a MASSIVE mechwarrior series fan with way more hours in this game than I should have on a separate non-steam linked account, I can only begrudgingly recommend this game. Do you have a serrious adiction to mech combat? Massive fan of BattleTech? Did you play countless hours of the old Mechwarrior games? You'll probably love this and spend way too much time and money on it, knock yourself out! If you are new, be forewarned, the grind is real. If you want to get a decent collection of mechs expect to spend real money, And if you are new expect to die horribly; a lot. You only get one life per game, so the learning process is going to be a bit painful as you spend a lot of time in the lobbies between matches, and then get utterly smashed for overheating, being out of position, missing your shots, targeting the wrong components ect. The new training is nice, but once you start fighting real people you'll probably get wrecked your first 20 or so games. If you aren't a fast learner, you should probably avoid this game. Also, another con is that you won't be able to customize many mechs. You have to own mechs to customize them and they are very expensive. You dont get many mech bays to start, and you need to buy three variants of the same type of mech and grind with them to unlock the piolet traits that make a huge difference in the mechs combat effectiveness. To buy more mech bays so you can own more mechs requires premium currency as well. So if you do grind enough to buy more than a few mechs you will need to spend money. I recommend that you spend a lot of time testing the trial mechs extensively. Get a good feel for what you want to play. The trial mechs are now always champion variants as far as I can tell, and this is great because they are often the best builds possible for the given mech type. Although, “Best” is relative to the meta at the time, and understanding how to play any given mech is not exactly self-explanatory for a beginner. Still, give them a spin, figure out what you like, and start grinding. If you like the idea of slowly building up to the perfect set of mechs optimized to your taste then you might just get to see where this game really shines. Once your past noobdom, or if your a veteran of the series, the combat is as rewarding as it is challenging. If you are looking for (What IGN called) "A thinking person's shooter" This game is for you. Manage heat, ammo, armor, target lock, weapon groups, and target key components where enemies' main weapons are, memorize mech layouts to engage and strip them faster... On its base level, if you are a fan of huge mechs trading blows in team centric combat, this is your game.7/10 They should have just launched a real $60 title, but this is way better than nothing for another 10 years.

												I'm a veteran player who has played since Closed Beta, spent a ridiculous sum of cash on this game, and logged over 4000 matches. I'll keep the review brief for those looking to get in.Do I recommend this game? Absolutely. But a warning:* If you're a diehard Battletech fan looking for a very deep experience such as Mechwarrior 2: Mercenaries or Mechwarrior 4: Mercenaries, you will not find it here.* If you're a diehard Battletech fan looking for a deathmatch shooter with Mechs and customization options that you recognize? You will find that in Mechwarrior Online.To everyone else? Give it a shot! The game is not without it's flaws, but the core gameplay is solid and a ton of fun.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												There's little more for me to say when so many other reviews have aptly described the issues with this game, so I'll be blunt:Try it if you really, really want to. There's no loss involved. But expect to be punished unless you're a veteran coming back or you've already spent money on the game.Since other users have already thoroughly warned you about PGI's track record (and if you haven't seen that yet, you should glance through a few negative reviews, because they're valid,) I'll focus instead on warning you on what you, as a new player, should expect to see starting out.The community is insular. They'll go on for hours and hours about how they want to be inviting and friendly, but their behavior and conduct don't reflect this. Teamplay is important, so pugs are referred to disparagingly by even the most polite of players. Most people still playing are still playing because they have intimate ties to the Battletech or Mechwarrior licenses; the game preys on their nostalgia and they in turn feed the machine and defend it from disparaging remarks. If you play other video games, expect to hear players lamenting about the "call of duty" crowd or other such stupid garbage - further distancing themselves from the general community of online PC gamers at large.The grind is deceptively monumental: you get a massive boost in cbills (ingame currency) via your first 25 matches and by completing the tutorial, which is generally enough to purchase (though not properly outfit) a single inner sphere mech. If you want to be on even remotely even footing with anyone else, you will need to do this three times: purchase three variants of a single mech, outfit those three variants so they're viable enough to play (stock builds are enormous garbage,) and then play them until you rack up enough experience points to grind out all their "basic skills," which are flat percentage increases to your mech's performance (reduced heat generation, increased acceleration and deceleration, the works.) This will allow you access to a chassis' "elite skills," which are even more powerful advantages afforded to you for greater XP cost (including increased top speed.) Unlocking all four on a variant will literally double all bonuses conferred from basic skills. Yes, you read that right. Grinding obscene amounts of experience into a mech makes it infinitely superior to the same variant, same build, piloted by a new player, regardless of player skill.After your cadet bonuses are gone, your average income per match as a new player may run anywhere from 50,000 cbills (on a loss) to 300,000 cbills (on a well-played win. You will not see this much money as a new player, as the game's mechanics are relatively complicated, poorly explained, and map design is extremely unforgiving to inexperienced players.) You can probably expect about 100k to 150k per match if you're new. Mech prices vary wildly depending on tonnage, stock loadout, and technology (a clan heavy omnimech with a gauss rifle is going to be much more expensive than an inner sphere light mech with medium lasers and machine guns.) You can expect a decent IS heavy to run you about 7-8 million cbills, then outfitting it with decent weapons, upgraded systems (endo-steel and double heat sinks are generally a must) and a good engine may cost you as much as 7 million more. You can expect a decent clan mech (the stormcrow and timber wolf, both clan mechs, are still bar-none the best vehicles in the game) to run you anywhere from 10 million to 14 million cbills, but luckily there's less to upgrade. Sure hope you know what actually performs well, though, because if you ♥♥♥♥ up and build something ♥♥♥♥♥♥, you'll be selling it back for a fraction of what it cost you.Weapon balance is comical. There exist entire weapons systems in the game that are completely useless, including machineguns and flamers. No one will tell you this, because A) PGI doesn't understand their own game and balances around a meta they know nothing about, B) the game is loaded with whales who believe themselves to be experts on the game's balance who will tout that you can pilot anything and perform well, as long as you know what you're doing (they don't.) and C) knowledge is steeply guarded by anyone who actually knows how to play the game. "Comp" teams are fiercely protective of their strategies and aren't about to share tips and tricks with every Tom,♥♥♥♥♥♥ and Harry fresh off of steam. There was a line from the old Battletech cartoon that the players think is a hilarious meme: "Information is ammunition." Well it's true, and ammunition is both in shortage and at a premium.Suffice it to say that lasers are almost universally better than any other weapon.Map design and the existence of 12v12 matches also have a massive impact on weapon balance, and very few players seem to understand this. Small arenas defined by chokepoints, DotA lanes, massive sight lines, and confusing geometry are the order of the day. Scale is confusing and map geometry frequently makes little sense (why are there rocks in the middle of river city if they offer poor protection from literally any angle? Why is forest colony so huge when there's no objective but to head straight for the middle and fight with the enemy?) Because teams are composed of 12 mechs, the key to victory is focusing targets. Even a premade composed of 12 clown-shoed morons like NKVA can stomp all over the game's population (which is likely to include you, new steam user.) The community will frequently lament the TTK (time to kill) being much too fast, blaming this on the weapons systems and completely disregarding that despite the game's glacial pace for an arena shooter, their woes can be attributed to the fact that the Smart Strategy is to move in a big blob and shoot the same target. These are the same people who sarcastically remark that "teamwork is OP" if you try to bring up disparities in the weapon and technology balance department.TL;DR the game is stupid, the devs are stupid, and the community is either stupid or uninterested in sharing with you how to get good. The game is enormously rewarding to those who have invested ungodly hours into it, and severely punishing of those who have not. The players and devs alike are confused at how this formula continues to drive away new blood, which the game desperately needs to survive, and don't understand why it leads to a mind-bogglingly steep pricing scheme, like paying 120 US dollars for a mech pack. But they totally want you to come revitalize their game. Because it is their game, after all. Not yours.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												Don't get invested in this game, that's the short version. I'll list some reasons for those who would like to know more:Incompetent devs who don't play their own game and balance it by dice and darts. Nerfs and buffs come and go, making some mechs god-like for a period and making some walking coffins. Small adjustments are rare.Core gameplay features still changing after release. Energy draw coming to replace Ghost heat (a failed, complex bandaid in its own right) after some sort of balance has finally been achieved using Ghost heat.Releasing completely untested mechs for real money, resulting sometimes in completely OP (Kodiak) and sometimes completely useless (Phoenix hawk) mechs being released.Rampant hacking and PGI has no way to deal with it. The small amount of people who have been banned, have not been detected using hacks. They have just been banned because PGI had reason to believe they were hacking.Broken promises and deadlines. For example, Community warfare (a big selling promise made very early) was supposed to be out 27th January 2013. It was released in December 2014. It was horrid then, it is horrid now. The maps are just chokepoint running where the defenders just have to wait for the attackers to walk into their guns. Russ has stated that the maps wont be redone.Every patch just adds more bugs, breaks working features (minimap fiasco, the current situation with dropdecks etc.) and very, very rarely, adds low quality content like Community warfare and all of its features, bland and similar maps, bland and similar game modes, visual reworks that kill peoples frame rates and so forth. New weapons can't be added to the game because PGI just doesn't know how to do it. And if they ever find out, they still wont do it because they won't be able to balance them.If there is something good about this game, it's the mechs. They are gorgeous.And yes, I have unholy amount of time clocked on this game. I'm an addict and I'm trying to get clean of this game. If I ever ask for mechpacks, don't buy me any. Don't buy any for yourself either.PS: I apologize for bad english, I hope this is coherent and understandable enough.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Some background:  I'm a backer of this game, huge fan of Battletech and long time mechwarrior fan.  This game could have been so much more than it is and to make matters worse, the devs have largely lost the trust of the community.  So much so that very very few people were willing to fund their followup game(known as transverse).  But lets get to the positives:-The art design of the mechs is pretty nice.  Alex Iglesias nails the concept art.-Its the only mechwarrior you're going to get that isn't ancient in game industry terms.-Lots of mechs and variants to choose from and even more to customize.  -Good controls for the most part despite the defaults being goofy.  Check the options menu.-Community Warfare features are starting to turn into a fairly appealing mode.-The clan equipment sound design is top notch.  I wish the IS stuff sounded as nice.And then the negatives:-The weapon balance is awful and so many little jury rigged fixes have been placed on the system to "fix" the problem.  PGI's gameplay design team is horrid at math and has been since beta.-The game is growing more and more poorly optimized and it stutters on systems that used to run it silky smooth with nothing to show for it.  NVidia cards can have serious problems despite the made for nvidia intro vid advert.-The player base has largely been chased off by false promises and bad ideas so there aren't a lot of people playing the community warfare.-The game is buggy enough to be frustrating.-The community mildly toxic but not the worst.-Clan tech is implemented as though its 1:1 with IS tech and you'll be matched against it as such.-All these assets and no mechwarrior single player campaign...-The mechs are horridly out of proportion.  This makes the speed of the mechs feel extra sluggish since you're closer to 20 meters up rather than 12.  Additionally, some mechs are punished a lot more by their size.  The Centurion, for example, is heavy/assault sized despite being half the weight of the Atlas.  Mechs should be in the 8-12 meter range not 6-20 meters.  That range is insane.  Update:  The recent rescale did nothing to fix this although it did bring mechs in the same weight class more in line with each other.Hopefully you enjoy the game.  I grow quickly frustrated with the choices the design team makes.  Give the game a shot though, it is free to start playing after all.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												The year is 3535.  Humankind has made great progress, especially in terms of finding new and unique ways of killing one’s neighbor.  Unfortunately for the denizens of the 36th century, theirs is a future that was conceived by bored DnD players in the mid-1980s.  This is manifested in their weapons of choice: large legged robots the size of apartment buildings.  Tank treads?  Puncture-proof off-road wheels the size of a barn?  Nah.  These bots have size 357 feet, ferro-fibrous shins and thighbones made of endo-steel.  As you might guess, this makes them clunky as all get out.  They have 1987-esque optics to match.  As you lumber along on your skyscraper legs, you might see enemies peeking out over yonder hills.  You might want to flag them for your teammates.  Not happening.  Not until you can see the whites of their cockpits.  Your futuristic laser pointer has a similar range and makes a visible line that lets the enemy trace it right back to your armor-encrusted jeep-sized fist.  And when that enemy shoots at you, you do what any 36th century advanced attack platform does: flinch.The above is what makes this game absolutely awesome (or should I say atlas?).  Driving around big clunky robots makes for far more strategic combat than your typical 2016 FPS.  The least clunky robots are light mechs.   They move almost like they’re not the size of buildings.  Mediums behave kind of like the heavy in TF2.  Heavies behave like the TF2 heavy wearing concrete boots, and assaults play like the TF2 heavy with concrete boots and a concrete helmet.  What does it all mean?  It means that you need to lumber along with your teammates instead of just doing whatever you want.  It means you really need to capitalize on terrain and cover to protect yourself or creep up undetected.  Perhaps the best thing is that driving an armored skyscraper means that you have a lot of armor and will not crumple the first time you get hit.  Don’t get me wrong, there ARE snipers, but these snipers do not sit around one-shotting everything that enters their crosshairs.  I have been headshot once and scored a headshot once (totally by accident).This brings us to the mechs themselves.  You have two varieties.  The more traditional ones are like tuner cars and hot rods (Inner Sphere).  The latter are more like Italian sportscars (Clan).  One requires a lot of time and tweaking to get up to speed.  The other is pretty solid out of the box.  The great thing is that there is a vast variety, and you see people using every make and model out there.  There is, of course, a metagame, but builds beyond the meta are viable, and you have enough room to come up with something that personally works for you that may not work for the greater MWO population.  I like that.The greater MWO population is generally a friendly, well-behaved bunch.  Yes, there are some droolers and screamers, but they are a decided minority.  The community as a whole is older than you would find in most games, and the kids you encounter tend to be the ones who are grown up enough to sit at the adult table without being childish.This is a result of the gameplay.  Strategy trumps reflexes, and the game encourages you to linger after you die in order to get more assists and, while doing so, learning from watching more experienced people play out the rest of the game.  This pace is not for everyone, but I enjoy it.  In between matches, I do a combination of watching my team, researching builds, and at times surfing the net.  With a max of 15 minutes a match (and the average probably around half of that), you play the game in bite-size chunks.I really enjoyed my initial day or two with the game, but I was playing while traveling in Europe.  Living somewhere off the beaten path, I feared that the servers would not be functional from home.  I was wrong.  Pings are not as solid, but the game is still very playable, and it plays incredibly well at pings that would make other games unplayable (150+).The devs are engaged with the community.  I’m still on the fence about how this relationship is going.  After all, what online game doesn’t feature players criticizing the devs for anything and everything?  At the same time, what business entity is angelic in its handling of online games?  The good that I see is that we are now playing a game that has 3 years of development put into it.  That means those who came before me sorted out the worst problems.  The bad is that certain aspects reek of greed and price-gouging.  Paint, for example, costs more than real life paint that you would put on miniatures.  One discussion I saw about improving the HUD seemed framed by how the players would pay for such an improvement.  In the realm of neutrality, there are a lot of game modes and whatnot that may or may not be coming out in the future.  I’d love for them to be implemented, but I’m reviewing what’s there.  Furthermore, the game has the licensing from the tabletop game, which means this IS the DnD of mech games.  That is important to me because it attracts the diehard, long-term fans and thus makes me feel like this is a solid investment that will not suddenly go bust or implode.  It’s not perfect, but it’s stable.And investment brings us to money.  This is THE best f2p model I’ve ever seen.  Instead of paying to win, you pay for variety.  Variety is more meaningful to me than bling, and the variety here is compelling.  There are scores of mechs, but you get only 4 mech bays to start with.  If you want more mechs, you have to pay for more bays.  The bays are cheap.  Beyond that, there is the temptation to shop for more.  Yes, the mechs are expensive, but I get to pick and choose as opposed to being forced to pay a subscription fee or some such.  And, if I only want to pay for mech bays, I can do that, too.  The game will proceed far slower, but no one is being denied the best gear because they don’t want to pay cash for it.  Is this a grind?  Yes, but the grind is the game.  I’m enjoying the ride.  Along similar lines, even newbs are vital parts of the team, and even newbs can get out there and hurt somebody.  You aren’t out there getting the floor mopped with your corpse on your first days out, but it is obvious how little you know about builds and mechanics.  There is sooooo much to learn, and yet so much fun to be had before you actually understand the half of it.  Perhaps most importantly, understand that this game was out for years before it came to Steam, and that means most of those playing it are not visible at the Steam community hub.  The community is larger.  Not huge, but again solid.  And there ARE new people joining.  You will not be the only new arrival, and it’s not too late to get in on MWO.In short, I love this game.  If I could compare it to anything, I’d say it reminds me of the days (in fact years) I spent playing Random Arenas in Guild Wars I.  Those were good days, and it’s nice to be back in a similar place.

content:
Posted: February 13
												So, what to say about a game that shows I have almost 500 hours logged since it arrived at steam and that I have been playing quite a while before? Simply put, I enjoy the Mechwarrior Universe where you do litle else than running around in a giant walking tank that is highly customizable. I've been playing this game since Mechwarrior II that I got with my Matrox Mystique in 1996 (oh dear) so I assume that nostalgia is one reason I keep on trucking. Of course, the Mechwarrior game is only a fraction of a much larger Battletech Universe that I find derivative and utterly boring; there are some factions at war and then there are some more and so on.Mechwarrior Online is the latest version and has improved several key items from the MW games. I cannot recall spending so much money on a free-to-play game (though you do not have to) and what you get is a game that basically never left the docks. At this moment, a new, major change is coming (again) to the game, this time new tweaks replacing old tweaks and this is pretty much how that game has been for the last years. The developer, PGI, is continously changing the game but rather than thinking it through they use hit & run tactics; it typically ends up as a large change for the worse from which they try to tweak further, loosing more players with each major change while the months tick by. Suggestions from the fiercely loyal fan base appear to be in vain and at this point I see each new patch as a weather report; you hope for clear skies, but usually, well, no luck for you.The game has been end of life for quite a while now with no other content added than new mechs, that become increasingly more expensive and usually just that little better than the previous batch. Sometimes an old map is updated, again typically made worse, and the game limps on as your battle-damaged mech would. Slowly, clumsily, and you can nearly feel the agony of its pilot. Which is me, by the way, so that comment doesn't make sense at all.The main reason I still play is because they game plays well with your fellow team mates and I've been part of a great group. Without it, I would have stopped playing years ago, because there really isn't much to do.Recommended? No, not really.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												This is the MechWarrior game I've been wanting since my childhood days playing MechWarrior 2. So how to describe it compared to other games? Well, it's not exactly a shooter and it's not exactly a sim. It's somewhere in between. The F2P setup is actually reasonable which is a rare thing to see, especially after my experience with World of Tanks and World of Warships and the obvious money sinks built into those. With MWO throwing money gets you nothing gameplay related that you couldn't get otherwise for free. Yes you can get cosmetic stuff, yes you can get first access to new mechs for a bit before they're available to earn for in-game currency, and yes you can buy "hero" mechs that give a little boost to XP earned, but little Billy with his daddy's credit card is going to get wrecked because cash won't do anything but save you time in unlocking things.Other than that, there's events for unlocking free stuff that happen on a very regular basis, and the community is actually full of (mostly) decent folks who just want to have fun blasting the crap out of each other in giant stompy robots.

Posted: December 10, 2015
												Going to leave a quick review here. Personally I think MWO is a great game. I have spent, and will continue to spend, many hours playing it. I've been a player for over 2 years now. It takes a little bit of getting used to it because of the learning curve, but if you want a first person, big, stompy 'mech battle with different types of weapons, then you should try out this game.You can drop in quick play for a 12v12 match or go into community warefare with longer matches and more 'mechs. Teamwork is a top priority. Take time to outfit your 'mechs with the right equipment for your playstyle as you go, and unlock skills with your experience points, to improve as a pilot.Pros:-Big stompy 'mechs-Good graphics and sound-Dedicated playerbase from before the Steam launch, but even more players with it-Free to play and not pay to winCons:-Steep learning curve (I stongly recommend completing the tutorial)-Technical loadouts for 'mechs can be time consuming to research or build, including the grind to get enough in-game money to purchase equipment and unlock skills (though you don't have to go too hardcore)Overall I say if you're unsure give it a try as it is free, and see if you like it yourself, because everyone is different. The community will give advice if you ask for it.So see you on the battlegrounds! o7

Posted: December 10, 2016
												Your mech will be made into scrap and you will feel almost powerless to the enemy. Everything will happen so fast its almost blinding. But if you keep coming back for more and practice moving your mech like its second nature you will find yourself more involved in the battles. Being able to see the enemies tactics for what they are. Then you will find your place, weather it be a light assasin removing the rear armour of a 100 ton mech who can't turn as fast as you can run or a long ranged weapon platform making the enemies think twice before leaving the safety of their cover. Personally I prefer to group up and smash into the enemy position with short range weapons and communicate with my team to single out and focus down targets until their team is split and in total disarray. This game has been through a lot of changes and still has many more to come. Anyone who says its glory days are over have not been paying attention. It is regularily updated and this game will still be in development even after Mechwarrior 5 is released in two years! Add me if you decide to join the invasion weather you will die well to spread the greatness of the clans, Stand up for the freedom of the innersphere or are only in it for the money as a mercenary. I look forward to meeting you on the battlefield.
