content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												TL/DR: As a long term (~30 years now) fan of all things Battletech, MWO does some things incredibly well, but the glacial pace of progress combined with a dev team who at this point can only be described as occasionally well meaning but incompetent results in a hollow and frustrating play experience. For fans of MW2 Mercs, MW3 and MW4, sadly this is probably not the game you're looking for. I can only hope that in the future there will be more and better Battletech games.Longer version:I paid for a founders package for MWO back in September 2012, long before the game was ever available here on Steam. I paid based on the advertising that was on the MWO site at that time. I paid based on the notion that we were going to get some sort of simulation of warfare in the Battletech universe, the game being some sort of mech-simulator-lite with a long-term game based on actual war, from the grand strategic level across the Inner Sphere (and beyond) all the way down to the tactical battlefield level. The game then came out in closed beta and I was thrilled to finally be back in the cockpit of my beloved Atlas assault mech which, in one guise or another, I've been piloting since the mid 80's.So why the negative review? Several reasons. Before I get in to them, I should say that the artwork, mech design and general aesthetic of the game is the best that I've ever seen in a Battletech PC game. The chap who models the mechs, the textures etc. has done amazing work and fully deserves to find employment in any AAA game dev studio.The issues I take with the game are:1. As a founder & huge Battletech fan, and therefore having financially contributed to the very existence of both the game and PGI as a viable company, being bluntly told by a senior member of the dev team that people like me (hard core Battletech fans) are, and I quote, "Not the target audience" for the game felt like a brutal slap in the face. Thanks for your money, but you're not really who we're aiming the game at. Really? Really? As one of very many founders who directly contributed to enabling the game to be made, being told that felt alienating in the extreme, and was frankly very difficult to forgive. This one thing above all else still makes me feel bitter to some degree.2. The glacial pace of actual content release. As time went on it quickly became apparent that mech pack after mech pack was produced and released (for exorbitant prices, but that's another discussion) in an obvious ploy to distract the player base with shiny stuff so that fewer complaints would be made about the lack of actual content. Almost FOUR YEARS down the line, and we were given something other than endless variations on the theme of team deathmatch... A couple of months ago? Many view the game as having an unacceptably slow pace of development.3. Lack of community engagement & listening to the vocal minority. I can understand the lack of engagement on the game forum, considering how blisteringly critical it can be, and I understand that the player base has hardly ever been united on anything. That being said, the two things that come to mind on which the entire player base did agree were that nobody wanted a 3rd person view in the game and that nobody wanted a coolant flush. What happened? We got both, pointlessly wasting an unknown amount of dev time that could have been better spent on other areas of the game development.4. Communication again. There never really was any sort of 'golden period' of communication from the dev team. I thought, and continue to think, that it's inexcusable that every form of communication is used except the official game forum. Back in closed beta hundreds of early CB players made lengthy detailed threads there, suggesting features using well reasoned and polite argument. Pretty much all of it was summarily ignored. Later someone, I don't remember who, suggested that for the dev team to make more use of the forum - the official game forum - would constitute an unacceptable drain on company time. My response: utter drivel. How long does it take to type an official post on the forum? Minutes? By all means use all available means of communication, but the fact that the least engaged method is the official game forum does not exactly engender confidence in the communication abilities of the dev team.5. Game balance. Wild changes are made to weapon and mech stats with each new patch, with obviously barely any actual play testing being done. Newly released mechs are usually vastly superior to older models wihch serves only to create a power creep dynamic that essentially forces players to buy incredibly expensive new mech packs in order to remain competitive. I have no idea if this is deliberate or an unintended consequence of the inability of the dev team to play their own game to a high level.Having taken part in organised team matches and also in the solo match queue I've both been pleasantly surprised and at the same time horrified by the differences between how the game plays in team matches (e.g. MRBC games) and the actual group / solo queues.Whether or not PGI had or have passion for the BT universe is open to question. From my personal experience I think they at least did at the start of the development process. What I think is more open to debate, and what I'm starting to seriously question, is their professionalism and competence. More fool me really - had I bothered to be diligent and researched their prior history as game developers I would have been unlikely to have ever paid them a penny for anything.From a personal perspective the game as it is can certainly be fun, but I look back today at what I was lead to believe MWO would be and I can't help feeling frustration at the obvious waste of potential, broken promises and utterly incompetent PR efforts on the part of the company.If microtransaction-supported e-sport team deathmatch is what MWO is destined to become, then I'm done with the game. I will not support something that has only a thin, superficial veneer of Battletech IP over a fundamental game that I no longer derive any pleasure from playing. I never dreamed that I'd get to this point, but I'm done. I'd genuinely, dearly love to be proved wrong and see some amazing changes in the future, but from everything I've heard and read I think the direction being taken is fundamentally flawed, and certainly isn't the MWO I thought I was signing up for. Those of you who enjoy the game, more power to you, I hope you continue to do so.Original game founder signing off.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												(Edit: I haven't played this since sometime in May in 2014.)I was one of the original 120$ Legendary Founders back in 2012. I played this daily for 2 years, clocking in a ridiculously large amount of time and Mech collection. I watched whole clans come and go as a community spiked up over the hype then died off when the game didn't deliver. It spiral downwards since it was created. We used to talk about it coming to Steam back then, and now, only out of desperation to save this doomed product, has it finally come. This is now the THIRD release for this game. The second one was falsely touted as the first by its own creators despite already having been out for a year... and now it's releasing again on Steam. They're trying to save what I used to call a sinking ship. I'd now call it a sunken ship. Btw, the Steam version still requires you to make a MWO account... defeating any point of having been put on Steam to begin with. This port tells me that the game is finally dying, which it should have done LONG ago.But hey, since they want to port their crappy game over to Steam, I guess I'll port my review too. This is for you PGI. I still haven't forgotten the times you wiped my CBILLS bank for not liking one of my Mech builds and unnecessarily suspending me off the official forums. As I said back then, you can't censor Metacritic. That applies to Steam as well.MechWarrior Online, August 18, 2014, from my Metacritic.PGI is a horrible developer; one of the worst I've seen. They go back on every promise. They miss every deadline. They make fake pipedream promises that'll never come. They censor or ignore their own community. They totally wreck things that were already working fine beforehand. They put in garbage no one wanted like ECM, ghost heat, 3PV, and UI 2.0. These things only hurt the game, not help. But any attempt to tell them this is met with a ban hammer, assuming you get read at all. MechWarrior Online as a whole has only gotten worse since closed beta, not better. Despite being a huge fan of the MechWarrior franchise and old games, I'm not one of the many fanboys that are going to stick up for this crap of a game or developer.The most pathetic part of this game is the money grubbing. This isn't just incompetence of "not" knowing how to do... well... anything properly, it's shameless greed. Originally promised with no hero mechs/variants, no consumables, they did exactly that as soon as Founders refund period ended, basically saying "shove it" to everyone that supported them. They then made the cash shop their # 1 priority, filling it out every month with stuff to sell while features the game actually needs continue to go long over due. The stuff they did waste their time on was stuff no one wanted, like 3PV. They'd waste half a year of Dev time for 3PV. Ya, thanks, that worthless feature that shouldn't be in the game that no one wanted nor supported at any point. You wasted all that time just to shove it down everyone's throat. They didn't even deliver it with the option to queue without it as promised. They went back on a big promise by putting in something they originally promised they'd NEVER do, made a new one to do it a certain way, then didn't even bother to deliver on that one either. It also took them well over a YEAR just to put in a no-base TDM. That should have been a day 1 release mode. All that time just to copy/paste a previous mode and take the bases out. That's the level of talent we're talking about here."Community Warfare" is slowly becoming just an obvious pipedream. It's like being on a ship and the captain promises you that he knows where he's going and will soon hit land. Surprise, there's no land coming. It's just an inevitable sinking ship. Instead of deliver on promised features, they just make more Mech packages to milk this dying cow for all its worth before it sinks. They now offer 500$ Mech skins. Not even League of Legends did this when they made that ridiculous Ezreal skin. Blizzard doesn't even charge this much for mounts or pets. How much is the newest Blizzard title with all DLCs/optional paid content? Not 500$. You could build a gaming computer with that. The only "Community Warfare" for this game was on the forums, where everyone voiced their complaints to the betrayals, but was met only with deaf ears or ban hammers. During the Founder period, PGI pretended to give a crap about its community and its feedback, but as soon as the refund period ended, they stopped acting, and very obviously so. Well, unfortunately for them, they can't censor Metacritic.Please do not support this game. I'm honestly asking you because I'm a true MechWarrior fan, and this game is just one big slap in the face to us. It's an insult and abuse of the license. Worse yet is that for as long as it remains active; the longer we'll have to wait to get a true MechWarrior game again. If you support this game, you're hurting the franchise and every real fan of the series. Please let the game go bust, the sooner the better, so that the long wait for the next MechWarrior game won't be as long. PGI is a terrible company that I can only hope gets shutdown as they deserve. They belong at a Mcdonalds flipping burgers, not trying to make video games. They flat out scammed everyone and continue to try to leech as much as they can from this license's rotting corpse. This was not the revival anyone was hoping for, not even close. The license was better off in retirement. I'd rather it remain dormant and continue waiting for the next game than have a parasite dig it up just to feed on it like a vulture while ripping everyone off in the progress.I leave you with these articles if you want more evidence as to just why you shouldn't even consider giving these shameless people money. While I can't directly link, a single copy/paste into Google will find them."What Happened to Mechwarrior Online?""Underwhelming ‘MechWarrior Online’ Launch Falls Short of Expectations""A Cautionary Tale: The Rage of the Mechwarrior Online Community""Free-to-Play MechWarrior Online Offends Players With $500 Golden Mechs""Shutdown imminent: MechWarrior Online is beyond salvaging"-Drain (Steam)

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												I have to say this game is fantastic.  First off, I don't think it's really pay to win nearly as bad as most free to play games.  I see alot of complaints about this and I don't agree. Here are my reasons:-You start out with 4 trial mechs from each weight class (trial as in they're set loadouts, you can't customize them, that's it). So in other words, you start out with 16 mechs to try out. That's plenty for me to start with personally.-Secondly, you can purchase and customize mechs with c-bills you earn from matches.  It's not too bad really, Ten 8 minute matches got me a good mech that I was able to deck out and start getting more kills with during matches.-You really could not spend a dime and get a fulfilled mechwarrior experience from this game. I know I did for the first few weeks without spending anything. You can earn everything you need pretty quickly to get a handful of decent to good mechs going, and the game starts you out with some c-bills and some premium time. I only spent money because I started really getting into the game and decided I wanted to get some premium time going and to purchase a champion mech pack at some point. Plus, I honestly felt like the developers earned my money because the gameplay is that good.OK, let's talk about the heart of the game.  How is the actual gameplay you say?  Well, as a pretty big Battletech fan and someone who played Mechcommander and Mechwarrior 3 & 4... IT'S EFFING FANTASTIC.  God, this is the best part of the game for sure.  I love the gameplay, the visuals effects, the sound effects, the tactics and potential for teamwork, everything.  The battles are how I would imaging actual Mech Combat. The autocannons roar, lasers tear, missiles swarm.  It's so good, I love it.  Even if you're not into battletech, I think most people can appreciate the realistic feel of the mechs, and the roles of the weightclasses: assault mechs brawling, heavy mechs dishing it out, and medium and light mechs supporting. It's beautiful.  I thought Piranha Games nailed mech combat.  Also, customization is awesome and relatively balanced as far as I can tell so far. I will give a fair warning that you have to use a little patience and thought when starting out.  This isn't CoD, you don't charge in and kill.  You have to stick with your team, use cover and try to use hit and run tactics.  Also, try not to drive an Assault mech first thing, you need to work up to that to utilize it properly.  If you're not a Battletech fan, I definitely recommend this game.  If you're a Battletech fan, you have to play this game!! Alright, so I'll telly you what I think the downsides are.  The quickplay matches are a little repetitive. Not as bad as some people are saying, in my opinion the gameplay more than makes up for it.  That said, there are about 8 or so maps currently, and 3 game modes (assault, conquest, and team deathmatch). It could use a little spicing up for sure. Games typically last 5 to 15 minutes.  However - this is only the quickplay version of the game.  The main feature of the game takes place in the form of faction play, which I'm only beginning to get into and understand.  This gameplay takes place in the form of territory conquest in via assault and defence of planets.  This form of gameplay definitely has some more meat to it.  For instance one game mode takes place in the form of defending a base with friendly defense turrets and gates at the front (highly reminiscent of mechcommander i thought) which was awesome.  This is pretty cool, but my problem with faction play so far is it seems more than a little elitist (tons of premades and clans steamrolling PUGs) and not only that but it seems very difficult to break into. Like, it feels like in order to get serious about faction play, I have to prove I'm good enough to join some group that meets every Sunday, etc. Don't like that, a little too reminiscent of WoW or some other mmo for me.  This part of the game is probably a little more pay to win, or, invest a ton of time and reading online forums to win.  I don't like that too much.  The game doesn't explain the faction play very well at all, and the interface is kind of a mess and overloading the player with options.  You have to look it all up online to learn anything.  Anyways, despite a few things I don't care for, I think this game is great.  I'd give it a solid 9/10 to anyone interested in picking this game up.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												I've played MWO since closed Beta, over 3 years, and I love it. After playing for all this time, I can easily say that MWO has had better staying power than nearly any other computer game I've ever played. I also, for the most part, like the MWO community. I've met some great friends and have a lot of fun playing with them. Although, you don't have to join a group to have fun. I've had hundreds of great games playing solo.The ability to customize your mech to fit your chosen game style is great. Scout, brawler, sniper, missile boat, leader or follower. Fast mechs, slow mechs, big mechs or small mechs. Lasers, canons, missiles, or support roles like NARC, ECM, and tag. The game has some real depth to it, and the developers continually work to make it better. My experience with the support team has been good (and I really have had to work with them on some connection issues). It's not like most shooters, where your life span is measured in seconds. In games like Halo and COD, I always disliked that the average life span seemed to be 10 seconds or less. In MWO you can live for several minutes while taking fire and get into some insane brawls with opposing mechs. Minor mistakes can be overcome (provided your mistake isn't walking smack into the middle of the opposing team) and you can really make a difference to your side's success even after half your mech is blown off.Having said that, the game does have a learning curve. There can be real depth to the gameplay. Teamwork is very key. You have to watch your position relative to your team, your enemy, and the map itself. Some locations on the maps are better than others, and you'll have to discover them. You have to pay attention to your heat, your mechs armor and internal structure, your weapon status, and to be a good player you also have to pay close attention to your opponents status and aim with precision at where they are weakest; all the while maneuvering as best you can to absorb incoming fire while delivering your own. The tutorial is pretty good and a must for new players. Several of the existing player groups will also welcome new players and help you learn. I know mine will. If you can, get into one of the teamspeak rooms and ask around, or look at the gaming fourms in the faction groups. Most players are helpful in answering honest questions. I would recommend premium time at a minimum if you're serious about playing. The 50% boost to Cbills and expierence really add a great deal over time and let you customize your mechs in a relatively short time. I would also recommend you find what kind of mech you like and then give a Hero Mech a try. The Hero Mechs give Cbill and experience bonuses that stack with the premium time. Make money with a Hero Mech and you can purchase and kit out your garage nicely without having to pay a dime more. I have way over a hundred mechs, and most of them were purchased for free, with Cbills earned in the game (or even given away by the developers during special weekend events!).Of course, some mechs are better than others, and there's always going to be "meta" mechs and builds that are at the top, but the developers really have done a pretty good job of balancing the mechs. The game is definitely NOT pay to win. The Hero Mechs and Premium time ease the grind, but they are not an "I win button." I love that it doesn't matter so much if you are in a light, heavy, or assault mech, if you are a good pilot and play it right, you can beat your opponent regardless of what they are driving. So long as you don't take yourself too seriously (remember, it's a game!) you can have fun with all of the mechs, and there are a ton of them to choose from.So what don't I like? I wish the game had better visuals and sound effects for internal ammo explosions (basically the MWO version of a critical hit where ammunication inside a mech starts to explode). I wish some of the original iconic mechs, like the capapult, looked and played like they did in closed Beta (give me back that torso twist and the monster PPC barrels!). I also wish that scouting and support roles gave more rewards than they do now. Oh, and I hate how the gauss rifle works. Other than that, I'd say I'm extremely satisfied in my experience with the game.One other point to add is that this game is pretty sanitary for a young person if you are a parent and concerned about your kids watching and/or playing violent games. There's no blood; no humans with guns killing other humans with guns (or worse). It's giant stompy robots blowing up other giant stompy robots, so the sense of human on human violence is much less than other first person shooters.So, if you like first person shooters and are looking for a game with great gameplay, good graphics and more than the ten second life-span of HALO and COD, the game is one you should give a chance. It's free to try, so you have nothing to lose, and alot to gain. Good luck, and see you in the next drop!

												I have played MW, MW2, MW3, MW4, its expansions (including MechTek) and the Mech Commander games.  MW4's multi-player PvP was awesome and all of the above were great games... MWO sadly is not.I really wanted to like this game and gave it a solid try, however it is nothing but a PVP grind designed to tempt fans into forking over money so they can experience their favorite battlemechs.  The assets and design are fantastic and beautiful works of art.  There is so much potential to use them to make a proper Mechwarrior game.  Right now the assets are used to charge fans ~$10-30 a mech (or a very very long grind).  Why anyone would use their money to buy these and not better games on Steam is beyond me.I love Battletech, but you PGI have turned it into an empty shell with only pretty graphics and no substance.  We have TWO options: PUGs or CW with forced 12v12: turning every game into a pop-tart shooting contest – where is the fun in that?  Shame on all of you (except your artists, they did a phenomenal job).Hopefully Harebrained Schemes can redeem Battletech with their new project.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												I joined closed beta in June 2012 and havent stopped playing since then. I have logged thousands of matches and have spent a few hundred bucks on the game. That said, you'd think I could offer up a recommendation for this game, but I cant really do that. It's literally only the fact that it is a Battletech related game that has kept me involved and willing to deal with the multitude of issues MWO has.The most prominent of these is the developer, PGI itself. Much of their more malicious and disengenuous history can be atrributed to the earlier years with IGP calling shots ($500 mech packs for just a golden skin spring to mind) but the absolute glacial progress MWO shows is the most grevious. Its been 3 years and MWO is still just an arena shooter, with next to no actual lore involved in regular gameplay beyond the mechs themselves. Community Warfare attempts to simulate the actual struggle between the IS and Clan forces, but its shortcomings are vast. The game mode itself is extremely limited with extremely unrealistic (an illogical) goals in place in each round. It allows no seperation between solo players and united 12 man groups, something you'd be hard pressed to encounter in any decent online game. Absolute miniscule, extremely necessary changes take weeks, even months to be implemented or corrected. PGI has a now legendary history of being completely incapable of small tweaks to balance. Instead, large and sweeping changes are made despite extremely vocal player feedback in test servers. The users who frequent the MWO forums often provide spreadsheets and their own data collection, with reasoned and well versed feedback as to how to make MWO balance better and fair, and it falls on deaf ears.I dont want to include PGI's pricing scheme in this review, as Im sure it will be mentioned over and over. At the end of the day, I dont think the value even begins to approach what you get, especially when it seems like so little progress gets made. In no exaggerated terms, as someone who has played from the very beginning, MWO is different now after three years of progress: There are more mechs, more (but not many) maps, far worse graphics, more Cockpit novelty items, and a broken community warfare module. It's primary mode of play is still arena shooter, despite having three different ways of calling it (Assault, skirmish, conquest). There is no depth to any of these modes, and no attempt has been made to fix that after all these years.Despite all of these shortcomings, I continue to play because Ive played Mechwarrior games since 1995. As soon as someone else is given the chance to make a Mechwarrior game, I will wholeheartedly jump ship, because I have a hard time imagining another company could do so little with so much time with the Mechwarrior license.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												I have been playing MWO for quite some time. I am not a hardcore fan. I did play MW on the Playstation and PC back in the 90s.MWO is a great game, there aren't many around, not many games that are not pay to win. A lot of cosmetics to your mechs and plenty of discounts and freebies. If you love Mechs or if you watched Pacific Rim and felt like you want a mech game I really do recommend MWO.Bear in mind that the Mechs are sluggish, they are huge mechs after all, they also behave like tanks, legs and torso move independently. The game is quite similar with World of franchise.In regards to gameplay, you can customise your mech with any weapons mods and gear you wish which is great as you will never meet the exact same mech on the battlefield. This is where the fun starts. There is no cookie cutter build, some would argue but really there isn't and I suggest to experiment and play YOUR way. Especially if you PUG and don't join a serious Clan. I did but I didn't like the fact they were dictating my mech set-up.Quick do and don't list:DO stick together with your team, else going alone you will get picked up and you will die.DON'T go alone unless you are very confident and you play a fast scouting mech, light/medium mech.DO quit the match once dead as you can start a new one without having to wait until end of match (something I did not know and wasted so much time looking at my team play, then again by doing so I did learn about mech setups and strategy)DO experiment with your mech, don't listen to people saying an Assault mech should not have LRMs. Many of the maps in MWO are LRM firendly. After all how will you get LRM 60+ if not fitting on an Assault mech?DON'T listen to Assault should never have LRMs on them.DO use LRM (homing missiles) when you first start playing regardless of the mech you use, it is a noob friendly weapon, hell it is a any player friendly weapon and you will do massive damage.DON'T go for Heavy mechs they are over used and will take forever to queue for a match. Also they take an Assault class spot.DO manage your heat, try to have rating of at least 1 heat management if not 1.2+DON'T fire all your weapons like crazy, get heat spikes and shut down, you will die. Cycle your weapons if you must and go for double heat sinks but bear in mind they take 3 slots. You will be surprised how efficient it is firing 3 4 5 LRM's by cycling (BACKSPACE key) than all at once. Same goes for lasers if you overheat.DO Lock your targets, ALWAYS, no matter what mech you are in. You help others see the target and LRMs hit it. It also helps you see where the target is damaged so you can do even more damage by hitting the same locations.DO check your weapons details, especially range. Some weapons have a minimum range so if you shoot them at close range they do ABSOLUTELY NOTHING. You would be surprised how many people shoot PPCs and LRMs at close range. Others that shoot them hoping to get people at 2Km distance:(DON'T test you weapons when you enter a game, you will just shoot your team mates and cause friendly fire. Use the Testing Grounds or If you must turn around find a safe area and do it but remember you will waste ammo if you use ammo. That 10 ammo wasted could make a difference when you have none left.DON'T block your team mates, and DON'T be a hero going first hoping to get them kills by blocking everyone behind you. You might get a kill but will also die and cause others to friendly fire you. I had highest damage in the game without any kills (you also get an achievd for this). Even with plenty kills your rating can be lower than someone that killed none but did most damage.MECHS: Remember you need 3 different mech variants to level them up. If you buy a medium as your first mech you need to buy it's borthers too (2 more). You have to play all 3 variants get XP and level them up. There are 3 levels, most important ones are 1 and 2 as 3 only unlocks a new module slot. I would suggest going for the heat management skills first 750 and 1000 XP, then the 3500XP which does rotation.LIGHTS: I have a few but I don't really enjoy playing them. Hit and run tactics, scouts, you will die very fast, frustrating for new players and for old. Can have a light 5x5LRM which is a trolling build but fun as hell. 8 9 medium lasers which wil do a lot of damage but do bear in mind that you have to constantly move and if you go toe a toe with any other mech you gotta circle it, move legs and torso independently to run circles around that mech. Something I can't do well.MEDIUM: Similar to Lights but can be fun, they are quite fast and can pack a punch, would be used mainly as hit and runs, brawlers or LRM. You will be surprised how much damage 5x5LRMs can do (over 1000 damage in a match). You are an LRM boat that can move around the battlefield at 80 to 100 Kph. Can fit a number of high damage weapons. IE: Cicada with 4 ER Large Lasers which will be a great sniper.HEAVY: My first mech was a heavy, the CAT, a lovely LRM boat, all I did was sit back and shoot a rain of missiles on my enemies:) I have the least Heavy mechs than any other one. They are great but everyone is using them and it takes FOREVER to queue up for games. As I mentioned earlier they also take 1 assault spot from the team.ASSAULT: Well, what can I say about these walking fortresses. They pack a punch and can take quite a few. Just remember to stick with other mechs, mediums lights especially as they can protect you. You will be surprised how fast an Assault mech can go down if even 1 good light pilot starts running circles around you and shooting your legs. As you will need 3 different versions of the same mech I say have at least 1 LRM boat. When people say it is a waste of 100 tons, I say well my score and damage says something else. So many maps now are long ranged that if you have any other weapons you are a waste of 100 tons, especially the snow maps which everyone selects because they cannot manage their heat or because they are LRM or long range weapons.As I said, experiment, you have 3 different versions of the same mech variant so you might as well go nuts. Put 10 medium lasers on an assault, 8 medium pulse lasers on another, 4 x 15 LRMs, 4 x LBX10 or 4 x 20LRMs. Same on heavy or mediums. By all means if you do not wish to get 3 variants, you don't have to, just level that mech up to level 1 of the skill tier and you are sorted. Since you will be making more money at start I would suggest to get an Assault mech first. Get one that has the weapons you need so you don't spend even more money on upgrades. Test the trial ones and remember if you buy the trial mech you have been using, it has the XP saved which is great as it can be used for skills once unlocked.I would say to go for a Heavy mech first but due to longer queues it will take you longer to make the money back so I say get an Assault first then a Medium and a light if you fancy that (run the trial mechs first for as long as you need as it will help you decide which you prefer and you will also see the difference in queue times for the different mech sizes).

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												MechWarrior Online is a game of thirds. 1 third is the actual game, i.e. using giant stomping mechs to shoot lasers, cannons and missiles at other mechs. The next third is build said mechs, the mech lab and coming up with builds is one of the best parts of the game. It isn't like most other games, you can make terrible mechs if you don't know what you are doing, but if you know your strengths you can make amazing mechs. The final third of the game is the people, I didn't enjoy MWO initially because I was playing on my own. I connected to the Comstar NA team speak channel and just met people who also play MWO and had a great time. I also lurked and eventually contributed to the forums at http://www.mechspecs.com and I enjoyed the game even more.You can drop some real money in the game to buy mechs, and I recommend you do to support the game, but you don't have to because there is no "Pay To Win" aspect of the game.I've spent more time playing MWO than any game I have ever owned and I still keep coming back for more. Highly recommended.

												I'll give it a thumbs up because the game is free, and what it does it does very well. butIt's really a pity that it is little more than arena deathmatch. Battles are glorious, mechs are awesome and the tactical level is very well done. Customizing your mech is fun. But that's it, there is no real "reason" to do things. Why am I on this planet, who are these guys, what's going on? Even "faction play" is little more than slap your name on a planet with no real consequences. No repairs or maintenance, so no consequences for loosing/dying. No salvage after a battle, no loosing mechs permanently. So basically, why go to battle? To grind money for another mech, or a piece of equipment, so you can grind money better for another mech or another weapon and..so on. This games lacks logistics, economy, more player interaction, a sense of real ownership and development. In a word, it has the tactics right, but it completely lacks the strategic side. Maybe the game is going to be updated in the future. In the meantime, it's a pity. But it's good. But it could be better. lol

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												A multi-layered cooperative tactical first person shooter. Your skill matters, but so do your choices regarding what weapons and equipment to put on your battlemech. Instead of being able to respawn, you have a durable giant stompy robot. Armor protects your internal structures (legs, arms, torsos, head) and components, and 'mechs are often able to stay in the fight with multiple destroyed sections. There are a variety of weapon systems, covering short & long range, and burst or steady damage -- with a cooldown & heat management system to keep you from firing all the weapons all the time. Battle awareness and communication play are crucial, as you work with 11 other players to encounter and destroy a roughly even opposing force of 12 rival pilots. There is a full spectrum of mech sizes (20 ton "light 'mechs" to 100 ton "assault 'mechs") that slot into a variety of roles (scout, close range brawler, mid range fire support, indirect long range fire support, long range sniper) that are needed in every battle, and rewarded for doing the job well.This game can be frustrating at time, and seems to have a fairly steep learning curve, but rewards strategic (loadout, map & mech knowledge) and tactical (positioning, targeting, communication) skills and keeps me coming back for the challenge and variety.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												For those new to mechwarrior, allow me to provide an introduction.These are not ultra fast, missile dodging anime style mecha.  These are big slow stompy deathbots that will get hit by hundreds of missiles, get annoyed and fire back.  Fast kills are rare, instant kills are extremely rare.A battlemech is a 20-100 ton battle machine.  Each section of the mech has it's own independant health, and you can lose most of them without dying.  For example, if you are running a standard type engine you can lose both arms, one leg, your left torso and your right torso and still keep fighting.  You get to customize everything.  We're not talking putting skins on your guns, we're talking what guns do you want to carry where, how many rounds for each, how many heat sinks to keep the machine from getting to hot?  What size engine?  How much armor on your left leg, right leg, left arm, right arm, head, left torso, right torso, center torso, left tear torso, right rear torso, center rear torso?  - oh yeah, you get to paint everything too if you still care.Teamwork is the deciding factor in matches, the nature of the machines and how they move and take damage means that even the most skilled player can't overcome a team that abandons them to the enemy.  Putting your team in a bad spot will lose the match even if you are better shots than they are.  This is chess with more layers of complexity.Play intergalactic war.  There are 10 factions vying for control of the universe, pick one and start claiming entire planets in their name as you fight your way across the galaxy.  Now that you have the basics, here's the details on how this game has been.  I joined in closed beta and have been an active player the entire time, including all the massive meltdowns caused by actions of the publisher.  These incidents are incrediby public and easy to look up.  Yes, they earned a bad rep.However, the game itself is quite fun.  It is not pay to win - the cash only mechs are not inherently better.  Different, but not better than the ones you can get for free.  If anything this game is only pay not to grind, which is fine.Honest final recommendation?  If you are tired of fast action, actually want to see who is shooting you, and want to actually fight the other guy give this a shot.  If you like it, then put in a few bucks for a pack of mechs, skip a ton of grinding and enjoy yourself.  Also, join a team.  If you don't join a team, you will get constantly stomped in the community warfare mode.  Cannot stress this enough - no team, don't join CW.

number of helpful: 36 of 51 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
												Mech warrior online is a thinking mans shooter based on the Battle Tech system.You have to select what parts of your mech are armored the most.You have to select what type of weapons to install on your hard points.You have to setup good cooling, or you will not enjoy this game, anything above value 1.1.For new users I would recommend nothing below value 1.3 cooling.You have to decide which mech is right for you.A light mech with the best speed, low armor, superior maneuverability, most often jump jets. Little room for cooling.A medium mech with balanced armor, slightly more fire power, good speed, and lesser to great maneuverability. Some times has jump jets, has a good balance for adding heat sinks and pretty much any equipment you may need.A heavy mech, the back bone of mech warrior arsenal, great armor, slower movement, and low to lesser maneuverability. Fewer heavy mechs have jump jets. You will have to decide what is more important. A higher alpha stike with higher heat spikes, or better sustained fire with very balanced heat.An assault mech can have the most fire power, the highest armor, slowest speed, and poor to very poor maneuverability. Very rare to use jump jets in an assault. Heating a cooling on these mechs is completly custom and up to the user.RolesLight mechs often are the tie breaker of any match. If you take out the enemy light lance early on you have almost full control over the battlefield during the course of any match. Lights are the bane of assault mechs. Light mechs are the scouts and the ace in pocket for advanced users.Medium mech are great for support. They can take a few more hits than the lights and are well balanced to fullfil almost any role long range or short, scouting, sniping, anti missle. You name it there is a meduim mech that can do it, they just make poor battle tanks.Heavy mechs are the real bread & butter of battle tech. Not always slowed down by a massive amount of armor and the can carry enough fire power to topple almost any mech in seconds 1v1. Heavy mechs also are some of the hottest mechs in the game, so beware of cooling issues.The assault mech is more than a tank. If built right, an assault mech can wipe out an entire lance quickly, but their slower speed and poor maneuverability make them prime targets for enemy light mechs and lrms. Do not chase the squirrels in an assault mech it will always end badly for you. If you have a squirrel climbing up your leg, call out to your team for assistance, or you better pray a lucky snap shot can take dispatch them quickly, otherwise your SOL.Very immportant words,, STAY WITH YOUR TEAM or die alone.Any first time player should stick with Inner Sphere medium or light mechs for the best playable experiance, they dont cost much but the equipment to add to them can cost a bit more than the mech alone.Plus the Inner Sphere light's have the most customization and max speed of all current mechs.Then work your way into a medium, heavy, or better, or even Clan mechs. The bigger the mech the slower it is and the bigger target you are for the other team. Light and fast is what I enjoy the most.I can not recommend Clan mechs for new players. The clan mech are sometimes gimped on tonnage for custom equipment because you can not change your engine on the common omni varients, and the heat build up is sky high. They do have better range and more custom hard points, but the heat build up is crazy, not easy to balance max fire power with max cooling. The max cooling is never enough for a Clan mech. The Origin ii c mechs trade omni pods (custom hardpoints) for the ability to change engines. They actually work quite well and can be cooled very well.Hope this post was helpful, and do remember to torso twist.

												Disgusting butchering of the original mechwarrior series, crowdfunded as a mechwarrior 5 game that turned into a freemium money maker aiming for the esports audience (for some reason)Mechanic wise it is a dumbed down version of mw4, which was already a simpler mw gameThe only game modes available are different variations of straight pvp matches, (walk forward until you see the enemy) and base defense, which is a regular pvp match with only 3 mechs to deploy and a wall in the middle of the way, which is destroyed in less than 2 minutesOnly a handful of maps available, and they only contain mechs. No structures to resupply/repair/DESTROY, no military vehicles or aircraft, but you can pay to get a one use artillery strikeThe powercreep is growing exponentiallyCoolant is a consumable item. WhyHorrible grinding, pay2win barrier Horrible graphics design. All mechs look like they were built using the same 5 pieces of legosIt is free, you can download it and enjoy it for a while until all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t overwhelms you, just dont spend money on it. The basic mechanics had the potential to be a decent mw experience, but it's all buried under layers of ''balanced matchmaking esports fp2 experience''. It is another example of a good idea ruined by the freemium standars, and like all the f2p games following these standars, it took all the money it could and started to lose playerbase quicklyThere are alternatives to this game if you feel the need to pilot a giant mech. Mechwarrior living legends for example, even if it's still unpolished, is what this game should've been and it was accomplished by a small team. Mechwarrior 4 still has some online matches going using the mektek packs

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												As a member of this community for nearly 3 years, I can confidently say that this game is worth your time.  It has had its up's and down's, even dissolved the original publisher (IGP).  But thats all in the past, lets talk about what the game is now.-- MWO Smurfy Mechlab is your best friend! -- I highly recommend using this site to build mechs before you spend your hard earned c-bills.The Good -Lots of stompy mechs (300+)Amazing CustomizationGood core gameplayGood beginner tutorialThe audio is pretty good.Graphically it is pretty good, however the pilot model should updated at some point.It is not a pay to win game, the pay features are to earn c-bills faster, the paid hero mechs aren't any better than the standard mechs, aside from earning 30% more c-bills.As long as you take your time in this game and dont just rush everything, you will do fine.The Bad - Mechbays are not easy to aquire for new players.  You get them from Community Warfare, events, or buy them.  However if you are enjoying the game, mechbays ARE worth the cost.Community Warfare - It is in beta and it IS being worked on.  If you want to try Community Warfare as a solo player, or in a small casual group, it can be quite frustrating. Especially when going against organized teams.Some of the free content is behind Community Warfare.  Example : Rank 2 of any faction gets you a mechbay.No tutorial for the mechlab / customizing mechs.  And no way to test the loadout before your purchase.Some information can be difficult to find.There is a lot of information to absorb in this game, and it can be overwhelming to some.  I am NOT adding balance to this list, because balance will always be changing.MechWarrior Online has been going through some massive changes in the last year, after the removal of IGP.  Rebalancing will always be an issue, nothing will ever be perfect, this is the nature of an ever changing game.  They have been adding more and more content and attempting to make Community Warfare something that we can all enjoy.  just take the game slowly, it is a bit of a grind to get heavier mechs, but it will be worth it if you are patient.Also if you have issues piloting your mech, drive it like a tank, its the same concept.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												As a veteran player, a long time Mechwarrior fan, one of the first 600 players to sign up in 2011, and a closed beta tester I will say that this game is a disappointment. The in-game new user experience is still dire after 3 years of the game being active. As of this year a new tutorial system has finally been implemented which helps players with movement, shooting, and controls but there still no in-game tutorial on how to navigate the MechLab (where you spend a good deal of time and build/customize 'Mechs). You're at the whims of the community on this one and will need to spend time reading guides and researching player suggested builds, which may be outdated or include biases. Since the MechLab is where you spend money (in-game and real), there's a good chance as a new player that you may spend money on the wrong thing and waste your time and money. The overall gameplay once you get past the customization is shallow. In closed beta it was quickly found that the most optimal strategy was to ball up as a team and have everyone target one enemy 'Mech at a time as this would kill them quicker. This creates a snowball where once one team suffers one or two losses it's very hard to bounce back. This is the extent of strategy and tactics years later. It becomes quite repetitive.Even though there are several game modes they all just devolve into team deathmatch, and some people even get real mad if you decide to play to the game mode objectives instead of just fighting.Community Warfare, which sounds like it would be the main draw to the game, is just an afterthought. It's a bland Attack/Defend gamemode that, like the other modes, devolves into a deathmatch. Objectives are usually ignored. It has such a low population that it's tough to find matches at certain hours, and the matchmaking system has pretty much been stripped out and geared towards 'hardcore' players, which means if you decide to play some matches you'll be going up against veterans with years of experience and hundreds if not thousands of dollars worth of kit.Visually the game used to look better. There was better damage modeling, the animation was better, and much of that deteriorated or was actively removed from the game in patches for some unknown reason. Some of it I'm sure was for performance reasons, but some of the changes over the years were baffling.Overall, it's a disappointing game when you compare it to what it used to be and what it could have been.  I wouldn't recommend it to anyone, especially with so many other great games on Steam.

number of helpful: 33 of 48 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16
												PAYWALL: No. There isn't a paywall, it's not P2W. Let me elaborate: When you first create an account, your first twenty missions each will reward a buttload of cash. More than enough to buy ANY mech in the game of your choice off the bat. After your first mech, the boost goes away which does lead into a grind, but that's in any game. For instance, a match on average gives you 100,000 C-bills. Most mechs can range between 6million to 14 million depending on the faction and its weight ratios. These are daunting looking numbers, but they're not as bad if you managed to get your favorite mech with your starter money.In my personal experience, being a big fan of the Timberwolf from previous mechwarrior titles (Mad Cat) I saved my noob bonuses until I had enough to buy one. I was beyond words with my excitement, and found myself forgetting an economy even existed. Why would I care? I got my favorite mech. Naturally I started looking at other mechs, and by then I had played my Mad Cat so much that I had enough C-bills to buy them. So yes, it's a grind. But they give you some lube by letting you choose a mech to start your grind with.They even have "starter" mechs which are builds the Devs make themselves that you can use free of cost. And they're by no means bad, either. Edit: Not entirely true. As someone pointed out to me, the trial mechs are builds created and voted on by the Community, not the devs.Moving on from the noob experiences, gameplay is actually quite fun. It's intense enough to have you on the edge of your seat but simple enough to where you can actually take your time and enjoy it. The learning curve isn't as rough as other games, and Mechwarrior is easy to sit behind in terms of actually piloting the mechs.Enagements can lead to being fast, agile light mechs attempting to weave between the armored titans and strike at their weaker rear armor to playing the massive skulking titans and delivering devistating volleys into your enemies. Keep in mind, however, that it is a TEAM game and that the biggest may not always be the best mech for the job unless you're working with your team.Customization on the other hand can be daunting, so I suggest maybe watching a quick guide if you're planning to play.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												'Mech Warrior Online is an incredible shooter that, while not as 'simulation' heavy as the older titles in the series, still ends up coming out feeling like the only decent 'Mech Simulator on the market for the last 10 years. Forget that Hawken junk.'Mech Warrior Online is set in the battletech universe and as such brings 30 years worth of history and lore with it, though admittedly most of is left on the table and instead you're given a solid, action packed shooter that focuses on what matters: The 'Mechs. And it pulls the combat off excellently. No absured spotting mechanic that plagues these kind of games, no stupid dice rolls and 24% deviance on impact, no sloping and facing that unrealistically bounces shots (Thoug this skill is replaces with your own skills at spreading damage) and of course, no Russian Bias.BALANCE, as with most shooters is a hard thing to talk about. It's constantly in flux and tryhards always use the current meta builds that weild the most damage in a single strike and nothing else. However saying that, balance is in the best place it's ever been for a long long time. Sure there are still some usless weapons (Flame throwerers) but now it's more about what works on your 'Mech rather than how many of weapon X you can squeeze on. I have never once found a death in MWO to be annoying or 'cheap' in MWO. Something I don't think any other game can claim.'Mechs themselves are also generally well balanced however there are 'Mechs that are simply better than others in certain weight catagories. They usually have tradeoffs, and many of the "Worse" Inner Sphere 'Mechs have "Quirks" to make them more appealing, like better refire rate on a weapon, more range, more damage, etc. You'll never disregard a 'Mech as fodder when it runs at you, but there are certainly others you'll back away from while calling to your team for help.MAPS are generally all good in the regular queue. The maps that the community dislikes are being remade with new features added to them and old design issues ironed out and the rest of the maps are for the most part perfectly fine. Everyone has their own favorites but there are no maps that are beyond unplayable and straight up unfair . You'll never find yourself spawning in and thinking "Oh no I'm at this side of the map" at least.And the big one: MICRO TRANSACTIONS\PAY WAL. Long and short there ain't one. It can be a bit grindy to get up to speed, it can feel like a chore to master a 'Mech you've grown to dislike and it can feel like you're so far away from earning that next 'Mech, but it certainly achivable and easily done for free. I have been playing this as a Legendary Founder since day 1 with a friend, who has never every, beyond that first payment put a further penny into the game and he currently has around 80+ 'Mechs. If you do pay, it's going to make your life easier, wether it be getting 'Mechs from packs or enjoying the benifits of premium time or perhaps a hero 'Mech (A middling 'Mech on a partcular chassis, only used because they generate 30% more C-bills.) but there are no guns or 'Mechs that you can never have sooner or later.Pay responsibly!And now a little newbie guide:A new player should hop in the tutorial and complete that, trying to score gold in the movement challenge before moving on to the main game. In the game you'll now get 25 matches that will grant bonus C-Bills known as a cadet bonus. Use these 25 games to get a feel for movment, positioning and managing heat in a range of chassis weights but do not spend a penny of your C-Bills until you get all 25 games done. You should come out with between 15-19 million depending on how well you did. This will let you get pretty much anything you like and I personally would recommend either the Timberwolf or Stormcrow, two very forgiving and powerful units.A new player should stay _far_ away from Assault 'Mechs and should really really think about if they can handle a light before jumping on it. From here you can now customise your 'Mechs though it's likely going to take a handful of games to earn enough money to do that. Be sure to spend your 'Mech XP in the Skills tab after each game and then use that 'Mech to build up a large stockpile of cash, once you've got three of the same Chassis (But different Mechs, so like TBR-Prime, TBR-C and TBR-D) all skilled up you'll be able to do the Elite catagory of skills and from here you should be able to fend for yourself.Now find a unit!Good luck, 'Mech Warriors!!

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												I've been playing MWO for around three years now. During that period it would be fair to say that the game has seen some ups and downs. However, over the last year or so, the game has got noticably better and it seems this trend is likely to continue.The things are like about it are*The combat is extremely deep, and tactical. The ability to specifically target different components to destroy or disable a mech is absolutely brilliantly done*The building of mechs. You can totally customise every single mech to your playstyle and liking*Balance. This game was horribly unbalanced between Clan Mechs and IS for a long time, but its better than it has ever been before currently*Strategy and teamwork. This game rewards intelligence and teamwork over quick reflexes and lone wolfing.The things I think could use some work are:*Maps. I'd like to see more maps*Community Warfare. Currently is too complicated and takes too long to find a game for casuals*The graphics. Some parts of the game look great, some like dire. Needs more polish overall.*There are still some terrible bugs that need fixing (like the stairs on Viridian bog)But overall, the game is great fun, and probably my most consistantly played game of the last few years. The learning curve is steep, but I urge anyone with an interest in big stompy mechs exploding to give it a go.Reactor....online.....systems.....online.....weapons..... online...... All systems nominal! See you on the battlefield, pilots!

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Mechwarrior Online came with great promises and expectations in 2012, hoping to revive the abandoned genre of Battletech, which was one of the most influential genres back in the 90's. There hasn't been a real Mechwarrior PC game since year 2000, so when the MW:O was announced, hype was real and genuine. The developers of Mechwarrior Online, PGI, stated that MW:O is going to be a credible representation of the rich Battletech universe, with tactical combat, simulator experience of piloting a battlemech, including a large, community driven territory expansion and character development ecosystem, combined with real-time lore timeline progression. PGI called their game “thinking man's shooter”, due to how deep the battlemech customization, information warfare and combat roles are compared to any other arena shooters in the market. They weren't entirely wrong, but MWO left a lot of things to be desired. Game has been available for 3 years, however many of the promised features are not in the game, will never be implemented, or are bare bone functional. MWO offers  two game modes, available to any player. First mode, called “Quick Play”, is an arena game team deathmatch mode, where a matchmaker puts you on a random map of 13, with random people within your skill pool. There is nothing particularly worth mentioning, it is a Team Deathmatch of 12 players per team with no respawns. A quick, straightforward game mode, with high ingame currency and experience gain ratio. It is a recommended game mode for new players, until they grasp the basics of the game, then maybe join a clan and select their faction.Second game mode is called “Faction Play”, previously known as Community Warfare. This is an advanced game mode, meant for intermediate players. You can play it as a novice, but you will be severely handicapped by doing that. FP/CW is a team deathmatch with objectives, where a team has to defend or destroy a mission objectives on the map to win the match. It is a slightly deeper in regards to tactics and drop preparation, since you can take up to 4 battlemechs in a match, however it is more time consuming and less currency friendly than Quick Play. This is meant to be the main game mode, but is currently in BETA 2, which is a PGI term for not complete. It should receive a  significant updates in the future, but is severely lacking currently.Mechwarrior Online is a game that is really unique in this genre. It is the only mech combat simulator on the market, and the feeling of piloting a giant combat machine is really outstanding. This is the thing PGI got right. Unfortunately not many other things are on the same level. Once you make through very basic new player experience, you will have a limited amount of really good experience exploring new maps, battlemechs and different strategies, but once the dust settles, MWO is only a mediocre team deathmatch arena shooter with mechs, played on a seriously flawed maps, lacking the promised combat roles and information warfare. Severely lackluster game modes, combined with slow content release cycle and non-evolving balance due negligence of developers leaves little hope for the future of the game.

												Great game! been playin since early beta 2011. Im a causal player who only plays a 1-2hrs a day tops, maybe more on the weekends/days off from work. In total ive only spent 160$ on the game over the last few yrs, 55 for a "a al crate" MadCat, another 55 for the Mauler that came out not to long ago.. and the rest on MC for PremTime, mechbays, Xp-to-Gxp conversions sales and 2 hero mech when they were 50% off. The Only thing you NEED to BUY in this game is MechBays and they are pertty cheap.. I have 41 mechbays maybe 10 were paid for.. the others were won from weekend events/CW rankings. I own 36 mechs, 8 were paid for with real money (Mauler 55$ = 3mechs, Madcat 55$ = 3mech, and 2Hero mechs) the reast are all earned with cbills. Yes it takes some time to build up cbills to buy mechs.. but plz keep in mind this isnt Pokemon you dont not need to get them all. Find a mech or weight class you enjoy and focus on that. WARNING: MWO is not a P2W game, more like pay-2-get-ahead... as in you dont have to play a bunch of games to earn cbills to buy mechs u can just use real money to get them.. buyin mechs for realy $$ will not give you a advantage. If you do feel the need to throw money at the game buy a hero mech when they are on sale, they provide a 30% cbill boost to your end match earnings when playing that mech. But i would really sugest that you play for atleast a month befor you do, this should give you enought time to play the trial mechs maybe buy 1-2mechs for cbills, and get an idea of what mech/weight class you enjoy the most.Hope this review is help full.. if you have any questions i highly suggest goin to the NewPlayer section of the forums on the MWO website to get real answers. content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
IntroductionI started this game 100% fresh to MechWarrior and BattleTech in general and am loving every minute of it. I don't feel as though it's pay to win, I'm no stranger to tactical shooters so maybe that helps. After my first 25 Cadet games I had ~20 mill C-bills which seemed to be enough to get either a few IS mechs or a single clan mech and completely kit them out with a custom loadout. Which may not seem like alot, considering the vast variety of mech choices there are, but for the most part it's a solid starting point.Free to Play modelI will argue that c-bill gain without premium time after those 25 cadet games can be very slow, but just like any similar game to this (World of Tanks, War Thunder, etc) it's just a grind, and for the most part the mechs are fairly well balanced at the moment. Some mechs are argueably just flat out worse than others, but if you learn the game mechanics and play properly any mech can work in the right pilots hands. So far I've spent very little money on this game and I have played it for a solid 2-4 hours minimum per day since I downloaded it and it's still a blast. I personally do not consider this game to be pay2win by any means.CommunitySo far I have had very little problems with the community, the occasional salty teammate in chat, but what game doesn't have that. Not alot of people use the in game VOIP which is relatively disappointing considering the game revolves aren't alot of focus firing and communication, but it hasn't seemed to dictate the overall results of my matches (though the matches go much smoother when communication is present). There is tons of useful information for new and verteran players alike on the forums, pretty much anything I've wanted to learn about the game has been readily available via a simple google search.Gameplay MechanicsBeing new to MechWarrior the gameplay mechanics at first were a little overwhelming but even the most average of gamers can readily grasp how to play the game and even more advanced mechanics like shielding and such. The introduction tutorial isn't anything incredible but it does give a fairly solid overview of the basics of the game such as targetting components, firegroups, and mech movement. For a little fun shoot the captain a few times after you finish the intial tutorial and are at the MechWarrior Academy.Overall VerditI would 100% recommend this game to anyone who enjoys shooters in general, especially tactical team based shooters such as Arma or most Tom Clancy games. Team play is pretty key to success, very rarely does a lone wolf accomplish much in a match of MechWarrior, but even when your team doesn't communicate via chat or VOIP as long as you pay attention and try to focus targets down with your teammates the game doesn't feel like a complete landslide.As for a number rating for those who enjoy those silly things, I would say somewhere around 8/10, definitely a game you can get very involved in and play every single day for extended sessions, or even the type of game you can just hop on for a couple matches every once in a while.

												The game is good for what it is. As it is, and not what it could have been.Because if you delve in what "it could have been" then no game is good ever. Allow me to say this: MWO is a ♥♥♥♥♥on of half released promises and a development with a snail pace, seemingly incompetent devs and really questionable design decisions that have made this game get the bad rep it has. And still the game is addictive and fun. It just is. The fact that so many want to moan around the game is because we're all in the stockholm syndrome. When you're hunting down another mech and land that AC20 and see the explosion from afar is priceless. The one man last stand win or the one last MPulse Laser knife fight makes it worth it. As an arena mech shooter it works, and it's fun, and if you like robot "simulation" adn multiplayer this is as close as you will get for the decade. Alex Iglesias art is beautiful and the Battletech redesigns are really good.I'm not defending PGI's past ♥♥♥♥ups, or the future ♥♥♥♥ ups, or the fact that this is going to be a slow year AGAIN with patches and content, but the game itself and what they have done right is a game that is fun at its core. Sometimes anger inducing, sometimes pure adrenaline fun.So if you plan to play this game just download it and test it for yourself. Don't let the golds and the jaded super fanboys tell you it's a straight bad game because it would be a lie. But as for their salt and hate, they wouldn't be wrong either in many points.

number of helpful: 101 of 173 people (58%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												TLDR: MWO is a solid Mech combat game that suffers from an Apathetic, minimum viable product developers. It doesn't have the depth of many previous Mechwarrior/Battletech titles but can deliver a decent mech simulator experience with up-to-date graphics for those wanting.It's hard to find a game as polarizing as MWO. Some love it, some hate it, but both sides have their points. The game is far from new, at the time of this review its a little over 2 years old and just hitting steam now. It launched in 2013 to middling reviews, many can agree the core gameplay is solid. But on launch it only had two gamemodes, and in the two years since they claim to have added 3 more. Though one is Skirmish (Deathmatch) which added nothing new gameplay wise, and Invasion/Invasion Counter Attack (Same mode mirrored). A vast majority of games will come down to destroying the enemy team, and to do so you have a very wide selection of mechs and loadouts. The meta of which has been evolving over the life of the game. As a Legendary Founder who has played on and off since beta I've seen the rise and fall of OP Alpha-strikes, LRMgeddon, Poptarting, etc. Currently the game revolves around mid-short range brawls, generally playing peakaboo at the line of skirmish until one side finds an edge and pushes through to vitctory. Games tend to play out a little one sided. At the core of many arguments is the pricing model of MWO. At launch they offered tiered packs with exclusive mech variants to raise support for the game. While many accepted it as a good way to kickstart the games development, few suspected it would carry on as a common occurance. In 26 months there have been 5 more drives for money including Resistance I and II, and Clan invasion 1, 2, and 3. Not counting pre-order exclusivity to new Mechs for cash only. These typically offer a range of mechs from Light all the way up to Assault in increasingly expensive packs. A common criticism is the option to buy mechs 'a la carte' being much more expensive without offering many of the benefits of the pack. Making heavier mechs arbitrarily cost more as you will either have to pay the fee or suck it up and buy the rest of the lighter mechs bundled together. Another criticism is the exclusive variants of mechs marketed as "heroes" for cash only. While they are generally considered on par if not worse than ones available for in-game currency. Many find it distastful to lock potentially gameplay and balance effecting loadouts behind a paywall. In recent months they've began running tournaments which make it possible to earn their premium currency and time without spending money. But you'll be grinding for a long time to catch up on all the mechs they've released since. MWO is not a pay to win game, but its definitely pay to skip the grind. It can be unfriendly to new players with a steep learning curve (Tutorial has helped somewhat), uncooperative community, and combination of unfriendly game mechanics. To master a mech you will need to own three variants of it, which means you will need to do your research if you don't want to waste your initial cadet bonus C-bills on a mech that you'll abandon down the road. It will also take a fair amount of games in each chassis to reach your maximum potential. Even just maxing out your favorite mech of each weight class will be a large undertaking without shelling out money for a mech with Cbill or Exp boosts and premium time. While not mandatory, it is a competitive PvP game and you're going to want every advantage you can get. The developers objectively haven't handled the game very well, they are typically slow to react to the players or occasional controversy such as the backlash surrounding the infamous $500 golden mechs. Their actions, or in-action has lead to the current climate in the community where it seems to be a 50/50 split between die-hard supporters of the franchise who love the game for what it is, and those that are upset with the direction the game has taken and that it doesn't stay true to previous incarnations of the series. At least within the vocal minority, many have silently left or continued to enjoy the game. Which if you intend on playing is my recommended course of action, avoid the forums/subreddits/discussions unless you want to see the toxicity first hand.

												Game can be fun, and how to keep it fun, is DO NOT buy any mech packs. Just use in game C-bills to buy your mechs. You will get them fom playing.  If you buy mechs, you will start to hate the game, because PGI like to swing the NERF bat.  So just play have fun, and don't spend real Money ont his game. So play the game, have fun... and don't spend real money on anything. Plus the stuff is way over priced, you can buy new games for the price of a mech pack.  It suxs when you buy a mech and then it gets nurfed.  They say it is for balance, and I give them that, but Clan tech should be better then IS tech, not even. if they want even for the e-sport they want to turn this game into, then advance the time line when IS and Clan tack are even. I will keep playing MWO, because it can be fun, but I do have a bitter tastes in my mouth from spending real cash on NERF bait. Just trying to save you the bitter taste. Take it from a long time player.  See you on the field, Happy hunting. Zom

content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												I probably have close to a thousand hours in-game with Mechwarrior Online and have certainly had some great times across its lifecycle, but I would not recommend putting a single cent into the game.MWO should serve as a warning to what can happen with a crowdfunded/early access title when incompetence and greed align. The game's original publisher (IGP) was created specifically to organise parts of MWO's development, yet for years it bled the developer (PGI) of incoming funds and directed them towards other, failing, projects. Actual work on the game would pretty much cease for months at a time, or end up focused on features that would increase IGP's revenue without improving the experience.Eventually the developer and publisher parted ways and just enough change occurred to make you hopeful. But through years of genuine criticism PGI's leadership team has hardened against any kind of feedback, resulting in increasingly slapdash decision making and implementation alongside very public hostility towards parts of the community.At this point the playerbase has declined precipitously and the free-to-play 'whales' have been bled dry. A complete redesign of one of the core pillars of the game has sat announced for almost a year, with very limited testing and no word on what the final decision will be. Not a positive thing in a game that exchanges real cash for in-game effectiveness.A palpable sense of desperation lurks in almost every aspect of Mechwarrior Online's experience, in the UI, in the gameplay changes, in the pricing structure and in the organised events. By all means check it out, a solid Mechwarrior title lurks beneath, but make no mistake MWO is dying. It's reached the point all free-to-play products risk hitting, more ponzi scheme than workable game.

content:
Posted: April 14
												If someone tells you this game is bad, they're bad, their mech is bad, and they should feel bad for talking this way about the game.  The epitome of team work and balance, a tactical game where knowing key map points and the weaknesses of mechs is impertive, if you're looking for a game that's immersive and balanced almost to the point of stupidity, this game is for you.  Work with your team mates, communicate well and call your targets, you'll have good games.Pros:- Extremely balanced.  Because all mechs in their respective factions pick from the same pool of weapons, you can't blame something for being overpowered unless you're just approaching it from the wrong angle of attack.  Everything has a weakness from not being able to aim at certain angles, to being slow, to being a large target, to being extremely squishy in certain areas, to not being able to turn fast.  Over time you learn what mechs can and can't do well, and you can exploit this.- Huge variety for customization to suit every play style from people that like tanks and huge damage to people that like stealth and fast jabs at enemies.- Lots of mechs to choose from, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.Cons:- Huge learning curve.  Your first 10 or so games you will do less than 100 damage, perhaps a bit over 100 if you're in an assualt, and after 50+ games you'll be happy if you get 400 damage.  A damage amount for a skilled player is anywhere from 500-1000, and over 1000 for long games.- Sometimes you get matched up with people that don't communicate.- Poor optimization.  I've got SLI 1080 ti with a 6700k OC to 4.8 and in some moments I drop down to 40 fps.  Turn down settings if you have issues.
