content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												Full disclosure, I'm a founder that's been playing since closed beta.Even if you ignore all the controversey including PGI selling a bill of goods and then pulling a bait & switch, most of which is detailed in this article http://www.gamefront.com/mechwarrior-online-forum-ragesplosion/ -addition of real money consumeables(buying power)-addition of 3rd Person View allowing players to peek over ridges-addition of ghost heat limiting viable builds that are already limited by a chassis weight class, number of critical slots, number of hardpoints and their locations to discourage laser/PPC boating due totheir pinpoint accuracy. Resulting in players being cored within seconds of a match. This resulted in lasers and PPC's being suboptimal as they were never buffed after the devs limited how many could be viably equipped relegating them to supplementary weapons because of high heat output, delay between shots on standard lasers or reduced range on pulse lasers.it doesn't change that the game itself isn't for casual Battletech fans. Especially with mech pack pre-orders in the hundreds of dollars that are withheld as timed exclusives until an arbitrary date after they are released. 'Whales' are willing to pay which is why the pricing structure hasn't changed since the beta.Virtually everything in the game besides non-hero mechs carry a premium real money price in the form of MC(MechCredits), including literally paint, none of which can be unlocked over time via the in-game currency you accumulate through normal play(c-bills).One of the biggest problems is the mechbay gating system. Each mech you own artbitrarily requires an available corresponding mechbay. If you have 10 mechbays and 10 mechs, you cannot unlock an additional mech until you either sell at a loss that you've already spent time leveling up, or you purchase an additional mechbay which can also only be purchased with MC. Effectively, you will always be spending money on the game. It fails as an F2P title because you cannot unlock using time as a currency by simply grinding out enough in-game currency through nomral play.TL:DRBottomline, I love Mechwarrior, I've been a fan since the 90's. Even in MWO I love tweaking the mechs, the combat is fun even with the flaws and I like being able setup various weapon groups to control which weapons fire independently of others. It's been proposed in the past that they offer a VIP system where once you've spent a combined minimum total on the game, you would unlock VIP status that would remove the Mechbay system and give you a permanent XP/C-bill bonus and maybe even a permanent 10-15% discount on premium items that would stack with sales promotions, if not also unlock the all the paints. I would gladly spend another $50 or $60 on the game if it granted those benefits. Sadly, however, I cannot recommend the game in its current incarnation. Hopefully we will eventually get a proper Mechwarrior 5.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
Product received for free
												Mechwarrior online is a Free to play shooter where you pilot mechs from the battletech universe against other players, this game has a few features i really like and i felt the need to voice my own oppionons about this game, so let's begin.#1 this game is free with in-game premium content. Now i know what you're thinking "OMG P2W BLEEEEEEH" i promise you it's nothing like the "World Of" games. The mechs you can access with only premium money are no more or less powerful than any other mech in the game. The only diffrence is a 30% boost to your chasis EXP and C-bills gained from gameplay, and of course a unique paintjob. You CAN buy only a limited amount of mechs before you start needing to buy mechbays, but even these go on sale and are usually only about $2.50 a pop usually. But once again, this game is free.#2 This game is easy to learn and hard to master. When you boot up the game you get a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of information thrown at you unless you play the tutorial, which is about 15 minutes long and explains everything you need to know about the basics of gameplay. BUT there are many high-level tactics such as twisting and jump-jet fluttering you'll need to learn about before you get to tier 1 or 2 play.#3 This isn't call of duty! This game is a bit slower paced and about tactics and position. Teamwork will make or break you almost 100% of the time, don't expect to get many kills early on, it takes about 25 games before you start getting one or two kills.#4 Trail mechs. My god do i love the devs for this. Every week or so the free mechs switch, and you never have to buy them, thinking about buying a timberwolf but you're not sure you want to spend 15,000,000 c-bills? play the trail version a few times and see if the mech suits your playstyle.#5 This game is beutiful, the sound effects, maps, visuals, and mech designs are stunning and you really feel as if you're piloting a 30+ ton war machine. Plus the faction warfare map is awsome to zoom in on and look at all the diffrent planets. The battletech universe is incredibly lore-heavy and the game reflects that.alltogether i give this game 9/10. the gameplay is amazing, as are the sound effects, but without a group of friends you won't have a whole lot of fun with the grinding.now a few tips for new players:your first 25 games you will get a "account injection: cadet bonus" this will give you a bunch of c-bills, you'' feel rich and want to buy a mech but take it from me: wait until you know what you're getting into! Outfittting a chassis takes A LOT of in-game cash and can eat your money up if you spend recklessly.find yourself a mic and a player who knows a thing or two about this game, listen to what they have to say and you'll start crushing in public games! Dont feel discouraged if you die without getting kills, damage is where new players need to focus, support your team and stay with the group. You can't take on 2 or 3 enemies by yourself!

												I wanted this game to be great and amazing, but it has become rotten egg...Keeping this review really brief...because writing any more about this review is a waste of time.  Game really doesn't have much depth or multi-layered depth.  An example of a game that has multi-layered depth (combines different gameplay/game-mechanical features) is warframe.Positives..+Has a good UI for customizing mechs+Graphics for mechs and Cockpit are done well+Game runs wellNegatives-Developer doesn't seem to know what to do with MWO.  They changed Faction play into quickplay mapsmodes, some of which are horribly designed to work for Faction play-No Salvage system like in other mechwarrior games-No AI, except for static targets-Game favors rewards based on kills/damage dealt, versus completing missions.  I thought mechwarriors was suppose to be more than this?-mission payouts are too low-very repetative gameplayIn relation to the comments for further reading, more indepth reasoning for the negatives...Salvage has been in nearly every mechwarrior game in some fashion.  Winning a battle and being able to salvage a mech or being able to salvage parts for a mech could have great feature added to the game.  It might have been outside the scope of the intial developement, but you do get salvage credits at the end of every match.  They could be instead be used for further depth into MWOAI added to the game let the developers add the escort mission into the game.  Imagine if they could do far with AI to bring a sense of immersion into the game using a lot of the battletech units.  Tanks fighting along side us mechwarriors as a simple example.The negatives mentioned above in "negatives" list could have great impact on what MWO could become, but like stated ealier the developers seem do not know what to do with their IP.  I am glad the timeline has been moved forward though, but then again some of the battlemechs added are in the wrong timeline.. (so does the timeline really matter?).

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												After logging in about 120 hours in a little under 2 weeks, I think I can safely say I am addicted to this game.Being a long-time fan of BattleTech and MechWarior games in the past, I was very excited when I found out about this game a few years back. I tried it then, but it failed to catch my interest. I think this was mostly due to the lack of classic mechs from those earlier games, mechs like the: Marauder, Archer, Crusader, Phoenix Hawk, Locust, Wasp, Stinger, Rifleman, and WarHammer.Here we are a few years later and I decide to give it another chance when I see it become available on Steam. The game play is fun and the graphics are really good. There are strategic and tactical elements to the game. There are advancements for both the pilot and the mechs. Between the large variety of chassis and the numerous variations of each chassis, plus the ability to customize your builds and looks, there are a huge number of options available.The one major thing that this game has done to capture my interest this time around is to include classic mechs from the early days of BattleTech. The Locust and Marauder are already in the game. The WarHammer, Rifleman and Archer are all on the release schedule with confirmed delivery dates. I still hope to see other classics like the Phoenix Hawk, Crusader, Wasp and Stinger eventually, but at least they now have some of the most important classic mechs available in the game.There is a lot to grind in this game, but that is a good thing. It means you will have plenty of work to keep you motivated for the long haul. You have the option to grind any mech you want in whatever order you want. Nothing is time-gated or level-gated. If you want to pilot an Assault mech from the start you have that option without having to work your way through Light, Medium and Heavy mechs first. The boosters and bonuses you receive during your first 25 missions are more than enough to help any new player get into whatever mech they are interested in. The company also seems to do a lot of promotions offering free in-game currency and gear. I come from War Thunder, where it took me over a year of playing to unlock top tier aircraft and max out aircrews in just one of five countries. The grind in this game seems like nothing compared to that. At least with MWO you have access to everything right from the beginning.MWO is a free to play game, but like with other such games, they do need a source of revenue. They earn this by selling early access to new content, cosmetic options, subscription time, etc. None of that is mandatory. The early access to new content is for things like new mechs, which everybody gets access to eventually anyways. The cosmetic options are nice to have, but are completely optional, and they let you earn some options during events. The subscription options are actually very beneficial if you are at all bothered by "The Grind", and give you a +50% bonus to XP and C-Bills. If you don't mind grinding content like me then you can just enjoy the journey and feel good when you complete your goals on your own merit.In addition to your normal quick-play modes of Capture, Assault and Skirmish on numerous unique maps, there is a more advanced mode called Community Warfare. This is the mode for experienced players that have built up a collection of fully loaded mechs, understand tactics and strategy, and work together in teams. This mode is about capturing and defending planets while fulfilling contracts for the Houses of the Inner Sphere or the invading Clans. The stakes are much greater, but so too are the rewards. It will be quite a while before I am capable of participating in Community Warfare, but this seems like a excellent mode for extending a player's interest in the game. I look forward to getting involved in this mode.I am very happy with the progress I have seen in this game since I first tried it a few years ago. It is much improved, and definitely worth playing for anybody interested in mech combat or fans of BattleTech.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												So many mechs!My background:  I haven't played tabletop, nor a huge Battletech fan.  I have played previous titles.  I don't normally play Shooters.  That said, here is an honest review...PROS:*Maps look great (graphics tend to the more "real" feel)*Good tutorial (Mechwarrior Academy)*Can run around solo on the multiplayer maps in Trainings Grounds*Almost unlimited configuations (once you can afford to buy mechs)*Earning in-game currency is easy at first*Mechs look amazing and there are plenty*Lots of weapons to choose from*Map voting*VOIP*Slower, more time to think than a Shooter*Simulation feel of being in the cockpit of a giant mech (has both 1st and 3rd Person available views)*Community Warfare shows initial signs of being a cornerstone of the Great Houses/Clans conflict*Matchmaker seems to generally do ok pairing players together*Excellent sound effects for weapons*3 Quick Play game modes plus Faction PlayCONS:*Navigating the UI can be a challenge.*Steep learning curve (previous titles in the franchise were just as difficult)*Only trial mechs to start out with*No tutorial on how to build a decent mech*Game mechanics seem complicated*No respawn (although limited in Faction Play)*No matchmaking in Faction Play*Game modes seem similar*Minimal destrucible environmentGRAPHICS: 8/10 (tend toward realism, uses CryEngine)GAMEPLAY: 7.5/10 (mainly Deathmatch/Destruction, with an occasional base cap)MUSIC/SOUND: 8.5/10 (Music decent, sound effects awesome, no music during matches)UI: 6.5/10 (it's pretty, but overly complicated)MAPS: 7.5/10 (13? distinct maps.  They recently reworked 3 that come with some destructible terrain, dropship, and time of day changes)MECHLAB: 7/10 (Building a mech itself is as deep as any previous title, but no tutorial and overly complicated at first)COMMUNITY: 7/10 (Most are friendly, some very sour apples...forums at http://mwomercs.com/forums/REPLAY VALUE: 8/10 (Enough maps, mechs, weapons, and game modes to replay, but can get repetitive.  At that point might be a good time to switch over to Faction Play)PRICE: 9/10.  It is totally F2P. Biggest complaint I've heard is that there are mechs P2W.  Not true.  Can buy any mech except Hero mechs with in-game currency.  Only about 10% of the mechs are Hero and do have different hardpoints, but they are rarely seen on the battlefield because they are not any better than others in the associated chassis.  They do receive a 30% Cbill boost which is why pilots buy them - to earn cash and not to dominate the battlefield.  If you are going to buy a mech I would suggest looking at the in-game store first.  A $14.95 MC package can get you 2 Medium mechs (Cicadas), or it could get you 4 Light mechs (2 Commandos, 2 Locusts).  Obviously Heavies and Assaults are more expensive.TLDR:  8.5/10.  Game is a blast, needs work, but bi-monthly patches introduce regular new content and fixes. (34 patches in the last 1 1/2 years alone...view them here http://mwomercs.com/game/patch-notesBright future ahead for MWO from announcement made at the Steam Launch Party here:  


YouTube™ Video: MechWarrior Online - Steam Party Announcements + Teasers 

			Views: 19,229		

			Footage from the PGI's Steam Party @ twitch.tv/piranhagames

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												This is a great game (if you want something different than any other FPS right now)(1000 hours on this game pre-steam release)MWO is a strange thing for sure. Will you like it? Well it really depends on what you expect from a FPS.In here, you will not run like a headless chicken (except if you drive Locusts), you will not instantly kill your opponent with a lucky (or skilled) headshot, you will not respawn, you will not magically heal the damages you took during the fight.You will take care of your team mates, you will run for cover under heavy missiles fire, you will sacrifice part of your Mech just to shield your engine while charging, and you will unleash the power of 20 tons of weapons (or more) against giant walking tanks.Pros:- Mech building: before you fight, you have to build your Mech. You choose its weapons, its engine, how much armor it has for each part, how much ammunitions, electronics... The Mechlab is a place where you are gonna spend a lot of time, as it determines a  lot of what you will be able to do in a game, but you'll spend Good time on it. - Simulation feelings: you are in a huge machine of death, but not a fast Japanese Meka. You're heavy, slow, and the controls feel that way. You have to plan your movements because you can't turn back in the blink of an eye if enemies show up. Then again, you are just driving some kind of a giant tank with arms and legs, so it's not that hard to master.- Unique combat style: in MWO, you can shoot with lots of weapons, on the same Mech, all at once... The only thing restraining you from non stop fire is the heat your weapons generate when fired. You have to manage this heat so you don't shutdown from overheating (which means standing still while your Mech cools off - a bad thing). You also have one life per drop, and no healing. Your Mech will lose some parts during a game, and learning how to spread damages as the fight goes on is a key component of being good at MWO.- Beautifull visuals: the Mechs are amazing, all of them. Of course, you will love some and hate some, but the redesign are all incredible. Why "re"design? Because next point:- A 30 years old universe: yup it's an old license, with lots of famous heros, feared mercenary organisations, long stories for every factions and clans.- Continuous development: there is a full team of developers on this game and you can see it. 2 updates per month since  3 years is pretty awesome, as the game is still evolving and switching towards a great balance (which has its Cons).- Giant robots!: we all love them, you know it, and there's currently undreds of mechs to choose from.- Trully Free-to-Play: All the game is available for free. You can't buy with real money better gear or Mechs. There are Hero Mechs you can't buy with the in-game curency, but they are far from being even "top" (some even far from being good - but that's another story).Cons:- Very steep learning curve: This game is hard. It really is. Movement, damage, heat, weapon firing, Mech building, all need a lot of time to be mastered, and you have to re-learn some of those each time you buy a new chassis.- It's not CoD: as said before, this is a slow paced game where you need to think. You need patience, teamwork and strategy to avoid getting wrecked.- Balance??: MWO comes from a 30y old franchise, ok, but that license has its flaws. Rules from the TableTop games were broken because they were not meant for a real-time FPS, and the MWO team does his best to rebalance everything while not going to much away from the original material, but there is still room for improvements (still, there aren't real "cheezy" Mechs or weapons, just some that are a bit better and some that are useless).In the end, the game is really enjoyable if you want a tough game that has nothing to do with any other game on the market so far. The feelings from moving from a cover to another under enemy fire while twisting your torso to spread damage all over your Mech, running and harassing while in a Light Mech- knowing you will die if you get hit-, or being a tower of destruction in an Assault Mech... In MWO, you feel like fighting, and the fight is a 12vs12 brawl. With missiles. And giant lasers.You don't need money so give it a try. Maybe you'll stay (I know i did, since 2012).

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Definitely not without flaw, but still a very fun game to play with friends and teammates.The community overall is one of the best I have ever experienced from any prior game. Much more mature players than an average shooter. There are the occasional bad eggs, but for the most part those people are not embraced by the community as a whole.Lots of units to choose from with varying skill levels or focuses. There are various recruitment threads on www.reddit.com/r/OutreachHPG as well as the hiring hall and recruitment forums on mwomercs.comPGI has been doing a lot better lately making positive changes and working with the community to make the game better. It is difficult the please everybody and they have made quite a few bad balancing decisions in the past, but it seems like they are starting to get more in line with what needs to be done.Some of the new maps have been focusing more on being pretty and large instead of functional and balanced. The fact that they redid the maps in the first place was a step in the right direction, but I feel like at the time they could have gathered more info from the community as to what needed to be done to make the maps better. They listened to the part where people wanted destructable trees and stuff, but then took it a step further and put so much of it in that it obscures vision. Also the fog needs to GO. Poor visibility does not make things enjoyable. We'll see if the next map the do fixes some of those issues.The 3rd party competitive scene is solid, and is only getting better as the community grows. PGI has been paying attention to 3rd party leagues and have been supporting them with prizes and coverage. They even had a team made up of their developers in the most recent season of MRBC!Come play with us!There is a handy player made starter guide here:https://www.reddit.com/r/OutreachHPG/comments/3w6ll1/welcome_to_mechwarrior_online_resources_and_faq/Edit: still playing religiously

Posted: December 11, 2015
												Well, I didn't even use Steam to play the game so far, apart from just logging in to compare, and I'll just play without Steam, so, the play-time is very likely to remain... low =]I've played MWO couple of years ago, when there were only Inner Sphere mechs, and not a lot of them, no Community Warfare, and mechanics were very different. Got bored after a week and gave it up.I've came back 4 months ago, following friends' interest in the game, and this time instead of joining random battles and getting tired of the game, I've read some guides, push-farmed my first Community Warfare drop-deck (4 mechs), joined a big and active unit, and still having a blast so far; making new friends, having fun, actually enjoying the game.So, is the game good / interesting / worth a try? Yes.Is it a " Battletech lore masterpiece"? Not even close. It's a MMO, based off Battletech universe, with everything that comes with those two things. There is a very strong and active community of players, but also a very steep learning curve, with "veteran players" not pulling any punches. And to boot it up - a lot of the active players also very critical of the game, despite playing it. And there are a LOT of bitterness from former players as well.So, both a pro and a con. Developers did introduce various mechanics to ease it up for new players, by making separate match-making ques for solo-players and for groups, and also according to their "mastery rank", which adjusts accordingly with one's experience and how well they play as well.The game is constantly updated, with various changes, not too fast to become a blur of constant instability, but fast enough not to get too stagnated and boring... in theory. New content, and especially events - every week or two. On the other hand - most of the new content just cosmetics: new mechs, sometimes redone maps etc. Mechs just recently got re-balanced, and not for the first time, but a lot of people feel, that changes could be far more substantial.The map for the Community Warfare (territorial wars) was reset recently, opening new possibilities etc - but no actual changes to mechanics of the wars there. Which make quite a lot of people sad...Would I recommend people to try it? Yes... but: After trying it out, finishing the tutorial and getting some games in various trial-mechs behind your belt and pocketing all the newbie-freebies - read manuals, get some non-trial mechs (remember, that your own mechs you can refit - and for Inner Sphere, green by default, you can change the engines and what kind of armor and structure to use, and for Clan, gray by default, you can change arms/shoulders/legs, to get different weapon-slots and bonuses), learn to play in those, and then look for a unit. The game is fun when you're with a unit, and not fun at all when solo.Then the learning curve won't be as brutal. And then you'd be able to judge the game for what it is and if you personally enjoy the game, and not feel frustrated at the starting learning curve and judge the curve instead of the game.Unlike some other "match-games where one team of armored vehicles fight another team", where they lure you in with easy and fast progression at "low-tiers", and then stomp some huge grind on top of ya on later "tiers", MWO doesn't have vehicle tiers or levels. Mechs differ in classes, but anyone can get any mech they wish at any point. The prices don't change either (it'll cost exactly the same for a newbie as for a veteran). So, they bite when you just start playing, and they are easy when you've been playing for a while.New players get it rather hard, because despite the huge tutorial and first-games pays off - it's barely enough to get you some mechs, depending on what you went for and without reading guides - one can easily spoil everything for oneself. On the other hand, once you did that first proper drop-deck to go join Community Warfare (I'd recommend mix of mediums and heavies to begin with - lights, despite being extremely fun, require fast reaction and some knowledge of tactics and maps to be good, and assaults... are very situational, despite being brutal in right hands), and manage to find yourself in a team, that accepts new players but also do organized drops that win games - getting new mechs isn't hard. After a while (after 5 weeks of playing in my case) an evening or two worth of playing would get you a heavy mech. That's when getting mech-bays (slots) will become more important, than getting money to buy those mechs =]P.S. yes, you can play it for free, without paying. Resisting the urge to "boost it up just a bit" may be hard, if you can pay, but if you cannot or just have a strong will combined with patience - it's very playable without any cash put into the game. Especially since often enough various "extras", including premium time, are parts of prizes for various challenges in events, that happen every week or two.

Posted: April 29, 2016
												I thought it might be some pay-to-win nightmare wearing the skin of a legend, but thankfully it isn't. Paying for *anything*, or not paying for anything, won't make any difference to your capacity to win (or lose) at this game. You don't even need to buy things with the in-game C-Bills you accumulate for simple match participation, as a rotation of community-designed mechs of all classes is available for free play anytime!You can even win the normally paid-for currency in events; I've been playing this for one week, and in this time an event has been launched which will last for 10 days where you can win all kinds of unique or normally paid-for stuff.Well done Piranha, well done.Now if you can only integrate the Steam market so people could trade bits of kit, mechs, camo's, etc. this might be the only game I'd ever play.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												After putting a fair time into attempting to play this game, I have to say this game is too unforgiving for new players that want to learn to play the game today.  New players will find themselves in matches that have been playing for some time.  This results in them having unlocked skills that can take some time to get.  While there is a match making system I can not say this system is effective as I often feel outclassed with games that I actually do ok feeling too infequent.  As a fan of MW2-4 I love Mechwarrior but this game is frustrating to me.  I can imagine it would be worse for those that have no clue when it comes to certain game aspects.MWO is F2P:  I can honestly say that players that pay will not kill you soley because they have paid money.  The money spent allows players to own more mechs, earn resources/exp faster and buy cosmetic items.  I would recommend anyone interested in this game to try before looking to spend money.  If you like the game there are 4 steam packs that allow you to grind faster once you find a class style that you enjoy.There are positive aspects to this game such as the complexity and potential for group tatics but in random matches you may not often find this.  You may lose when you should be pushing forward when other times you should employ other tatics.  Perhaps playing with several friends and work together will help you fare better.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												I have played every Mechwarrior game since MW2 and this is the best yet. Obviously the graphics are a huge step up, but Faction Warfare also makes the universe really come alive, especially now that there is a parallel Scouting mode. The Quick Play game modes are also very interesting.Even though this is a free-to-play game, there isn't really a pay-to-win component, and the mech customization is on par with what you would expect from previous MW games. You can really get into details and have a lot of fun with it. And there is a huge range of mechs to choose from which keeps things interesting.There is still work to do: 1) Faction Warfare needs an endgame, i.e. if Clans capture Terra they should win. 2) Add even more modes to Faction Warfare 3) Fix queues in Faction Warfare, the waiting is too long, 4) If a planet is completely captured then a new planet should open up for the attackers, 5) More in-game lore, 6) Better documentation for new players, 7) More mech customization options, especially more weapon types.Those are just my suggestions but on the whole I really, really like this game!

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												Giant Mechs shooting eachother and plenty of cover to make your 20 ton Locust effective at hit-and-run sweeps against a 100 ton Atlas.One match I was deployed in a Locust (smallest mech) and I was up against an Atlas (one of the largest mechs).  We found ourselves facing off as the last two alive.  Effective use of cover and a lot of running happened.  In the end, I took the Atlas down.  The learning curve can be steep but keep in mind it's free to play.  The mechs which require real money to buy aren't any better than other mechs but simply offer unique loadouts and paint schemes.  Additionally, all the pre-order mechs that you can purchase will eventually be available for the free in-game currency.  The camo specs, and paint colors that you have to purchase currency for can typically be picked up during the frequent weekend-based events by participating.  In short, this is a fun game.  Get teamspeak and play with friends.

You have to take the good with the bad.Don't take MWO to seriously, have a plan on what you want to accomplish, do your research on how to play and you will find a great lobby shooter that stays exciting.

content:
Posted: February 10
												Matchmaking hasn't been fixed since I started playing. Tier 3 forces you to play against people between tier 5 and tier 1, lowest vs highest skill.Dying community is not assisting in any way and a very large number of individuals are toxic and will moe lances around just to mess with people.Grind is okay in my opinion, but it's understandable how so many people would be irate at earning only 200k (If you win and do well, otherwise expect only 50k in earnings) when a light mech requires 6 mil in cbills.With ghost heat, there are OPTIMUM build in this game. Go either Gauss Rifles, or an ERPPC supported by lasers. For lights: Take an SRM boat or a mech with jumpjets and the ability to mount an ERPPC to poptart with. No other way to play the game and be effective.Horribly balanced as a result of ghost heat and that DOUBLE heatsinks only provide a piddly 15% increase in heat dispersal, and guaranteed to only get worse with the suggested 'energy drain' mechanic.No map differentiation. Every map is either an open plain or an open plain with mountains occasionally in the way. Even the 'urban' maps are still an open river with cover on either side or a mountain with no real cover at all. There are no maps built towards brawling, being in close confines, and no map statistic variation such as E/MAG blanketing from tabletop (Which stops your radar from working properly), hints that close range combat with non-light mechs is a  pipe dream.Developer: Stop adding mechanics and just give us tabletop battlemech construction rules. Give us better and more complicated maps. Give us the option and ability to play more than one type of mech.If you want to play a Mechwarrior game... well... look up a game called MechWarrior: Living Legends. Buy the appropriate Crysis title. Play that instead.

number of helpful: 62 of 111 people (56%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												First of all as a long-time player before the steam release, my hours clock in at around 300. If you don't believe me and you're one of the 2 other people who use the Raptr gaming client, go look me up there.Mechwarrior Online is a shooter that brings a lot of unique things to the table, and while I could tote the customizibility and unique feel of each chassis that makes owning over 60 mechs feel insufficient, I'd rather just explain the main reason I love this game so much. Not only is this a "thinking man's shooter", rewarding tactical thought and teamplay to a far greater degree than most others, Mechwarrior Online also has an immense skill-cap. Pilot skill has more to do with the effectiveness of any given build than any other factor. The game is well balanced in the sense that everybody has access to the same tools to make their mech perfectly suit them, and once you find those builds that just feel right, you can take on a 100 ton direwolf in a 35 ton panther with nothing but 4 lasers and come out with a solo kill as long as you know what you're doing. But this game doesn't only reward individual skill: far more valueable is your ability to position and work with your team. That's what makes the release of this game to the broad audience of steam so exciting. Players who are used to voice chatting with random strangers (hint: the current community does not utilize the built-in VOIP at all) and who can breathe some life into this stale yet unusally friendly and passionate community. The learning curve is steep, but at its peak lies a game that you can sink just as many hours into as TF2 and CS:GO only with a kind of gameplay you won't find anywhere else. And ignore those people who complain about "paywalls"; the developers frequently hold challenges where everybody can earn rewards such as the paid currency (in good amounts, too), mechs, mechbays, and colors, as well as a ton of in-game currency. My only advice to new players is: stay behind cover and check your mechs for ghost heat (when you fire too many of the same weapon at once they generate exponential heat). While this game is definitley not for everyone, it's definitley something worth trying to see if it's for you.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Would like to recommend but...The pros; Mech combat feels great, they have some nice custimization available. Battles can get fairly intense. The game can be very enjoyable. The addition of events helps makes things feel a little more fresh. They seem to always be adding new mechs and maps. The cons;My biggest beef with the game is that its really only feels like its half a game or that its still in beta. There is no single player, there is no coop mission modes, only multiplayer deathmatches. To which you will be doing the same death ball attack pattern in every match. There is different factions but really there is nothing that makes you feel like you are on two different sides. I get that its free to play so maybe no single player camp, doesn't mean i give it a pass as the in game charges more then make up for it being "free to play". At the very least coop event missions or something that actually utilizes the lances and brings in mission objectives and tells a little story. Encourages people grouping up. Bring back that squad feeling that the previous games had. You will also find that you and a few others stand against the rest of the team while the rest of your team run and hide. This happens at an alarming frequency. No faults of the devs but i feel this goes to the previous point of no small group work.  There is other issues but they are small in my books, hit boxes around objects can get frustrating, weapons will be hitting air and wont be getting past. Some places in the map's where if you hop up on jump jets you will bounce around like a trampoline but really i'm not too worried. Jump jetting is still very buggy, blown off legs from jumping bugs? One of the bigger bugs is warping that happens when you get too close to an enemy mech. All of a sudden the enemy isn't in your sights but a few feet over. Little glitchyOveral i would like to recommend, could just be my childhood influencing that but there just isn't enough here. Numerous bugs that go uncheck, team balance issues where 12-2 is frequent in hours of playing, events are the same thing with a different package on. Feel like this free to play model makes developers think they can release half a game and say its complete; now would you like to do some in game purchases for $60 for a mech.

Posted: December 10, 2015
												As a long time Battletech / Mechwarrior fan I've been one of the suckers who bought the super expensive Legendary founder package and Phoenix package. I've played MWO since closed beta, stopped playing some time ago. On the PLUS side I have to admit the game looks nice and is mostly fun to play. On the other hand the game and its developers have also disappointed severely, never really delivering on the promises. Development is slow and new release sometimes introduced more bugs than it solved. Wild changes in mechanics or effectivenes of individual weapons happened every few months, rendering previously successfull mechs useless. It felt that devs never really listened to the community. The contents (mech packs, camo paints) are incredibly expensive. Progression is non-existent, there is not much to aspire to. It is just a brutal grind to earn XP for one mech, then for another variant of the same chassis, and for the next one......... or grind to earn credits to buy the next chassis. And let's not forget MWLL - the free Mechwarrior-like game that was at least as good as MWO and had to be killed to make room for MWO.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												This is great example of a game that should have been a classic, but instead is merely mediocre.The graphics and sound are decent, and it is a good foundation on which a great game could have been built, but wasn't. Essentially the game is just an arena combat game using mechs  - there is a Community Warfare mode which seems very unpopular, but really the game is just deathmatch. Having played on and off since the original Beta, I can't help but feel that if the developers had put a little more effort into fleshing the game out with a bit more depth and variety it could have been so much more. Essentially the game we have now is little more than the core functionality upon which a game world could have been constructed. Calling it an MMO in its current form is pretty funny really, as there's only the skimpiest of metagames or player interaction. This would be fine for a simple FTP game, but as the inheritor of one of Sci-Fi's finest (if cheesiest) franchises, and bearing in mind the frankly incredible amounts of real money demanded for Mechs, it's just not enough. In addition the rich lore and background of the Battletech universe has been largely ignored or contradicted when large parts of it could have been exploited much more cleverly.In my view the IP should never have been given to these developers (or indeed their even shadier former publishers) and I'm afraid it seems that they just weren't up to the job of turning out a solid game that's worth the money that so many have already spent on it.

number of helpful: 252 of 472 people (53%) found this review helpful16 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												I've played this game off and on since 2012, starting with the Founder's beta.We'll start with the good things: the core gameplay, is solid and actually works fairly well.  The weapon effects are nice and some of the artwork is very good.    The game has very good sound design and effects.Now, for the bad: everything else.It is an arena shooter with long queue times, lousy matchmaking, bad netcode, a terrible community, and terrible balance decisions.  It is extremely grindy, the cash shop packs are insanely overpriced, and development on the game has been virtually non-existent for three years now.   Oh, and the game is extremely buggy.  And I can provide examples.Let's begin with the queue times.  My average wait to get a solo match in the 'public' arena game queue is usually about three minutes.  My average wait to get a group game (groups have an entirely different queue) in my last play session was over five minutes per match.  The average wait to get a community warfare match during peak hours is typically about fifteen minutes.  Sometimes, after waiting for fifteen minutes, you don't even get a real match, but instead you're forced to grind out turrets for minimal reward.Let's continue with the matchmaking system, which recently ditched ELO in favor of a 'skill tier' system that is actually just a grind.  If you win a match, your skill rating will improve.  If you lose a match, but displayed more activity than a moldy potato, your skill rating will improve.  The game literally rates player skill based on the number of matches someone has played.The netcode is bad.  You can play the game and see for yourself, if you don't believe me.  However, suffice it to say that it is entirely normal in this game for shots to simply fail to register on the target at all, or for other weird things to happen, such as taking fire from the front and noticing that the damage registered on your back.---The game is badly balanced, because the designers of the game do not understand their own game.  With every other game update, certain mechs and/or weapon systems will go from being completely worthless to utterly overpowered, and there is absolutely no rhyme or reason to how, when, or why this will happen.  Actually, I take that back; I do know why balance changes happen.  When the lead game designer actually deigns to wade in and play his own game, he is typically embarrassed on account of being awful and not understanding what's going on.  But rest assured, that he will nerf the hell out of whatever killed him, because clearly that must be overpowered.  For instance, look up "Goons Heart Paul" on Youtube and then consider that the mech knockdown mechanic was COMPLETELY REMOVED FROM THE GAME FOREVER in the patch immediately after that video was recorded.Oh, and there are also two different levels of technology in the game.  Inner Sphere (IS) technology, and the more advanced Clan technology.  Clan mechs are faster, more durable, and hit harder.  They participate in the same matches as IS mechs, and there is no penalty on the player for bringing a Clan mech into battle.  You may have noticed that the Clan mech packages are more expensive than the IS mech packages.  Surprise, that's because they're better! ---When I say the game is grindy, I mean that the game is grindy.  You get a huge cash bonus in your first 25 matches, enough that after playing 25 games, you will be able to afford a mid-sized Inner Sphere battlemech.   Then you have to buy equipment for it.  Double Heat Sinks: 1.5 million c-bills, MANDATORY on all IS mechs.  Endo-Steel structure, MANDATORY, will run you maybe another million c-bills.  That's not counting the weapons and engine you're going to have to buy when you customize your mech, assuming you actually want to run a good build on it so that you can be competitive and kill people. Note that you have to buy three variants of each chassis (full price!) to "elite" a mech, which is ultimately necessary to be on even footing with veteran players.---Development on this game has been dead pretty much since release.  I don't think I need to go into fiascoes such as Transverse (when the developers decided to abandon development of MWO in order to try to kickstart a Star Citizen ripoff) or the $500.00 gold mechs (Google it), but ultimately the development of this game has been nothing but one mech pack grab deal after another, with pretty much no development at all of new gameplay features or content.  The game is buggy.  The HUD is frequently glitched or displays incorrect information (generator displays were broken for MONTHS in Community Warfare matches), but is also poorly optimized and tanks the game's framerate.  Crash to desktop remains a persistent issue.  I wish I could add more, but the character limit on Steam reviews prevents me from doing so.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												Great game, Gimmicky name:MechWarrior Online is bar-none one of the greatest team based shooters out there. It is extensively well balanced and has a great deal more strategy and teamwork than any other shooter I've played. The mechs are diverse and in the right hands even a garbage mech can be a war hero on the field of battle. Moreover there aren't any game breaking builds, which is unheard of in competive multiplayer games. It has a steep learning curve and takes awhile before you can find a mech that best suits you, but once you do the game is extremely rewarding.My biggest complaint about the game it is the name. MechWarrior Online sounds like a trashy free to play mech game so the fact that this is free to play doesn't do itself any favors as far as marketing goes. I've been a fan of the MechWarrior games for over a decade but I took years to try this because I assumed it was going to be a piece of crap due to its name. My Steam friends don't want to try it for this sole reason.Beside the name I have no issues with the game itself, in fact I would say this is leagues better than other strategy based shooters like CSGO for instance. If you are looking for a game more involved than hiding out in a bomb simulation I would highly recommend this.

number of helpful: 40 of 71 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												I've played MWO for a bit over a year now, and it's the only game I've consistently come back to in that time. I really loved MW2 experience and seeing the mech lab for the first time and customizing my mechs really brought those feelings back. Then dropping into a match and unleashing destruction upon the enemy is extremely satisfying and cathartic. Good play is often rewarded and you can really see your tactics help. There are rolls from both sides, but there are the games that both teams had something great going for them and it gets down to one or two mechs left dueling it out. Those are such great moments that really keep your on the edge of your seat, especially while spectating after having dropped earlier in the match. The faction play is fun, but still has room to grow. There will be a 3rd phase update soon that will hopefully add a lot to the game mode. The faction play is a bit difficult and higher skill level than the normal solo queue or group queue. I highly recommend new players tough it out in those queues before attempting the face-rolling potential of faction warfare. This game definitely has my support and I'll still be playing it for years in the future, I think. This is one of those games that I'll constantly come back to. That list of those games is short, but there was definitely a FPS Mech shaped hole in that lineup that this game fills.

number of helpful: 36 of 63 people (57%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												MWO has come a long way from where it was when I started playing it in January of 2015. PGI has made great strides at improving MWO.Now how is the game itself now? Pretty darn good. The game is easier to get into than say World of Tanks or WarThunder as everyone has access to to pretty much everything from the start. With the playingfield far more level you also do not get oneshotted as easily making MWO far more forgiving to the new player.When trying to learn MWO do the tutorial, do the optional parts of the tutorial not just for the bonus Cbills but also to get a better idea of how mechs handle. Learn how each weapon system handles, look up some guides, and if you are in doubt, suck up the high price tag of clan mechs and get one with your cadet bonus. Trust me it is worth it, use it to learn how heat works, how to torso twist, get yourself a Hunchback, Stormcrow or Timberwolf and go to town. Seriously go grab a Stormcrow it is one of the most forgiving medium mechs in the game. If you want to get an Inner Sphere mech? Hunchback, any of them, but, best would be the one with the AC/10 which is the Hunchback HBK-4H. The Hunchback and Stormcrow are very, very forgiving and flexible mechs. Also everyone wants to pilot a heavy mech as well, so a medium mech will help with queue times.Another advantage of grabbing a clan mech first is that when building your mech you have far less things that you can do wrong, like under-engining your mech and making you an easy target. Get to also know what the various upgrades do for your mechs, get to know how much ammo you use.Reading guides on the meta is a good idea, it will give you an idea of what you will be fighting, it will also give you an idea of the weaknesses of each weapon system is and strengths. You do not, and I stress this, and should not blindly follow the meta, learn why the meta is the way it is so you can tune your mechs to capitalize on how the game works.Most of all, find what you enjoy to run in your mechs and run it. Also don't forget to find some friends, look up the faction team speak servers and do group queue drops. Trust me, working with friends or just communicating in general will do more for your match score, cbills, and exp gains than any metamech build.Before getting into Faction play, otherwise known as Community Warfare you should get a good grasp of how your mechs work and get four of them that add up to 240 tons. Make certain they are all basiced.MechWarrior's, I look foward to meeting you as friend and foe on the battlefield.

number of helpful: 47 of 84 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26
												Don't even think about starting MWO.If you love the lore or story you started playing a long time ago, for all others this game just falls flat.The grindwall for new players is gigantic, even if you pay for exp-boosters in this F2P game.  The new skill system currently on the PTS will probably do very little to change that. If you decide to spend money in this game the return per buck spend is very poor. Mech packs or Exp-Boosters are very expensive, the cosmetic patterns are chassis specific and you even have to pay for the colors (account wide) you'd like to use.The asymmetrical balance widens the gap between new players and veterans with clantech being better and more customizable but also too expensive for most new players.The lore (and playerbase) prevent all adempts to balance or enhance the gameplay. Because of the small playerbase and to reduce wait time, the matchmaking system doesn't take any skill into consideration but only matches similar tonnage of mechs.This means as a newcomer with a standard mech, no modules, no map- or timing-awareness you WILL match against the best players this game has in their completely outfitted, optimized Mechs.There are different game modes like Capture the Base or Conquest, but 90% of all games end with killing off one team, making them essentially all team deathmatch on a limited set of maps.Faction play, supposed to be the serious end game, is played on a random map/game mode with 4 mechs for each player.Additionally to the flaws in Quick Play the matchmaking here also pairs random groups with 8+ player premades resulting in lots of games being spawncamps starting after the first wave of mechs.With your limited (not optimized) mech pool as a new player there is no chance to get into serious organized group play in a reasonable amout of playing time.Edit: As discussing game balance in a game review is pointless I striked the balancing part of the review and also the skill tree part because it has been (indefinitely) postponed.

number of helpful: 30 of 52 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												MW:O was my first contact with the Battletech universe.I started playing around october 2014 and did enjoy the game from the beginning. Although, at this time, there was almost no help for new players and the whole game was quite confusing.But I kept playing and with the help of some other players I got the hang out of it and since then I just love the game (and the whole universe, which I learend about after getting both legs in the game).You have endless combinations of 'Mechs to build, tons of different 'Mechs, with tons of different variants. Every variant can be customised with a lot of weapons and equipments. You don't need to take "meta" builds and you don't have something like "the OP super cool" 'Mech. More importantly than the meta is, that you find a 'Mech and a fitting, which suits your very own playstile. Although, of course, some people would disagree: I would say the game is balanced good and you can have a lot of fun with every 'Mech.There is absolutly NO need to pay money, if you don't want to.You won't get an advantage ingame, for paying real money. But there are some variants, which can only be achieved via real money (or premium currency won by events). But these 'Mechs (called "Hero" and "Champion" 'Mechs) aren't better than their ingame-currency-variants. They "only" give you the ability to gain more income or more XP from battles (30%).Real money can only be used to lessen the "grind", but if you play regularily, you won't need to spend money, you can get enough income over time to afford your own hangar full of 'Mechs :)The game is developed further, every two weeks there is an update on tuesday, which provides new content, or updated game aspects.You should try MW:O and make a decision for yourself :)A happy MechWarrior.

number of helpful: 41 of 73 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												Overall Rating: 8.5 / 10DISCLAIMER: Please do not be fooled by my amount of time played on Steam. I have been playing this game since Beta 2012, so I assure you I have many, many hours logged on this game. More hours logged then all other games I own combined for that matter!Review:This is an excellent game with great potential and a bright future ahead! I recommend this game for anyone looking for more tactical gameplay in their FPS gaming.Last year, the devs introduced Community Warfar, a gamemode targeted at hardcore players with an entire star map and several factions to fight for. If you decide to give this game a shot, I recommend shying away from this gamemode for the first while until you get a grasp of the main concepts of combat roles and loadouts, and decide this is a game you want to continue with. If you make it to ComWar, you will enjoy increased rewards, frequent events, and the final end-all Battle for Tukayyid Tournament to end each season of ComWar. ComWar is currently in Beta II, with Beta III just around the corner. In Beta III, players will be able to choose from several unique Career paths, vote on planets to attack, pool C-bills for tactical bonuses & ordinance (TACTICAL NUKE CONFIRMED), and perform either full out planetary Assault or planetary Scouting missions to collect intel for additional bonuses.The devs are continuously pumping out new content in the form of Battlemechs, Camo, (coming soon) Decals and Maps. They are also dedicated to perfecting player balance as much as possible, so one can expect one or two updates to gameplay mechanics every month, on top of new content updates.MechWarrior Online got off to a rough start in 2012. Whether you talk to the haters or the lovers, everyone can admit this fact. This was largely due to the now defunct company Infinite Games Publishing (IGP) and its control over the project. The good news is that since its departure, progress on this game has been swift and positive. The game's 'mech concepts are lauded as one of its strongest points, with much of the beautiful 'mech designs now slated for use in the upcoming turn-strategy game Battletech (if you don't know about this game, also worth a look! www.battletechgame.com).The game's UI has been improved frequently, but new players will still have some difficulty navigating some tabs. Notably, new players may struggle with customizing loadouts. My best recommendation for this is to visit the game's forums (mwomercs.com/forums/) and get advice from the playerbase, most of whom are very helpful.The game's Tutorial zone has been revamped recently! All new players should visit this zone first, because this is not a game that you can simply skip the tutorial unless you are a returning player (the tutorial even has in-game rewards for completing challenges). As a veteran player, I still use this zone to practice with new 'mechs.Some may get turned off buy the game's MC currency (money purchasable currency) that allows players to skip a lot of the grind and get the good stuff. While this game may seem Pay-To-Win, this is certainly not the case, as virtually all chassis, weapons, equipment and upgrades are purchasable with C-bills (gameplay generated/earned currency). The only things unobtainable without MC are vanity items & a select group of 'Hero' mechs that come with unique camo patterns and weapon hardpoints (which are arguably no better or worse in performance when compared to their standard counterpart). Also purchaseable with MC-only are designated 'Champion' 'mechs, but do not be fooled! These mechs are simply optimized versions of standard C-bill purchasable mechs, they do not differ at all in performance potential!In summary, this is a great tactical shooter with very unique gameplay concepts. As such, the learning curve can be rather steep for some, and there are still a few rough spots that require development. The future of this game is bright, however, with constant updates and some really exciting new content lined up for spring. In the words of the game's devs, they are "far from finished" with this game!

number of helpful: 31 of 54 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												I recommend this game if you're a fan of MechWarrior or if you're looking for something unique amongst the F2P catalogue.MechWarrior Online is definately a game worth trying simply because it is free. But be warned: the game is very grindy and difficult. Matches will seem unfair to someone new. This game is slow paced, which is different from other shooters.This game is also very niche. Even if the game was perfect, most will not like it because it's only fun for certain people.The main issue this game faces is the grindy nature of the game. You will spend a lot of time playing to get the end game stuff, which is acceptable. However, you have to specialize in a mech (buying three varients of the same mech) in order to get high-level "masteries." If you make the wrong choice, you could find that you just wasted millions of C-Bills (in-game currency) trying to play.Real-money prices are also high. So expect to drop serious coin if you want a small advantage. Like with everything in this game, you have to educate yourself before you buy. You might not like that sweet mech you just spent 10 dollars for. Personally, I don't mind throwing a little money here and there to stack up my real-money currency, because it adds up fast. To cut on the grind, you can throw some money for an XP and C-bill boost, which is nice and adds 50% to all earnings. Certain mechs that cost real money also carry a XP or C-BIll bonus when using them. You could be earning upwards to 70% extra money and XP due to these mechs.Overall, try this game out. I love it, but it's still a work in progress. The say it's released, but they need to address some things.

number of helpful: 14 of 22 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Its quite simply the best stompy robot game out there, and its the first game of the Franchise for years, that isn't homebrew, if you like Battletech, Mechwarrior, or  just shooting stuff with Lasers piloting a big♥♥♥♥♥♥♥robot, then you should try this game.Its not a fast paced game, unless you play a light, but that doesn't mean it takes little skill, you have to be aware of your surroundings, and work as a team, Rambo's that think individual skill will win all before them, are going to be the scrub that fails, as TTK is high when your focus fired on, and there is a high learning curve, unless you are an exceptional gamer, you are not going to master this game in a week, or even a month, for many players, but people that genuinely desire a challenge, should take to this game.Now the negative first for old time Battletech,Mechwarrior fans, last paragraph more general.Its the least like the franchise that has been produced, though it looks visually great, there are only mechs no support troops of aircraft, P.G.I decided that they couldn't produce a match maker that has uneven numbers in teams, so clan tech will not be recognised as anything like as powerful as it is in Lore, athema for clan fans, myself I never liked the OP bestest mechs that brought totalbalance fail, so I'm fine with it.Customisation is also a balance issue, though hundreds disagree. None of the load outs will look anything like the Canon mech's which is pretty sad, if you are a real hard core fan of the old lore. Very few close to Canon builds  work in comparrison to what you can  built with the custom system, its sad to see Warhammers, and Marauders, handing in their AC5's SRM's and of couse PPC's, for laser and more lasers.  or warhammers with twin AC20's where the Machine guns went.This is I'm afraid from my point of view the big negative, even ignoring the lore and the canon builds, the game has lots of weapon systems but  various  hit detection issues and the use of HSR has made many weapons nonviable and turned the game into a lasers with everything meta, because they are hitscan and can have the beam corrected, as opposed to point of impact damage which can be ducked more easily,  and at times miss because  hit dection is out, so a PPC is a rare sight on Mechwarrior online, and that says a lot, because if there was an Iconic weapon in  the lore it  is the Partical Projection Canon, but sadly  the Laser Aces it in every way.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												Its a good game. Feels like a slowed down version of Armored core with a harder lock on system. That said, this game feels more achin to chess then to Armored Core. You will die from the pawns as a queen, knight, rook whatever, if you are in the wrong spot. Through trial and error or success you'll learn where risky places are and where safe ones are and how to pander to bad situations or simply to know when you've been outclassed. You WILL be outclassed, some people are simply better. Good news is, its not about how quickly you can sight cross hairs on someones head from 100 meters (although you if you get good at that in this game you will wreck) its about awareness and team cohesion.The mechs DO look amazing, all the hype about the models is real. They look amazing. THe maps are.... interesting. They range from super long range, to super short range, but there is no way to say whether as a short range mech, you get the map you want. I feel that not all the maps have somewhere where every play style shines. I look to TF2 for map design, and feel they did very well. There are tight corners, little nooks, long corridors, hoppable outcrops and cover smattering everywhere; all things, that each seperate class looks for to allow them an advantage. Not quite so in this. Pretty much it plays similarly to real life. Life occasionally hands you lemons and you need to deal with it.THe rewards system i would like to see buffed, but as it is, being a heavy brawly mech is the best way to get C-bills *in game currency*It is NOT pay to win. Eventually, everything that you can pay for with $$$ you can also pay for with C-bills. *with some exceptions* eg. hero mechs. (which don't break the game, just another variant of existing mechs)I recommend this game. Its a solid title that will scratch the mech-customization-fps itch some people may have. Its not the best, but as far as mech games on a PC goes,  its brilliant.

content:
Posted: March 18
												Okay, so... Here's the thing. Although steam only says I have 1.3 hours in this game, I have a total of roughly... I don't know, I don't feel like doing math. Let's just say I play an hour to three hours of this five-six days a week, roughly, and have been doing so for the past year.I grew up playing Mechwarrior IV Mercenaries and the Battletech Tabletop game. And I loved both. MW4 was fun as hell, even if it completely screwed canon. There was not really a "learning curve" to it. And that's not even going into the arcad-y shoot 'em up that was the Mechassault series.So, Mechwarrior Online is interesting. It's the closest to tabletop rules a Mechwarrior game has gotten to in recent memory. But it's player versus player only, undoubtedly a loss or turn-off to a lot of people. And there's a hell of a learning curve to it, seriously. People play a few matches, freak out because they die every time, and give up, leaving a bad review before even actually getting to play. To like this game, to get good at this game, you have to put in the effort. You have to grind for experience-not in-game currency/mech experience, *Actual* experience. You have to know your mech, you have to know your role, you have to know the maps. For as much of a "Thinking Man's Shooter" as this game used to be, it still is, even if people say it's not (And they are wrong.). You *NEED* to use teamwork. You *NEED* to communicate. Otherwise, your team gets rolled, and it's a slippery slope when you try to get out of the hole you dug yourself and the rest of your team by lone wolfing it.Don't let the nay-sayers get to you. This really is a great game, but you have to be willing to learn to play it. About a 7.5/10, in my opinion, and it's slowly getting better for me personally even now, especially with the upcoming Summer updates.

Posted: December 15, 2015
												There's no doubt about it. MWO is a flawed game on a number of levels, and the development of this game has been troubled.I mention all of that because it helps to explain why there are such different views of the game.  The game has fans who enjoy it greatly, and yet certain things with PGI in past years have left some people bitter and angry.  That's reflected in the comments, and so you really need to take both sides with a grain of salt. (Ok, a salt mine.)That said, for the real "review" part of this.  For all of its flaws, I find the game to be enjoyable, and it's improved greatly in the last 18 months or so.  To my mind, the fact that I have fun with it is the most important part of the review. It's easy to post lists of flaws and strong points (many of both) and I could certainly add my own list of complaints.  That said, for the flaws, the false starts in development, the game is still fun, and I'm not sure that you can ask any more.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												In a nutshell, Mechwarrior Online is a multiplayer battle arena with gigantic robots. Unlike many other games with mechs however, Mechwarrior Online does an amazing job of actually feeling like a robot,rather than a big metal man.Pros:-Looks very nice.-Feels like a real mech. Huge stomping strides and the cockpit rocking are very... Mech-like?-A huge amount of depth and customisation for those who look into these areas.-A blend of medium and fast paced combat and variety of Mech classes for varied playstyles.-Fairly fun to play in general. Very rewarding for team players and those who put in time.Cons:-Very complicated to new players. Can be overwhelming if you're not willing to put in time.-Some cosmetics are incredibly expensive.-There's a lot of grinding to earn enough credits to purchase and upgrade Mechs to a useful level.-Furthermore, many Mechs are rather bad in their stock state, which can be misleading.-Rather mercliess gameplay; no respawns can leave those unprepared feeling destroyed. (Well, you were, I guess)Overall, Mechwarrior Online is a surprisingly high quality battle arena styled game that doesn't getthe attention it deserves. It's  very complex and hard to learn at first, but behind that, it's an incrediblyfun game that can have you playing many more matches than you'll expect. If you enjoy giant robot gamesand are willing to learn, give it a go. If you enjoyed games like Hawken but want something a little more complicated andinteresting, this is your game.

number of helpful: 29 of 52 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												I have been playing MechWarrior Online since closed beta (summer 2012) and have to say that this is one of the most gratifying and addictive games... once you climb the learning curve. The gameplay is unique in that you can customize your 'Mechs with a very wide variety of weapons. There are no re-spawns in 2 of the 3 game modes, which forces you to play smart rather than run and gun, like most FPS games. It can be frustrating to die in the first few minutes of a game (solo and group queue matches are a maximum 15 minutes, but usually average about 10 minutes, while Community Warfare matches typically last 20-30 mins).If you are an FPS gamer, you will appreciate the higher level of tactical play and it rewards good aim and movement. In fact, the component/hitbox design of the 'Mechs really rewards players who have precision aiming. Headshots (cockpit kills) are extremely difficult, but highly satisfying in this game... more so than any other FPS I have played.There are 4 weight classes of'Mechs, ranging from Light through to Assault, and offer you different roles to play within a team and changes your playstyle. Some people specialize in one or 2 roles/weight classes because it suits their playstyle and others are flex players who like variety.Team Damage: Yes, it is a real thing and it is annoying as hell to be on the receiving end from trolls (which are few and far between, I might add). Thankfully, you can monitor your team damage at the end of round info screen. Do keep your firing lanes clear and apologize to your teammates if you accidentally shoot them in the back (where there is MUCH less armour and can destroy weapons or even kill them in one full volley of your weapons if placed in one spot). If you are tabbed out of the game and click back in with your mouse, you will fire your weapons, so please alt-tab back into the game instead.Interface: The out of game user interface in the game has changed a lot over the past couple of years and it still isn't perfect, but it MUCH better than older ones. The lack of customizable UI is understandable, due to the sheer volume of parts that make up the info needed and it still can't all fit on one screen. This is a game that is very complex when played to its fullest potential, yet offers instant action once you become familiar with the ideal builds for each 'Mech. Expect to spend a lot of time initially tinkering with Mechs and unlocking skills and items (modules that enhance your weapons, movement or ability to gather info). The in-game interface is pretty cool and has recently introducted additional info within the cockpit (you can also play in 3rd person view, but it highly affects your aiming for precision shots and people can see you are in 3PV because a drone flies above your Mech... you may get a bit flamed for it, as it can also be a visual cheat due to terrain design).Team-Play/Communications: As with any team-based game, you are highly recommended to find a unit and utilize voice comms, but you can play strictly in the solo queue to build your experience, level up your 'Mechs (skill trees take about 30-40 matches to complete for one Mech chassis), or experiment with different weapon loadouts and heat management. Voice comms are available in game, but not used by everyone. You can mute annoying players quite easily. Clans, House Units or Merc Units (aka guilds) are constantly looking for players and have their tag displayed in game next to their name. If you start to see players with a given tag and like your cohesion (and win rate!) with them, I advise you find out their voice comms info and play with them in a group. Just request to join them in chat or add them as a friend and use the in-game messaging feature.Heat?: Ah yes, heat management... this is a layer of complexity that requires you to really be aware of your heat production caused by weapon use and movement. Learning to squeeze out the most of your Mech takes a lot of time and understanding, but there are some great community resources out there. You eventually can do it by feel, but there are visual and audio cues to help. Overheating causes damage to your internals and you can even blow yourself up by riding in the red too long. In those last ditch attempts to squeeze off a final kill, you can choose to override your auto shutdown when past 100%, but do so wisely! Suiciding due to overheat can still reward the kill to a player shooting at you.Community: there are always toxic players or trolls, but you will find an overall very nurturing community. The game is no doubt a niche game, but has a very, very loyal following with some very big whales who love the BattleTech universe. There is no other multiplayer game on the market quite like this one and it induces a lot of passion within the MWO forums and MWO sub-reddits.eSports: There is a budding attempt to turn MWO into an eSport with a $100K prize pool world tournament starting in Q1 2016. Those in the competitive-minded community hope that enough new players with great skills enter MWO to spawn new teams or revive some old ones that have felt that the competitive scene is stale. Most competitive play is accomplished via community-run leagues (MRBC, RHoD, and a few 8/12/16 team invitationals). The publisher did host one official beta tournament, which brought out a lot of new names to the competitive scene and we hope that will be the case in the near future with the influx of new players from Steam.Pay Model: The game is F2P and used to be very limited in this regard, but has opened up widely since Community Warfare started. Initially you begin with 4 Mech Bays. You had to buy additional ones in the past, but now you can earn them through in-game rewards and special events. There are some Hero and Champion Mechs that are only purchasable with real money (MC), but they are not mandatory to buy. They do offer enhanced XP or C-Bill (in-game currency) bonuses, so it can be a good way to farm cash to buy additional 'Mechs. As with most F2P games, you will end up paying more for this game than a retail box model should you get into it... and there is nothing wrong with that at all! Mech Packs are pricey, but it is more of a pay to early access feature rather than a Pay 2 Play/Win model. There are only a few Hero Mechs that you may want to buy should you wish to get into competitive play. Wait for paid items to go on sale at 50% off to get the best value, which happens often.Matchmaking: There are 5 skill tiers and that is how the base matchmaker tries to pair up players. Sometimes you will be matched with players a tier higher or lower, but the idea is that both sides are matched as evenly as possible. There are also weight and chassis limits per side, so as to maintain some degree of balance of teams. The past saw some issues with queue times due to lower populations, which has been less of an issue since Steam release. However, the Community Warfare (CW) mode still suffers from a lack of popluation due to lack of real incentives to play that game mode vs time per match. We hope that an increased CW population will reduce the wait times and increases the potential of this game mode. More on CW below.End Game: Community Warfare is the persistent universe game mode and is not based on any matchmaking at all, but a specific weight tolerance of the 4 Mechs you can bring to each match. Yes, this is the only game mode where you have respawns, but you still need to use each Mech wisely, as matches are more prolonged with different phases to the fight. There is a defense and an offense mode to each map and new game modes are going to be introduced to increase playability of CW during off-peak times. Here is where you can unlock in-game rewards and also earn MC, the real money currency that can unlock more Mech Bays (character slots, per say), cosmetic items, or even Champion or Hero Mechs, if you grind it out.
