content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Please note that despite my listed hours played, I've actually been playing since the closed beta.Pros: *Huge* catalogue of 'mechs to choose fromGreat loadout customizationSome good looking mapsConstant stream of weekend events, and tournamentsVisceral and engaging 'mech combatVery active development teamFaction Play/Community WarfareAll competitive/meta grade 'Mechs are avaliable for free-player currency.Mech art design is really quite gorgeousNeutral:Sound design is functionalDevs *can* have a problem listening to the communityUnlocking 'Mechbays pretty much requires paying money, or playing every weekend eventHighish investment price, about on equal footing with World of TanksFrequent sales on cosmetics and paid 'mechs'Unique' XP unlock systemSteep learning curve, but an okay tutorialCons:Jarring disconnect between 'old' and 'new' map design philosophies and qualities.Some 'Mech textures can be downright uglyOnly five gamemodes and 18 mapsCumbersome frontend UISmall team can lead to slow fixes, and glacial development speed on some features.Nickel and dimingPoor optimization leads to a poor performance to fidelity ratioSome bizzare 'balancing' options come down the pipeline, sometimes.Conclusion:It's a great arena shooter, with decent customization depth, but not much to do beyond fighting. Graphics and sound are good. Updates come frequently. The real-money stuff is way too expensive, but anything worth half a damn goes F2P within a couple months anyway. Anything else becomes avaliable for MC, which you can earn for free. The devs can be rather ignorant to the realities of the game's meta, but it kind of, a little bit, maybe seems they're starting to listen to the community, but they could *really* work on that. It's probably worth a download, and some free-play, but keep your wallet closed unless you find you're enjoying yourself.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Its quite clunky, especially the graphics/physics, but overall i enjoy this game, and even decided that its worth spending money on it.The damage/weapon-system is interesting and the battletech universe in which MWO plays is rich in lore and there are over 100 novels since the 80s. The balancing was not good the last years since its release as far as i uncovered (there are 2 sides Clan and Inner Sphere which battle each other with different levels of technology), but there was a recent patch in December which seemed to turn everything to the better. I started late December so i cant tell the difference. :)The game is not overcrowded in CW and its not adviseable to join those as a random because you will get stomped 9 out of 10 matches by highly organised and trained units, but its easy to get into solo battles and pew pew away.If you want to do more team oriented stuff like CW or the soon to be introduced 4vs4, join a unit.There is a skill-matchmaking in place, which has 5 levels.You start with 5, and you can be matched with ppl that are 2 levels up or down.This just grants you to make the first steps in peace, after like 70 hours you come to level 3 and can be matched against the best.If you want to play in the long run, you need at least premium time if you want to get new mechs regularly,but unlike WoT you can buy any mech you want immediately and level it.Its not so easy to get to know the game, since the factions mechs have differences with Omnipod and Quirksystems and the weapons are very different, but if you just use google and read the MWO guide for beginners and the comics, you should be fine to start.If you like vehicle combat, just give it a try.

content:
Posted: January 3
												MWO is a very enjoyable game - but it is not a perfect game.  So, let's look at the pro's and con's shall we?  (Also, I played on the original launcher and have only recently moved over, so add roughly 150 hours [over the course of about two years] or so to my 'Time Played' count please)It is a F2P game with good graphics, a stable engine and solid game mechanics - though note that the "Faction Warfare" gamemode is still fraught with problems but is still an enjoyable if sometimes taxing on your sanity.It is NOT a BattleTech game - though if you don't know what BattleTech is then you might not care.  I care, but it is still a good game regardless of this VERY important misstep.  The game struggles very much with the technological disparity between IS and Clan machines and equipment - this 'struggle' comes from the artificial 'balance' between the two rather than using the already well-established BattleTech rules that this game is based upon.  VERY important misstep.The player base seems to consist mostly of people who are looking for fun and are willing to help as much as they can rather than to fall under the "Internet is for a**h***s" standard of user base.The game does rely on microtransactions, packages and other bits of the game that require real money to be used - HOWEVER - I personally have yet to notice any real "Pay to Win" - but the so-called Hero 'Mechs are certainly "Pay for Variety" and "Pay for BattleTech" - in the case of the Yen-Lo-Wang for example.  NONE of this a bad thing, however, as it is almost solely used to pay the company, expand the options for or allow access eariler to players who are willing to pay for that, but does not allow access to things that give the "wallet warrior" any appreciable edge during gameplay.The META is REAL! - Real BattleTech is better.  I play BattleTech in here, it makes it harder but also gives me satisfaction to use that and kill META users...hehehe.While the basics of the gameplay are easy enough to learn (keyboard and mouse), they are a bit more complex than a run-and-gun shooter.  More important than twitch shooting (see above for that) is your ability to read situations, plan ahead and keep awareness beyond often what you can currently see.  It WILL take time to learn the how/when/where of its combat, but it is well worth the struggles earlier on.The best and worst parts of a multiplayer game are the players - what else is new.  No, this is not a contradiction to what I said earlier.  Both are correct and it was worth mentioning twice.  This is a team-based game.  Leave your team or get left behind, and you're life expectancy will drop drastically.  And yes, you will have bad teams, bad luck and bad timing - no honest person will tell you life (or death) is fair.If you like the idea of using a giant walking tank to shoot up other people in giant walking tanks with guns, lasers, missiles, countermeasures, electronic warfare, positioning and maneuvers - and of course are willing to accept its faults (which you really should IMHO)...PLAY THIS GAME!

content:
Posted: February 21
												Pains me to re-write the reveiw of the game negatively. But after all the years of optimism I just haven't seen PGI making enough good decisions and thus I have lost faith in their ability to fix this game's issues. Nowadays I just see maps being made worse (though some have indeed improved) along with questionable "balancing" as well as a continued trend of power creep. While the power creep may not be intentional it still doesn't change the fact that it is there.  New mechs are still constantly released with many having various unbalanced (both under powered and over powered) traits often and they only get "properly" balanced when released for cbills (in game currency). However the game itself is still playable and still much better than most other free to play games out there. Skill will still beat out running op builds. And even then most builds can be countered with the correct application of tactics and other builds. I do still recommend trying the game out for yourself. Find a good team and you can still enjoy the game's community (so long as you find the right groups). With PGI now also developing Mechwarrior 5, I do wish the best of luck with that and the fresh start it brings. Hopefully you can learn from the mistakes in MWO and develop a wonderful game from the start.

number of helpful: 17 of 30 people (57%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												MWO is a free to play game based on the Mech Warrior series which is based on BattleTech. The mech combat is good, possibly some of the best in the series' history. I've played the TT and franchise for over 20 years and can safely say that at its core, MWO is true to the premise of piloting a big battlemech.There is an extremely steep learning curve for new players that is not helped by lack of good documentation explaining some of the more important mechanics. The community is really good at filling in the blanks though and most are more than willing to help new players get acclimated. The artwork is gorgeous and if you are able to play on higher settings the game really shines. Although a bit dated now, you can see that the artwork is top notch. It's a very fun game, especially being free and I would reccomend it to anyone looking for a new game. This isn't your typical shooter though, it tends to move at a much slower pace when it comes to combat and it is heavily team oriented. Those that try to take down the enemy team solo ala CoD will find nothing but frustrating losses. That's not to say it is without issues. The gameplay itself is repetitive and most modes equate to stomp forward and kill them all. There are additions in the pipeline to include new modes that should break up the monotony but if you're the type of gamer than enjoys a lot of diversity in modes such as CtF, KoH, etc. this may not be your cup of tea. The pathfinding is frustrating, especially when you're stomping along in a 100 ton assault mech and are brought to a complete stop due to a "rock" no higher than your mech's ankle. The mech customization is amazing with literally thousands of mech and weapon combinations. It's one of the few F2P games out there that does a very good job of walking that line without getting into P2W territory.    The developers are very responsive and interactive with their community via Twitter which is exceptionally rare in this industry. Overall I would give it 3 out of 5 stars (which could easily jump depending on what the company does with the recently released Phase 3 of Community Warfare). It's a free game and within a few hours of playing as a free player you can easily accumulate enough cbills (the free currency) to buy and outfit 2-3 mechs.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												A friend of mine recommended this game and before commiting to it I read a bunch of reviews on this site.  There were several "Do Not Recommend" reviews which complained of a grindy nature, lack of infantry/vehicle targets and a power imbalance due to skills unlockable through regular play which noobs have no access to.  So I was pretty skeptical but DLed anyway to give my friend the benefit of the doubt.Gee, I'm glad I got this game.  Despite there being a fair amount of truth to the negative reviews this game is great fun regardless.I would like to address those issues from negative reviews mentioned above:  The game is grindy?  Well, if you call playing a lot of games driving around in giant stompy robots shooting lasers in the faces of other giant stompy robots a grind, I guess it is.  The whole point of the game is to drive around in giant stompy robots and blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up.  Not to level up those skills.  First: Blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up, second: gets skills.  Blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up, it's so much FUN!  When you unload on someone with a bunch of lasers or short range missles and their arm falls off or you cripple their leg, or your first solo kill!  Revel in it.No other targets besides giant stompy robots shooting lasers and massive autocannons around the place?  Well, if I was infantry and there were giant stompy robots blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up all around me, I wouldn't want to be poking my head out.  And if I was driving a tank around said robots, I'd think it prudent to drive away as fast as posible.  There should be NO other targets both from fluff and gameplay perspectives (though there are infantry and vehicles in the original game and fluff, once the Mechs arrive, the little guys don't really matter anymore).IMO, anything other than Mechs as opponents would be a pointless distraction.  Any infantry or light vehicles would have to be AI as they would die in droves, no one would want to play them.  The players are there for the giant stompy robots afterall.  That these have been left out of the game serves to keep the gameplay focused on the PvP, robot vs robot theme of the game.There is an imbalance between newer and experienced players?  And this doesn't happen in any other game?  When you start out in any new game you'll likely to get your♥♥♥♥♥♥handed to you a few times.  The learning curve might be a bit steeper in this game as it doesn't play like a typical FPS, thank Google for variety!  Persevere, click on "Spectate" when you get killed, watch how other people are playing, learn and get better.  Games are over pretty short and there are no significant repercussions for dieing in a dozen games, except that you might get a bit better each time.Yes, there are skills that can be unlocked on Mechs which give them small bonuses.  I don't think these are especially unbalancing towards a new player in a trial Mech.  Though it might be if the game was one on one.  It's not, you have 11 other allies backing you up.  In fact, a much more significant factor in whether you survive a game is how well your team co-ordinates together.  And it's also likely that the other team will have as many noobs or vets as your team does.  It balances out.If there is anything i would gripe about it is the cost of purchasable packs.  Especially the Steam bundles.  I'm not sure how they have decided on their pricing for these packs but it would be great if they were about 50% cheaper.  But would they sell 50% more packs?  Saying that i've still bought two 3 Mech* bundles.  These are the lowest tier on the purchasable packs and are pretty good value at $20US.  Even better value if you preorder and get early adopter rewards.  There are also periodic sales on various things in the store.  So if you are patient you can make savings.(*  Three Mechs of the same chassis are required to fully unlock all tiers of skills available and these bundles come with a months premium time which gives extra XP to help you along.  Each chassis also has distinct quirks and weapon hardpoints so you don't have three identical Mechs.  You get decent variety)The game also rewards noobs quite generously with bonus in game currency for the first 25 matchs.  After this time you could get virtually any Mech you wanted that is available for cBills.  Buying bundles is not necessary.So, in summary:  Yes you grind, if you call game after game of robot battles a grind.  If you don't want to battle giant robots you came to the wrwong game.There are no other targets to shoot at or drive around.  If you want tanks there is a game for that.There are skills.  Your teammates will have a greater influence on the battle than the skills will.  See who plays well in your games and Friend them, then ask to group and learn from them.Bundles can be expensive but there is some good value in there too.Your biggest hurdle will be getting past the CoD playstyle and learning to play within the limitations of what sort of mech you are driving.  There is a lot more to this game than running around the map blasting people.Oh yeah, you wont respawn either.

												The core game had a lot of promise. A decades old franchise with tons of lore, background story, technology, etc. There has been a great stable of games based around Battletech. While this game has shown off some great mech designs and renders, it falls very short in play-ability, some of the worse Free to Play grind of any other steam game, and a learning curve so severe that the few new players that do try it, leave frustrated. It`s even worse when new players put real money into the game only to be matched by so few, much higher skilled players who have stuck around so long, me included. The game population is so low, wait times are long, and the skill disparity of the so called "matchmaking" system will leave new players disappointed. The underlying reasons for these issues start from a unwillingness to listen to the community, and severe censorship of any one who tries to criticize them, including streamers who won`t do what they tell them to do. A once great franchise is being ruined by a inexperienced deceitful game company.

number of helpful: 12 of 21 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												I've been playing MWO since closed beta, Summer 2012.  Four years is a loooong time to be playing any one game, but it's kept me and my crew together.  If you want heavy firepower wielding mechs, this is pretty much the best game in town.  Less twitchy than other FPS titles so better for older players.  The Good:Art and Design of the mechs.  By far this is the best that battlemechs have ever looked in a video game.  Just go look at MW4 and cringe.  While a few of the redesigns were a bit of a miss (looking at you WarHammer), the major are unbelievably good (Atlas, Catapult, Cataphract, Summoner) etc.  Even o es that never looked that good to being with (Jager mech, Stalker).  Gameplay is solid.  The arm+torso movement for aiming is simple brilliant and this is the best mechs have ever handled.  Assaults (except Kodiak...) feel heavy and methodical.  While something as small as the Locust feels insanely fast and nimble.  Mech customization is damn near infinite.  Not very chassis can do what you want, but there's a mech or variant somewhere that CAN.  Build variety and the near endless way to build a mech is solid.  Negatives:Harsh to new players.  Much like Eve, opening this game up the first time is less of a learning curve and more of a vertical WALL.  There is finally a new player tutorial for driving a mech, but still absolutely nothing for the mechlab.  That said, the community is very helpful, and there are many community run Team speak servers avail with people glad and willing to show players the ropes.  Tiny community.  MechWarrior just isn't that big anymore.  While huge during the 90s, it's very much a niche product today.  After 11 or so Pacific, you'll start seeing familiar faces every drop or two.  Just not a big enough pool to build matches.  Big fish in little ponds.  This game has a "Pilot Skill Rating.". (PSR) Basically it's an XP bar that fills to move you up in tiers.  Play really poor early on and you'll probably start at Tier 5, and over time you'll move up.  Big issue is it is HEAVILY biased to move players up, so you'll hit tier 3 pretty quick.  After that you're just food for the Tier 1 elite crowd.  They tend to be the players that support the game the most financially buying the pre-order mech packs, so to keep them entertained the game is geared to throw easy targets at them.  Unless you run with a crew that WANT to be the best and focus fire and build to the meta, you're going to be rolled a lot at higher tiers.  My crew is a very casual group that play because we love big stompy robots and want to play something that supports 2 to 12 of us at a time.  But because the PSR is biased so heavily, most of us are tier 1 or 2, but we're NOT that caliber of players.  We've just played enough it shoves us against MS, 228, KCOM, etc.  So we get rolled. Small community though so MM is designed to put as many people into the same port as quickly as possible.  Limited game modes.  You've got Assault (kill everything or capture their base), Conquest (kill everything and capture enough bases), and Skirmish (kill everything).  There's none of the real objective based gameplay that MechWarrior is known for.  There was an attempt with community warfare for two years, but it's largely died off because of poor design and developer miss steps.  Glacial development.  The last real issue is development is at a snail's pace.  The core gameplay really hasn't changed since Alpha.  They do have mech creation down to a science, but actual Ballance changes or adjustments are once yearly, at best, with huge imbalances receiving no attention for months at a time.  Overall what you see is what you get with MechWarrior Online.  I don't see it changing much in the next two years, but for solid Team Death Match with Robots, it's pretty much unbeatable.  Just don't go in expecting the Battletech or MechWarrior heritage for objective based gameplay or more.  It's not here

number of helpful: 13 of 23 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												Closed Beta player, so I have been there from the beginning in 2012. The game has substantially evolved since that time period, from 5 'Mechs and a single map with 8 vs 8 and one game mode (Assault), to 3 Quick Play modes, 2 Faction Play modes, 12 Quick Play maps, 7 Faction Play maps, over 60 'Mech chassis (totalling 300 variants), 12 v 12, and a host of other improvements.But this review isn't about a chronological list of stuff that happened, you wanna know how the game plays, right?The new Player Experience is still a little rough. Once you've gone through the MechWarrior Academy (a welcome recent addition), there's no real tutorials on proper teamplay with other players, as well as any information on customizing your own BattleMech. However, the pace that PGI has been going at of late, this stuff may all come soon.Once you've actually learned basic and advanced tactics, it is a proper BattleMech simulator; your 'Mech has a limited pivoting torso, you have loads of weapons on your 'Mech that can make you overheat if you're not careful, and of course, speed is still life. Assault 'Mechs, the biggest of them all, do indeed struggle with much smaller 'Mechs (such as almost all Light 'Mechs, and the Cicada and Ice Ferret), because of the much slower pace of the lumbering giant compared to the relative agility of the gnats surrounding it. This sort of inherent balance, coupled with different scouting mechanics that feel closer to World of Tanks than previous MechWarrior games (a good thing) already makes this feel more balanced and visceral than those earlier MechWarrior games.Maps can and do restrict tactics in places, and many  of these maps can also change up the gameplay or make it stale. They're not quite as pretty or realistic as some of today's AAA titles, but I think they're very much sufficient for what they're trying to do, especially for trying to realize BattleTech's universe.All this and I forgot about the pricing model. 'Mechs are EXPENSIVE when paid for with real money. If you want to build a collection, you will have to fork over a little money for MechWarrior Credits [MC] and buy some bays, and if you're not patient enough to accrue C-Bills (keep in mind that your first 25 matches, you get a major bonus to get you your first couple 'Mechs sooner), you can buy 'Mechs with MC, too. Fortunately, PGI runs sales and events rather regularly, so you may be gifted with some scraps of MC or some free 'Mech Bays, and rarely, even a new 'Mech! Keep an eye on their website for more information!Give Piranha Games some patience, the greatest has yet to come. They are overhauling Faction Play a bit, and someone's pet project is proper Single Player/Cooperative. TD;DR: This isn't your father's MechWarrior. It comes with its ups and downs but it is very much worth a play. Just be mindful of your wallet, 'Mechs are not cheap.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												If you're a long-time MechWarrior or Battletech fan like me, you're going to be disappointed. This isn't the game we were waiting for. It doesn't respect the source material, in ways that are especially frustrating because there seem to be some fairly straightforward solutions. Also, through various dumb decisions better explained elsewhere, it's pretty clear that the developers simply don't care about the hard core fans of the series.However!The game itself, taken in isolation, as it is right now, is very good. It's fun to play. So, in all fairness, it gets a thumbs-up. When it's good, it's VERY good. Teamwork is not just rewarded but demanded - if you try to go off and solo you'll get swiftly destroyed and put your team one player down. It can be frustrating when you get a team that scatter like headless chooks, so you'll need to cultivate a bit of a zen attitude, but the good moments are worth it.There's a very satisfying cycle of customising your mechs, trying them out in battle, tweaking them, salivating over the next big engine upgrade or new chassis, taking that out in battle, eyeing the next big upgrade, and so on.I wouldn't spend any money on it, though.NB: I've played for a fair bit before this was on Steam. Apparently I have 97 hours of in-cockpit time all together.-------------------------------------------e: quick PSA here: you need to stick together. You NEEEEEEED to stick together. You also need to use terrain to your advantage. Going off by yourself to try to flank the enemy WILL get you killed. Pushing through a narrow pass WILL get you killed.See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defeat_in_detail . You'll be more successful with your whole team fighting together, targeting one enemy at a time, occupying ground that allows your team to focus fire, than you will by trying to 1v1 everyone. Even in the very heaviest mechs, you cannot reasonably expect to win against more than one opponent at a time, and if you win a 1v1 you'll take far more damage doing it than if you and your buddies were focusing on one target instead.Even if you don't agree with where most of your teammates are headed, sticking with them will win more often than going off and doing your own thing instead. Trust me. For the sake of your future teammates' sanity, please stick together.

												If you've ever played a mechwarrior game, the combat mechanics will be pretty familiar to you. All players are offered a variety of trial mechs which change frequently. The trial mechs are very competitive and often 'hero' variants are available as well. If you wish to modify your mech you'll have to buy one with c-bills or real money, which is easily done after playing your first handful of matches. Premium content includes mech patterns (skins), colors, war horns, dashboard bling and experience/c-bill boosts. The built in VOIP is excellent and allows for even random quick match groups to be extremely well organized. Graphics are excellent, audio is excellent, no input lag to speak of.The user interface can be a little overwhelming at first, but after some experience you'll find that the flexibility that comes with having a ton of options can be extremely rewarding.10/10

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												DISCLAIMER : THIS GAME HAS A MASSIVE LEARNING CURVE, BE PREPARED TO FEEL THE SUCK FOR A FEW HOURS OF PLAY UNTIL YOU GET THE HANG OF IT.I HAVE BEEN PLAYING SINCE CLOSED BETA AND AM STILL PRETTY TRASH.Having put hundreds of hours into this game before its steam release, and with a large number of mechs in my stable without spending a single dime despite having a premium mech and cosmetic items earned entirely from in-game Events (Which happen quite often actually, or did before steam release, we'll see!) I have to say that I enjoy this game far too much, The thing is, even if you buy things you are getting NO ADVANTAGE. This game's ONLY deciding factors are player skill, luck (Just like anything else luck is a factor) and utilizing the built in communications to coordinate with your team.TIPS FOR NEW PLAYERS :1. Turn off the ♥♥♥♥ing 3rd person, there's alittle camera drone behind and above your mech with a flashing red light EVERYONE CAN SEE when you're in 3rd Person, and its actually detrimental to your ability to aim.2. Controller support is wonky, and you DO NOT want to use a controller anyway, M&K is going to serve you much better, tracking targets smoothly and quickly is ESSENTIAL in this game.3.Never go out alone, you will die faster than you can say "What's going on?!"4. Save every C-Bill you earn until you can afford an IS assault or Clan Heavy, then save a few million more to outfit it as best as you can.5. USE OUT OF GAME UTILITIES LIKE SMURFY'S MECHLAB AND METAMECHS. YOU WILL NOT BE DISAPPOINTED.6. The community has developed a Utility called "Fire Control" it has a weapon toggle feature for things like machineguns and TAG Laser designators, It is not against the game's rules and has other features as well like fire sequencing multiple fire groups instead of MWO's chainfiring mechanic, I only use it for very specific builds that are heavy on constant fire weapons like MGs/Missile boats with a TAG, but it can be used for other things as well.7/10 This game has its problems, and will continue to have problems, but It's had a great year this past year and with it's deadweight publisher IGP gone since like two years ago IIRC PGI has been making massive strides to regain community trust and has produced an enjoyable if frustrating stompy mech shooty game. Its not battletech, but then again mechwarrior has never been battletech, its just set in the same universe!Server Disconnections are semi-common for me its kind of annoying but has been getting better lately.SCREENSHOT! : http://images.akamai.steamusercontent.com/ugc/395552769137893977/105682C1B28BA38BAE6FBF0F31C7C8960EEA272C/

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												I'm a long time battletech fan that grew up with Mechwarrior 2. I absolutely love the franchise and played Mechwarrior Online before it was ever released on steam. Played closed beta since 2012, and revisited the game after a long hiatus to see how the clan mechs were in game. Revisited the game again and logged in over 400+ combined hours with my profile. Scroll down to TL:DR if you don't want to read this long review.If you are a new player in this game, beward of the skill tree that these devs plan to torture you in the future with. There is a SEVERE lack of commuication between the devs and the player base. While the game has a forum for suggestions, it is often overlooked in favoritism by the devs for Twitter. Yes that's right, Twitter. If you spot something that needs to be fixed in the game or a suggestion I hope you can get your point across in less than 121 words.With this being said, they are planning to drop in something called the Civil War tech era which will introduce new mechs and new technology to try and breathe new life into the game. Sounds good right? Well, PGI has some kind of short sighted vision to make MW:O into an e-sport so "balance" takes "top priority" (as CEO Russ Bullock tends to repeat) as something akin to CS:GO. May I add that this is the only game in the mechwarrior franchise that has GAUSS RIFLE CHARGE UP TIMES. So wan't a sniper weapon platform for your mech? I hope you like holding down your firing button precisely at the right time or else it won't go off. Not to add on top of that how unlore friendly this entire concept is.Another thing that proves how disconnected PGI is to their own game is when they start nerfing things with no logical reasoning behind them. Certain mechs got hit in the past with nerfs THAT WERE UNDERPEFORMING TO BEGIN WITH. I can speak for myself since the Executioner I have in game feels like a card board cut out than it does a war machine. And while the playerbase rose their voice about it, nothing ever came of it.This doesn't even cover a fraction of the problems that this game has.PGI's dependency of income now is the occasional steam player that might buy a mech pack for $20, and the nostalgic whales that still lurk in the community that are living in denial for a better Mechwarrior title. They already lost most of their founders that backed the kickstarter project for the game. PGI also has unfortunately a monopoly over the battletech franchise title. Their holding over the license won't expire until 2018 to 2020. Rumor has it that they might have been responsible for disbanding titles like Assault Tech 1: Battletech and Mechwarrior Living Legends. Now they are working on MW5:Mercs which will be an single player focused game. Why don't you fix what you have now for more customer confidence if you want people to buy your new game?TL:DR A game that had a lot of potential during that went to the wayside over the years.I'll change this review to a positive one if there are any permanent positive changes. As of right now, I honestly can't recommend this game to anyone. If you wan't your mech simulation fix, I strongly suggest revisiting the older titles or checking out MW:LL for online multiplayer.

content:
Posted: April 22
												Piranha Games has done an amazing job with the BattleTech/Mechwarrior franchise here. MWO plays a lot like a "tank" simulator requiring every pilot to consider range, heat management, hit loctaion, ammunition depletion, weapon payload, and many other details when preparing their mech "build" or dropping in to combat. The gameplay reminds me of a mix between Ghost Recon 2, World of Tanks, and Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising. I feel like for the casual tactical simulator player, MWO can be pretty punishing. I also think this is one of MWO's many strengths. To be a successful pilot the player will need to be co-opertive (most lone wolves aren't gonna make it), understand good mech build practices, and watch the changing meta-game so as to inform them on those mech builds.MWO is amazingly a Free-to-Play game. Yes there are many things a player can spend their money on, camos, warhorns, special mech types, BUT unlike WoT, Hawken and other F2P (pay-to-win) models, buying a specialty mech rarely affects actual performance on the battlefield. The MWO devs have done a spectacular job balancing this game. The specialty mechs do appear on the battlefield, and they perform generally well, but rarely will they outperform a variant chassis with a good build. MWO is one of those game it is easy to jump into walk around in your mech and shoot at other mechs.... that's easy. Performing at a high level requires practice and good judgement on the player's part. This is a great game and although I'm not great at it, I am getting better.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												I keep reading this is a game that has a steep learning curve...Briefly, you are inside a building tall robot, with 1 to 5 sets of weapons, you fire them at the group of 3 - 5 enemy mechs that seem to want to kill YOU first than the rest of your team...There are several ways to play it, but there are no classes, its your speed, choice of weapons and your team behaviour that determines what you'll be that game.Customizing your mech will take your time but not at first, take one of the trial mechs, I recommend a "Heavy" for decent armor and firepower.Despite the flaws, there are some things that make this a different game. No other "fps" moves like this, torso and legs are independent, the speeds, the vision angle limits, the arms range, everything matters. The weapons feel good and you can for example have an arm destroyed, or a leg and still carry on fighting as long as the Center Torso is intact and you can walk.As a game engine (graphics/gameplay) its awesome, how it plays and also the visuals. It is demanding and seems to be getting more, you might need a powerfull PC to run medium/high.Finally, MWO has a very decent player base so you'll get in a game fast by clicking quickplay and can try against other starting Tier 5 players. In the end spending money might give you a little advantage but you still need to know how to make it count. It's mostly for cosmetics.--

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												MWO is unique in the world of modern games, the F2P model is solid (though I find the prices a little high, you are not forced to buy anything to be competitive).  It's definitely more of a sim than a shooter, heat management and trigger discipline net you more kills than charging in with guns blazing.  A couple things you should know before you drop in:1. Stay with the team - A solo 'Mech gets scrapped in short order, always.2. Press 'R' befpre you start shooting at something - Your target lock is shared with all other players on the team, by letting us know what you're shooting, you might get some assistance befor you get scrapped.3. Trigger Discipline (this is NOT CoD with robots) - As you fire weapons, your 'Mech begins to heat up, keeping an eye on your heat gauge and knowing how much heat your weapons generate per shot is vital to your success.  If you overheat, your 'Mech shuts down until heat levels are within spec again, leaving you an immobile target in the middle of a battlefield.4. Jump into VoIP!  - MWO is a game that heavily emphasises teamwork, grab a headset and coordinate.  Even if you don't have a strategy, you can call out targets that are too far away to target lock, and you can call for help if you get ambushed.  The difference between winners and losers is coordination.5. Read up! - MWO has some great guides available to help the new MechWarrior in understanding his place on the battlefield, read some of them (Google is your friend) to get a leg up on the competition.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 19
												I have not played that many hours via steam, but have played extensively through the direct play client, so don't let my lack of hours play time on steam fool you.Mechwarrior Online, at an initial glance, seems to be a continuation of the Battletech franchise. After all, that's what it bills itself as. However, when you take a close look at the game, what it really boils down to is a giant robot combat sim that borrows some names from the B-Tech universe and some very basic mech designs. Using the Inner Sphere vs. Clan theme, there are supposed to be two technology types. In all previous renditions of the game (including table top), Clan was always superior tech wise. However, thanks to the very venomous and rabid community, PGI has decided to nerf Clan back into the stone age and buff IS way beyond what it should be. Clan is now ultra fragile technology while IS has become the tankiest of the bunch. PGI has tried to reason this away in an attempt to appease the crybabies of the community instead of making other changes that could have addressed this in better ways.To top it off, most of the player base is very toxic. The most vocal of these are those who prefer to meta a game to death and look down their noses at anyone who doesn't play according to their ideas of how it should be done. If you post something on the forums that these self appointed "elites" disagree with, they'll let you have both sawed off barrels. In game, if you make a mistake, take a loadout they don't like or anythine else, you'll get verbal abuse like you can't imagine. The moderators are not much of a help either.As someone who has been playing  Battletech since the late '80's, I'm very distraught over the direction MWO has gone. If you're a die hard fan of the universe, a lover of the lore and everything that made Battletech great, stay away from this game - especially if your allegiance is to any of the Clans. If you are a lover of generic giant robot combat sims, someone who doesn't give a care about the B-Tech universe, is someone who only wants to meta a game to death, and is someone who has a very toxic personality, then this game is for you. I'm done with this b a sta rdization of a once great gaming system. I'm so disgusted with PGI now that I won't even purchse their Mechwarrior 5 release due out in 2018. They haven't done anything to earn another cent from me.------------------I just posted the following on my unit's message board. This is how bad it's gotten for me...Over the past week, I've found that I haven't really been playing too much. I haven't been able to nail down why until today's patch and my reflections upon it.I haven't been having fun any more. It began with the nerfing of my favorite mech, the Kodiak. Then PGI decided to nerf the hell out of Clan tech. In addition to that, they mismatched the weight in faction play between the two sides. The Stormcrow (whom right before the nerf I spent $20 to get the Jade Falcon camo) was no longer able to be used for scouting. So, the Kodiak package and the storm crow camo were both things I spent money on which became basically useless. That was wasted money down the drain.Then PGI went on to nerf Clan missiles and autocannons. SRMs generate a ton more heat, ballistics do too as well as an increased chance of jamming on the ultras. That ruined a lot of favorite configurations that I had. Having a mech with a single UAC was basically useless. When I tried to address this on the forums, I got nothing back but venom from the forum regulars. This opened my ears to the truly venomous player community and what happens during drops - how the other players' attitudes are.I used to love faction play, but now I hate it every time I play it.Then PGI continued to ignore Battletech lore, starting earlier in 2016 with setting up the Mercenary loyalty (Clans hiring mercs? What?).Now PGI has struck again with more nerfs to Clan while continuing to buff the Inner Sphere.I just don't have it in me any more to play this game. It's no longer fun. I've wasted money on mechs and patterns. I still have 30 days of premium time waiting to be activated due to all the money I've spent and time banked up. But I don't even have the desire to use that any more. If this was a game where I paid a one time fee of $40, then... I dunno. But I've spent a heck of a lot more than that in this "Free to play" game. It's just not worth my time or money any more because I no longer have any fun.This is why I haven't been playing much, and this is why I won't be playing for a while, if ever again.You guys are my friends and I've really enjoyed getting to know you. I'm very sorry.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												A totally solid Mechwarrior game.  While it does have issues such as a limited number of maps and game modes, it is clear that the developers want to expand the game greatly in terms of content and game experience.  There is already robust support for multiple playstyles.The need to balance player experience with sellable content is obvious in a F2P game, and I feel the developers are making a fair and earnest effort to provide a great game for those on a budget while offering the big spender ways to part with their money without completely breaking the balance of the game.All in all, the game art is beautiful and the game tries to adhere to Battletech lore insofar as is possible, so fans of "armored combat" style shooters and Battletech fans alike should all be able to find something that keeps them coming back.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												I have to recomend this game (sigh)I have been playing it for about 3 years now. If I didnt recomend this game, I would feel bad for the last 3 years :PPro'sThe mech's look amazing, and allot of the graphics are pritty goodPGI has really stepped up their game in map design, and allot of the new maps have depth.The difference in playstyles of each mec can be vastly different, be it light, med, heavy, or assault. Not all mechs are viable but allot of them are, so there isnt one or two mech's that are the best.If you get onto a decent team, you will have alot of fun, dosnt matter if you want to do compeditive or just tool around in community warfare.If you played WoT(World of Tanks) you will have a one up in this game being that they are very close in play style and form.Cons:The hitreg varies between the different weapons and is infuriating. Some times your damage numbers reflect exactly the work you put in, then other times it dosnt and then some time you get no hitreg and you dont even effect you target by shooting him/her...it. It is theorized that if you can have a ping of 120 consitantly you are in the sweet spot and your hitreg will be perfect, and that if you have a stable ping that dosnt vary allot, it will be even better.The balancing of the game by PGI is real, they over balence them to try and make every weapon viable and nerf mechs just to make them less usefull, instead of realizing that they are only balancing the game into frustration. The new player experience is very difficult. Most of us have been playing for several years, as such we have become really good at the game, figured out what mechs we are good at and are up on the current meta. new players arnt, and often get frustrated because the biggest and baddest mechs arnt nessessarly the best. once they figure that out, most of them have already sunk allot of cbills into bad mechs. Also the learning curve can be brutal and unforgiving, between knowing where to go on the map, to just maneuvering around in your mech. Sticky walls that break your legs, and small rocks that keep your 100 ton mec from moving are just some of the frustrating things that can run you away from this game. It dosnt happen as often as it used to, but it still happens.Finnaly the community, this community is the most loyal, and at the same time can be the most hateful. There have been and are allot to trolls, at the same time, a game can be won and lost by one person doing somthing really stupid. This is a team game, not a single player game, and is much more unforgiving than all other shooters. Your teamates rely on you not doing stupid things and staying with the team.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Played this game quite a bit since 2013. I really do like it. It is not a perfect game, but it is pretty good fun. While it may seem kind of expensive for some 'mechs, the truth is you can use the free 'mechs you get and still do very well. The only real thing you would want to buy is more slots for 'mechs. The devs make consistent updates to the game every 2 weeks on Tuesday, usually consisting of balance tweaks and bugfixes. We are supposed to be getting a fairly large addition of content in the form of a "Phase III" for the Community Warfare aspect of the game in the near future. There are new 'mechs added regularly, and they have been doing a pretty good job recently of making them moderately balanced against each other.As far as the grind goes, it recently got much better. The in-game currency earn rate was increased by a pretty significant amount, which means less time spent to buy a new 'mech. There are also very regular events during the weekend where you can get a good chunk of premium and in-game currency, and somtimes even new 'mechs or mechbays. This game looks pretty good graphically, though if you look too close some of the textures are a bit low res. It is running in Cryengine, so the optimization is iffy at times. You may need a pretty good machine to run with all the bells and whistles, and even then probably won't want to run things like particles too high, as that can cause FPS dips. The 'mechs are mostly well modeled, and look good. There is the occasional low res texture on a 'mech, however.PROS:-Can do good as a pure F2P player-Grind is not so bad anymore-Core Gameplay is pretty solid-Constant in-game eventsNEUTRAL-Need to spend money on mechbays in order to build up a large stable of custom 'mechs-Pretty steep learning curveCONS-Runs a little bad on older machines-Not too much mode variety currently-Textures bad in some spots

												8.5/10                         ...Would turn 12 enemy Mechs to burning heaps of scrap again. I have included two video's of me playing in one of the heaviest and one of the lightest Mechs in the game. Nothing gets the adrenaline pumping like perma-death Arena Combat!


YouTube™ Video: MWO Heavy Hitters - Dire Wolf Killing Machine 

			Views: 3,269		

			Dont forget to turn up the resolution Forget Dakka. Dakka sucks. Its all about the pretty lasers now....		

Pro's- Great Gameplay - Extremely satisfying combat- Easy to pick up controls and get strait into the fighing but extremely hard to Master a Mech and become an Ace pilot (Pick a Mech and carve out your own Piloting Style)- Fantastic sense of developing your armoury and customizing Mechs to suit your Play style- Great replayability and sense of earning/time invested for tangible rewards- Regular Community wide tournaments and events which reward all players with real money purchasable items from the store (cosmetic colours and commos/Mech Bays/War horns/Cockpit Items/Free Mechs etc.|)  - Can play this game Free2Play, there is no Pay2Win except temporary pay walls when new Mechs are released- Teamspeak address known as Comstar to find players to play with or clans to join mwo.syn-games.com or na1.mech-connect.net- Doesnt need a high-spec machine to run. Those two videos were filmed on low settings on a low-med spec computer.- Cadet bonus and tutorial give new players a good chunk of the in game currency allowing them to kit out any Mech of their choice to start earning some C-Bills 


YouTube™ Video: MWO Light Assassins - Last man standing 

			Views: 2,351		

			does nobody else put XL engines in their stalker? am I alone here?		

Con's- Dev's who often apear to have no understanding or experience playing the game- Some really bad maps - Forest Colony, River City and Caustic Valley (ironically these maps used to be fine but the dev's tried to improve them)- Quite a grind before you have any decent variety of Mech's- Conquest and Assault both are lacking as game modes leaving skirmish as by far the more popular- One of the most toxic gaming communities around although i personally enjoy this as it means you get raged at regularly by the feeble opposition you just slaughtered single handedly. However most of the abuse will come from critical members of your own team. This similarly is a source of entertainment for me. If you are dead and i am alive your criticism means nothing! - Did i mention how bad the Devs can be? If you want a game that you can play regularly on your own or with friends that includes big stompy robots blasting bits off each other then look no further. Combat that stays satisfying after the 1000th time you have walked over the vanquished corpses of your enemies and shot a 100 ton Mech that towers over you in the♥♥♥♥♥with all your weapons and watched him topple like a giant tree to come crashing down at your feet.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Let's start simple. Try the game for yourself. I can only tell you that my experience with this game since 2012 has been good. That is my experience alone but you can make up your mind by trying it yourself.Play the 25 matches for the in game currency to see if you truly like the game or not._______Let's break this down into several components. Gameplay, UI, Graphics, Content, End Game.Gameplay 8/10:This game down to its core is a very fun game when you play it and learn it. Its an action shooter but it doesn't have the cartoon speed of some other FPS where you die after stubbing your toe on a bullet. No you can take a hit and if you are smart can survive for as long as you can. There's a sense of tactics in there somewhere. It's knowing when to attack, when to retreat, when to work with your team. You don't just run and gun and respawn.That is just half the game to launch into a match though. The second half is to make and create your own mech builds. To be able to tinker and change a chassis to how you want to play and not some stock loadout. To own and change every mech that you can get. To collect and master all the mechs you want provided you get the mechbays you need.It isn't perfect, balance could be better in regards to lesser used weapons. There could be more balance between the two major 'Factions' the Clans and the Inner Sphere.Overall it feels like a fun game to play,UI 7/10:The first incarnation was terrible, the second incarnation horrific, and now we have this current '2.5' UI that has honestly been a success. There's a lot of clicking but in comparison to other games like say Armoured Warfare it isn't actually as bad as it use to be. A lot of information that needs to be presented to you is but there is room for improvement which will come.What the game needs? UI Tooltips when you work in the Mechlab. UI for Mech Modules (Extra addons for mechs), and just quality of life improvements.Overall the UI is not special but its not terrible.Graphics 8/10:Mechwarrior: Online is showing its age. It runs on a outdated engine that has high demands for less gains. We've seen the power and scale of CryEngine 3 as a FPS but it demands much more when you see 12 vs 12 Giant mechs that take up a lot more power to render. The graphics are however still quite amazing. The visuals of seeing your lasers, cannons, and missiles fire is amazing. You won't be disappointed by all the effects.However you would want optimizations out of this game. It definitely needs to be optimized across the board.Overall its a great visual overall but it isn't the type of visuals you would expect from some triple AAA title which you shouldn't anyways.Content 8/10:In my opinion the story is not rich but the lore behind it is. It leads into having a lot of room for content in the future. It already has hundreds of mechs to choose from which is the meat of the content. There's so much room for variety that it provides so much content already. Could it have more than just mechs? Yes.I want to see more than just PvP Matches. It lacks in content that isn't just PvP.Overall its still good but that leads into the last component.End Game 5/10:The end game is unfinished. Plain and Simple it is not done. It is an interesting Idea of a moving world but it just seems like a map and place to fight right now.The future looks bright for it with new modes of play, the ability to use guild/faction/unit money to buy things with but its not there yet._________Overall this game is 7.5/10 until more patches come out. I have some faith but it needs to be proven at this point.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2016
												This game is the worst piece of trash game i've ever had the missfortune playing and actually be intrested in.If you are new and want to check if it is worth playing, no it is not. The game doesn't teach you anything and actively spites you for giving it a try. Let's get this straight:the client - let me quickly mention that it crashes all the time and then get to the REALLY BAD things about it. Like it having to load all the ****ing time. Did you crash to desktop or just got dc'ed again ? Thank god PGI frontloads their advertisement and newsfeed. Once this is loaded your mechs need to laod in, all while you impatiently just want to get back into the game. finaly everything is loaded. Let's just click "rejoin" and suddenly the pgi manager comes screaming into your room saying that that would be WAY TO CONVENIENT, better remove that and make it unneccessary complicated.Finished a match and won something, enjoy your loading times!Lost a match and just want to play with another mech, loading times!And no i'm not complaining about that there ARE loading times, i am complaining of how long they are and how they are staged. You know how in World of Tanks it takes less than 30 seconds to exit a match and get into another one, yeah that's a good standart to measure against.the UI - utter trash and most of all, useless in conveying information, want to skill up one of your mechs? well have fun clicking yourself through one of the most annoying and convoluded interfaces designed to this date. want just to "quickly" upgrade a weapon have fun finding it!I think the ui is best described with this, there are three buttons that all have the same function! GENIOUSThe gameplay - well it's 12 vs 12 battlearena gameplay what possible is there to mess that up ? - was the question PGI set out to answer when they decided to develope this tragedy.Hint: they f***ing nailed answering that question.So let's see how they accomplished this from the ground up:You know how in good games multiplayer maps allow for a certain kind of flow?Where there seems to be the right amount of cover so you just barely can make it.Open fields that are just long enough that you dare sprinting across themBottlenecks to funnel your enemies into and always corners to retreat to?Yes?Good, because this game has none of those elements, map design apparently was amateur hour.Long streches of nothing and more nothing then suddenly cliffs that all funnel everyone to that one ramp from where you emerge into a city, djungel or what ever random scenario they came up with next.But hey those are just the maps your first players and new users get in contact with, i mean it could be worse, they could play one of the braindead factionplay maps. Implying that new users even are able to play in this mode in the first place. Since you couldn't just let me pick a house i want to fight for better make this too overly complicated by needing to sign contracts, create units and clans. No the faction play maps are the worst from floating objects and assetts, over invisble walls and horrible hitboxes that block your shots in mid air or making a casual walk out of bounds while heading straight torwards the objective, because reasons. Yeah, slopeing the out of bounds inwards makes total sense. no really. And let's not forget the respawn points for both teams, undefended & unproteced open to everyone but hey if they design it like this you can surely pick different drop zones, have many ways to run to cover, right?So how is the weapon/ mech balance?Well let's put it like this, if you are cool with selling all your favorite mechs in favor of the NEW & SHINEY and SOOO MUCH COOLER mech PGI promotoes this month then yes you can play always with a well balanced and most devinetly not overpowered mech. But, let's cut some slack, if LoL can get away with this kind of design while raking in millions, PGI has just as much right, no not right! A CALLING, to do so too.I hope you also like either reading patchlogs and crunshing numbers or you might as well guess which weapons currently are best. Why not play a few matches with different systems to find out? well it seems that blasting for minutes at that assault isn't working out. You barely made a dent in his backarmor when you suddenly exploded into a violent burst of nuclear fire. because now you can read that,.... well that you died of engine failure and isn't that what is really necessary to know?And last let's talk about who you are playing with.I have NEVER met a bunch of more desperate, friendly and borderline psychotic people in my life. Let me explain this:These people are so desperate for a good mech based battle game that they are openly welcoming everyone who is willing to play with them they know that this game lives on each player because the fewer players there are the lower the chances for PGI to still turn a profit.But if you DARE to speak out, point out obvious design flaws they flip their crazy button, "the game couldn't possible be bad! you just suck at playing!" "no everything is perfect they just played better in team like when that one guy came torwards the three of us facetanking everything and then just blow us up, you just don't realise that yet."These players, players in general deserve better. But noone is demanding it because they are either not into gamedesign or just want to be happy to have at least some mech game.If you play in faction warfare the whole thing reverts, you find clans and groups that will actively stall games to maximise their rewards, you will encounter people camping your respawn or just walzing in there and farming your mechs while you can do nothing.Well i am not happy anymore, the straw that broke the camels back was today when the entirety of clan -MS- decided to walk into the dropzone of the map and start respawnkilling and on my remark that this is bullsh*t, someone replied "we deserve to be respawnkilled here." Well i don't think so, and any course on basic game design would support that.It's not even that they were respawn killing without repercussions except some slight dropship turret dmg, it's that PGI and the way rewards are given in this game actively encourages this behaviour. It's a disgusting thing to encourage in people and brings out only the worst. And most of all it would be easy to fix.UT 2003 had short invincibity for respawned player and a canon at the spawn points that would one shot anyone walking into the entrance.Rtcw: ET had a freaking mortar that could be aimed at the enemy respawn point and again, short invincibility for respawning players, choice of different spawn locations and several exit points for each of these spawns.But hey you could fix it much easier reward extra points for remaining time that outweight the points killing give - ♥♥♥♥ like this you could also give the defenders points for enemy time wasted making that despereate light mech push that much more rewarding.Or how about negative feedback, punish killing in the respawn zone or just make it simply - pointless, Or some positive reinforcment, award more points for killing pilots that have done more damage and 0 if they just respawned.The possible solutions are endless, some of the implementations really simpel, but PGI does none of them and this community still defends this behaviour. And this is just one of the countless problems this game has.I don't care anymore, i won't waste any more time of what little i have left, with a game that does so much wrong and yet gets defended by a community that has developed severe stockholm syndrome.Can't recommend this game, not at all.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Mechwarrior Online is a worthy followup to its legendary predecessors, and the best large robot tactical action game on the market. It hits the rarely achieved sweet spot between first-person twitch gameplay and methodical strategy, combining extremely deep customization of beautifully brutal war machines with intense moment-to-moment combat. The pace of battle is somewhat less than the warp speed found in most first person shooters, allowing the player's tactical awareness and strategic creativity to come to the fore, in contrast to other games where raw reaction speed is king. This more thoughtful pacing is consistent with the game's stylistic choices as well, which hew to a more traditionally "western" aesthetic of plausible tank-like distopian death machines stomping across war torn cityscapes and dangerous alien worlds, in contrast to the glut of "Japanese" style lithe robots that dance across most videogames today.  The game's free-to-play economy has gone through various permutations before appearing here on steam, but has settled into a comfortable place, providing adequate resources to free players in normal play, along with increasingly generous special event prizes most weekends that prevent any "pay to win" problems. Additionally, they have reduced "XP" requirements to narrow the gap between old-hands and neophytes, making this the best time for a new player to enter the arena since it's original closed beta launch. While the enormous variety of potential player customization makes balance devilishly tricky, the developers have consistently improved it over time, and managed to move it to a remarkably tight band that permits significant variety of viable playstyles. In sum, I give this game my highest endorsement, I have been playing it since closed beta and it is undoubtedly the strongest it has ever been.

												Great Mech game. Endless customization, great immersive feel...you really feel like you're there, piloting a Mech.  The controls are almost as complicated as getting acquainted with the game systems and HUD, but a decent tutorial and remapping keybinds makes it easy to get into this game and on your way after the first hour...but mastery would take hundreds of hours. The combat is great. the graphics have held up beautifully. Game is gorgeous. Lots of maps and play modes. Gripes: The menus are pretty bad and there are many things, such as simply changing the basic color of your mech, or worse, elite consumables, that you won't get unless you pay big bucks. You even get "crates" with potentially good stuff, but have to pay for "keys" to unlock said crates. I get it, its a store model, but games like LOL do it best, where 95% of the game is available to you for free, it'll just take more time.Overall, this is a great AAA quality game with dozens of hours of fun for free.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												I want to start off my being clear that I'm a returning founder who left the game initially because of problems with balance, meta, and PGI's inability to deliver.I picked the game back up again about a month ago, figuring i'd get in, check out CW, and lose interest within a day or two.  And to be honest, i still feel like i could lose interest any time now.For better or worse, this is not a direct port of TT.  To be hoenst TT had some mechanics in it that were just not suited to real time simulation.  PROSThe mech models are really good.  There are some technical issues with some models (hit boxes, scaling), but i think that on the whole, the mech models are in good shape.We got the Unseen showing up.  While the mech modles are altered, they are still immediately recognizeable.Most of the weapon and component implementations make sense when ported over from TTCommunity is generally less toxic than most others (That said, this is a team-based game and people do ge frustrated when people ignore attempts to organize in match)The number of mechs now available makes it less likey that during drops (at least in the lower 3 tiers) you will encounter  cookie-cutter meta teams.CONSBallistic weapons aer still just a hair to accurate.  While rounds drop in flight, they don't really seem to deviate in any other way.  Some of the weapon conversions are just badly implemented:  A 5 second cool down on gauss rifles, then charge time before you can fire, which really adds up to a double-lencgth cooldownClan implementation was just baddly handled, and it still causes gameplay and balance problemsGameplay/Mech balance issues can take some time resolve, and are sometimes knee-jerk reactions (Ask a veteran about tackling)Community Warfare just isn't ready yet.All in all, despite having some issues, the game does have promise, and is fun most of the time.  There are some changes coming up in the immediate future that address some of the outstanding issue and open up more content for Community Warfare.  So with all of that, for now, yes, I'd reccomend it, because you can get damn near everything out of the game without spending any money, though obviously people who spend the money get access to new chasis sooner.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												As a fan of any game that has big, heavy and powerful mechs to pilot I could already recommend at least playing this game for free. It starts you off with four "Trial Mechs" for each weight-class of mech. You have Light, Medium, Heavy and Assault mechs to try out with rather optimized loadouts, but on the whole they'll be suited towards default playstyle rather than individual tastes. The game's intro academy run and tutorial is very nice and simple, it even gives out some free in-game currency (C-Bills), and for the first twenty matches you drop into you get cash injections. By the end of the twenty matches you WILL have enough to buy your own mech to fully customize.For those who want to drop cash on a starter kit? I'd recommend it, though I also recommend looking at the website for the developer, "MWO Mercs". It has active bundles for specific mechs, iconic mechs, pre-order packs and "al a carte" style purchasing to pick and choose. It is a bit of an advantage over other players earning mechs via hard fighting, though trial mechs also build XP for those buying that variant. All in all, the game is fun. There's many ways to play and be a credit to your team, and this isn't even touching upon Community Warfare which introduces more organized combat that offers rewards such as in-game items for decoration and "real money" Mech-Credits to buy custom colors and such with.In the end, it isn't Gundam, it plays heavier and slower for most mech pilots. You're in anything from a 20-ton Locust with high-speed capabilities to a 100-ton Atlas that can literally bludgeon through enemy lines to open up holes for the team.I recommend this game, while it might not be for everyone, it's definitely a "Freemium"/Free to Play title that is worth trying.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Pros- Beautifully designed Mechs by Alex Iglesias (the man is a god)- Not a twitch shooter. Needs map awareness and thinking to play well.- Kit out your mech- Play as a team or lose.Cons- Developer has no clue about game mode mechanics- Developer has no clue about map design- Developer has no clue how to optimise a game engine (DX9 runs better than DX11 here)- The game will never be finished. Developer is constantly fiddling around with it.- Faction Play (Community Warfare) is a bust- Conquest modeHaving played this for 2-3 years since before Steam release. I have to warn you that the learning curve is fairly steep. There are a lot of things to know about the game, and they will not come quickly.Most of the guys who have stuck around are hardcore Battletech/Mechwarrior fans who just want to pilot their favourite mechs into battle and blow up other mechs.The core gameplay loop is improving how fast you blow up the other guy with well placed shots. But the game modes are standard. Skirmish, Assault, Domination are all just Deathmatches with some twist or none. I personally hate Conquest mode because it simply doesn't work without respawn mechanics.A lot of this review sounds negative, and that is intended. I would recommend this game, but ONLY if you like the few things it does right, and if you like beautiful mechs.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Its not bad.If you're looking for a modern day Mech Warrior game, this is a pretty good fit.  The game play seems to blend the best part of MW3 and MW4 together, while at the same time eliminating some of the most annoying parts of each.  Gone are the laser bunnies that dominated MW3.  Gone are the crippling customization limitations that made MW4 bad.  While you don't have complete freedom, the game gives you enough to capture a good experience - if you're willing to grind for it.The C-bill grind wall is pretty massive after the first 25 games.   You cant just jump in your mech of choice as in past games, you instead have to buy it and you'll farm for quite sometime just to gear out a good sized mech the way you want it.  This kind of sucks.  The games microtransation system is not required at all, but is also not very generous.  If you do want to support the game, be prepared to pay 20$ just for 1 medium sized mech.All and all, if you're looking for some old fashion mech action, this game is good.  Just make sure to buy the mech you want in the beginning, otherwise it's going to be a long time until you get it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												Title: Mechwarrior Online (MWO)Platform: PCGenre: MMOFPS (kinda), Its currently restricted to 12 v 12 pvp.Non-Spoiler Opinion: Since there aren’t really spoilers I will post my general opinion here and in the spoiler section give my tips to playing the game effectively.Pros: Balance seems relatively good however I prefer the Clan mechs over the Inter Sphere mechs because of the omnipod system. I have heard people argue Clan vs IS supremacy but I have seen relatively good balance on both sides. IS gets more quirks (bonuses for specific things) and Clans can swap out omnipods for greater customization. Player skill seems to make up for many things but nothing beats good team work in this game. It really doesn’t seem like a tank combat game as a light mech, its more like sniping or fast pace brawling game depending on build. The heavist mechs (assault class) do act rather tank-like and the balance of speed vs damage is quite good.Cons: This game appears to have some glitching issues. There is quite a benefit to people who pay money to get a hero or variant mech by giving a 30% C-bill bonus from each match. Of course, it is more cost efficient to at the very least learn to play and find which mech you like the most before you spend money on a hero mech.Overall Rating: 8/10*SPOILERS*Story Arc: None.Opinion in full: (my favorite builds) Light mech- Arctic Cheetah (you will need to buy omnipods for arms)ECM,6 - Small Pulse Lasers. How you want to play this build is to flank the enemy and pick off any mechs that break off from the rest of the group.Medium mech- Shadowcat B-variant ECM, 2 ER-PPC. You will want to snipe with this build and use the MASC ability in short burst to assist you in evading enemy fire. Heavy mech- Hellbringer 4 medium lasers, ECM, LBX AC 20 (shotgun autocannon), lots of ammo for the LBX. This is a strong brawler heavy mech with high damage output, just watch out for overheating if you fire the lasers too much.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												For fans of the Mechwarrior series, this is the online competitive version we've been waiting for. It certainly lives up to the previous titles. It isn't 100% perfect, but I think the positives certainly make up for the faults and the dev team is actively working on the game and improving on it. They also listen to and interact with the community pretty regularly through podcasts and town halls.The most important part is the mechs in a game like this, and in that regard they've done quite well. There is a huge variety of mechs of all sizes from 20 ton lights to 100 ton behemoth assaults and everything in between. Each mech has multiple variants with different hardpoints and options so it's easy to find something to fit your playstyle. They're also operating on a monthly release schedule which sees a new mech released mid-month every month. Initially mechs are sold in packs for real money but become available for in-game currency shortly after, so paying players effectively get the first crack at the new mechs.Maps could use some work. The maps themselves are great, well designed, look nice, and have pretty good diversity. The problem is they could stand to add another 4 to 6 maps to the game as currently I believe there's only around 10 or so for quick play.The gameplay is a nice mix of FPS and vehicular combat. While it does operate like an FPS in a sense, you are in giant robots and they do act like giant robots. Once queued and a match is found players are presented with a vote screen to vote for map/mode, which is something I wish other games like this would offer (looking at you War Thunder). The matches themselves are 12v12's and each player has the one mech they dropped with and that's it. There's no respawn, there's no heals, and no second chances; so play smart. This is probably the part of the game that can be frustrating for new players, but I think once you get past the punishing nature of the game you start to prefer it the way it is.One of the games current negatives is its faction warfare system. This is meant to be a sort of faction versus faction warfare system and is supposed to be more competitive. Unfortunately it's just not very active as the majority of the players still just play in the standard play queue and the motivation to play in the faction system is really rather lacking. It's a good idea, I just think the scope of it is too great for the limited appeal, particularly in a more niche game like this.One of the games best parts is the mechlab where you can customize your rig. Decide which weapon combos you want, how many heatsyncs, extra hardware, and so on. Clan and Inner Sphere mechs do operate a little differently in here as IS mechs allow you to modify the engines, while the engines are generally locked in clan mechs. However clan mechs offer the benefit of being able to switch out components with those from other variants which IS mechs can not do. Using your mechbay to upgrade and modify your loadout is extremely key in this game to be able to make the most of your mech and how you play it.The economy of the game is generally done pretty nice. It doesn't take too much to earn the credits in game required to buy a mech unless you're going for the biggest and most expensive clan mech. It really isn't pay-to-win as most of what you purchase using MC's (premium currency) are cosmetics like colors, decals, camo's, and so on. There are hero mechs that are available only for MC's however these mechs don't really provide an advantage, more a c-bill earning bonus while piloting them and a camo that is unique to the hero. I think the biggest hurdle for newer players are the MC costs of some things, particularly mechbays since the number of mechs you can purchase is always limited by how many bays you have available. Colors are another issue as their costs are pretty high and there's only a small selection of maybe 5 basic colors you can buy for c-bills, though once a color is unlocked you can use it on any mech. Camo's may seem expensive at first, but there is a "one shot" option that you can use that will apply the camo to your mech and it will remain so long as you don't change the camo later. Buying the camo outright costs 10x the price and really has no value unless you're constantly swapping camo's.The game does almost weekly run events that do allow you to earn MC's just through gameplay, and generally one of these events will net you enough for a mechbay. Prizes also often include things like c-bills, cockpit decor, MC's, and occassionally even colors. The events are very practical unlike some other games that offer event prizes where the requirements to get the prizes is often ridiculous.All-in-all I would say this is a great game that is worth a shot. It offers a lot of gameplay options through mechs of different sizes, speeds and styles and the community is generally pretty decent. I mean, sure you're going to get some jerks now and then, but overall the community is not overly rude or salty. This is particularly valuable given the game does have built-in VOIP for communication in matches, but there is a mute ability if you do run in to the occassional loudmouth you'd rather just not hear. So I would say definitely give the game a shot, particularly if you enjoyed or played previous Mechwarrior games.
