												The game has flaws. It lacks variety in game modes, some maps aren't balanced well enough, some weapons don't work as supposed to like LBX, team work is difficult without proper ingame commands except for chat, Faction wars are pointless at the moment but, damn, this game gives a proper MechWarrior feel.It appreciates team work and tactical movement around the map, flanking and other stuff, it gives you epic moments when staying on top of a close and tough round with a new mech and loadout.Do you need to pay to be able win? Nah, only learning and thinking brings victory. All mechs are available for ingame currency sooner or later except for Heroes and Champions, which are not a must.Do you need to follow the Laser Meta? Not at all, any variety of weapons can work out if you utilize them properly.There is a ton of various loadouts you can come up with for most of the mechs.Stay away from Trials as soon as possible, but they sure helps to take a look at various Mechs.The game gets updated often enough and it's a lot better than it was in 2013 and still getting better.It's great to play this game in a split with Megamek to help visualize the last one. :)240 hours since Steam release and still enjoying it.

												Been playing this game for years before it came to steam. At the time of writing this, It's easily in the best state it's ever been in. If you want to try your hand at a solid mech simulator, pick this up. It's entirely possible to play and do well without spending a dime, all it takes is practice practice practice. number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												Great game. PGI has brought it up from what it was (not that it was ever bad in my eyes) They continuosly work on fixes, balancing and any other issues that arise, props to PGI for getting it to where it currently is. Will continue to throw money at them since I'm that happy with what they're achieving for the Mechwarrior fans. GAMEPLAY: The game plays as a slower paced thinking shooter which I find very nice. Making one wrong decision in this game can turn disastrous for you very quickly. If you've ever played a game where you drove a tank that's what this is like in terms of controls. Being able to change Mechs that you own to your style of play allows for near endless combinations (some vastly more effective than others). You can build from Long Range Missiles (LRMs) Short Range Missiles (SRMs), Lasers, Autocannons, Gauss Rifles and you can often pair up many together depending on the Mech you are running. All in all it's a very solid game and can be completely free to play if you choose to go that route and not preorder for early access to Mechs before they are out for C-bills(in game currency). So far I would not say I've run into any particular area of the game where it is pay-to-win only pay-to-early-access.TO ALL NEW PLAYERS: You have nothing to lose and everything to gain by trying this out, it will appear grindy at first, and undoubtedly you will be pulverized by those more experienced than yourself. Remember this though, you'll enjoy every second of seeing that Atlas round the corner and lay into your face with it's massive alpha and in turn you will find yourself striving to learn how to avoid and combat such situations. I look forward to seeing you on the field Mechwarrior.UPDATE: Many new Mechs are available for in game currency compared to when I last revised my review, as well as many upcoming Mechs that will be first available for real money but will come later for in game currency. Some of the included Mechs for in game currency are the Archer, Rifleman, Warhammer, and Marauder. Others on their way that are available for preorder include the Viper (July 19th), Cyclops (Aug. 23rd), Night Gyr (Sep. 20th), Huntsman (Oct. 18th), and my personal favorite the Linebacker (Nov. 15th). All of these dates are for 2016. Many changes have come to how the Faction Play (previously known as Community Warfare) works and all of them are absolutely great in my opinion, there are now scouting missions which will land you bonuses for when you invade etc. As well as changes to the Faction Contracts and Career Choice options. Freelance, Mercenary and Loyalist are the options and all have their bonuses and drawbacks.

												Polished mech game definitely woth the download. It feels like a moba with two teams going for objectives or just skirmishing. If you've played World of Tanks this is the same thing with mechas. Earn enough to buy new mechas or upgrade modules. A nice touch is that you can customize your loadout to be a missle, laser, speed, low heat, or ballistic mecha. I can see how this would be a little grindy but its not bad compared to WOT. there is also a good rotation of free mechas every week but you just cant customize those easily.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												*Edited: This was before I began getting into the faction (ranked) gameplay. The mode is way more tactical with actual strategizing, that the community often engages in. However, the queues are extremely long, even longer than gameplay somtimes. Here's the rest of the review:I have mixed feelings about this game, but overall I feel it's a pretty fun, semi-tactical combat arena game in the Battlemech universe. I've been looking to play something like Mechwarrior but more recent, and this fits those old games with improved gameplay and graphics.I haven't been huge into the Battlemech universe, so part of the game is overwhelming. There is a lot going on in this game; so many Mechs to choose from, weapons and builds to go with.The community has been pretty solid thusfar. I've only had 1 game where a teammate purposely shot off my arms. I expected more, but everyone seems to either be going along with the gameplay or actively tactical and supportive.The gameplay is very short and can miss a lot of the tactical aspect. The maps are diverse and offer some strategizing, but within the community, the strategy features aren't used often. The same can be said for any gameplay mode that isn't deathmatch; all objectives tend to be to elimate the other team.Some purchase aspects are mainly skins, or things that can be grinded for. So it's not unfairly balanced to those who pay to win. The challenges add some objective and diversity to the gameplay, but I feel it is really lacking in tactical-based objective seeking gameplay.This is a game that works well, plays great and has the community to support it. You get dig deep into the immense Battlemech universe, grind and build limitlessly, or just skirmish in a well developed combat game.

												Been playing this game for years before it came to steam. At the time of writing this, It's easily in the best state it's ever been in. number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Fun free to play game. I always loved robots and mechs so this is right up my alley. Was a fan of battletech universe as a kid too. the cartoon, ccg, and table top games ive dablle with them all. MWO does the brand/lore justice even if its not exactly like what you may be used to. The game plays a blast at first but some frustrations to arise. So id reccomend it but its not perfect. It seems pretty close to WOT or Warthunders business model.The best part, is that bad♥♥♥♥♥feeling of taking control of a giant robot and fighting other bad♥♥♥♥♥robots. You get those sweet FPS moments to where you clutch for your team or beat the odds. Its got the collecting and progression model which can be fun to sink your brain teeth into but becomes pretty grindy. Customizing the mechs is super fun too but its kinda diluted with min maxing.Biggest gripe has got to be the price point they targeted for paided content. Ill always support games I like but my commitments gotta be relative to all the game out there. Theyre looking for $20-60 for mech packs witch seems quite high to me.  Ill play a few dozens games this year and cant be shelling out that much regularily for trinkets to play the game. if that same content was $5-10 i wouldnt sweat it and could do it over and over again through out the year. think of having to pay >$20 for a new League of legends character. That price just doesnt work for me. Id happily spend $100 a year on a game I like but I gotta feel like im getting good value for that and a few playble characters doesnt really do it for me. not when that totals the amount of a new AAA title.Second gripe, the meta seems kinda flawed. For a world imersed is so much history and story the games kind of diluted by the shooter game at its core. Min maxing seems to be the most popular style. which take you out of the immersion. Everyone seems to strip off the classic mech configurations to load on the seemingly op weapons. feels like every ones got a million lasers. The light mechs go as fast as possible with biggest engine no matter what. peek out for a second and your bombarded by dozens of missle strikes. players strip the armor of the backs and unused limbs to max out stuff. anywhere people can, they go for the extremes. and why wouldnt they. they are kind of rewarded for doing so. its simply the math of it all. even tho the practicality of it would rarely exist in the battletech universe. in a shooter it does work. dps is king. you just have a round to work with and little consequence for losing. The last few decades of FPS gaming strategy doesnt exactly allign with the classic battletech universe. I think it needs work. Compromises to be made. Id like to see them address this. id like playing true to lore to feel more viable instead of a liability.All in all I say give it a chance it might be for you. Ive definitly sunk some hours into it ive even bought a few things and not regret it. The devs seem commited to it and the games improved in the short time ive been playing. I like it but im on the fence about my commitment to it long term. I hope it not just a flavor of the month because it really could become a classic.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												Long time MechWarrior fan, and I have to admit this game feels very much like, if not better than, the previous MechWarrior titles from way back when.  Teamwork and knowing the particular strengths / weaknesses of the Battlemech you take out will drastically affect how well your matches will go.  My only cons with the game is that there's no single player or at least some kind of co-op vs AI mode.  Also not having any game mode population sizes outside 12v12 can be annoying....I'm much more of a 4v4 or 8v8 match playstyle as the smaller numbers allow for more individual player skill to shine rather than deathballing in a 12 man match.  Despite the cons I mentioned if you like tactical 1st person shooters then you should give this a go.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Crunch has been playing MWO since open Beta in early 2012. He only recently added MWO to his Steam account. He has more hours in game than listed by Steam ... far, far more (but not as many as a lot of players).Crunch is a long time fan of the Battletech/Mechwarrior game universe stretching back to the tabletop and the first computer versions, Crescent Hawks (circa 1990). He has played multiple computer versions (including the Crysis mod Mechwarrior Living Legends). The long dry spell between computer games (2001 to 2012) led him to other games, with the Mass Effect series supplanting Mechwarrior as his all time favourite games series. Then Mechwarrior came out, and slowly won it`s crown back (as it worked its´ way out of Beta).Crunch could sacrifice many innocent and defenseless electrons telling you MWO is a great game. Many others have already. MWO is a free to play title. Give it a try. Make up your own mind. Be aware, there is a learning curve to piloting a mech well. Use the Academy to get used to the controls. Try out the testing grounds. Play around with the trial mechs.Personally, Crunch gives MWO 9/10. Even nearly 5 years after open Beta, there are things that need to be improved.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												+ Satisfying Combat++ In Depth Customization of Mechs makes your mech made just for you+ Awesome Community+Money does not make you better in combat... might make your mechs look coolio tho.+Nice graphics-This game might seem abit grindy to some.-Customiztion may be overwhelming at first.Combat in this game really satisfying, you can really tell you did a number on your opponent... when you completley blow off his mechs arms or send him running with a silly limp :D. The nice visual effects really add to that as well.Its more of a shooter that involves more strategy, teamwork and knowledge of your mech and, with experience, the weaknesses of your enemies mechs to succeed.Tho, having skills like a stready trigger finger and good situational awareness will also get you far... plus it keeps you from being deadz.The main thing thats really got me hooked on this game is the in depth customisation of mechs in this game. I've spent hours endlessly customizing and testing them on the battlefeild just to find that sweet spot, only to have my taste of weaponry shift again and again depending on me wanting more pew pew or dakka dakka. Or whether i want to be a "In Your Face" role or a support role. To simply put it, I love it!That being said, the customization does look quite intimidating to beginners and new players may be lost at first with all the numbers and different components. But the high amount of detail you can go to customizing your mech, right down to the armor in each limb and type of Missle, Cannon, Laser, Sensors, Engines, makes each mech tailor made to your intended play style.Glad to say, this game is far from a pay to win kind of game but does allow you to use real money to get what you want right away if your not willing to grind for it. But gives no real edge in combat in the end of the day.However, the game showers new players with loads of in game money when they start out. Which leads me to the biggest advice i can give to new players.Try the trail mechs first before spending all that c-bill moola. The game affectively gives new players the choice of any mech in the beginning due to the extra c-bills players get in their first few matches (first 25). So get a good idea of what matches your play style first THEN buy your dream mech.Last few words : Stick together and TEAMWORK is king.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												I watched all the videos.  Everyone said it's a "thinking player's shooter."  Sounded good, since I'm an old school RTS gamer and I've always prefer games that weren't twitch-based.So...I started trying to play a laser mech because they don't run out of ammo.  Lost 5 games out of 6.  Badly.  I decided to try something different, so I bought 2 new Omni slots on a medium mech and outfitted it with 3 LRM10's and decided to play fire support.  Won 3 out of the next 4 matches.  Actually survived 2 of them to the end of the match, too.So my review of MWO is basically this: it's a shooter where you CAN be tactical, deliberate, and patient.  You just can't play like that right up in the enemy's face.  If you aren't looking for a twitch shooter, you can still find a home here, but just do yourself - and your team - a favor and switch to a missile mech because that's the only class where someone with slow reflexes (like myself - hey, I admit it) can really be more help than harm.And who knows.  You might get lucky and kill someone with the lone Medium Pulse Laser you have.  Like I did 2 matches ago.  Hey, it happens.EDIT: Just wanted to add a little tip.Once you die in a match, it's helpful to watch other players and learn how they play, but if you don't want to, you can quit the match.  When you do, your mech will show as "in mission" and you can't play another match until the game finishes.When this happens, switch to another mech and queue for another game.  You will still get credit once the other match finishes, and you can switch back to your other mech for the next match.  In this way, you do not have to sit on your hands for several minutes waiting for the game to end.And if you love one specific mech, you CAN own two of the same mech, too.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												Despite its questionable pricing model, MechWarrior Online is just way too much fun to play.It's relatively complex when it comes to customization, but the game is tons of fun. My opinion is somewhat biased (or not biased at all, as it would push me to scrutinize the game harder) because I have been a long-time fan of the BattleTech/MechWarrior franchise and series. I've played the MechWarrior games since the first, and always enjoyed them.All that said, I found myself pleasantly surprised with MWO. I feel like they have done the franchise justice quite well, and, although I had concern that the Clans weren't getting a lot of love, we have gotten quite a hefty hand of Clanners recently, along with IIC 'Mechs, and more Clanners incoming even.If I have anything to complain about, it's that the 'Mechs don't totally feel like 'Mechs at times. They control a little too... Smoothly? I guess? Smooth is good, but something about it feels 'too' fluid, if you know what I mean. Also, when a 'Mech is destroyed, it feels like there's no real weight behind its descent... But these are minor, minor complaints. I adore this game, and if you want a fun technical shooter with a strong focus on teamwork and patience, start playing. You don't lose much if you don't like it, really, the game is free.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												Warning! This game can be extremely addictive!I am a Tier 1 MWO veteran who has been playing this game for 2 years almost exclusively. You won't understand why until you are the last pilot alive, forced to confront five enemy Mechs with a cored centre torso, having only half your weapons at your disposal. The adrenaline rush in this game is real.When you achieve victory on those situations, your satisfaction is immense: both intelectual and physical. You can't win at this game with just twich reflexes. You need tactical and situational awareness, teamwork (not even the best MWO players can win their matches on their own) and some serious multi-tasking skills. You need to know your Mech inside out: temperature thresholds, weapon ranges, cooldowns and projectile speeds, just to name a few, all while you aim at open components and hide yours from enemy fire.The learning curve is steep and extremely rewarding: you learn from every defeat and victory. You hate some Mechs or weapons until you learn something new that makes you love them. You learn how to handle your legs independently from your torso, and then it's time to spread damage by torso twisting...I have been playing this game for 2 years and every day I learn something new. And that's why I keep coming back.The experience is so rich and engaging, you just can't get enough of it. I know I can't.

content:

												For free it's an amazing shooter, it has very similar game mechanics to Elite Dangerous, as far as weapons and heat management go. I dont think you would ever have to pay a dime to win, i find the Ebon Jaguar is great and if you buy it and customize it, you will dominate the battlefeild from afar.What's important is its free, not too hard to get the hang of (if your willing to learn) and NOT PAY TO WIN. I dont usualy play f2p games, but i just had to give this a go, and i regret every time i gave this game a pass simply because it was f2p.Money is not very easy to earn however, and this could have hurt gameplay if you were limited to the mechs you own, but instead you get trial mechs that let you change up your play style, and get a feel for the game without spending any of that hard earned Cbills. There is special currency that is kind of expensive in real money, and lets you buy special mechs, and lets you buy normal mechs cheaper. Overall this game is worth your time, and honestly, your money. i would go ahead and pay 15 bucks to get enough of that yellow currency to buy a mech that best suits your favorite playstyle.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												I've been playing this game since right before Clans dropped, when fellow clanmates got me into it. As such, I have no gripes with what the publisher and devs did before I started playing, unlike so many people who are still salty about this game's beginnings. As it stands now, it's a fun mech game which focuses on player positioning, teamwork, and mech customizability. One factor that the salty ones are going to rant about is that they think the devs are greedy. Yes, the monotization model is rather expensive, but the game is not pay to win. You can play and enjoy the game just fine without shelling out any money. In fact, as a closed beta World of Tanks player, I can say the game is better priced and less pay to win than world of tanks is.I suggest you play and make up your own mind about this game. No point in not even giving it a chance. After all, it's free to play.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												I love Metal Gear Solid and I liked MechAssault well enough....needless to say this only has big stompy mechas in common with those series. Delivers tons of content for a Free-To-Play game and I don't mind saying that I've spent some hard cash on it as well. Need that new 'Mech for mastery, ya know? A game that really relies on teamwork and communication with some room for crazy heroic antics as well. The Faction play is rather slow (dead) but Quick play is always there for 10 minutes of fun. MWO has become my go-to game to chill out; the playerbase is the friendliest and most talkative I've encountered thus far. Outside of combat is the excellent and initially confusing metagame of customizing the loadout of your BattleMech after you purchase one of the four classes: Light, Medium, Heavy, and Assault. Trial 'Mechs are available to test out and they change periodically but you're really gonna want to get your own. I could go on but it's free so just try it. Lasers and air strikes, base captures and missile boats. Don't miss out.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												This game used to be a disappointment to me, and in a few ways it still is. The development cycle seems to be dragging at a snails pace, and the community has a shaky history. However If I were to compare it to other free to play games on Steam it comes out on top of a lot of them with really solid gameplay and customization, good graphics and sound, and on top of that probably the best in the big stompy mech genre for now. The greatest amount of naysaying you will hear is going to be from the old NBT Hardcore Vets. The real Battletech badasses of a bygone age. content:

												I love Metal Gear Solid and I liked MechAssault well enough....needless to say this only has big stompy mechas in common with those series. Delivers tons of content for a Free-To-Play game and I don't mind saying that I've spent some hard cash on it as well. Need that new 'Mech for mastery, ya know? A game that really relies on teamwork and communication with some room for crazy heroic antics as well. The Faction play is rather slow (dead) but Quick play is always there for 10 minutes of fun. MWO has become my go-to game to chill out; the playerbase is the friendliest and most talkative I've encountered thus far. Outside of combat is the excellent and initially confusing metagame of customizing the loadout of your BattleMech after you purchase one of the four classes: Light, Medium, Heavy, and Assault. Trial 'Mechs are available to test out and they change periodically but you're really gonna want to get your own. I could go on but it's free so just try it. Lasers and air strikes, base captures and missile boats. Don't miss out.

content:

												I've been playing this game since right before Clans dropped, when fellow clanmates got me into it. As such, I have no gripes with what the publisher and devs did before I started playing, unlike so many people who are still salty about this game's beginnings. As it stands now, it's a fun mech game which focuses on player positioning, teamwork, and mech customizability. One factor that the salty ones are going to rant about is that they think the devs are greedy. Yes, the monotization model is rather expensive, but the game is not pay to win. You can play and enjoy the game just fine without shelling out any money. In fact, as a closed beta World of Tanks player, I can say the game is better priced and less pay to win than world of tanks is.I suggest you play and make up your own mind about this game. No point in not even giving it a chance. After all, it's free to play.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												Overall this game feels like it lives up to the MechWarrior standard we all know and love. I read reports of it feeling incredibly Pay2Win in the early stages. This discouraged me quite a bit until I decided to play just recently. And I have to say, they have fixed this massive issue from my experience so far.This game sets you in the seat of any one of dozens of building-sized mechs (with variations for every appetite of carnage) as it pits you against one another in a thought-provoking strategy. Run&Gunners will not like this game, outright, to be successful you need to utilize what you can with your team and weigh strategies. A single mech can turn the tide of battle depending on the game type and the strategy employed.PROS:-High on the thought-provoking based gameplay. (Moves/actions/assaults require tactics)-Built-in Voice to assist with this-The mech choices feel endless and nearly every style of "approach" can be found in at least one mech-Weapon balance is very sold, something you expect from a MW game-Builds for any mech can keep even veteran tinkerers happy-Maps have variety (even if people only choose a few maps)-The game feels organic and very immersive as you are set in the cockpit of a 30-100 ton war machine-The smallest mechs have strategies to employ against the largest, and vice versa. Not one mech can truly reign as "king of mechs"CONS:-New players will feel overwhelmed with the amount of options and how to actually build/load a mech-The tutorial is nice but not as extensive as the game itself-There is no "try before you buy" unless your mech of choice happens to be in the weekly(?) trial mech line-up-EXP gain and Credits gain after your first few battles feels molasses in January slow-Game requirements may be high for some older PC'sOverall the gameplay is as solid as titanium with a few flaws in regard to resource income. Good visuals, good gameplay, and the community is actually quite friendly for a team-based competitive game. Let's just say I'd rather meet with MWO folk than LoL/DOTA2 folk any day of the week.Solid 9.5/10Promote whoever did the improvements for this game.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												I strongly recommend this game to anyone who likes the idea of fighting in customizable stompy robot tanks.If you are a Battletech/Mechwarrior fan and haven't yet picked this up, you owe it to yourself to download it and play.  If you played it back and left, you should try it again.  I've enjoyed playing both quick match (which I rarely have to wait more than a minute), and community/faction warfare games.  As a fan of "Instant Action" games from MW 2/3/4, this scratches that itch perfectly.  I really like the variety of maps and mission types.  Plays great with a mouse and keyboard.Unlike a lot of other F2P games, you don't have to put in money to get enjoyment out of the game.  There are bonuses for completing the tutorial up to about 6 million C-bills (currency), and you get a bonus for the first 25 quick match games you play - win or lose - which amounts to about another 8 million.  This is enough to buy one of the really large assault battlemechs or a couple of the smaller ones (I personally recommend medium or heavy for newer players).  I also don't feel that it is pay-to-win, since real money can get you more variety faster - or cosmetic items, but it won't make you a better player.   Money can't make you more situationally aware, a better team player, or a better communicator.  Summary: If you like customizating robot tanks and shooting at people in a 12v12 team environment, play this game.  It's free.  If you like it, support it by buying a Steam pack or a premium/mastery pack from the MWO website.Side note: I'm glad that my friends taught me the phonetic alphabet.  It has been really useful!-----The stuff below are things that I think new players should know going into this.- I recommend that you have a mic or headset.  It's not required, but it helps since you aren't going to have time to type meassages while driving your 'mech.- Weapon groups.  Life is easier at first if you set your weapons to groups 1 & 2 (left mouse button, right mouse button).  Change it once you get a little better and can handle a larger variety of weapons & groups.- In-game money & grind: I would say this isn't as much of an issue if you are careful with your purchases.  Really try those trial mechs so you can focus on what you like.  - Inner Sphere or Clan?  Pick one to focus on - since in community/faction warfare you will be limited to IS 'mechs for the houses or Clan 'mechs for the clans.  The weapons and equipment are not interchangeable between technology bases.- Understand that you will lose matches at first - and that's okay.   Learn to communicate, call targets, be a team player.  A lot of the "veteran players" have given good advice on staying alive and being effective.  If you do die - spectate other players to see what they do right and wrong.- Don't go it alone.  Alone = dead.  Coordinate with your teammates.  A team that talks together wins together.- Spending *real* money:  Once you have played through the trial mechs and found a size type that you prefer, then look into spending real money.  The Steam packs are pretty good when on sale, and I would buy one if you *really like* one of the 'mechs in the pack.  Just be aware, that you need three of a chassis (which have different weapon loadout possibilities) to "master" a mech, which provides performance perks.  Also look at "mastery" packs - which are sold in the MWO gift store, or premium packages which have different price points.  (Note: before you buy a mech, see if it is included in one of these - that way you can buy a variant that isn't included so you don't have a duplicate mech). I personally have purchased the light 'mech pack from Steam first, since I thought it was good value for money, and the Marauder pack from the MWO website since that is one of my personal favorites.  I have been happy with both purchases.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Love this game so far. Fair warning to new players though..... Within my first hour of playing and learning I was bombarded with name calling etc. by veteran clan players on my team about every other game for not knowing the maps, what my mech's role was, etc. It was pretty harsh.... and of all the time I have played online MP games this was probably the biggest bash-fest on new players in the game I have ever seen.... They are easy to ignore... Just keep playing on and learn!! I look at it this way.... if players take a loss in a random, match-making battle so personal.... They aren't worth the bits and bytes of text data they type when they cry about losing in a match with mixed noobs and vets...Game is free to play as it says and lots and lots to do for free. Trial mechs of every class to learn on or decide which you like, you can buy your first mech or 2 and load it out, as well as add some perks and what not all from playing the game. No purchases really needed. If you want more advanced mechs and components....asthetics... yea it is a little pricey with real money. All in all this one can be played without spending a dime and still have fun doing it. If you are obsessed with kill ratios, cool paint jobs, clans, and want to take this game from recreation level to "my day is ruined because I lost again" fanatic....You will need to open your wallet up a little...Graphics are pretty decent for what it's worth. Gameplay is great... A LOT of different mechs and configurations for them are almost limitless...and free. From what I have seen so far, there really isn't a balancing issue bc of this... Everyone uses all different mechs that are custom built to their style...and none really overpowered considering this is a team effort game.... The guy who goes out solo away from the group always dies.... No matter how good he is... A group of baddie mechs will tear a lone player apart.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												As someone who LOVED MechWarrior 3 and 4 and played the hell out of these games, I first was not confident, that a F2P-MP-game might be the right for me. I was afraid of P2W, OP mechs not properly balanced by the devs and all that stuff.After a friend convienced me to give it a try, I got addicted. This is the "shooter" I was looking for. Not that focused on reflexes and fast pace movement like CS:GO or similar FPS, but more tactical approach with steady aim and a deep thought in positioning to maximize your damage outpot while staying alive. And the theorycrafting, oh good, I've never thought that you could talk 3 hours about the best loadout for a certain chassis of a mech. But you can. And I friggin' love exactly this kind of depth this game delivers.Patches are rolled out on a monthly basis. The devs, well, TRY at least to be as much community driven as they can, the playerbase, although you find your foul apple every now and then, is mostly calm and mannered, which is absolutely rare for a F2P-title. But, you have to be that honest, there IS a small, but really really small, Pay-2-Win-factor in this game. There are some mechs that you can only buy with real money that have a specialised loadout and weaponry that may seem OP in certain situations. But a mech is still only as good as the pilot and when you suck at piloting, the best mech falls in a few seconds because he doesn't know how to torso twist or how positioning functions.As a BattleTech-fanboi, I rate this game a solid 9/10. The one point missing is for maps like Viridian Bog. ♥♥♥♥ Viridian Bog. Oh, and ♥♥♥♥ LRM-Boats on Polar Highlands, too. That♥♥♥♥♥♥s awfull.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												MWO is an FPS simulation (and yes, I saw that walking simulator tag...sigh) where you drive 35-100 ton death machines around and blow things up.  If this sounds awesome welcome to BATTLETECH, a universe where war is decided by these giant mechs.  Each mech has a ton of customization with the different weapon groups.  Lasers, balistics and missiles.  The game can be daunting for someone new, but it does come with tutorial missions and practice missions to help get new players up to speed.  Of course, you could also jump straight into the action and that's fine as well.Graphics are good.  It runs off the cryengine which while dated can still put out some good images at the highest settings.  Of course, it's also scaled pretty well, so if you experience performance issues feel free to turn down some settings.  The only gripe I have with the graphics is low-light vision.  Sometimes it gets hard to see enemy mechs, especially on night maps.  There are two vision modes designed to help with that.  Thermal (triggered by pressing H) allows you to see the heat signatures of enemy mechs.  Hot objects glow bright white in this view, but be careful not to use it on the Terra Therma map or you'll go blind.  It can also sometimes be hard to drive with this mode especially in cities as buildings don't show up too well.  The other vision mode is night vison (Triggered by pressing n) which is the same green-screen that you would expect.  It works well most of the time and provides good contrast but it has problems with smoke.Controls are pretty simple but you have to get used to thinking of your mech as a tank.  Comming from World of Tanks and a longtime battletech fan, it wasn't hard for me to get used to this but some people really struggle not being able to strafe side to side.  You have to turn your legs first!  I've tried it with a controller as well and it takes some configuring but you can set it up no problem.Gameplay is awesome.  It's an FPS but mechs have lots of health so you can take a few hits and trade with enemies.  Position and line of sight is also really important, as is TARGETING.  There is a radar screen but only the mechs you and your team target will show up on the map.  There is a lot of info warfare demonstrated in this game and I love it.  There are target painting lasers, beacon rockets that can light up enemy mechs for the world to see, ECM and counter ECM, active probes.  I could go on all day.  There are a lot of really skilled players out there that have written and videoed great guides, or just, had fun!  The game is fairly balanced for the most part but it is very heavy on teamwork and focus fire.  Individual 1v1s are rare, and sometimes they aren't always in your favor as different mechs have different roles, some mechs are superb duelists while some mechs are more long-range fire support.  If a duelist gets in close to a fire support mech that fire support mech is probably dead, that's why this game relys so much on teamplay.Mechwarrior, and battletech, has a lot of fans.  If you love battletech, you'll love this game.  However, I have some tips and warnings for newbies.A tip: Don't get intimidated!  Battletech has a rich lore and a vast customization system.  Look up metamechs (its a website :P) mess around in smurfy's mechlab, above all else, keep an open mind. This can be a slow game, but it can also be very fast, it all depends on the flow of the match you're in.  Don't listen to people crying about P2W, for the most part, the game is pretty balanced on that front.  It's more, 'pay for convenience' and PGI has a habit of releasing mechs in stages, first stage is like a preorder, then it's available for premium currency, then it's available for C-Bills (The standard currency)A warning: You need a lot of patience to play this game.  The cadet missions and training missions give out some C bills, but mechs can cost upwards of 9million Cbills when fully decked out.  It will take you some time to get up to speed, but it's worth the wait, as once you have your own mech you can do whatever you want with it.  Fight in community warfare!  Master your mechs!  And have fun!

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Ummmm Yeah... This is Bill Lumbar reporting in for my first review of MWO.  I started playing MWO around 2 years ago.  I have always been a fan of the BT table top, grew up playing it as a child and young adult.  38 now, and through the years I have played many of the BT games on sega, super Nes, playstation, xbox and pc to name a few.  I used to head up to chicago to the BT center as a kid with my dad to get my fix.   Life took over and I found myself not playing BT games anymore, and for years.  I got that hunger again around two years ago and googled new BT games.  First hit I got was MWLL and I happened to have the old Cyris game so I was all set.  Jumped right in and I loved it... then bam!  MWLL got shut down/they stopped developing it.  I then read the rumors surrounding the "why" and came across MWO and downloaded it and started playing it more then I would like to admit.  For a solid 6 months, I dropped over 6000+ matches.  Within the last two plus years I have spent around $90 dollars on this game between two accounts, one IS, and the other straight Clan.  This game has faults..... that is for sure.  One of the two biggest issues for me has always been the painful "grind" and snails pace one progresses at in this game, even when spending hundreds or even thousands of dollars on it.  Thankfully, right before the Steam release... PGI decided after 2 plus years of very low ingame earnings to increase the C-bill and XP earnings.  I don't believe its where it needs to be, but it is up around 15-25% of what we all used to make per match.  I wanted and felt a 50% increase was long over due, but hey its a start.  Secondly, Prices for everything in this game besides Mechbays are pretty much crack priced.  How they unlock camo, patterns, and colors is just insane for the price.  All the bling for the cockpits, prices are pretty much insane IMO.  Third game lacks serious content and depth.  It needs so much more, and it has been screaming for more for a very long time!  Now to the good things,  Core game play is fun.  I am looking for more of a sim type game when it comes to BT... because I like to build sim pits... I love BT... and I hope they keep it moving more towards that style of play in this game.  for what ever faults this game does have, PGI has come a long way with this game.  I took a several month vaction from this game... going from playing around 100-200 matches a week, to only 5 matches a week.  The  last 3 months I have just got back into playing this game and am back up to maybe 30-50 matches a week.  This was mostly to do with PGI ignoring the pleas of many on the forums/forum warriors that earnings needed to be brought up so this game didn't feel like a snails pace.  Even with PT it still felt very slow, making not buying PT a no brainer.  All in all I would recommend this game to others, core game play is fun.... and I have met some really cool people in game.  The forums are a trip some times... much hate...but there is also a lot of love out there and some really cool people that love to help and also even share/give aways.  One piece of advice...spend wisely, and don't go on a crack spending spree....seriously, its not worth it IMO.  If you have the dollars to do that and want a place to blow them, by all means, knock yourself out.  Plenty to blow money on in this game...golden mechs.... you name it, PGI will sell it!

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												Hello potential MechWarriors,I am Khan CoffiNail Tseng a unit leader of the Clan Faction loyalist unit Clan Ghost Bear International. I have been on and off heavily active in MechWarrior since May 2010, a year before MWO was even announced playing in a MechWarrior mod for the game Crysis. I was a zealous fan of MWO from the start of announcements for MechWarrior Online using a daily puzzle of the Atlas concept artwork and twitter to stir a buzz felt around the net. I was so crazy in love with this game I ended being the 25th register forum member. I still play this game and am more a grey knight than a zealous fan for various reasons, but I am a die-hard Mechhead and love to see MechWarrior in the spotlight it had back in the 90s. The game has its flaws, but so does any game that is in development still, it may be out but it is a perpetually in development game. So the MWO you play today, will not be the same one in a year, as content is continuously coming out and being teased with.It is a great game. It has very well done artwork, and the Mechs are extremely well done. Animation is great as most mechs feel weighty and others make you jump if you run in to them around a corner and you skid to a stop to try and get back around your corner. Scale could be considered a little off by some, but with the addition half a year ago with destructible light posts, knockdown trees, etc the scale seems fairly well for Machines only a dozen meters tall. The environments are beautiful and I still find myself getting lost in them at times. Do you want a game that can be both twitch and slow, where good aim pays off to take down critical components, but someone who’s aim is mediocre can still do decent damage and have a great time doing it? MWO is a good FREE game to add to your library. If you want a game with a lot of weapons fire going off and an often chaotic battlefield or something to get a fill of stompy big robots this game is a great FREE addition to your library. You are someone who just loves to tinker with things until they are just right, shedding armour off this leg to add a bit more armour or heat sinks, crafting the perfect build and playstyle this would be a great FREE addition to your library. Honestly, it is free, so give it a try and do not take my word for it but experience the battlefield of 1980’s 31st Century Battlefield Technology. This game has had its ups and downs much like any develop game and the fact their game has been in a large sense open to the public since November 1st 2011 and the very start of their development, now this means they have had a lot of scrutiny and under the microscope. They have been developing a nestablished universe with a fairly strong fanbase. These fans have not had a game since early 2002 in MechWarrior 4. Of course these loyal crowd, to which I am one love the core universe MechWarrior Online was place in, Battletech. It has a deep and rich backstory that is the effect of an alternate history starting in the 1980s.PGI’s announcement of MechWarrior Online had a very exciting start. With a twitter feed giving daily in universe news written by the current developer of the tabletop, backstory universe Randall Bills. It had hints of the setting, a puzzle of concept art. The month of October 2011 was fairly amazing from a Mechwarrior fan’s point This is getting to be a very balanced game. No longer do you have a arms race to the largest Mechs with the most advanced tech. Every mech in the right hands could be a very deadly opponent. Like in this universe the elite skilled were some of the deadliest pilots, who could operate their machines like and extension of themselves. A green and fresh pilot in a Atlas, should come down to a veteran in a light Mech Jenner.The Customization of Mechs via the Mechlab. Giving you hours of lost time playing around to get your warmachine just the way you like it, with the weapons you like. The deeper meta of the mechlab is an art all in itself and is a core aspect to master in competitive scenes. Role Warfare: Where your Assault Mechs going in force alone would mean nothing, but a well-coordinated team, mixed with different weight classes and loadouts could crush a more numerous opponents. Your Heavy Mechs were the support and the force going in with the assaults and crushing the opposition. Medium Mechs the backbone of the game, your go to for price and power. The light Mechs of your team were experts as going in behind enemy lines and at using Electronic Counter Measures (ECM) to shield your team from enemy sensors.Intelligence Warfare: From the above lights, to other, heavier chassis with ECM and other electronics of the battlefield. Using your gear to assist in spotting for you Long Range Missiles allies in the rear or to jam the ECM of your foe.Community Warfare: The creation of units in-game. Guilds, clans, communities. The larger picture of the glory that is a game set in the war torn Inner Sphere of the Battletech Universe. There is always war, and this give the community as deeper meta game to bring to the table.Something always feels great about piloting 20-100 ton Bipedal Warmachine of destruction and smashing them around a forest or city. The rush you can have being the last pilot in a match, or as you take on a mech in a higher weight class, or even as that Assault crashing in to wreak havoc with your team.Thanks for reading. I hope I have given a bit of sway for you to try MechWarrior Online, or at least to keep it on your scope to try soon. We see the same games in different forms, and MWO has a bit of a different take on the FPS. I hope to see you on the battlefield MechWarrior. -Khan CoffiNail Tseng, Clan Ghost Bear International ghost-bear-command.com

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												I find it a little difficult not to recommend a free to play game, especially one that has the polished look that MWO has. One that has the look/feel of a complete pay to play game. That being the case I won't say - no, I don't recommend it. Instead I will say don't get into this free to play game expecting great things. As some reviewers have mentioned the grind is real. I don't really care about comparisons of other games and how much you have to grind on them to get anywhere. From my personal experience I have probably in the neighborhood of 75 hours into this game. I also have well over $80 into this game. If the cost of MC is the same it has been for a couple years then I have $95 into the game. So that's nearly 80 hours and $95... Know what I have? Ten mechs currently. I believe I have sold one that I decided I'd never use again, and it was a mech that I had won. Also one of the mechs I currently have I won as well. Three of the mechs I have I bought with real money essentially. So that means I've been able to afford to buy six mechs in the game with nearly 80 hours worth of grinding. And this includes using "Hero" mechs that net you more c-bills per match. If you spend real money on this game know that the "value" simply will not be there. I have never spent $95 on a single stand alone game. A full copy of a game, then DLC that comes out later, yes. But $95 for a game that completely lacks any kind of story mode, only allows for online multiplayer and last I knew in order to "host" a game yourself with buddies that cost real money. Bottom line is if you put any kind of money into the game you're essentially paying for - at best half a game depending on how you want to look at it. Because real money doesn't even come close to unlocking or allowing one to use all of the mechs in the game. Worst case scenario dropping $50 on the game has the potential to allow you to play with... 5% of the game, at best? I think that's pretty fair. And if you're one those that doesn't spend any money on the game be prepared for some major grinding. And if the grind wasn't bad enough the game becomes very monotonous because of the underwhemling gameplay.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												As a new player I kind of have to wonder where all the bad reviews are coming from. I almost didn't give this game a shot because of them, but when I eventually did there were plenty of powerful mechs to play for free and I didn't do bad at all. You get a nice fat bonus for your first matches and you'll be able to buy one powerful fully up-to-scratch best-level mech for yourself. I reccomend choosing carefully. The grind gets real bad after a while (to the point where a second full-power mech is paid DLC), but at least the game itself is fair. You can always use the free mechs if you don't care about the metagame and just want to walk a hulking mech to shoot people. Plus the unleveled versions of mechs are kinda affordable, and they aren't too much worse than top-level mechs.The core game is more strategical than most shooters. Because it takes a while to kill someone and you can't easily reposition, the tactics behind your attacks are invaluable. There is strength in groups, because in this game there's no cheap one-shot kills. If someone shoots there will be plenty of time to react for the opponent, because you won't kill anyone with just one shot and going back behind cover takes getting that robot up to speed again. If the guy you shot has 5 friends you'll be shot back way harder. So attacking goes in groups, that way the odds won't be stacked against you. More people is more joy, because if you brought 8 friends along the enemy will have a lot worse of a time. Then of course there's flanking and attack routes to keep in mind, maybe sending 4 guys to flank can be an advantage etc., you get the gist. Shame there's a lot of pubnoobs who don't care for strategy.The meta-game is building your mech, which is another collection of strategic decisions I won't go too much into depth on. The basic idea is that you can't have it all, you'll have to choose your strengths and weaknesses. The grind is more important. Basically free players can have 1 mech up to full power, if you want to max level another mech you'll have to buy space and get the mech you want 3 times over. Grinding up the money and premium currency for a second fully powered mech takes so incredibly long I'd actually say it's not possible. For all intents and purposes you get 1 max-level mech, you'll have to pay real money for more or settle for not-max-level-mechs. That sounds really bad, but keep in mind that not-max-level-mechs are pretty decent and usable.

												Long time closed beta vet. Very deep and rewarding mech game. It has the right mix of sim/fps/team tactics. It also stays true enough to battle tech to keep it interesting and nostalgic. This game is not perfect but it is super fun and it's not impossible to play for years without spending any money.  It does have a pretty expensive pay for convenience and early access system. These do not break the game balance as PGI is mindful to avoid pay to win. Speaking of balance, the game is a modders dream so balance is hard and constant. Lately PGI has done better responding to balance changes and issues. In short this game is my favorite game I currently play and worth a few weeks try to see if you like it. It's free so try it. My in game name is bradleyusm friend me and I'll be happy to help newer players get acclimated.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25
												In a single year this became my favorite game of all time. When I first heard of it I thought it would be terrible, and only gave it a shot because there was nothing else quite like and, well, it's free. And I'm very glad I did that.The gameplay is really good, with a lot of depth and customization. It features hundreds of different 'Mechs variants that can be customised: loadouts, cockpit items and camo patterns. Some 'Mechs and weapons are inferior to others, but overall the game is pretty well balanced.As for the F2P aspects, there are C-Bills, the common currency earned in every match, and MC, the premium currency. The best things that MC can buy are premium time, that increases C-Bills and experience earned in every match, 'Mech bays, that increased the maximum number of owned 'Mechs, and Hero 'Mechs, unique variants with a 30% C-Bill bonus.The Hero 'Mechs are not overpowered (some are actually worse than their C-Bill variants) and so players that spend money on them have to rely more on their loadout, skill and teamwork rather than the type of 'Mech they own.One of the biggest problems with the game is the lack of more advanced tutorials. The in-game tutorial only teaches the very basic concepts, and for everything else I had to watch tutorials on Youtube.The performance of the game, while not terrible, is still worse than it should be, especially for a F2P game.That being said, Mechwarrior Online is a really good game, albeit with some flaws. It is the only game I never get tired of,  and I can't wait for the new content planned for 2017 (new weapons, equipment, 'Mechs and skill trees).

number of helpful: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												If you have been reading the reviews, then you will notice a trend of either bitter long time players, or veteran players with a new hope for this game. These view points are obscured in broken promises, gameplay features, or the feeling that a childhood game is not what they wanted it to be. However, this review should be based on the game in question and not the previous titles, or the best laid plans of a company that has never developed a title like this before. If you take this game as a stand alone product and review it fairly based off its production, content, and concept, their is really nothing like it in the gaming community. However, players that have played Battletech games in the past, or played table top versions of this game, and use that as a back drop to compare this game are always going to have problems with what the developers do to this game.The truth is the player base is much older in this game and most are not skilled FPS gamers like in other titles. So the great whole of the communty wants balance to the game and often blames a lot of their own inadequacies on the developers rather than holding themselves acountable. While, the small percentage of gamers with skill in the game are left unsatisfied because their is not enough competition in the game. This is where the Steam launch means everything and where players thinking about trying this game should really give it a chance. This game came out in 2011 (Beta) and I started playing early on in 2013, but to many people this game is just now being released. If the player base expanded, with the current opportunities in this game, as well as the improvements PGI has been making in the past year, then this game could become truly great. However, players that have been here since 2011 have lost faith and are a little burnt out with the process. The bottom line if you like big stompy robots, and a thinking man shooter, then Mechwarrior Online is the game for you.My advice is check out the reddit pages, use the mwomerc.com website, watch streamers on Twitch, and try to find a unit in game so you can ask questions. Take this game as a stand alone product and have fun, as someone who plays it everyday I recommend it. See you on the battlefield!

content:

												     >>>>>Good game, Good devs with fairly constant new maps and mechs, Not P2W, Free, Generally good community<<<<<      If your not familiar with battletech/mechwarrior it can be a bit confusing but once you get used to it its fun (the new tutorial is alot better) so be prepared to dedicate a bit of time to getting used to it.      You can pay $$ but its not really pay to win since most "hero" mechs have very similar models available so more pay to shortcut not pay to win, soem mechs are OP but they usually get nerfed relatively quick.     Also realize that its more tank like not one of the games where you have a instant reaction super mech (aka more strategy (battlefield) than twitch (COD)). Very team oriented as a result the solo guys always gonna be the first to die so stay with your lance especially when your first starting out.      Only real issue i have is no that is multiplayer only but hey in terms of mech combat its still the best imo. There were some issues with AMD processors on occasion(Fps spikes/drops(primarily regarding smoke/steam particles))  but they seem to be fixed,

number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												I love MWO. I think it's a great game. Reading negative reviews, i am seeing alot of people saying, "The Devs don't care about the community." I dont get that feel at all. Reading any game, there are always those that think because its a F2P game and they paid in some money, they feel they should get a dev to rock them to sleep everynight. IDK. I can't speak for them but i know every game has neg players like these. All i can say is, its F2P. The game is what it is, and to me it's fun. Recently just installed from Steam to make updating/matching up with friends easier, but I have to have at least 300+ hours in and have been playing since it came out. Took a break for a while and am back. and what i see from that year long break is a ton of new maps, new mechs along with CW, which i have never done. The Devs are always trying to balance mechs. THEY TRY and i see them trying more in the future. Sure your favorite weapon may get nerfed but that's part of the all games. You adapt or try a different mech with different weapons. Even the most severe nerfs still have all weapons still being effective. Plus nerfs and buffs actually can add fun. As of the Dec 2016 patch, machine guns just got a buff and are way awesome. Its fun then to take out that 6 machine gun blackjack and watch it wreck face you know? Victors got some love on the last patch - now you get to see a few victors roaming the bf again. They try guys. That's what i see. Overall it's a good community. I try to give advice to new players that i see sucking horribly. they just not might know that you need to be 90m away from a target when firing a PPC. Or they try and shoot LRMs at targets well out of range (over 1000m). As mentioned in other posts, there is a learning curve. My advice is start with a medium or heavy mech and stick by other players. Dont know where to go? stay with your lance. Dont know what to do? Stay with your lance. Live or die with your lance. and if your lance is full of idiots well...then you learn one way or another right? there are ppl that bark orders sometimes and my experience is, they usually know what they are talking about. Listen to them. Then if you die, you can say, it's that guys fault. ;)

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												I'm an old-school gamer, gaming since I was in my early teens (13-14) and a veteran of MechWarrior 4 (Mercenaries + Vengeance). I played competitive CS and Battlefield most recently at a high level. My usertag back then was "3N3RGY".I have friends from MechWarrior 4 that have been waiting for the newest installment of MechWarrior since 2003. I, myself, and others, literally built PCs (computers) for this game when it was announced. Everyone had VERY high expectations. I played the game in beta and upon release.The game had numerous drama since, and if I talked about it all, I could write a 100 page paper. I'll try to keep it short. I'm stll a bit salty because I feel this game, MWO, has a lower skill-cap than MechWarrior 4, but there are simply NO mech games on the market. Thus, if one is looking for a "mech" fps game, then this is it.I still wish the game implemented suicide options for the mech, crouch ability, active/passive radar ability, and more freedom with movement, as-well as bigger maps and weapons with longer ranges with high skill cap to allow more elite/skilled players to master that have more hours in the game, to show their expertise over more novice gamers. I feel currently with the way the game is setup, a good player can peak at 100hours, and there wouldn't be THAT much difference with someone at 1000hours, but this skill cap just isn't that high (i.e. CS:GO).Anyway, as mentioned before, there are simply no other mech games that compare, thus I have to recommend. I guess I also have immense nostalgia from MechWarrior 4, and I truly have not met, not in Battlefield or Counter-strike or ANY game I played, as many DEDICATED, DIE-HARD battletech fans as you find in MechWarrior. There has been a lot of critiscim on PGI and Russ Bullock, but they have made efforts thus far and I have to support though (Though I am still banned on MWO Forums and they refuse to change my ingame name, "ENERGY").Nevertheless, try the game, love or hate it, it is one of the best if not best mech game on the market currently. I would love to write a more comprehensive review, since the drama around this game has been insane, but instead I recommend new players log-on to HPG outreach on reddit, as it's a very good MWO resource.Energy signing off....

												Although this game does have some flaws and unfufilled promises (like a lot of negative reviews will say, which is sadly ture), I feel it is better than a lot of games on the market--more importantly, the developers are VERY active and patch the game twice a month. Pros:+No velicle tiers: every 'Mech will meet every other 'Mech in a game.+No optical camo system. No more "premium or broke".+NOT pay to win. The game sells newly made 'Mech for cash but eventually they'll be CB (game currency) available. Heroe 'Mechs are just slightly different version of normal ones, they are NOT "better" because they have to follow the same limitations (tonnage, sapce, heat, etc,etc) and basically use the same weapons.+Short but action filled games. Average is 7-10 minutes, great when your time is fragmented.+Depth in both 'Mech customization and gameplay. I played 5000 games and I still have a lot to learn.Cons:-1st person: some of my friends have motion sickness and can't play the game. :(-Acess is somewhat troublesome from places out of North America.-Hard to learn. content:
Posted: February 7
												While I am glad to see the MechWarrior series get a reboot, this game falls seriously short of what people expect from a MW game. First of all is the F2P format. Though great for exposing people to the MechWarrior/Battletech Universe, it makes for a really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ online experience. There are quite a few hackers, as to be expected, since the game offers ZERO hack protection. Secondly, this is still for all intents and purposes a Microstank version of MechWarrior, if only slightly truer to the lore than the MW4 games. Purists (like me) beware. Lastly, it doesn't feel anything like a sim. Try to use a joystick in anything other than the tutorial, and you quickly find yourself at a significant disadvantage due to the game's focus on twitch-shooting with keyboard and mouse.I'll be waiting on MW5:Mercs to come out, which is supposed to feature REAL content and not expensive perks. Although considering it's being developed by PGI, I don't have high hopes.

number of helpful: 14 of 27 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												Alright, where do I start?Also this review is written on 12/21/2015, so some information may change.- F2P -The game is a free-to-play game, so give it a shot. The grind in-game isn't as bad as it used to be. You can now gain in-game currency at a reasonable rate whether you do well or not. There is some content that's locked behind a paywall. There's some stuff you can purchase with the premium currency (MC) and some stuff you can purchase with cash directly from the mwomercs.com website.The premium currency stuff is mostly cosmetics. You can purchase mechs and stuff with the premium currency, but that's a waste. There are some premium only mechs with unique hardpoint configurations.Thankfully, PGI is rather generous, as there are ways to gather the premium currency in-game. As for the direct cash purchase items, they are typical pre-order mechs that'll eventually get released for purchase via the in-game currency. Some of them have special stuff that's exclusive to the purchase, so if you're a sucker for some of those aesthetics, feel free to purchase?- Gameplay -As for the gameplay, its a more tactical shooter, with a simulation game feel. It significantly slower than most shooters in the market, so don't try to play it like those other games. You get to pilot some stompy robots and shoot some lasers, ballistics, missiles and stuff at each other. And you get to fully customize their loadouts and such. It's rather entertaining.There are 4 weight classes of mechs you get to pick from. Lights: Played fast and twitchy. They typically have little armor and weaponry, but they get to run all over and wreck heavier mechs in various situations. If you have a twitch shooter background, playing lights may help you ease into the game. Mediums: Relatively nimble and armed. I recommend playing mediums if you have no clue where to start. They have enough tools to show you the range of what mechs can do. Heavys: Well armored and armed. Heavies are the bread and butter of the team, as they have the mobility and firepower to influence a match greatly. Most players play heavies for that purpose. Assaults: Heavily armored, and armed to the teeth. Playing a assault makes you a walking turret. You're supposed to tank damage and push for your team, as most players will follow you. If you get cold feet or are indecisive, don't play an assault. There's a ridiculous amount of awareness you need to play an assault well.- Learning Curve -The learning curve is steep. There are a ridiculous number of mechanics to keep note of. And a lot of them aren't explained at all in the game. I could type endlessly about it and probably not cover it all. But thankfully, there are various external informational outlets you can find to tell you about those. But for the most part, there's a lot to take in. So don't be intimidated by that fact. Just play and learn from your mistakes. Also, big tip: use the minimap and don't use 3rd-person view.Give the game a shot, its a genre that's been overshadowed, and who doesn't like robots?Also on a side note: PGI has done some shady stuff, so keep note of that if anything seems to be going south.

number of helpful: 15 of 29 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												Dezgra scum! You dare refuse my Batchal?!I've been playing MechWarrior Online since open Beta (August 2013) and the road has been a bumpy one since the original release. Though, it has come a long way in terms of user friendlyness and content. It's at the point between "it could be better" and "just right" for a multiplayer only game.MWO was once only 8 versus 8 deathmatch early in development, then became 12 vs. 12 with team play queue. Now, we have tutorials, ease of 'Mech customization, and Community Warfare (still in Beta, but can participate to gain the highest rewards) with more in production. So, content is slowly being added, but the speed of release can be a turn off to some. There are plans for PvE, co-op, and smaller 4 vs. 4 events in 2016.This is a fun game if you do not take it seriously and would rather role-play a Clammer (Clan pilot) with 11 other drunk, uncoordinated players. The PuG games will make you rage quit if you have a nack for skill and winning, so it is wise to pick up a team or join a faction and use TeamSpeak/Ventrillo to better your chances and reap greater rewards.I recommend this game to any true die-hard MechWarrior fan, as it is the only MW game availalbe (until Hairbrain Scheme's BattleTech in 2017) that has a resemblence of MW4's multiplayer. It's still a decent simulator/shooter despite most of its flaws.MWO is one of those games you can splurge for a month, drop it for a while, and come back and enjoy relearning after some major content patches. It's easy to pick up for the price of free-to-play.However, MWO does suffer from poor optimization with many players crashing and disconnecting at the beginning or mid match, which is another off-putting minus to the game. Especialy, since loosing an Assault in a critical point can make battle exchanges lopsided before they rejoin.I hope to see some of you on the battlefield and as they say: "Die well" (because you will die a lot).

number of helpful: 15 of 29 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												Edit: As people didnt seem to find my review all that useful (9 of 15 as of this edit), lets try to fix that.Slower paced than hawken, much more unforgiving.  This is a thinking man's shooter; if you want to mindlessly kill things without any real skill involved, CoD is probably more up your ally.  Basically, you play a big♥♥♥♥♥stompy robot, loaded for bare and ready to ♥♥♥♥ up the nearest scrub to cross your path.  Think Gundam.  There are 4 mech weight classes in the game, Light, Medium, Heavy, and Assault.  There are many mechs of each weight class, just pick one that fits your playstyle.  Each weight class has a different purpose.  Lights act as nimble scouts/Assault killers/Fire support.  Lights are typically fast moving, highly mobile, low damage mechs.  GOTTA GO FAST!!!!  Mediums act as nimble fire support.  Mediums have a nice balance of weapons and speed to out manouver your enemies while still putting decent fire down range.  Heavies are your fairly hard to kill well armed mechs.  Heavies act as moderately mobile weapon platforms that you dont want to get in front of in a light.  Assaults are your heavily armored slow moving death machines that can kill you in a couple volleys, but get shreaded if a light gets behind them.  Pick a mech and and stick to your team like a sad lost puppy (especially if your buddies are bigger than you, give those ♥♥♥♥ers a hug).  If you're in a light/medium, use your heavy/assault buddies as human shields while plinking the enemies in their weak points (which vary).  Shoot anything that gets near your heavy/assault buddy  If you're in a heavy/assault, pick the nearest/most damaged enemy mech and pull all your triggers (plural ♥♥♥♥ing triggers).  When you shoot, your weapons ganerate heat (IT'S JUST LIKE REAL LIFE!).  Therefore you have to watch your heat generation and not just mindlessly fire your weapons into the abyss, you'll overheat.  Much like a computer when it overheats, you shut-the-♥♥♥♥ down, and damage your internal componets, leaving you vulnerable to enemy fire (as you cant dodge/shield the damage).  So, check yourself before you wreck yourself.  Lasers generate a lot of heat, but have infinite ammo.  Missiles generate moderate heat, but have limited ammo.  Ballistics generate low heat, but have very limited ammo.Credentials:  I'm a veteran player (since beta) and I love this game from a PvP persepctive, it forces team cohesion and team play.  I almost always have a good time, even in defeat.  I have 1749 games on record (quick play games, not CW), given that ever match is about 10 minutes, that's 291 hours on record (just in match time, double/tripple that time if you count the time i've spent in the mechlab and CW). This game used to take a bit of a beefy computer.  Optimization has improved tremendously in the past couple years.  I wasn't able to play much in beta or through initial release due to having a crappy PC, but i got a new computer about a year and a half ago and picked the game back up.  I was amazed by all the improvements made to the game in the time i was away, and I've been playing since.The game has improved EXPONENTIALY since initial release, and it's only getting better since the Steam release.  Give it a shot, it just takes a few minutes and a little bandwith.This game's community is phenominal, if you want to learn something, go check out some of the streamers or youtubers, especially NGNG (No Guts, No Galaxy).  If you have any questions about anything, multiple people will be happy to answer you in detail.  NGNG is the largest group of MWO content producers.  They're all good guys/gals that provide good content/informative content for the community.NGNG YouTube:  https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCfjiF6LH7fxeEoe8u6PONDANGNG Twitch:  http://www.twitch.tv/ngngtv/profileOther Content Creators of interest (Check these dudes out if you're interested): Everyone loves TheB33fTheB33f YouTube:  https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCmxv6LmrmYXZxX0mt-cNQiATheB33f Twitch:  http://www.twitch.tv/the_b33f/profileOther Streamers with Quality content:http://www.twitch.tv/angerbeard/profilehttp://www.twitch.tv/thepanzermagier/profilehttp://www.twitch.tv/watcherrat/profilehttp://www.twitch.tv/escef/profilehttp://www.twitch.tv/z0eff/profileAny one of these content producers will happily help out new or returning players.  They often do charity streams and giveaways as good human beings.If you want mech builds, check out: http://mwo.smurfy-net.de/ There is a ton of info there for building your mechs for success.If lore is your fix, check out the wiki for everything battletech: http://www.sarna.net/wiki/Main_Page Short explanation of some bad reviews:  Lots of the bad reviews come from unfulfilled promised of what the game was supposed to be.  The old publisher IGP (Infinite Game Publishing) was ruining what the devs PGI (Piranha Games Incorporated) was setting out to do.  This caused IGP to see the game as a flop and return the game rights to PGI.  Many of this game's founders and vereran players felt wronged by some of the actions forced upon PGI via IGP.  Since PGI broke away from IGP, the geme has been on an upward spiral in every respect.  IGP was a group of money grubbing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s that wanted a flow of income from the game they had the rights to (to an extreme degree).  Many people are still butthurt over these things.Intense Con:  Mechs are expencive with IRL money, keep in mind, this is a small developer making a very high quality game, and they have to eat too  (plus the Mechwarrior Community is a niche with many whales who will throw money at a develpower willing to make a game in the nearly dead franchise)Potential Pros:  With the influx of new players from the Steam release, prices of things in game (IRL money) may become cheaper due to the larger player base.  PGI has hired many more people to work on the game (i caught this bit of info from on of the devs in a twitch stream chat)The free to play model is actually not too bad, with 16 trial mechs each on rotation (that actually have good loadouts).  Back in beta, and early release, there were only 4 trial mechs with garbage♥♥♥♥♥loadouts.You don't need to put any money into this game to have a good time, but hell, if you find that you're having lots of fun just with the trial mechs, toss $20 at the game, and get a mech or two.  If you enjoyed the game for many hours already, it's probably worth atleast a couple dollars.TL;DR:  New players, give it a shot, it's free.  Old players, give it another shot, it WILL surprise you with all the improvements made since beta.Edit:  I will happily answer any questions if it is not within my review, just leave a comment and i'll do my best to get back to you ASAP (assuming the question is something i can answer).
