content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												Pros: - free to play- easy to learn- not pay 2 win when it comes to playing casually- not hacked to death, unlike most other free shooters- unique, niche simulator, with fast-paced and, at the same time, deeply tactical gameplay- instant access to 16 Trial Mechs (4 different mechs per each of the 4 different mech classes) without having to pay or grind anything. The only downside to these mechs is that you can't customise them, they're all pre-built- new players get massively inflated rewards for their first 25 matches- plenty of diversity in terms of various mech classes, mech types, mech builds (weapons, modules, etc)- team-based game which rewards you for sticking together and helping each other- some maps are huge with varied terrain and plenty of cover, which promotes tactics like flanking- lazorz- lazorzz- lazorzzzCons:- very little gameplay variety: instanced PvP matchmaking across 3 very similar game modes on 18 maps, of which you will usually only play the same few, because people vote for the same ones most of the time- no PvE, no Open World, no real M M O gameplay - unless you count instanced matches for control of planets on a global map- some maps are somewhat linear and so small that you will engage the enemy within 30 seconds after a round starts, and the round will then devolve into head-on barrages with minimum tactical elements- key elements of combined arms from previous Mechwarrior games (and mods) are missing, like being able to pilot Elementals, drive non-mech vehicles, fly aircraft, etc- after your inflated income for the first 25 matches dries up, the game becomes a massive grind for enough in-game currency and XP to fully upgrade and tailor your mech- if you buy a mech and then decide you don't like it and want another one instead, you might as well make a new account- you will have to play hundreds of hours to get properly upgraded mechs to be competitive in Community Warfare, unless you want to buy your way to pimped mechs, which cost dozens (if not more) dollars per unit- some consumables are low-skill and incredibly cheesy, like air strikes and artillery strikesVerdict:9/11 ign

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												MWO is a very teamplay focused 12v12 tactical shooter. Teamwork and good positioning including good use of cover are key to winning. It is free to play and there is no pay to win. Definitely worth to download and give it a try.There is a nice, short ingame tutorial that teaches you how to move and kill stuff. Beyond that there is the mechlab, where you can customize your mechs and adjust their loadout to their playstyle. It's easy to spend more hours in the mechlab than in the matches themselves.In higher tier matches, even the geometry of the mechs and placement of weapons on them become important. The higher the weapon mounts, the less you have to expose yourself from cover to shoot your enemies. In short: There is a lot of depth to the gameplay to explore.The usual MWO Quick Play match lasts for about 10-15 minutes. Faction Play matches last longer, usually about 20-30 minutes. MWO is perfect for one to three hours of gameplay in the evening and a ton of fun. For longer playing sessions, it feels a bit too repetetive, but that's just my personal experience.Quick note for newcomers:If you are new to the game, you should finish the tutorial first and complete the callenges in the Mechwarrior Academy for extra CBills (ingame currency). Try out the different trial mechs available to you in Quick Matches, until you know which kind of mech suits your playstyle best. Once you earned your complete cadet bonus (you get extra CBills in your 25 first Quick Matches), you will have gathered more than enough money to buy your first mech and start to customize it.That's about it. Good hunting mechwarrior!

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												I Beta Tested. I Backed it. I left it a long time ago.It was refreshing abit to come back, but the core issues on the game keep coming back to me on this, and as such - I just cannot reccomend it.There is so much in this that "isn't" how it should feel to me, making this off-putting, at least as it is for this specific game/goal.It is not Mechwarrior. It isn't anywhere close to BattleTech. That much makes the naming only for the looks - but I have to admit, it looks great. Its just not the same in either the lines of the old Mechwarrior games, and the translation of the numbers from BattleTech makes this feel choopy.The gameplay is much the same as it was. It feels "floaty" in a way that can only be described as this is a FPS with a mech-skin. Think Modern Warfare or Call of Duty and the gameplay makes so much more sense.The biggest issue for me is the mechs have no weight. They feel light as a feather, responsive as any twitch-shooter, and as such breaks the immersion of the idea - you forget you are driving 100-ton mechs when the respond like a sports car.That to me is why this doesn't feel right. But that's my feelings on it.The game itself, the way it plays, the intent the devs have put into this is... alright, but its just not how I would think the game should be. It doesn't strike me as Mechwarrior outside the appearance. And that's it.The other major reason I gotta complain? When I backed this in its beta the cost for mechs and parts were reasonable. Cheap, effective - now? Its like pulling teeth through your toenails. They bleed you dry in this Pay 2 Win. And it is P2W. You need to grind for perks, grind for credits, grind for that mech - until you grind to the parts that work and eventually the neigh-broken Clan equip. All the while others are standing on the top of that shooting you back down to the ground.It just doesn't feel right. The MM is dodgy that way, often placing vets against newbies, slanting the games into a slaughtering ground. All and all.. it feels much the same it was back in the day. With a direction that just doesn't feel like it should. Not Great by any means - but also not horrible.So long as you get into it knowing and understanding its P2W, grinding, and its somewhat off-kilter approach to featherweight mechs you'll probably enjoy it - but don't expect much more from it.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												First things first: I'm reviewing this game based on what it its now, not on what happened in the past or what it could have been.Be aware the devs made quite a few mistakes in the past and didn't hit all the goals they set when pitching the game for crowdfunding (which was to be expected, since the goals were quite exorbitant for such a small studio). They made mistakes in their communication with the playerbase. There is a vocal part of the (former) community which is "very" disgruntled over these mistakes (and decisions they didn't like), so take reviews with a grain of salt. When reading reviews or discussions be aware that there are some guys on a crusade to make this game fail. Furthermore many guys are wearing the thickest rose-tinted nostalgia glasses I have ever seen in any game series (regarding previous Mechwarrior games).I'm recommending this game. It isn't perfect, but it is better than many games on the F2P market. Take it for what it is: a tactical, slow paced, vehicle combat arena shooter. As of now, it doesn't have an evolving endgame, but Community Warfare Phase 3 has recently been announced to be released around spring 2016, which looks like it will add long term goals. The game always had balance issues to some extents, but since the last balance overhaul it's the best it has ever been. The devs recently fixed some issues that plagued the game for a long time, and the overall state of the game is better than ever.Pros:- The core gameplay (mech combat) is really good, probably best of any Mechwarrior title- Lots of customization- All mech classes play differently but fun- IT IS NOT P2W- Graphics are above average for a F2P game- You can play this game without ever spending money (mechbays can be obtained in CW)- Devs frequently give away ingame and real money currency through events- Overall a really good communityMixed:- The maps swing between really good and bad- Balance still not where it could be- Game is not easy to learn- It seems to be pretty grindy in the beginning but it gets alot less once you understand the game betterCons:- Community has some self-proclaimed gamedesigners who depreciate all but their own opinion and constantly bash the devs for not designing the game after their (often terrible) ideas- Community Warfare is not where it should be- Prices are pretty high (don't buy at full price, there are plenty of sales)- Game is not optimized well (hardware)- The 3 gamemodes in quickplay play pretty similarVerdict:Try it, it's free. If you are looking for rock solid mech combat, this is your game.  You currently won't find a better one. Don't decide based on reviews, give it a shot. Ps: Don't buy stuff without reading a guide or asking the forum. You "really" don't want to waste  your cadet bonus on things you don't need.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
A game that could be great held back by a terrible developer.Short version first:I had played this game during closed beta and for roughly 2 years after that. I stopped playing just after the release of the Clan mechs. I was disgusted with the developers choices and behavior. This made me and my friends decide to stop playing entirely. The game could be good but the developer holds it back.ProsIt's a new Mechwarrior game.The controls are pretty good.Deep and rewarding customization.Combat can be pretty rewarding.Team play can also be rewarding.Deep backstory.ConsThe developer.Long delays in changes, balance, and content releases.Many lies about release dates and pay to win elements.Convoluted and sometimes frustrating game systems (Heat Scale is the big one here)Did I forget to mention the developer?Bait and switch sale tactics for content releases.Balance, but this is typical in a game with such freedom and inherently built-in unbalance in the original game this is based on.Russ Bullock, Paul Innouye (Trained by Nexon), and Bryan Eckman.The grind is beyond ridiculous last I played.Oh and finally, the Developer.Seriously, these guys made Navy SEALS: Weapons of Mass Destruction.Now for the long version.Through a glitch in the developer's website I got an invite into the closed beta. The game was much simpler then and was actually pretty fun. I told my friends about the game, got them into the open beta, and we had a lot of fun. Then they started adding in some missing gameplay elements and we started to see how the developer was going to handle introducing systems and balancing. As timed passed we've played through an LRMpocalypse, Squawkalypse, ECMalypse, Splat-cats, Poptartpocalypse, and the Return of the LRMpocalypse: The Quirkening. We played through all of this. All during this time it seemed as if the developer that was creating these new systems were not the original developer of the game.Once Clans were released ($500 for a gold-plated one) is when we really saw the developer's true colors. You could not purchase the 'Mechs in game unless you spent money. They were quite a bit more powerful than the regular IS 'Mechs (they technically were supposed to be...). This forced you into a terrible situation where you were playing with IS 'Mechs and losing often or spend money and winning 90% of the time. All of us gave up on the game shortly after this. We've watched the descent of the game's population ever since.The grind, last I played, was particularly awful. It required many days of consistently good matches to be able to afford a single new chassis with no upgrades. You also could not test-drive them. If you choose the wrong one, you were out the money... no refunds.I mean, I really like Mechwarrior and Battletech. I used to have a spinning wireframe Timberwolf from Mechwarrior 2 as my Avatar. I really wanted to like this game... but, after ~2 years of abuse from the developer I just couldn't take it anymore.tl;drI do not recommend this game, especially if "[you're] on a bit of on an island".

												I've already logged thousands of hours in this game before the steam release.I have only two gripes about it.1st gripe is, invisible corners and or walls.  You can obviously clear a corner, enough to make a shot and you end up hitting an inviso wall.2nd gripe is, when you run into someone, sometimes it glitches out and you teleport behind them or to the side, or just get stuck for a moment.  This is more noticeable in a light mech, and it really screws with you when you are trying to circle a bigger mech.  All to often has someone back into me when im shooting their back only to find my self glitched infront of them all of sudden enabling them to get a kill shot on me.Those 2 gripes im pritty sure its just bad physics bugs or bad coding, would really like to see those 2 cons patched ASAP.Other than that the game is puuurfect.  You can seriously waste alot of time on this, and it can quickly turn into a sport for you.  And thats exactly what this game is, an E-Sport, this is not a little kids game, this is full on mech battle simulation.  You are a Pilot when you log in.  Learn to pay attention to the letter of the alphabet thats on top of your enemy, because people will be calling targets by those letters, example - Target A will be called "Alpha" focus fire on alpha, beta, charlie, ect.  Learn to read and navigate the minimap/radar properly , those numbered squares are coordinates that will be called out to move to, to watch for flanks, or to attack.  Be prepared to strap in and learn millitary lingo lol..   ENEMY SIGHTED IN CHARLIE FOUR, FOCUS TARGET ALPHA!!

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												I've been playing on-and-off since Closed Beta, with most of my time played after the original publisher (IGP) departed.I'm not going to touch on the history of the game, nor its previous states. If anyone out there hates PGI or this game for its history, I think their opinions are valid but I'd like to focus my review on what the game is here and now.Mechwarrior Online is a game about piloting giant walking tanks.As far as these things go, this is the best on the market. The initial learning curve can be pretty steep, but once you get your bearings this game provides an experience like no other. Half of the game is customization; swapping out weaponry and equipment on your massive death machine. The other half is tearing other players' mechs apart; shearing off limbs and blasting holes in their torsos.This is a game where your hitboxes, health, and loadout all go hand-in-hand. You might be missing your entire left half, about to die from one more shot to the chest, but still have armor on your right arm. Many times victory will hinge on your ability to shield your critical components just long enough to get one more shot at the enemy. This game truly shines when both sides are locked in this desperate struggle, trying to mitigate incoming damage while simultaneously finding moments to strike.There's nothing quite so satisfying as firing the massive, deafening AC20 and watching an enemy mech rock with the impact. No other game makes me laugh with such maniacal glee, as my 100-ton Atlas obliterates an enemy with a cluster of short-range missiles. Nothing gets my heart racing quite like speeding around the map in a light mech, scouting the enemy team's location and harassing mechs several times my size.I couldn't possibly hope to cover all the tactical elements or loadout considerations in this review. What I can tell you is that all the research pays off. The more time you invest in looking up strategies, loadouts and mech roles, the better you will perform and the more fun you will have. You'll learn which mechs to fear, and the range of their most likely loadouts. You'll learn where to shoot each mech to most efficiently disable or destroy them. You'll learn the best way to play to your mechs' strengths, and the result will be a game that keeps your mind racing as you work to counter each new enemy.This is a game I can't recommend enough. Nothing feels quite as cool as becoming a Mechwarrior.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												"The Thinking Man's FPS"TL;DR Big mechs shoot each other in a rich setting and beautiful maps with a focus on tactics and customization and teamwork.I've heard this game called that from the community as I've played and I must say it is very accurate. There is a LOT going on in a typical match for MWO. Constantly knowing where my allies are moving, keeping an eye on the Assaults (the slow behemoths) to make sure we don't leave them behind, scanning the targets that the lights (the small speedy ones) are scouting, and always monitoring heat while being under fire by the enemy team. It is exhilarating!Mechwarrior Online is set in the Battletech universe that has a ton of history and lore to back up the mechs in the game. While this game is less canon and more action, it is a still a great place for lovers of the setting to get their fix. The lore is unimportant to gameplay, so there is nothing stopping a complete newcomer to the game to feel left out.This is a game about tactics. You choose your mech from a starting roster of trial mechs after a tutorial that just BARELY gets you ready to dive into the deep ocean that is MWO. There are four "weight" classes: Light, Medium, Heavy, and Assault. Upon first look, it appears to be a rock, paper, scissors type of scenario, but that is entirely not the case. This game offers a ton of customization to certain mechs (which are available in two separate "makes" that are similar to factions) so that your assault can run with the heavies, or allow your light to carry more firepower than some Heavy mechs. It can be tough to pick a mech in the start and there is no right or wrong mech, but after a good game and some quick deaths, one quickly learns the pros and cons of each class.As I mentioned before, there are two "factions" that really only shine in the Community Warfare gamemode, which puts the player in a mercenary position accepting contracts from one of the separate factions in the game. Otherwise, a mech's faction has no real difference besides the level of customization. Mechs can be outfitted with weapons based on the "hardpoints" found on the frame. For instance, an arm could allow three energy weapons while the right torso could allow a ballistic and a missile. Mechs must be build around what is allowed by the hardpoints and weight limit while keeping survivability in the amount of armor and heat management that the build will allow.The Inner Spere mechs (IS) are special in that they allow one to customize engines, jump jets, and a host of weapon customizations. However, the IS mechs have special "quirks" that allow them to really shine with a certain weapon type that should be taken into consideration. This allows the IS mechs to be specialized to a certain blend of combat and makes for each mech to be slightly different from another mech of the same build but on a different frame. The Clan mechs are a different beast entirely. While the IS mechs can change engines and loadouts, the Clan mechs cannot change the default engines or jumpjets in their mechs. They do allow one to swap out pieces called omnipods that change the hardpoints on a certain piece of the mech to allow for greater variety in weapon loadouts.This game has a great community with a nice dry humor while at the same time being very competitive. From my time with this game, salt and toxicity has always been rare, something that I contribute to the personality that is drawn to the lore and gameplay. Being a free game, there is an incentive to buy mechs with cash to gain early access, but every mech in the game has a variant that can be purchased with in game currencies. There are also "hero" and "champion" variants to most mechs that give a boost to mech xp or in game currency rates, but they don't feel necessary. If you enjoy the game, the grind will be something you enjoy and not a burden. The only cash item that is "mandatory" or addition mech bays that allow you to own additional mechs. These are occasionally given away during events, but mostly will need to be purchased.In the end, I recommend this game to anyone who considers the RTS style games enjoyable and to anyone familiar with Battletech in general. It is a fun game and a great way to spend an evening.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												I work full time, and play a lot of mechwarrior, so I don't have time for a big review, but here's the gist of it:Come in with no expectations, and be very happy. It's pretty much like getting to play multiplayer mechwarrior of old. The effects are cool, the graphics are okay, the gameplay is slightly different but still about shooting lasers, autocannons, and missiles at enemies and blowing off their limbs.However, I have never seen such visceral hate for the developer as I have in this game. Everyone who plays routinely poops all over PGI (the developers). I understand the REASON people are mad. The mechanics are so solid in this game, that it's just BEGGING for some cool stuff. Cooperative missions, single player campaign, more multiplayer modes, really cool base sieges and destructable buildings. Those would all be really, really great. And yes, the developer talks about how those are going to be in the game, and yes, they are not in the game yet. Should that equal anger and a vicious attitude to the development staff? I guess that's up to you to decide.As for me... I still play for a few hours every day, so I can't complain. It's a good game, and it's a mechwarrior game. See you on the battlefield.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												Grew up with BattleTech and the MechWarrior series, so my opinion might be a little biased, but I love this game. F2P isn't the easiest thing to balance apparently, but I think they did a good job here.There will be grinding if you want diversity and mastered mechs (you need to obtain 3 of a chassis and grab tons of XP to get this) - not to mention the pilot skills which require an XP hit to unlock AND a C-Bill hit to purchase.New mechs are coming out all the time and the devs are pretty good about releasing new maps and/or upgrading the older ones. You've gotta pay to get into the new mechs when they're released, but eventually they become available for either MC (premium currency) or C-Bills (grind money).It's free, so you should try it out. Read up on some lore, too - BattleTech's is pretty awesome. :] And if you do end up playing, don't feel bad when you inevitably spend the $20 to get some new mechs + early adopter rewards. The devs gotta eat!

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												I've been playing this game since beta.At first, I was somewhat hesitant about MWO. You see, I’m not all that into PvP games. And, when I learned that MWO was all PvP, I really wasn’t interested at first. But, the lure of Big Stompy Robots eventually dragged me into trying it.So, there I was grinding out my twenty five cadet bonus matches in a Trial JM-6 Jagermech. My first mech purchase was a Blackjack as they were first released. I realized that this was a different kind of PvP game- it was slower, the concept of walking tanks did a good job of mitigating the twitch play that I didn’t like. Sure there was still twitch play with light mechs, but it was still a little slower and methodical that other FPS games I played.Now, a few years (and a bunch of mech packs) later, I find I truly do love this game.What I like most about this game, compared to other tank games, is the method in which you get your vehicles. See, in other tank games, you have to contend with tech/progression trees- forcing you to drive or fly equipment you don’t like in order to work your way into gear that you do.Not so with this game. If I want to drive a Timberwolf, I can either grind the CBills to get them, buy the MC to get it or buy it straight away from the gift store. Can’t do that with an M1 Abrams, German Tiger or P-51.I love how customizable the game is. Much of the fun of the game is spending time in the mechlab finding that perfect build that synergizes my playstyle with the mechs quirks and hardpoint arrangement. See not all build fit all, some build that work great for one guy may not work so well for other. But, finding that great build that works for you is truly satisfying.Another thing I love about this game is the regular events that PGI holds. Grab bag events, Leaderboard events, Faction play events and Cumulative stretch goal events, there’s always something going on.There’s a lot of good stuff on the horizon for this game-The fabled Unseens are being released on a monthly basis as we speak.  If you’re a Battletech aficionado, you can truly appreciate the return of these classics.PvE is coming; we already see glimpses of PvE in the Mechwarrior Academy.A large update is coming to Faction Warfare that will appeal to small groups (4v4) as well as large.If you’re new to the game, do check out the Spike Brave tutorials on youtube. Also, play the Mechwarrior Academy, play it a lot, play it some more. The Mechwarrior Acandemy is a great resource.Give the game its fair shake, just like I did, and I think you will be impressed with it, just like I am.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												TL;DR - It's not perfect, but it's my perfect.First off, my credentials to write this review: I've been a fan of Battletech and Mech based games and shows in general since I first picked up MechAssault for the Xbox around 12 years ago and shortly thereafter fell in love with the MechCommander games for PC and have been a giant stompy robot lover since.  I've also purchased every top package for MechWarrior Online from Legendary Founders through the latest unseen mechs and have probably sunk about 300+ hours of play time into this title before the steam launch and have been playing since beta.  Ok, on to the review: MechWarrior Online has had it's rough points in the past and it's still not entiely perfect.  The graphics aren't mind blowing.  The in game music basically has to be supplied by you running an old mechwarrior OST in the background.  The camos and paints are overpriced.  The cockpit items are cheesy and borerline immersion breaking.  The UI is inherently flawed.  The gameplay can be repetitive on certain maps.  The default keys and some of the game options are questionable.  Some of the warhorns can be headache inducing.  And the power level difference from a new mech to a "mastered" mech with modules and a custom build is a vast bottomless chasm.  However, it is fun.  The community is fantastic.  The in game chat is professional.  The devs do listen and are trying.  The redone maps are fantastic.  The selection of mechs is excellent.  The weapon and chassis balance is a lot better than it used to be.  The customisation is awesome.  The gameplay is tactical and skill based.  And finally the feeling you get from coring a mech with your last salvo while limping and with only one arm barely hanging on is unparalleled.  I have experienced some of my favourite gaming memories from this title and I don't regret a moment of it.  I have no doubt there are both positive and negative points about this title that I've failed to mention, hell, there's probably things I have never encountered having not played through the "new player" or f2p experience.  But I've had fun with it and if you're a fan of Battletech or of giant stompy robots in general then I'm sure you will too.  One more thing, if you're just getting into the game here are some basic tips:  Fight from the cockpit, unlock your arms, torso twist when you're reloading, use double heat sinks, assign left click = left arm, right click = right arm, side mouse buttons = torso weapons, press R to lock target, remap shift to full zoom, set your FOV to 0.75, concentrate fire, stick with the team and watch your heat.  With that all said, I hope you found this at least a little informative and it helps you out with deciding whether or not this is the game for you.  Good luck, Mechwarriors.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												Firstly, this game is not a Pay to Win. For more info, scroll down to the micro-transactions section.Mechwarrior Online is a game that (despite my hours on it so far via Steam) I have played since its open beta and friends I play with have played it since closed beta. In reality, I have around 1000 hours (maybe more, maybe less) on the game before its launch on Steam.This game has been a rollercoaster of ups and downs as well as a game that has seen huge changes. If you were to compare the open beta and my first match with the way the game is today, it is almost completely different.If you are looking for an honest review from an experienced mechwarrior fan (fan of the original battletech board games and of the older mechwarrior games) then look no further.------ GRAPHICS ------9/10The graphics for this game have always been on point, however at times this can cause PC problems if you do not have a decent setup. It is a graphically demanding game, make no mistake. The grahpics have seen huge improvements to not only how they look but their impact on the game.  The first wave of graphical overhauls saw outrage in the community due to the bugs and lag they caused (due to the high polygon count of the textures). This has been fixed for the most part but it is still demanding on the graphics side of things. I would recommend a GTX 650 (or AMD equivalent) or above for this kind of game if good graphics are a must for you.------ MOVEMENT/DISPLAY MECHANICS ------8/10The movement mechanics of this game are complex and different from most shooters. If you are not familiar with how to steer tanks and similar vehicles in other games, then it may be tricky to begin with. Mechs essentially work like tanks in this game in that your control the lower half of the mech with WASD and you control the upper half of your mech with your mouse. In terms of jumpjets (built in jetpack devices for some mechs, to allow them some extra movement options) are a keyboard feature. The mouse is simply for aiming with. There are also two view modes in the game: 3rd and 1st person. However you will need to know that you will be easier to see in 3rd person from the enemy's perspective. Due to 3rd person being enabled by a drone that hovers just above your mech, the enemy can see this and locate you with more ease.For both 1st and 3rd person, the crosshair is fluid and easily seen in every environment in the game.TIP: You may want to disable arm locking, as this will lock your arm movement with your torso movement - rectricting your firing arc.------ MECH BUILDING MECHANICS ------10/10The mech building mechanics of the game are like no other game I have played. For older fans of mechwarrior, this game replicates the older games (and the board games). For the newer fans, the cusomization can be confusing at first (especially with the UI) but with practice as well as the tutorials, you will get the hang of it.In this game you are able to customize the following:- Armour (for specific parts of your mech, i.e legs, arms, torso etc.)- Weapon Systems (lasers, cannons, machine guns, rockets etc.)- Engine Size (more powerful engines = faster mech) (XL engines are lighter however span across more of your mech, however they make you more vulnerable to being destroyed.)- Heat Sinks (for cooling systems)- Ammo Types- ECM (radar cloaking device), BAP (probe for countering ECM)- Jump Jets- Camo patterns (paint, colours etc. - however cosmetics cost money)And other equipment (too much to list everything)There are also four main types of mech:- Light Mech, main roles include Scouting, Locking Targets, Capturing Bases and support of heavier mechs. (really fast, really weak armour, low DPS)- Medium Mechs, main roles include support of heavier mechs, targeting light mechs, supporting light mechs. (moderately fast, average armour, average DPS)- Heavy Mechs, main roles include support of assault mechs, targeting medium mechs, dealing damage. (slow, above average armour, above average DPS)- Assult Mechs, main roles include leading a front of mechs, absorbing damage, dealing damage, need to be supported. (very slow, heavy armour, high DPS)There are two main categories of mech:- Inner Sphere- Clan MechsInner sphere clan mechs tend to be more robust whereas clan mechs can be brittle in comparison (depending on the mech). However Clan mechs have more powerful weaponry compared to Inner sphere. That said, Clan mechs tend to be the more favoured of the two but I am an Inner Sphere, light mech pilot.In terms of the mechs themselves, Inner sphere tend to have better light mechs and the clans tend to have better assult mechs. The heavies and mediums being around the same.The best part of all this is that it is true to the lore.------ MICROTRANSACTIONS ------5/10The microtransations are soemthing that have always been argued about since the game's launch. Most of the cosmetic features will require you to spend real money. To own a vast collection of mechs, you need mech bays - which cost money (however you get four free mech bays to start out). Some mechs can only be bought with real money, however these mechs do not give you any advantage in a fight - they just provide you with better bonuses (such as more in game money and more XP). You can also purchase mech packages, for a collection of new mechs that come with mech bays.This game is NOT A PAY TO WIN.If you decide to spend money on this FREE game, you will simply skip the grind of saving in game money to buy your own mechs. I have played well over 1000 hours before it went onto Steam and only spent money on a few more mech bays and one mech.THERE IS NO DLC.All the maps and extra content added to the game are not DLC packs, they are added to the core game. The mechs added to the game will always have varients you can buy with in game cash. Generally, new mechs are released and for the first few months you can only aquire them via real money. After these few months, in game money varients are released for you to buy.------ ADVANCEMENT ------7/10The game's grinding system can be tedious after a while but is not as long as some other games I have played (such as RPG MMOs). The grind will not be really easy but it is not so bad that you cannot get anywhere - it just takes a little time. You can put money in to skip this grind but it usually does not take long to earn enough in game money for your first mech.The only downside is the mech bays, as you only start with four.------ SERVERS ------8/10The servers are generally quite good and do not suffer lag now as much as they did. They have dedicated servers in the EU, US and in Oceania. Meaning no matter where you are in the world, there will be a server with a decent latency for your to join. You can switch where you are playing via the main hub screen.------ USER INTERFACE ------6/10The user interface is a part of the game that has seen massive changes. In my own opinion, the oldest UI and original UI was the best in terms of layout as it was not complex or confusing. However the new UI is more fluid, is nt as buggy as the older UI at the cost that it is more complex than the old UI.If you are a new player, it can be confusing at first but not too bad to get the hang of. If you are a returning player, it will be like a different game.------ MAPS/ENVIRONMENTS ------In the beginning, the maps were few but the quality was high. As time went on more maps were added into the map pools and (you'll be pleased to know, they do not require additonal DLC). With the advancement in graphical technology in computing and gaming in general, the older maps have been reimagined and re-released with an even higher quality than before. You'll find yourself fighting on desert planet mech scrapyyards to swampy, steamy bogs and on moon bases in outer space.I ran outta space, GG steam!

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Giant stompy robots. What more do you need?Fair warning: the new player learning curve in this game is steep. Like 90 degree steep. Do yourself a favor and DO THE TUTORIALS. Run them until you're very familiar with how to handle yourself. You don't want to start a match off and get stuck running into a wall, getting you butt shott off, because you don't know to move your legs independantly from your torso. Once you've mastered the basics then hop in and get ready to be shot up to pieces. You're probably going to lose right away - or at least get blasted pretty quick. Like I said, the learning curve is a wall. But if you can push through your initial deathfest and learn a few things in the process you might just have what it takes to start racking up the kills yourself.This game is also F2P, and as far as free-to-play games go this one is pretty forgiving. The ONLY things you cannot purchase with game-grinded monies are additional mech bays (you start with 4), and Hero Mechs (honestly, nothing special. Just different varients of a chassis, none of which are amazing.) However, between monthly (or bi-monthly) events, contests, competitions and whatnot you can earn premium moneyz to buy those things, or earn them outright. So yeah. It's pretty forgiving.That all said, I've spent over $200 on this "free" game. FML.

												Mechwarrior Online has been a regularly played game of mine for 3 1/2 years now.  I enjoy it because the mech customization and uniqueness is very good and that translates into many different potential play-styles. I recommend this game if you prefer a more tactical, unit-based shooter where you generally must work together with others to be most effective.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												"Who is Piranha Games?"8 out of 10 Tell your friends Mechwarrior Online is live!-----Skip the first two paragraphs if you just want to learn about the game play.When I first tried it in 2013 I felt a nostalgic tug for the game Mechwarrior 2: Mercenaries that I used to play. I lost interest for reasons. But I do recall the game felt like it was missing a lot of mechs.A year later I turned the game back on and found the developers, Piranha Games, has been busy adding content and even a whole new series of game play modes related to the Inner Sphere and Clan factions and taking place on a star map of the inner sphere. If you're a fan of the Mechwarrior games you'll like MWO. It turns out Piranha Games has been busy on MWO since 2011!If you're not a seasoned Mechwarrior expect a steep learning curve, the game is very strategic. Then expect long periods of learning. One fast huge tip -- Don't sell anything ... keep all the stuff you get because you'll want it later. Just keep increasing your C-bill worth. Every piece of equipment is c-bills you dont need to spend later for a laser and can go to a new mech chassis. If you save up and buy a mech, don't sell it, or the parts that came with it. It will really pay off after you own your first few mechs and want to change them up a bit. The game itself is a multiplayer Omnimech, Battlemech, Mechwarrior 12v12 (first person or third) with 2 modes, Quickplay and Clan Warfare. There are three game types for Quickplay mode. Skirmish, a team battle - last mech standing. Conquest, there are multiple points on the map which teams must capture to earn victory points. Assault, when the teams can capture a single base to win the game. In any Mechwarrior Online match the game is won when all enemies have been killed.The second gameplay mode is Clan Warfare. This mode puts the mechwarrior in the front seat of a battle on a galactic scale. Incorporating a star map of the inner sphere, players can battle to gain territory or defend what they have. Players must choose allegiance to a faction (Innersphere houses or Clan). The mechs you can select and play in Clan Warfare mode depend on your faction. For Clan factions, only clan mechs will be available, same for IS factions. Players can then select the star planet they wish to attack (or defend). Depending on the status of the contested planet different game scenarios can play out. Players might find themselves "Holding ground" on a recently conquered enemy territory, in this case an attack mission has become a defense mission. Eventually, if your faction persists and succeeds, the planet will be converted to your faction's territory. The starmap changes over time as different factions gain/lose territory.Add up to twelve of your friends to a unit and smash the opposition. This game features automatic matchmaking and in-game voice communication on par with other popular games. The game has a great "Play for Free" model. You can become a powerful and rich mechwarrior with out spending money and eventually will unlock items that cost money for free in special events held frequently.EDIT---------September 15, 2016After having this game on my computer for years and now steam for almost a year, I have to say, it is on the list of my favorite games. Coming back to it and comparing it to when I started playing in 2013 isn't even fair. This has become a whole new game, better, faster, more versatile -- more fun! This is the Mechwarrior game you've been dreaming of since the late 90's.

												Definitely a good game to get into if you're into Mech combat. While not exactly a fast pace game, there are moments of all out slug fests when head to head engagement over a point become inevitable. This game comes in second place just under Mech Warrior: Living Legends mod, only because that mod allowed the use of air units and tanks along side mechs. There is the issue of expensive mechs, and I agree the prices for them are pretty steep and the grind for them is tedious. However when it comes to mechs it isn't about having many, but mastering the one you own. A light mech can just as easily out manuever and harrass the heavy tonnage mechs. Though the risk is there for being outright killed if they get a shot on you. They do a good job at immersing you into a battle as well, with game rounds starting with your pilot doing a systems check in a drop pod into a battlefield.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												I, personally, love this game. Take a look at that word there, "personally".I say that because this game isn't for everyone. It's not CoD, it's not Battlefield, it's not even Hawken. It's a robot simulator with 30+ years of Lore, books, and other games behind it. It's slow, it's grindy (when leveling up new mechs, when you choose to do that), it's got it's own share of problems constantly popping up, or constantly being fixed and hammered out.Don't come in to MW:O looking for your next singleplayer robot game, or come in expecting to kill everyone forever, or expecting your robots to fly around the maps while doing backflips.Come into this game looking for a unique, fun, slower paced game. Come into MW:O looking for kick♥♥♥♥♥robot battles, missiles flying overhead, lasers everywhere. Come for the giant land-slide games where you and your team crushes 12 other robots into the ground with giant guns... stay for the games that drag on. Stay for the games that come down to the wire, with a panicking Light mech falling apart while darting around the map to spot the last few guys on the other team, so your last few nearly-exploded friendly mechs don't walk into a trap. Stay for the games where you're the last-mech-standing on your team, going full Rambo on the last lance of enemy mechs.Yes, the game has its flaws, but it's a free-2-play game that's actually fair and paying money gives no in-combat advantage. Give it a try, just understand this isn't your average robot shoot-em-up.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												QUICK REVIEW:If you're looking for a fast paced FPS mech shooter this isn't the game for you. STOP READING If you enjoy teamwork and stratagy focused game with some simulation elements this is the game you been looking for! Cont. reading...It's a great fun game once you grasp it! I've played it off and on for 3 years. It requires good communication, situational awareness, and methodical thinking. ADVICE:My advice use the tutorial and practice in the Mech Academy and the Mech Lab for the first few days. Look at the controls and button mappings. Try out different Trial Mechs BEFORE YOU BLOW YOUR CADET AND TRAINING BONUS! Think of your play style check out the guides on YouTube, in the forums, and here http://mwomercs.com/game then buy and build your mech. The game does have grind that is curved by spending money after all it is the F2P model. But if you follow the advice above the grind won't be so bad because you didn't jump the gun and buy the wrong mech before you found your play style. PROS/CONS:Pros:-Solid gameplay -Robots-3D cockpits -Customization -Hard Working Dev Team-Continually updated product-Never ending updated mech roster coming to the game Cons:-Steep learning curve-Not as new player friendly -Lacks Campaign / Co-OpINFORMATION YOU SHOULD KNOW:Features to being worked on / added:-Comunity Warfare phase 3-Single / Co-Op Campaign -Decal mech customization -More balance passes (these won't ever stop) -VR HTC Vibe and Oculus Rift support -Map and model updates and makeovers (Ongoning process) -Dynamic Weather in gameThings being considered TBD:-CryEngine Update and DX12-Collisions (Knockdowns / Physics)

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												I've loved MechWarrior ever since MechWarrior 2 back in the day. MWO improves much of the gameplay aspects (espectially the multiplayer balance) over the past games, and despite other big name shooters - Titanfall, Battlefield, Battlefront - I still come back to MWO. There is no other equivalent to customizing your mech, taking into account each chassis' quirks, weapon types and equipment, and having that all play out in real time during a match. For instance, did you store ammo in your leg? Well, if someone strips your leg armor, there's a chance that the ammo will explode and take your leg with it. How about a heat sink instead? On certain maps, there are large pools of water; submerging your legs in them will make those heat sinks work more efficiently. On top of all this, you can pick your opponents apart piece by piece; or opt to try and core them out and take them down as quickly as possible.Now, the drawbacks: Visually, the mech designs are awesome (and by far the best this franchise has seen). However, the actual art direction (coloring, textures, map design) are only just adequate. Colors are often over-saturated, bloom is used too much, and texture resolution is hit and miss (mostly due to the complexity of having so many patterns and giant vehicles to cover, which can wreak havoc on install size if not toned down). The other drawback is the lack of a single-player component, which is probably my favorite part of the series. The devs have it as a future goal (and have started to implement AI) but it will likely be a year before we see the beginnings of that coming to fruition.Overall, I've sunk more hours into this game than any other in recent memory, so if you've got a stompy robot addiction like me, then this should provide your fix. Plus it's free and has no equivalent to 'gold ammo' or other pay2win mechanics (hero mechs generally range from terrible to just ok, anyway) so there's no hurt in giving it a try. Just be sure to go through the Mechwarrior Academy training mode first.

number of helpful: 19 of 38 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Ladies & Gentlemen, boys & girls.  - This here isn't your average run of the mill game, and the amount of hatred & white-knighting is immense, when it comes to this game. - Where does the great divide stem from?- The Former Publisher IGP's calls of pushing PGI around. Right after IGP left the scene and PGI took over as a Publisher... everything changed. - Within 6 months, Community Warfare Beta Phase 1 was released. By now, in around two years PGI has took the 'nigh toxic community by the horns. Cleared the air, voiced concerns & opinions. This sounds more like a company that loves its community, instead of whines for more money, like it originally was.- Was I about to abandon ship when IGP was around? I seriously was. I would be raging here with the negative feedbacks along with the rest of 'em.After PGI bought the publishing rights from IGP, everything changed:PGI is fixing the game, a milestone at a time, and thus far... it has delivered. +100 mechs & variants, and they all feel different. - This alone, is quite a feat to accomplish. The core of the game is 'nigh rock-solid. Extra content is on its way for 2016 to bring first vehicles for the game as well.***Everything in the game can be bought with in-game money, including basic colors.- Events are held where you can get free Mech Bays.- Anything that you can buy with money, won't give you an advantage.- Grinding is a lot smaller in part in comparison to most f2p games, though getting C-Bills(in game currency) fast is mostly up to your pilot talent.- What is in major part is the simulation, and finding the right role for your talents.Best community in TS Servers I've thus far met. Also, the most mature & the most aged in general.- This isn't for those energy drink whopping, twitch shooter friends who crave for their next fix.This is for us, who require a blend of wisdom/tactical thinking, and strategy, while commandeering a role that will either make the team, or break the team.- Teamplay is the key word, so think wisely... This game is unlike any other simulator out there. Keep a cool hat and see only after 25 matches how things go. 5-10 rounds won't get you nowhere(you just might thank me later).There's also a lot of great youtube videos out there to help you get acquinted with various roles, weight classes & "How To Build Your Mech" kind of schematics.And one more thing: www.sarna.net ||| Use the Search, this is your IMDB of Mechs & Battletech history, including weaponry & what they are primarily used for.

number of helpful: 14 of 28 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Hello everybody. I write this review as a fan of Battletech, MechWarrior in particular, and as an MWO player since late closed beta. According to the stats page of the game, I have spent 205 hours in-matches. Note that this does not include Community Warfare matches which should be roughly another 30 hours and tinkering with mechs inside the mechlab or one of the many player-made mechlabs available on the web. The money invested into this F2P title is around 70 dollars which includes the Hunchback IIC package (40$) and a few other MC (MechWarrior Credits, the IRL money currency in-game) transactions for hero mechs, premium time and colors. I primarily play as a Heavy pilot, with a few choice Assault and Medium mechs. I am also a Tier 2 rating, so I like to think I have an O.K. understanding of the game and it’s Meta. All these things may have colored my perception of the game and the experience it offers.The Good:-Unique gameplay that seems to be underrepresented in today’s market-Vastly improved controls over its predecessors-Complex and meaningful customisation (MechLab)-A mostly mature community that is supportive and enjoys explaining their passion about stompy robots-A great selection of mechs with varied play styles. This game has so many of them, there will be one for you. During the writing of this review 12/9/2015, most mechs are in a good spot with some underpowered exceptions.  The most recent balance patch was on 12/1/2015 so the new meta has yet to solidify.The Neutral:-Starting Trial mechs are a mixed bag. Try all of them-Steep learning curve-Lacking in-depth tutorial about most important part of the game (MechLab and Mech Customisation)-Runs on CryEngine and has performance issues on weak CPU’s. Recommend lowering “Particle” setting-A fair selection of maps, but could use more. Maps also vary in quality-Owning 4 mechs of each chassis allows you to “Elite” your pilot with the chassis, used to grant you considerable buffs. Those buffs were since nerfed hard, but are still noticeable. Investing in a mech chassis you enjoy is still recommended and somewhat expensive- Mech Upgrades are expensive, required for competitive play and are NOT factored in the initial mech buy price (hidden costs). Same goes for different engines ratings or engine types. It may look like Light Mechs are the cheapest but a competitive Light Mech can run you the price of a Competitive Assault Mech (hidden costs)-All new mechs release in a Pre-Order Pack model, where the mech becomes available for those who pre-order, a month later it releases of MC and a month later for in-game CBills-Community Warfare technically no entry requirement, but having 4 custom mechs is highly recommended-Performance based economy. As in any game, you probably won’t be amazing at it right away. The game can be somewhat grindy between your first and second mech. However, once you perform well consistently, the money will be flowing in.-Controversy around developer and their practises-Community Warfare lacks a matchmaker. It’s considered the “hard core” mode where people play with their units!The Bad:-Limited base game modes .Quick Play only has TDM with a base, pure TDM or Conquest. Community Warfare features an asymmetrical Attack/Defend mode with turrets and dropships that let you deploy up to 4 of you mechs (Each mech acts a as a life) as well as a TDM mode where the invader team defends the destroyed base from a counter attack. That’s it until a new “scouting” mode drops sometime next month.-Signature game mode Community Warfare has low population on off-hours and work days (This may change with steam release)-Somewhat slow development rate on big features. However, there are 2 patches per month and fast hot fixes (even on weekends).-Hit or miss balance patches-Minefield of an in-game store. Somewhat expensive too! Please research a Hero Mech before purchasing, not all of them are good!Overall, the game is solid enough to warrant a download. Most importantly, even if I find it somewhat stale nowadays, it has a way of being FUN. Try it out, but it’s not for everybody. Look up some of the excellent player guides and resources.I recommend visiting www.reddit.com/r/outreachHPG it has a great player resource selection. MechWarrior has a passionate community that are willing to help out new players. It might be overwhelming at first, but this game can grow on you easily.

number of helpful: 11 of 22 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Mechwarrior Online continues the tradition of a proud franchise. This is a sim-light shooter that maintains all the greatness of the previous versions while also providing a fantastic community of people to play with in a simulated galactic war that, while still in development, is shaping up to be a very unique experience.Most importantly this "freemium" game has a very reasonable grind and practically no "pay to win" elements. The Hero mechs are a nice way to ease the grind, but after playing 2 years I can honestly say that most of my best mechs were purchased with the in-game currency - "C-Bills", which are earned by simply playing the game. There is no "gold ammo" or any other such pay to win devices here. The only thing that costs money that is essential are mech-bays, but these are frequently rewarded in weekend spanning "events" that offer many prizes for scoring "points" for game play. Many of these prizes are "real money" items and PGI has proven very generous. That's not to say that there isn't a reason to spend money. There is plenty of "swag" that can be purchased to deck out your favorite mechs, such as - War Horns, Camo Patterns, Paints and cockpit items. You can also purchase mech packs or if you want the hot new thing, you can pay for early access to new mechs before they are available for C-Bills. Last but most importantly there is "premium time" which increases the XP and C-bills earned during matches. This decreases the grind and when coupled with Hero 'Mechs practically removes the grind completely. I have spent more money on this game than any other in my life, and I will continue to do so, simply because I don't feel I have to.. There is no extortion here, no "pay to win". The grind is hardly a grind at all. If you enjoy playing the game, forget about your bank account and check on it occassionally and be surprised by how fast it grows.To sum up, MWO is perhaps the best "free to play" game on the market. It hits that perfect balance of "free" and "grind" without aggravating "pay to win" mechanics. I have been playing it solidly for over 2 years now and still play it more than any other game I own. Be warned though. The learning curve here is very steep (2-3 months). Don't be surprised if you go a week before getting a legitmate kill. But in return MWO offers an incredibly deep and diverse "thinking man's shooter" experience unlike any other.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												I have been playing since the open beta in 2012. I'm still playing it. Why?It's a lot of fun.It is as simple or as complex as you wish to make it.  You want simple? You can run around using default loadouts not caring where you shoot. In that sense it is 'just glorified deathmatch in giant robots' You want complex? Use targeting information to find weak spots on enemy mechs. Make tactical decisions about whether to destroy an arm or a side torso that contains the most dangerous weapons on your opponent before finishing them off,or go straight for the kill through their heavily-armoured centre torso section. (Or maybe, if you think they might have an XL engine, go for a less-protected side torso first and get a quicker kill).Pilot nimble, lightly-armed mechs or massive lumbering weapon-laden assaults. Learn which tactics work for each mech class and each weapon, on each map.Spend hours in the mechlab customising mechs with the balance of speed, armour and weapons that suit your playstyle.-These latter points are what lays the foundation of the game's claim to being 'the thinking man's shooter'.It's also possible to do all of this  without investing a penny , but you have to invest the time to earn the money to buy what you want. Personally, I have paid around £60 over the 3 years, which for the amount of hours of fun I have got out of the game beats the value of almost all the AAA titles I own. The main reason I paid money was to show support for the game, so that it carries on being developed and played, not because there was something behind a paywall that I desperately needed.Try it out. If you have never played a mechwarrior game make sure you play the tutorial!

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												So... I don't like FPS games in general. Hey - come to think of it, I barely like any games.But, I like this one. I've played it for nearly two years, practically every day.Two reasons: 1) You are part of a team.Sometime your team is a blessing, sometime it's a curse. The game is unforgiving and does not keep tabs - make the wrong choice of 'mech or loadout, forget about where the team is and what they're doing, play in a match of random players doing all kinds of funny (bad) stuff - one misstake (yours or a team mate's) and you're out. Cry and moan every way you want about the outcome of the match or the performance of your team, but there's always something YOU could have done better  or better communicated with someone else about. Every now and again you have nothing to do with the outcome of a match - learn to live with it!2) It's Battletech(tm).Yes - It lacks some of the elements seen in previous titles in the franchise. It also is better than previous titles at other things. The last year, I've seen improvements in development I never would have thought possible when I started playing. There's also a lot of great improvements in the roadmaps, which I hope will adress many of the current shortcomings.I know many care about what have been and what will come. Me, I just play the hand I was dealt - Adopt, and have fun.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												The core game play experience is well worth people trying it out and seeing for themselves if they like it or not.  The game is fun and deep compared to many other games out in the F2P space and well worth the time of anyone to download for free and try it out to see if they like it or not. Particularly of note for those that do play other F2P games that will make this game more appealing: - No tier system.  If you grind your cadet bonus' in trial mechs, by the end of your cadet period you can buy literally any non-pre-order mech in the game to start out with. - No golden ammo or boosters that directly affect the game matches. (Only booster is premium time that boosts earnings and experience grind. - In general no P2W mechs.  The "hero" mechs are fairly different but not inherently better then their counterparts. (No boosted weapon damage etc.) And the company sells mech packs under a "pre-order" moetization system that as a generalization isn't pay to win.  Full disclosure though, every now and then one or two mechs defiantly creeps over the power scale before being nerfed leading up to a more general release. But for every mech that tends to break this curb on release ends up being about 3-4 mechs that are either mediocre or under-powered during their pre-order access and are buffed at a later time so it does even out in the grand scheme of things.The game isn't perfect, but trying it out for yourself and let you form your own opinion of it. Its good enough to at least give it a try on your own. Of particular note is that MWO has been getting better with every patch, and in particular the past year of development has really stepped up the pace when it comes to meaningful changes made to the game.  If they continue the pace of development they have been maintaining up to this point, the game will only get better in the long run.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												Mechwarrior has been a fantastic series of games, but in the past, the multiplayer options never even began to capture the feel of the old pen and paper.  It was always a race to the top.  Run the biggest mech or die!MWO has fixed that.  This is a tactics game.  This is a game where how you play your role is REWARDING.  This is a game where two large teams enter, but every player counts.And this game rewards you for finding your favorite balance of speed, armor, firepower, and battle field enduance (heat and quantity of ammo).This is a game about trading blows, taking risks, and defining the envelope.And the best thing about this game, is it truly is free to play.  The light mechs are cheap, but POWERFUL in skilled hands.  The medium mechs are affordable and are the standard battlefield units.  The expensive assault, though expansive, may have a role to play, and are worth every penny, but they do NOT own the battlefield.And every patch rewards people who play their role more and more.I am a freelance mercenary.  I am not a part of a unit, I do not use team speak, I am a pug player, and I still thrive in Community Warefare.I cannot say how amazing this game is.  It is amazing, it has been amazing, and every month, more and more value is added to the game.DOWNLOAD IT!!!! You cannot lose if you get it for free, so what are you wating for?!

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												What a Gem.I have to admit i was a bit sceptical running around in robots over using a marine type toon. But the gamplays great. Its got loads of depth too, there must be hundreds of machines and 1000's of load outs/ways to equip your tin can/mech. Mature loyal game following too. This is a FPS that is not too heavy on your PC too but that doesnt take away from great gameplay. Games at first are bit like hide and seek but when you get in front of your target you either got to have back up or hope your mech's set up can dish out more DPS than the other guy because it can be over in seconds.Also you can get into games very quickly compared to others in this genre. One of the things that i really liked is that even as a noob you can have value on map. If you pick a trial mech that has one preferably 2 AMS (anti missile system) hard points on it you can offer anti missile defence to your team mates, just by standing near them, as your learning the game by watching others.Also for a free to play! you can earn alot of in game cash at the beginning  so you can try out different tin cans/ robots and find your own style of play. Dont be like me though, play tutorial and first 25 games before you actually buy anthing in game (its about 500k a game which is enough to get you going), thats what  the forums said and its true.With about 10 free mechs you should play these because it will take you a while to actually work out what to buy. Its best to find out the best style of game for you be it machine guns or LRMs/missiles/lasers etc or 5 different classes of Mechs. Its got Faction warfare too, that takes the strategy and depth of the game to new level, I have not really got  into that just yet but the player base is friendly and solid. This franchise has been around for years but its been a well kept secret!

number of helpful: 33 of 66 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												It may not look like it, as it's new on Steam - but after hundreds of hours in this game I can safely say it's one I heartily recommend.Not recommend without reservation, mind, but heartily reccomend.The game is difficult.  Screamingly difficult.  The learning curve is steep, mostly because it's unlike any other shooter out there.  It moves like World of Tanks, but plays slower, and with near infinite customizeability.  When you die, you're out of the round - no respawns in quick play, and a new mech in Community Warfare.  Ammo matters - you can't resupply, there are no 'pickups' or in-game mods that matter.  Taking damage matters - you don't repair in a match, can can lose entire sections of your mech or just a gun here and there as you are beaten by enemy fire.Your environment matters - how hot is the world you're on?  Can you stand in water to help disssapate heat? Can you see your enemies, or will the ground clutter make targetting difficult?Your teamwork matters.  No one's rambo here - your mech has hard limitations that mean you simply cannot win a game by yourself.  You can customize every mech - mechs can suit your playstyle and loadouts are up to you, from engines to capabilities, with no real 'best'.It's fantastic.  A "thinking man's shooter" indeed, where every decision has consequences that can be extremely far-reaching for a match.  Signal intelligence matters.  Knowledge matters.  Skill matters.  Make the learning curve and you'll have near infinite permutations to experiment with.  Hell, put on a different weight class and learn how to play an entirely different game with the same parameters.The downside?  There are two solid gamemodes, with only a handful of objectives.  While this will expand (and it's going to take a while for them to feel stale), it's currently somewhat limited.  The initial learning curve is a cliff - it's not an easy entry, though the new tutorial helps a great deal.All in all, though?  It's a fantastic experience, one that gives a great deal of reward to those that can get over the initial learning curve.

number of helpful: 48 of 96 people (50%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												A little background on my MechWarrior Online (MWO) experience:    Joined MWO community on November 3, 2011.    Closed Beta Tester starting in late May 2012.    Broadcasting MWO exclusively on Twitch since October 2012.I know this sounds like bragging, but I want to be clear on how much I love this game. Is it perfect? Nope. Does it have a steep learning curve? Kind of, but it really depends on your previous experience with MechWarrior/Tank games. But it is very fun to play once you get the hang of things.The graphics are good. Especially if you have a good processor and graphics card. The sounds are well done and help with the immersion. The game maps are fun for the most part (PGI is in the process of rebuilding older maps) and everyone has their favorites and most hated maps (Caustic Valley is my least favorite). The Quick Match game modes are OK and currently don't have a lot of variation in how they are played due to people being stuck in their ways, but there is enough variation to keep things interesting. Usually. I suggest you stick with the Solo Queue until you are more comfortable with the game as the Group Queue tends to be a little more competitive.Faction play (aka Community Warfare (CW)) is still in development and can be fun, but right now it is really only a game mode where you get four lives instead of one. I highly suggest a new player avoid CW until they are more experienced because it is considered to be "hardcore mode" and you will be put up against some of the better players and their friends.The community can be very helpful and I strongly encourage you to check out the Twitch streams as the broadcasters and viewers are usually very knowledgeable and eager to help new players.If you love big stompy robots blowing up other big stompy robots, give it a try, visit the Twitch streams, and ask questions.Good luck and send me a friend invite ingame. I'd be more than happy to help you out. Gimpy

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												This game is like mustard: -There are people who hate it while others who love it. It all depends on what you personally enjoy.- It takes a while to get used to so dont get discouraged if it leaves a bad taste after a while for it does get better with  repetition and experience. (steep learning curve)Pros:- It's free so you wont lose anything if you give it a try.- No pay to win through added steroids and costly rare seeds.- Many and continued improvements throughout the years- Enjoyable and clean game play- Plays best when accompanied by other helpful entities (TEAMWORK and friends)- Many play styles to choose from like up close and personal or support (I like my mustard off to the side)- Occasional free items through eating contests- Many varieties to choose from (mech variants)- Friendly community of enthusiastsCons:- Lack of teamwork will make the game sour and spoil the experiance - Stains carpet- Pay for branding (colors/camo/aesthetics)- Some minor ingredient imbalances but nothing really worth throwing it out over- Learning what play style you enjoy EARLY in game given limited starting resources can be frustratingFinal thoughts: I dont really see this game as much of a grinding type game due to the enjoyment i get out of it. Given that, either you will enjoy it or you wont. I find this game relaxing and fun to play, plus it's free which is just an added bonus and gives ME an incentive to help the developers through in game purchases such as camo, colors, warhorns or to obtain mechs sooner. Not like other twitch FPS but requires thought and stradegy given lots of different variables.There is a lot to learn so do the tutorial and look up mechspecs to help you out and then fine tweak it to your play style.  I sucked at this game at first but at least give 10hrs(?) of play time to develop an understanding of game play mechanisms and tactics before leaving the community which may be hard to ask for someone to do.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												First and foremost, if you are into the Japanese anime style mechs that have faces, lazer swords, and move around like the mutant offspring of a fighter jet and Jackie Chan (shame on you) you should bail right now. This is a tank warfare game where the tanks happen to have legs and are designed with an 80's retro vibe. For those of us that envision mechs as believable (abiet cheesy) machines of war, you've come to the right place. These things move with a sense of weight and momentum that simply isn't conveyed by other vehicular combat games. The torso section of the mech moves independently of the legs (think tank turret), and the arms can in many cases actuate indepently of the torso. All these factors require you to think about motion and positioning in a way most other first person games never touch on. This is also a fiercely team-oriented game, so all you lone wolves out there best stick with CoD. Pros:-giant robits!-Not pay-to-win-actively in developement with features added regularly-Completely unique even among other vehicular combat games-increadible mech customization options-good weapon variety-great sense of weight and impactCons:-really steep learning curve-game is more resource intensive than you might expect-LRMs (you will understand when you play)
