content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
 TLDR: Great game, try it, it is free (better to say "free"). If you want play it seriously, you have to pay some real money. I am playing this game for years, since it started. I used to play it a lot, every day many hours, I am also Legendary Founder, and I've put to this game a lot of money - simply because I wanted, and I trusted that this game will be awesome.And it is. I love BattleTech (BT) universe, I love BT board game, I've played Mechwarrior PC games, red BT novels, I was immersed in reading BT manuals, readouts, and other BT related things.Gameplay of this game is great, and it is better and better over the time. They are adding more and more things, improving a lot of details, adding a lot of new mechs etc.And this game is free. Better to say "free"...You can play it without paying any real money. You can buy a lot of Mechs for earned in-game money. You don't need color and decals to paint your mech, you don't need cocpit items. You don't need a lot of things in this game, but if you want play a lot, you want (and maybe need?) more mechs to be able to switch to another and play different game style etc. But mechbays - slots for mechs (1 mechbay = 1 mech) are obtainable only for MC, which you - guess what? Yes, which you can get only for real money. And this is from my point of view the biggest betrayal from developers.Also a lot of (better?) mechs are available only for MC.Developers often reveal new mechs, mech packs with a lot of variants for every mech, with a lot of benefits, etc. - sure for real money, and for a LOT of real money. Look, I am an adult, I have own home, work, I am paying bills, I don't have problem with money to be sure. But I always compare the value and usefulness when I am buying something. Paying tens of dollars for ONE MECH and a few other variants (this mean, you will have a few, for example 4 same chassis mechs (same type), with some differences) is not worth imo.So I can recommend this game, but I hate this style when game is "free", but developers are milking players for almost everything, in particular for key things such as mech-bays.I, as Legendary Founder and buyer many of these mech packs want some kind of respect and appreciation, not to be milked again and again for everything as other player who did not payed anything.By that I mean, that loyal fans (who paid (a lot of) money) should have some kind of discount reward system, or something like that.For my loyalty I got almost nothing, except some mechs (4?), some premium time (provides some exp. and money bonuses), and an cocpit item or something like that... that caused that I became tired of this system of milking and almost stopped playing this game.But as I told, even with this, I can recommend it, especially if you're a fan of BattleTech, MechWarrior, or just big fighting robots in simulator-like game :)

number of helpful: 25 of 50 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												I played this game from closed beta. Many fun times where had, it felt like a reasonably good battletech game, there was only a handfull of mechs, there was no Double heatsinks basically 3025 tech. When wanting to play a match it was easy to get a drop in, click launch and wham you were in and playing. If you wanted to play with friends you could group up and easily get into a match. There was repair and rearm mechanic which was a good way to govern people running munchkin builds.Over time numerous changes were made that made this game less and less fun, until finally I was forced to stop playing with the introduction of cockpit glass, since then I never went back.Now with the introduction of steam I thought I would be fair and have another crack at this game I used to like playing, however sadly it just does not have it. It is not what I would expect from a mechwarrior game, it is very shallow, limited repetive gameplay. The tier system is not a true ranking system and the only goal in the game is to pokemech so you can collect them all.The mech chassis are mostly just skins, and lack real variety or flavour, you have a few key loadouts replicated multiple times with just a different look. Since I last played it looks like they introduced the quirk system, this attempts to provide some unique flavour to mechs, but is more complicated then it needs to be and you need to play spreadsheetwarrior to be able to make sense of it. If mech customization was a bit more restricted I feel the balance would have been more natural then the artifiial quirk system that was introduced.Since the lack of repair and rearm munchkin builds became prolific, and continue to do so to this day, there is no consequence to running the most expensive kit in your assault mech. Every other F2p games introduce a repair mechanic and it works quite well as a natural balance mechanic, ala World of warships, World of tanks ,Warthunder and Armored Warfare and it manages to work quite well but PGI could not make it work.The graphics looked great back in Closed beta and were amazing, nowdays they are very hohum, the mech Models up to a certain point look pretty decent, but looking at some of the more recent releases, it looks like they are just calling it in doing the Bare minimum to pump out mech packs. The textures and effects are very dated looking now. Whether that is the age showing , or as Ihave heard they have dumbed the quality down because they couldn't make the game run optimally on higher settings I don't know.The community is polar opposites generally, you have black knights who hate the game with a passion, and the white knights who love the game like it was brought to us by the messiah. In my eyes both are wrong and the game is just meh.I may try a few more sync drops with friends that still club pugs over the next few days as that is the only way to get matches going quick enough, but taking the game as it stands today I find it a very shallow and meaningless game, unable to easily and quickly drop with friends for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles anymore. The beauty of it being F2P is you can try it out and make your own decision as to whether you want grind away or pay to skip.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												So... I don't like FPS games in general. Hey - come to think of it, I barely like any games.But, I like this one. I've played it for nearly two years, practically every day.Two reasons: 1) You are part of a team.Sometime your team is a blessing, sometime it's a curse. The game is unforgiving and does not keep tabs - make the wrong choice of 'mech or loadout, forget about where the team is and what they're doing, play in a match of random players doing all kinds of funny (bad) stuff - one misstake (yours or a team mate's) and you're out. Cry and moan every way you want about the outcome of the match or the performance of your team, but there's always something YOU could have done better  or better communicated with someone else about. Every now and again you have nothing to do with the outcome of a match - learn to live with it!2) It's Battletech(tm).Yes - It lacks some of the elements seen in previous titles in the franchise. It also is better than previous titles at other things. The last year, I've seen improvements in development I never would have thought possible when I started playing. There's also a lot of great improvements in the roadmaps, which I hope will adress many of the current shortcomings.I know many care about what have been and what will come. Me, I just play the hand I was dealt - Adopt, and have fun.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												Hello mechwarriors, and potential mechwarriors.I'am a long time player, original founder, and competitive team vet. I also played ALL the previous iterations of this franchise, going all the way back to the beginning. For what it's worth. I have played in well over 5000 drops, own 200+ mechs.On to the game itself.Oh I have spent money, but mostly, because I wanted to, I buy mech bays, and premium time mostly and up until recently every mech pack they sold. I took a small hiatus from purchasing packs until some game issues were resolved, I did not stop playing, not even a little, but I voted with my wallet for a while :).The game is fun, it's fast paced, and it requires you to think about what you are doing at all times, stop for a minute to look around, and you might be dead. There is a unique variance in how you play based on the type of mech you bring in the game, light, medium, heavy, assault. You can play the game as a solo participant or as a group participant, here is the divide, teamwork is OP, and always will be in a game that boasts a 12v12 atmosphere.Many people are reviewing this game, and many giove it negative reviews, mostly, because they are now, or at least were at some point, very passionate about this game, this is the common theme you will in reviews on steam for MWO, passion, it makes for a diverse and interesting commentary on how this game effects  the people who play it. Many people come and go, some say the "best" players have gone on to other games, tired of waiting for changes, and that may be true to an extent, though there are many current players that would argue the point :).Try the game, see for yourself, if you like shooters, this is the ultimate one, the diversity in how you kit out your mech is completely astounding, you have tons (literally) to play with, as I noted above I have 200+ mechs, and each one can have almost unlimited different configurations, just this alone is worth hours of ones time, mech lab is the game within the game, who can build the best robot? who is going to set the next "meta" ? no one knows for sure. There are so many resources and established units within the game, you won't be alone for long if you want to play with people, use HPGoutreach on reddit for many good guides, even though sometimes you need a salt filter in there, this is normal, and there are good people that simply will help you for nothing. If you want fierce competition and are willing to put in time, the competitive scene is pretty serious, you can get lost in tactics and builds and, well all the things.......one thing, always have fun when you play, try new things, run through the new tutorials, they are very good! play the trial mechs, they arent bad. You will start with others who have not played vis a vis the newish tier system implemented, you start at tier 5 and walk your way up to tier 1, tier 1 is pretty broad in scope, but be ready to play if you get there!!! some people do not miss, almost ever :) take your time in tier 5 and see what you like to do, shoot some stompy robots.If you see me in game, say Hi, my in game name is the same as here, and I will be happy to help however I can.come play my favorite game of all time, you might get hooked, you might hate it :) but it's free so why would you not try, I bet most will like it, who does not want to shoot giant stompy robots after all :)Never mind the occasional jerk in game, rats gonna rat, ask questions, have fun...

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												An overall Average game with good customization (though Meta inhibited) let down by a lack of polish and progress.Bought into the founders pack years ago, buying Piranna's hype talk as if Microsoft didn't shove the game in their laps and force them to develope it.  Unfortunately there really hasn't been much improvement/optimization nor really any signs it's not a stagnated project that they keep around to farm money from the die-hard BattleTech fans who spew dosh to avoid the grind and coat their cockpits in swaggle.Maps -                  4/10Gamemodes -      6/10Server Health -    4/10Customization -   9/10 Communication - 5/10Graphics -             4/10F2p Grind -           5\10Maps:They're nice and open, but have dated textures even on the highest setting and they're poorly polished with the small selection getting extra boring extra quick-like.Oddly enough despite the 3+ years Piranna has had with the same maps the object collisions are still goofy. thin radio towers with mech wide invisible physical bodies or structures with giant gaps you try to shoot through/around only to be blocked while quite a few large rocks seems to have no collision presence.  You'll have to constantly struggle with your Mech catching on physical barriers that can't be seen and each slope is a gamble wether or not you can traverse it.Gamemodes:Standard f2p fare with your capture the flag and deathmatch that's about it, unless you do clan wars which is just the same.  Platooning is a nightmare, pairing up with only 1-2 peeps and you'll be facing whole teams of the same clan sync dropping to farm pubs. or come hauling a teams worth of pals and you'll still only go against clans.The pubcrawl is awful, there's a small player base which if you ignore the oceanic server for ping reasons gets even smaller, so you'll be in queue alot.Server Health:There's a worringly thinning player base, and everyone pinned their hopes on it spiking after the game was added to steam, but http://steamcharts.com/app/342200 .Customization:You can make a large variety of custom builds, but all mechs look the same unless you put actual money into it, which is fine.  The main stinker is the awkward balancing that creates a standard that everyone uses to stay competitive.  Worst thing is ballistics never seem to get a spotlight.Graphics:Dated and poorly optimized.Grind:I would compare it to WoT, you grind to get your mech, then you grind to make it useful.  You'll buy your mech, let's say a medium for 5mil, then you'll need to grind another 1.5mil for Dheatsinks, then another 1.9mil for a practical engine (hopefully your build doesn't need a 4mil XL engine), then another 500k for a lighter frame, then 1.6mil for weapons.  You'll need to do that 3 times so you can have enough of the same chassis to unlock useful perks for it.  Painful even with premium.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												As a three year vet, I love this game.  There are too many reviews to wade through for me to egotistically believe that a long meandering review will cut through the rest.  So I'll keep this short and sweet.It's a free to play FPS game where giant stompy robots shoot each other in 12 v 12 matches.  To the new Steam players that are joining us: this is not a simple game.  Your twitch skills from other shooters will definitely help you, and may even give you an edge over the old timers eventually.  But prepare for a steep learning curve.  There is SO MUCH nuance to understanding this game, let alone succeed at it, that no one will be an elite pilot without some serious time logged.  But, if you want a challenge, this game is it.My advice to you, the new player, is this.Join the game.  Jump into the tutorial system and get the hang of the basics of movement and shooting.  Play 10 matches or so in quickplay to get a taste of combat.  Save up that starting cash and play trial mechs at first.THEN: Ask in team chat or General chat if there are any vets that would be willing to help answer your questions and show you around.  You can lone wolf all you want in this game, but there is simply too much to understand if you don't ask questions.  Established units all have teamspeak servers and would love to help you learn the game.  Please take advantage of the existing community.  Most of us are drinking beers, having fun and are ready and willing to share both with anyone that wants to learn.  You don't need to make any commitment to joining units.  The community of vets truly want the game to succeed and grow, and we know that the best way to do that is to tutor new players.  When you know what you're doing, you've built a stable of mechs that fit your playstyle and you drop with a group of pilots that you have grown comfortable with, there is simply no better gaming experience to be had anywhere.  Crack a beer and look me up on the Steiner Teamspeak hub.  ts1.housesteiner.com  No Password.  My Callsign is Veritae and I'm the XO of Team Cortez Merc Corps (TCMC).  I'll vouch for any unit on the hub.  Peiper and the Devil Dogs are a great group of guys that switch between Wolf and Steiner and enjoy roleplaying.  FFI is a growing and emerging comp merc unit that switches between Clan and Inner Sphere and are a blast to hang out with.   6RCT, 5RCT, OCP, LoP and on and on and on all have vets that play every day and would love to help you out.  Play the game.  Join the community.  Welcome to Mechwarrior: Online.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												My review of MechWarrior Online:  Jan 15 2016Mechwarrior was one of those games I grew up on when I was younger.  The player pilots an armored mech and does battle with eleven other players on a variety maps.  Graphics:  I have nothing much to compare this against except maybe Hawken and Titanfall and it can match some of their look.  Maps are generally good looking ranging from desert wastelands to artic towns.  Weapons like lasers glow, leaving heat marks. and missles/rockets general smoke trails.  You can tell the damage of mechs by how much smoke they can sometimes generate from the damage they have taken.  Cockpits are fully detailed, though you can't push the buttons, and are unique for each kind of Mech.  Sound:  There is not much to say about the sound as much of it is muffled.  You get verbal warnings and indicators for what is happening on the map or happening to you.  What I mean for muffled sound is;  you are hearing what you would hear inside your mech.  The thumps of your feet stomping around and bumping into terrain. The hiss of your heat sinks trying to cool you down.  The bang of ballistic weapons being fired and the cycling of energy weapons as they discharge.Gameplay:  In the main menu players can select which Mech they want to pilot.  Once you pick a chassis (general shape and character of the mech) you pick a varient (loadout options)  and you are ready to go.  The roles are broken up into weight classes.  Light mechs are your small light weight fast movers.  Mediums mechs and Heavy mechs seem to be your general all round mechs and Assault mechs are the heavy hitters.  While fighting players have to manage their Mech's heat and torso while they manuever around in battle shooting enemies.   After each battle awards players with xp for their chosen Mech and credits that they can spend on getting new mechs or customizing the ones they currently own.  You spend your XP on skill boosts that affect the performance of your Mech.New player experience?:  After installing and signing in, players complete a tutorial to learn how to effectively pilot mechs.  Though many of the more advanced systems are not discussed or gone over in the tutorial, players can complete challenges to see said systems.  They recieve a stack of credits where they can save up to buy their first mech.  Trial Mechs are freely given and rotate regularly to allow players to try out different styles.  Overall:  It is a fun game,  you could lose many hours of sleep into it.  The community seems fairly friendly as the game does have built in voice chat.  Games tend to be more group friendly as you get awards for fighting together.  It does have a bit of a learning curve but what game doesn't.  Just remember to not go alone,  lone mechs are tasty.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												I love this game and it really is free to play. They have rotating trial mechs in all weight classes so you can take anything for a test drive and figure out what fits your play style best. Purchasing mechs can be done by using in-game money given after each match or by purchasing currency with real money. Purchasing mechs lets you be able to customize them and save load-outs but is something anyone can grind away enough to buy for free. There are premium mech designs that are real cash only when they first become available but these are mostly pretty eye candy and become available to be purchased with free in-game money after awhile I've heard. This may sound like a P2W aspect but it's really not. The pilot is more important than the mech. You can spend as much money as you want and still get your a$$ handed to you by a grade school kid who knows how to pilot his freebie mech.  It mostly comes down to this: If you want the newest thing right now today you can buy it, but you're willing to grind away you can get it for free down the road. If you're like me you'll try it for free and then want to make some purchases to get some neat stuff and support an awesome game at the same time.

												Grew up with BattleTech and the MechWarrior series, so my opinion might be a little biased, but I love this game. F2P isn't the easiest thing to balance apparently, but I think they did a good job here.There will be grinding if you want diversity and mastered mechs (you need to obtain 3 of a chassis and grab tons of XP to get this) - not to mention the pilot skills which require an XP hit to unlock AND a C-Bill hit to purchase.New mechs are coming out all the time and the devs are pretty good about releasing new maps and/or upgrading the older ones. You've gotta pay to get into the new mechs when they're released, but eventually they become available for either MC (premium currency) or C-Bills (grind money).It's free, so you should try it out. Read up on some lore, too - BattleTech's is pretty awesome. :] And if you do end up playing, don't feel bad when you inevitably spend the $20 to get some new mechs + early adopter rewards. The devs gotta eat!

content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												The good:>Lots of customization of mechs AFTER you buy one (there are lots of guides available on which mechs to buy for what playstyle once you've familiarized yourself with the game.) Want bigass cannons? Go for it. Like EZ aim mode lasers? Pew pew.>Graphical update in March made this game look amazing. Every mech has 2k textures and the game set to ultra high looks awesome on systems that can run it.>BIG MECH. Knock over ALL OF THE TREES. RaaaaAAAAAAA.>Smart play and tactics get rewarded. Idiots that rush in alone die, even if they bought a "pay to win" mech.>There is no pay2win model here. Most purchases are cosmetic; extra mech bays can be earned thorugh faction warfare (please save this for when you've played lots) and most mechs you see only for sale for real money are later available for in-game currency.>Your first 25 matches have a HUGE bonus to in game currency earnings. Save it for when you're ready to buy; the 17 million total plus whatever you earn playing will be enough to buy an assault mech.>Hot damn, the animations are great.>PGI is somewhat connected to their playerbase and actively tries to improve their game.>Free to play; if you don't enjoy it, all it costs is time. If you love it and never spend a cent, WOO. Free game!>Active and helpful community. If you have questions, there's always someone or somewhere you can go to get them answered.>Supprt is generally helpful and almost always polite yet concise. Even though they have a small team, they are a damn good team at that.>It FEELS like you're driving a 20 to 100 ton machine of doom. Even the smallet of these things dwarf some of the buildings in this game. The scale is AWESOME.>Every cockpit of every mech is different. It's awesome.The bad:>Limited maps in both quick play and faction warfare. You will learn them all fairly quickly.>If you want to own ALL of the mechs, you will have to pay for them in the long run. For some people, that's fine. Just be aware of what you're buying first. Do research on mechs before you buy. DO RESEARCH. You will hate yourself if you get something you do not enjoy playing.>Despite the few years this game has been out, not a lot has come out aside from a couple maps here, a UI update there. PGI has a small team; expect the game to evolve somewhat slowly.>Not every mech is a good one. There are balance issues like in any other online game with player versus player, but it sucks to buy a crap mech. But yes, research. You can avoid this with KNOWLEDGE.>No single player mode. There is work being done for a PvE campaign, but I don't expect it to be done any time soon.>Meta play gets to be a bit.. well.. obvious. Just be ready for the occasional tryhard with a 100% optimal build that can three shot you with alpha strikes. Of course, you can always shoot them back.>In game currency earnings gets really slow after those first 25 matches. Sorry. It'll be grindy to get that second or third mech you want.>Premium time in-game is used even if you are not actively playing. If you have 3 days of premium, it will be gone in 3 days. Regardless of if you play or not.>Faction play needs work. I'll not say more. It's fun and all, but it needs work.>Third person mode sucks. If you despise first person, well.. good luck?(who hates first person though lol psh)>NOT GAMEOAD/JOYSTICK FRIENDLY OMG Even with custom inputs it blows. You're stuck with KB&M.Overall: 9/10 game, would recommend

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												I've been playing this game since beta.At first, I was somewhat hesitant about MWO. You see, I’m not all that into PvP games. And, when I learned that MWO was all PvP, I really wasn’t interested at first. But, the lure of Big Stompy Robots eventually dragged me into trying it.So, there I was grinding out my twenty five cadet bonus matches in a Trial JM-6 Jagermech. My first mech purchase was a Blackjack as they were first released. I realized that this was a different kind of PvP game- it was slower, the concept of walking tanks did a good job of mitigating the twitch play that I didn’t like. Sure there was still twitch play with light mechs, but it was still a little slower and methodical that other FPS games I played.Now, a few years (and a bunch of mech packs) later, I find I truly do love this game.What I like most about this game, compared to other tank games, is the method in which you get your vehicles. See, in other tank games, you have to contend with tech/progression trees- forcing you to drive or fly equipment you don’t like in order to work your way into gear that you do.Not so with this game. If I want to drive a Timberwolf, I can either grind the CBills to get them, buy the MC to get it or buy it straight away from the gift store. Can’t do that with an M1 Abrams, German Tiger or P-51.I love how customizable the game is. Much of the fun of the game is spending time in the mechlab finding that perfect build that synergizes my playstyle with the mechs quirks and hardpoint arrangement. See not all build fit all, some build that work great for one guy may not work so well for other. But, finding that great build that works for you is truly satisfying.Another thing I love about this game is the regular events that PGI holds. Grab bag events, Leaderboard events, Faction play events and Cumulative stretch goal events, there’s always something going on.There’s a lot of good stuff on the horizon for this game-The fabled Unseens are being released on a monthly basis as we speak.  If you’re a Battletech aficionado, you can truly appreciate the return of these classics.PvE is coming; we already see glimpses of PvE in the Mechwarrior Academy.A large update is coming to Faction Warfare that will appeal to small groups (4v4) as well as large.If you’re new to the game, do check out the Spike Brave tutorials on youtube. Also, play the Mechwarrior Academy, play it a lot, play it some more. The Mechwarrior Acandemy is a great resource.Give the game its fair shake, just like I did, and I think you will be impressed with it, just like I am.

number of helpful: 13 of 26 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												As a long time HAWKEN fan, I avoided this game as I constantly heard pay to win and outlandish mech pricing claims.Having just started playing, one thing I can say is this is no Hawken and I was wrong to draw comparisons. This is much more of a simulation experience and not a FPS - in the style of something like Elite: Dangerous or World of Tanks. It has a slow, deliberate pace focusing on the strength of the unit and not the individual.It's deep and complex but once you buy and outfit your first mech (which can be done straight away) you absolutely can compete with those who have been playing since the beta. A few novice light mechs can take down or disable any Behemoth, if they work together and target the right areas.If you're a big badass robot fan like me who was really skeptical about about Mechwarrior Online, now's the time to give it a try. It's not perfect and the interface is pretty clunky but on the battlefield, where it counts, Mechwarrior Online is the game we all remember.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												MWO is, and probably always will be, something of a work in progress. It has it's faults, but can be an amazing game as well.Pros:- BattleMech customization: They have struck a fairly good balance between the standard tabletop construction rules and a hardpoint system to prevent rediculous boating and encourage customization. You CAN make pretty much an kind of variant you want, even if it's not always smart (See the Cons)- Variable gameplay: You can make your play as involved (or not) as you want. Quickplay gives you the ability to jump right into a match, which lasts for a maximum of 15 minutes. More depth can be had in Faction Play (also known as Community Warfare), where group play is strongly encouraged and players fight across various planets in the Inner Sphere. Keep in mind, this mode is scheduled for significant changes in the next few months (CW: Phase 3)- Community: This can be a negative in any game, but MWO at least has the redeeming feature of a strong population of mature gamers and Battletech veterans to balance out the annoying trolls. You can find groups to match what you're looking for.- Visuals: It's made by a small dev studio, and some of the graphics can show it at times, but they are rescued by an indredibly talented art department. Mech models in particular are almost universally superbly done.- It's an F2P that is most assuredly NOT Pay2Win. Real life purchases are for cosmetics and boosters, as well as early access to newly released Mechs. It may take a month or two, but any mech that is initially released for $$$ will always subsequently be released for in-game currencyThe Cons:- Time-sink: Yes, it's a time sink. The grind can be pretty severe at times, as in-game earnings can take quite a while, especially if you are playing as a solo player.- Release Schedule for mechs: This can be a matter of perspective. While the game is not pay2win, there is a tendency for new mechs to be initially relased (during the real life $$$ period)  with "op" characteristics. Sometimes it's oddly coded hit-boxes, sometimes it's poorly thought out design quirks that give an advantage. The design is then fixed/nerfed just as or shortly before the design becomes available for in-game currency. Taken individually, any of them appear to just be mistakes by the devs, but it is slightly suspicious that the pattern has repeated itself so many times.- The "pro" or "comp" community: MWO has a small but dedicated group of competetive players. They play in the Faction play, and third-party tournaments. While there are plenty of good people who participate, the overall comp scene can be quite abrasive, and it's members pompous and annoying. It likely stems from being the top dog in a very small community, like being boastful of being elected Class President of your home-school class of 1 person. If you've ever known that team in an adult rec league that take things too far, as if they're pros or something, that's exactly what this is. Most enjoy showing how "leet" they are by clubbing seals over and over. It's possible that revisions to CW and the influx of new blood from Steam will help, but that remains to be seen.- Teamwork is required, but rarely to be found: Teamwork is huge, people playing as a team have a huge advantage. The game has built-in chat and VoiP, but they are usually just used to troll/abuse. Especially on the weekends, there is an influx of low-skill players who simply do not work with their team at all, and this can be frustrating as it can virtually guarantee losses if you get stuck with that team.- The "meta": While you can theoretically build any type of mechs you want, certain weapons/combos/variants are just plain better and stronger. If you want to have any success at the higher skill levels, you have to use the meta.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												I'm not sure if I can fully recommend this game especially newer players from steam. veteren players will constantly verbally assault newer players because of their lack of skill which also brings up the fact that they need a playlist for newer players to get adjusted. Before there was no tutorial good enough to prepare you for the brutal multiplayer where veterans would slaughter new players often turning them away from the game. They have a new tutorial which teacher you mmuch needed info but still not enough to just thrust you into hell. I had played this game before it came to steam and decided to bring along a friend and teach him how to play but he quickly stopped playing after three matches of toxic players calling him trash and to uninstall the game even with warning to these players that he was newer and its to be expected especially with the games terrible tutorial at the time. The gameplay is solid and exciting for sure. If you have assistance breaking the learning curve and have friends that you can communicate with you will have a much better experience like most games.One final complaint is the horrid grind to "master" specific mechs and the game often puts you in uncomfortable positions grinding out currency to pay for varients of the mech you want.I would recommend this game but its to steep of a curve for new players mixed with the toxicity of the veteran community. If you can handle that you probably could enjoy the game but bringing in new friends is hell.

number of helpful: 35 of 70 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												This game is like mustard: -There are people who hate it while others who love it. It all depends on what you personally enjoy.- It takes a while to get used to so dont get discouraged if it leaves a bad taste after a while for it does get better with  repetition and experience. (steep learning curve)Pros:- It's free so you wont lose anything if you give it a try.- No pay to win through added steroids and costly rare seeds.- Many and continued improvements throughout the years- Enjoyable and clean game play- Plays best when accompanied by other helpful entities (TEAMWORK and friends)- Many play styles to choose from like up close and personal or support (I like my mustard off to the side)- Occasional free items through eating contests- Many varieties to choose from (mech variants)- Friendly community of enthusiastsCons:- Lack of teamwork will make the game sour and spoil the experiance - Stains carpet- Pay for branding (colors/camo/aesthetics)- Some minor ingredient imbalances but nothing really worth throwing it out over- Learning what play style you enjoy EARLY in game given limited starting resources can be frustratingFinal thoughts: I dont really see this game as much of a grinding type game due to the enjoyment i get out of it. Given that, either you will enjoy it or you wont. I find this game relaxing and fun to play, plus it's free which is just an added bonus and gives ME an incentive to help the developers through in game purchases such as camo, colors, warhorns or to obtain mechs sooner. Not like other twitch FPS but requires thought and stradegy given lots of different variables.There is a lot to learn so do the tutorial and look up mechspecs to help you out and then fine tweak it to your play style.  I sucked at this game at first but at least give 10hrs(?) of play time to develop an understanding of game play mechanisms and tactics before leaving the community which may be hard to ask for someone to do.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												Mechwarrior has been a fantastic series of games, but in the past, the multiplayer options never even began to capture the feel of the old pen and paper.  It was always a race to the top.  Run the biggest mech or die!MWO has fixed that.  This is a tactics game.  This is a game where how you play your role is REWARDING.  This is a game where two large teams enter, but every player counts.And this game rewards you for finding your favorite balance of speed, armor, firepower, and battle field enduance (heat and quantity of ammo).This is a game about trading blows, taking risks, and defining the envelope.And the best thing about this game, is it truly is free to play.  The light mechs are cheap, but POWERFUL in skilled hands.  The medium mechs are affordable and are the standard battlefield units.  The expensive assault, though expansive, may have a role to play, and are worth every penny, but they do NOT own the battlefield.And every patch rewards people who play their role more and more.I am a freelance mercenary.  I am not a part of a unit, I do not use team speak, I am a pug player, and I still thrive in Community Warefare.I cannot say how amazing this game is.  It is amazing, it has been amazing, and every month, more and more value is added to the game.DOWNLOAD IT!!!! You cannot lose if you get it for free, so what are you wating for?!

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												To truly enjoy MWO:1) Get a microphone2) Get used to team work3) Remember that FF is on and to not overheat because you will damage yourself and you will kill yourself.-Short Review: It's a good game that is very addictive, very fun and very team oriented. If you're a lone-wolf type prepare to be disappointed because this game isn't for you.  MWO uses a number of effects that you rarely see in FPS shooters and requires more thought to kill one mech than I have ever seen in any game before.Things that I liked about the game:+ HEAT: Mechs don't just fire lazers endlessly, you have a certain amount of HEAT before you pass the thresh-hold and just shut down. This makes firing something as unlimited as lazers tricky. HEAT is effective by the ambient temperature as well as other enviornmental quirks. What I liked about HEAT is that it balances the fire-power within mechs. +A lot of variants: MWO has tons of variants and classes of mechs to choose from. Don't like being a big clunky and slow target? Pick a light class mech. Don't like using only lazers? Well there's different variants for different chasis. Because the variants are so easy to get and the upgrades for them are cheap this makes experimenting with the bots less costly and more fun. +FACTIONS: This conquer and defend style of factions kept me in a very happy mood. Loads of banners to cast your loyalty to and loads of perks and rewards for siding with those factions. FACTION PLAY is the big leagues for MWO. With thousands of planets and maps to explore you will be occupied with more than just the DM style of quickplay. Not only does FACTION demand a sense of loyalty but a sense of tactical approach I have never seen in an FPS. You will find that players are actively trying to call out and use plans to thwart their enemy combatants. From defending a planet you own to attacking another to increase your factions control of the galaxy this is something that I really enjoyed!-What I didn't like: -Mech Bays: Mech bays limit the amount of mechs that you can buy and add to your MECHLAB. This doesn't seem like much of a big deal but the SKILLS for certain variants of mechs require you to buy and maximum level 3 variants. You only get 4 empty mech bays at the start and you can only aquire more by either paying real money or by earning them through faction promotions. This makes it difficult to get EXPERT into mechs and limits your choice of weight class if you're interested in experting in a certain chasis.----That's all I feel about MWO. The content is grand and the players are fun.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												MW3 nastalgia.Play a Cata A1 Missile boat. Ran out of ammo. proceeded to run around and distract/tank shots while team mates around me dropped the Mechs. after getting them down to a single light, i took an opportunity and pinned the silly little chicken while my team pounded him with a hail of fire. Funny Business aside, this is at first glance a battle arena "shooter". However, you have to think with this one. if you're not a MW fan then you may fumble with the controls initially but just think that its a tank. the Tutorial is quick but you learn the basics. This is definitely a good one to play, especially Fans of the universe. The major Drawback in my opinion, is the lack of Modes and maps. it has somewhere between 5-8 maps but only 3 modes, Assault, Conquest, and Skirmish. There could be a bigger selection of Game modes and a few more maps and this would be a lot better. Hawken, another F2P Mecha shooter, has several modes and a hanful of maps. the mode selection is what caught me on that game. If a lower budget Mech shooter like Hawken can have multiple modes why doesn't MWO have more? In conclusion, I think this is a great Mech Shooter. its not the simple shooter mechanics, it stays true to the MechWarrior playstyle. the MW3 Nastalgia hit my in the gut hard. The game suffers from the lack of Modes, a few more would really benefit this game.

												I grew up on the original MechWarrior games and this definitely brings me back to those great times. The gameplay is amazing and for a competitive game the community is surprisingly helpful and non-toxic. The game is very heavy on teamwork, which is refreshing in this world of games where you just go around and do your own thing. You'll find your teammates to be usually helpful and there's a built-in voice chat system when in a match so you're able to communicate more easily with your team. I would definitely recommend this game, especially to anyone who loves games with giant robots, as MechWarrior is THE best mech game title ever.

Grinding for mechs takes forever, and once you fill the very limited number of mech bays on your account, youre left with either not growing your hangar or shelling out money for the opportunity to grind even more and purchase other mechs. Posted: December 12, 2016
												Mechwarrior Online, This is a Free to Play PVP TDM shooter game with you driving huge battlemechs in combat.  It works in Win 10, looked good, plays good, sounds good.  Has first person cockpit view and 3rd person over the shoulder view.  There is no other mech combat game that can come close to it.Store sells cosmetics, New model Mechs with and without xp/credit buffs, xp buffs, credit buffs, xp conversion.  You can also buy mechs and gear with in-game earned currency.If you die in a 12 x 12 TDM match, there is no respawn. Winning the matches give you the most xp and credits.  Winning a match requires teamwork, communications, good aiming while moving skills, tactics, good mech builds, using cover and speed, and luck to be on the winning side.PROS:Free to play.Great graphics, sound, gameplay.Complex Mech building system.Free Trial mechs that rotate at a set interval.Community warfare and Faction gameplay.Has Steam achievements.Tutorial mode and Good instructions.Joystick support.Mech and Pilot module unlocks.Many Great mech models with variants. for more info:

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												I've been a fan of the BattleTech Universe for over 20 years.  I've played many iterations and versions of the games.  I've decided that this is probably the best BattleTech based game I've played in a long time.This game is a Free-to-Play game, with in-game purchases available.  However, it's perfectly playable without spending anything.  It puts you in the cockpit of a giant robot weighing anywhere from 20 to 100 tons.  The game does take a little bit to get used to and the initial learning curve can be steep.  I found I had to reprogram the default keys to match my play style better.  Once I did that, I found myself doing much better.  There is a plethora of guides and tutorials available as well as a large number of communities.  Give it a chance.  If you're into this genre, you won't be disappointed.  It's like World of Tanks, but with BattleMechs.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												Let me start by saying that this game has a lot of flaws, including but not limited to:-Getting your 100-ton death machine stuck on a small, unrendered pebble is occasionally a thing.-Getting your 100-ton death machine stuck on a small, rendered piece of gutter is a thing.-Trees stop railcannons, lasers, missiles, and autocannons, but will never hinder movement, even if they are saplings.-There are only ~25% of the mechs in the battletech universe available for play.-Clans don't get a lot of their guns.-Missiles are broken, albeit still useable with a great deal of effort.-Certain weapons are misused-Glitches can cause issues with the HUD and other important gameplay aspects-"Rebalancing" measures often cause problems rather than solve them. For example, there are two factions in the Battletech universe (during the era the game takes place in); Clan, high tech badasses who use GMO troops and lasers, and the Inner Sphere, who have more resources, mechs, land, and everything, really. In the tabletop game, the Clan's superior guns and tech are offset naturally by going up against seas of richer opponents. In MWO, the Clans have to deal with the IS advantages, but are often left without most of their advantages. I understand that this is mostly to allow a 1 Clan : 1 IS ratio in fights. But I think the game could be made far more dynamic by "de-nerfing" Clans and giving IS more troops per fight, thus making Clans and IS require different playstyles and tactics. Presently, there isn't a huge difference between Clan and IS, which is just a shame, as there's just SO MUCH wasted potential.But this game is an excellent one, despite its flaws. Why?+Great community.+You can blow giant robots to bits with other giant robots.+The game has rebindable conrols that work reasonably well with keyboard and mouse, joystick, or controller. +It's "pay to not play" and so anyone who tries to "pay to win" will find themselves lacking in skill, which is a great offset.+They add new mechs about every 1-2 months. These are available for 1-2 months as "paid only" and then can be purchased with in-game money. +None of the mechs are in the "invincible" or "overly broken" category. Some may say "you can't have it both ways" when talking about this and what I mentioned with the Clans, and that may well be so. Still, it's a shame to see your favorite mechs artificially nerfed or given tech they didn't have. The IS is also a victim here, as they lack things like their C3 advanced targeting computer, and are instead given a "command console".+The controls are really good.+Customizing your mechs is SO fun. You can adjust the armor point-by-point, shedding tenths of a ton in order to fit just a little more ammo on, and it's made so that you can spend years tweaking a mech without ever feeling like you hit "perfection" since builds are always being changed to counter the latest trends.+For all the mechs they have, only THREE fall above the power curve, and they all have some detracting factor that evens them out, like the Adder lacking jump jets, or the Ice Ferret having a bad loadout.+Almost any of the mechs can be used to great effect.+The game encourages teamwork, and you will never win without it.+There's never a "correct answer" in any situation. If I send in a really big mech and three medium sized mechs, you might want to kill the smaller ones first and quickly, or beat the big guy to a pulp. Either way, you take a lot of damage. But if you have lighter mechs than I do, you might be able to outmanuver them and take no damage. Or you might have heftier mechs to kill me first and still live.+Money can be made really fast, and you can get mechs for in-game currency really quickly.+Teamwork and tactics will often beat skill. The clever, charismatic commander will find that his enemies pose little threat when the enemy can be placed at any sort of disadvantage.+The maps are well made and only one or two are "bad". *Glares at Terra Therma*Now, CW Phase 3 is purported to fix many glitches on release. I'll change this review accordingly. This game is free, and you're short-changing yourself to not give it a shot if you like giant robots.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												Probably one of the most comprehensively balanced multiplayer games ive played. The matchmaking seems to be spot on and matches are consistently tactical and thrilling.  A huge variety of mech's backed up by an even larger variety of mods, addons, weapons.  You can tweak your mech's to your preferred playstyle and more importantly, take premium Mech's out for trial. The community is great, the surrounding ecosystem of forums, Smurphys Mechlab and wide variety of clan specific pages remind me a lot of the commiunity around EVE.Overall, one of the most consistently fun multiplayer experiences I have had. I dont even mind the grind for credits and skills simply because I get to drop into battles and mash other players in walking tanks bristling with lazers.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												I have been playing this game for years, and really enjoy it.if you are looking for a simple shooter look elsewhere, this is a complecated game with a lot of diferant mechinics which you will need to learn if you want to be sucessful.think of it like a tank game, the Mechs are giant robots on which the legs move inderpendantly of the torso and arms where the guns are mounted, initialy you will be using "trial Mechs" which are player designed builds on a variaty of diferant Mech types, after completing the tutorial (I strongly recomend doing the tutorial because it does cover the basics and rewards you with 5 million cbills) and the first 25 games you should have 18-20 million Cbills (earned ingame money) enough to buy and outfit any Mech you want, or 2-3 less expensive Mechs, after the first 25 your earnings slow down.on any Mech you can change the weapons for whatever you want provided it has the relevent hardpoints and tonage available, Omnimechs have fixed engine and some other equipment but can swop e.g. an arm, leg, side torso or head to change the hardpoints, Battlemechs have fixed hardpoints but you can change all the equipment, including engine and upgrades, most of which are a tradeoff internal space for tonnage.some Mechs can be realy expensive to upgrade, most Light Mechs look cheep to purchase but you will have to spend double the purchase price upgrading it to get it combat ready.the comunity is extremely helpful, so if you have any questions visit the new player help forum where veteran players will try to answer all your questions.this game is not pay to win, the "premium" Mechs are no better than the regualr ones, they just offer faster earnings, all real money gets you is time saving, cosmetic or early access (getting new Mechs a few months before they become available for cbills) in natureif after that information you are still interested please give it a try

												Very fun game overall.May not be the best combat experience for those who like quick kills, but it is interesting with all the variety of Mechs that you can play as. Has a wide variety of mechs that suit each persons needs, whether that be fast movement and scouting, support spotting, high damaged support, tank damage or tank damage and high damage output.The immersion that I get from playing this game is not like any other game that I have played before, it grips me into the experience and makes me believe I am inside one of these mechs.There are no abusive text chats that I have seen so far in the total 2.3 hours I have played this game, only supportive unlucky man or nice shooting.I may not be the most experienced player but I highly recommend this game to anyone who maybe having thoughts of whether to play it or not. number of helpful: 13 of 26 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												As a long time HAWKEN fan, I avoided this game as I constantly heard pay to win and outlandish mech pricing claims.Having just started playing, one thing I can say is this is no Hawken and I was wrong to draw comparisons. This is much more of a simulation experience and not a FPS - in the style of something like Elite: Dangerous or World of Tanks. It has a slow, deliberate pace focusing on the strength of the unit and not the individual.It's deep and complex but once you buy and outfit your first mech (which can be done straight away) you absolutely can compete with those who have been playing since the beta. A few novice light mechs can take down or disable any Behemoth, if they work together and target the right areas.If you're a big badass robot fan like me who was really skeptical about about Mechwarrior Online, now's the time to give it a try. It's not perfect and the interface is pretty clunky but on the battlefield, where it counts, Mechwarrior Online is the game we all remember.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												MW3 nastalgia.Play a Cata A1 Missile boat. Ran out of ammo. proceeded to run around and distract/tank shots while team mates around me dropped the Mechs. after getting them down to a single light, i took an opportunity and pinned the silly little chicken while my team pounded him with a hail of fire. Funny Business aside, this is at first glance a battle arena "shooter". However, you have to think with this one. if you're not a MW fan then you may fumble with the controls initially but just think that its a tank. the Tutorial is quick but you learn the basics. This is definitely a good one to play, especially Fans of the universe. The major Drawback in my opinion, is the lack of Modes and maps. it has somewhere between 5-8 maps but only 3 modes, Assault, Conquest, and Skirmish. There could be a bigger selection of Game modes and a few more maps and this would be a lot better. Hawken, another F2P Mecha shooter, has several modes and a hanful of maps. the mode selection is what caught me on that game. If a lower budget Mech shooter like Hawken can have multiple modes why doesn't MWO have more? In conclusion, I think this is a great Mech Shooter. its not the simple shooter mechanics, it stays true to the MechWarrior playstyle. the MW3 Nastalgia hit my in the gut hard. The game suffers from the lack of Modes, a few more would really benefit this game.

Posted: February 22, 2016
												I grew up on the original MechWarrior games and this definitely brings me back to those great times. The gameplay is amazing and for a competitive game the community is surprisingly helpful and non-toxic. The game is very heavy on teamwork, which is refreshing in this world of games where you just go around and do your own thing. You'll find your teammates to be usually helpful and there's a built-in voice chat system when in a match so you're able to communicate more easily with your team. I would definitely recommend this game, especially to anyone who loves games with giant robots, as MechWarrior is THE best mech game title ever.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												First off: This isn't a twitch game. Being a good button-masher isn't going to make you a good player.Second: This isn't Call of Duty. You can't carry your team's weight. Teamwork is necessary, so use that option to talk to your team.Third: Big stompy robots with big weapons are awesome. This game takes it to a new level in the sheer variety of what you can do to make your big stompy robots YOURS. You have a mech with two ballistic hard points that has enough slots for a pair of AC 20s, go ahead and slap 'em on. Not to mention the game is balanced. Having a big mech isn't an automatic win.Fourth: The game really is free to play. It isn't pay to win. You pay for things like different colors for your mech or some cockpit bling. Maybe you just really want that mech right now, so you can use actual money. There is not one thing you need to buy to be an actual, competitive player.

												Free to play tactical FPS shooter.  The pace is slower than most FPS games, and it is brutal in punishing poor tactics, and lack of teamwork.  I enjoy the less twitchy nature of the gameplay, and have been a rabid battletech fan since the early 90s. This game definitely scratches that itch, and I find the moderately steep learning curve to have ultimately been rewarding once I got the handle of the game mechanics.  If you are at all interested in this genre / flavor of game (big stompy robots) give it a go.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												As a long time fan of Battletech / the Mechwarrior, I'm glad to see the franchise has been picked up and dusted off. I've been playing this consistanly game for 3 years or so now (using the stand alone client) So I've come to share my opinon of this game as a true vet.So what is Mechwarrior about? From the very beginning, it's always been about piloting giant, multi-ton battlemechs into battle. Smashing trees, stomping cars, high-powered futuristic weapons. Carnage. Destruction! Battlemechs operate as walking tanks. You can move the torso independently from the legs. And you can Aim Arm mounted weapons independently from weapons mounted in the torso. It takes a certain finesse to get the hang of it, but it does lead to a pretty fun experience in battle. That said, MWO is a solid tactical shooter. It can be a bit slower paced as you really have to be able to land consistent shots in the same component location to effectively destroy your opponents armor so you can get to the internals, who will be doing their best to spread that damage all over his mech. But on the other hand it can be brutally fast paced when a coordinated team focuses down targets. Though there are a few lone wolf roles that can be quite disruptive to the enemy team, Team work as well as positioning and situation awareness is Key in this game. It cannot be ignored that there is a learning curve to Mechwarrior. It does take a certain finnese outside of twitch shooting. It can be frustrating if you're new and trying to get the hang of the game, as it does take a while to learn proper maneuvering, how to manage your heat and preserve your armor. There are no respawns in MWO, but if you play it right, most mechs can take quite a beating. Once you get the hang of it, combat is seamless and satisfying. Another crucial part of the Mechwarrior franchise that will keep you coming back for more is the Mechlab. Here you can browse thoughscores of available mechs for purchase (Most mechs and ALL weapons / equipment in the game can be purchased with in game currency that you earn in battle), choose your ideal mech, strip it down and build it up to your preferred role / play-style, finding that balance between heat management, firepower, mobility, ammo and any other support tech. Here is where you will fine tune your mechs and try to squeeze after last bit of performance out of it to fit your needs.  Each chassis is different. They will have different hardpoint types / locations and / or quirks that may make them excel in some areas. PGI has done a great job of making each mech not feel exactly the same as another so there is lots of variation to be found.Mechwarrior also offers several types of weapons that you can choose from to equip on your battlemech. They fall into 3 main categories. - Energy - Those are your lasers and particle projection cannons. They come in different sizes and beam duration lenghts for different roles. Damage is done instantly to your target. But damage is DOT, so you have to hold the beam on a specific spot on your target to get the full damage to that location. Energy weapons generate the most heat but require no ammo.-Missiles - Again, come in different sizes and salvos. Short and long range versions. Can end up weighing a lot. variants that can lock on to an enemy do less damage. Generally low heat, but can get hot with long periods of sucessive fire.-Ballsitics - your Autocannons and Guass rifles of different calibers. Require lots of space and tonnage to equip on your mech. Rounds do have varying travel time and range depending on the calibre of the round. Ballistcs that don't burst fire will do their full rated damage on impact if within optimal range. Generally very low heat weapons.Mechs come with combinations of these hardpoints and it's up to the player to figure out what works best for them.


YouTube™ Video: Mechwarrior Online: Snipercat 

			Views: 279		

			Trolling, harassing and thinning the herds with the CERPPC shadowcat.		

Above:Sniping and harassing in the shadowcat: Medium Omnimechs equipped with Dual Extended range PPC's. Heat managment and positioning are key on this build.That said there are 4 classes of mechs to choose from.20-35 tons - Your nimble annoying light mechs that will pick and peck at you. Infuriate you! Low armor, low to decent firepower, high speed and maneuverability. Very effective against slower targets. 40-55 tons - Medium mechs which as less mobile but carry more armor and firepower. By lore, they are the workhorses of the battlefield.60-75 tons - Heavy Mechs, Good armor, good firepower and decent mobility.80-100 tons - Assault Mechs - Expensive, Slow, lumbering heavily armed behemoths of destruction. With just as heavy armor.As far as DLC goes, there is a lot out there. But you don't really need to get any of it. New players only have access to trial mechs, most of which are decent but cannot be customized, but new players also earn money bonuses for their 1st 25 games. Completing the tutorials will also net a nice tidy amount of cbills which should allow new players to buy 1 or 2 maybe even more Mechs of their down. And yes, any mech in the game ouside of hero mechs can be purchased with in game currency. Hero mechs are usually not the preferred variant of a mech, they may have a couple hard-point changes and come with their down custom camospec and a 30% boost to money earned in matches. The only thing that a new player that is into the game should buy is Mechbays - you only have 4 to start with, and if you want more mechs you'll have to sell mechs to free up bays or by more mechbays. Mechbays can also be earned in game by playing faction warfare, completing weekend challenges and more. Sounds and graphics are all nicely done, though the game could still benefit from some optimization in some areas. This is still a work in process and there is new content in the making and improvements are always being added.I'll end this review with another video of some of the sights and sounds of mechwarrior.  Hope to see you on the battlefield Future Mechwarriors!


YouTube™ Video: All Systems Nominal 

			Views: 185		



All systems nominal!

content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
Download this game. Play it. It's free.I definitely recommend this game to any fan of:BattleTech UniverseStrategic FPS (more Battlefield, less CoD)Rompy Stompy Robots with LAS0RZThe mechanics of this game are similar to previous MechWarrior titles. You pilot a Battlemech, have to deal with ammunition for your guns and missiles, and manage heat and cooldowns for your energy weapons. There's 4 classes of battlemech (light, medium, heavy, assault) and a variety of roles that each can play, based on loadout, which for mechs you own is fully customizeable. There are two multiplayer game modes: Quick Play and Faction Play. Quick Play is where the majority of pilots spend their time, dropping into 12v12 matches on a variety of maps and with varying objectives (Skirmish/Deathmatch, Conquest, Domination/King of the Hill, Assault/Base Capture). Faction Play allows pilots to participate more in the lore/IP; by signing on with one of the Inner Sphere houses or one of the Clan tribes as a loyalist or mercenary, and shape the Mechwarrior universe (unfortunately, in practice this is not as cool as it sounds - more on this below). I'm 100 hours in as of this review, here's what I like and don't like so far:Pros:Free to play, but not pay to win. More grind involved if you don't want to invest any $.A very strategic FPS (if you're a fan of World of Tanks, you'll enjoy this)Tons of diversity when it comes to the different classes of mechs, as well as the weapons and equipment you attach to themVery similar feel to the old MechWarrior titlesThe community, from what I've seen, is pretty forgiving to rookies, and if you ask for help, people will help you. As a former League of Legends player, this blew my mind.There are pretty regular community events, in the month I've been playing there's been 2 (as well as a sale on mechs), that allow you to obtain pay-only items as rewards for performance. Rompy Stompy Robots with LAS0RZ!Cons:Because the playerbase is smaller than a lot of other F2P titles (daily uniques range between 1200 and 2500), you're usually in matches with people of varying skill level. Their matchmaking service wouldn't be able to launch games in an acceptable time frame otherwise.If you're a big fan of the IP (read the books, played all the previous titles, maybe played the tabletop game), their 'Faction Play' mode doesn't delve much into the lore. In fact, Faction Play is difficult to get into as a rookie pilot, as you're typically up against pre-made teams who've been playing together for awhile.Learning curve - not so much if you're familiar with Tank mechanics a la Battlefield, or old Mechwarrior titles, but definitely takes some hours to 'git gud' at.Overall, if you've got a few hours a week (or more) to kill, this is one of the better F2P 'puter games I've played. The publisher definitely doesn't get everything right all the time, but I think overall they've done a good job, and I will definitely be playing this game for awhile. Not convinced? Watch this.

												I cant really promote this game.  Dont let the short playtime confuse you. I'm a huge mechwarrior fan from the old days and as such this game was what I hoped for..or at least I thought.  I was an early backer / founder and put a fair few hundred hours into the game  prior to it being added to Steam.  Soon enough it became apparent that the games a cash grab rather than offering content and  little has changed with the game since being added to Steam. The Devs are more interested in selling you mechs rather than adding any form of gameplay. Feel free to play and enjoy without buying any of the ridiculous overpriced mechs on sale or paying for premium but you'll soon find it's an unbalanced grindfest (i.e constant weapon rebalancing) with little to do but play the same handfull of maps over and over again. But dont take my word for it. Just go google the controversy that has followed this game since it's early days. The game is about milking you for cash for mechs and paint jobs, not giving you content to use said mechs in.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Actually very good for a free to play game (or really even for a full price AAA title.) You could very easily play this game and not spend a dime if you wished to. This and Star Trek Online have the best 'free to play' models that I have seen. Combat is very fun and engaging. Obviously there is a wide variety of skill level in opponents so you won't win every time, but you likely won't lose all the time either. You're always in a large team, so if you struggle, you can always stick with the pack and up your chances. Going off on your own is generally not a good idea.If I had to say something bad about it, it can be a little complicated at first, it has a somewhat steep learning curve and that can be intimidating to new players. It's best not to spend any of your early money on a mech, play the free 'trial' mechs until you know what style you like and then buy something that fits your style. There are A LOT of Mechs to choose between and you're likely going to have to watch some videos and do some research, it's not a simple game. I'm not normally a guy who likes PvP type games, but this game is great. If you can get 2 or 3 friends and travel in a pack it's even better.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												Elite Founder here - I supported the game late in its closed beta period.  It showed amazing promise back then.  Its a shame that, 4 years later, they've only put a coat of polish on a busted machine instead of actually addressing the core problems with the game.  PGI has always been more interested in producing monetizable content than actually making the game that founders like myself were sold on.  Matchmaking is a mess, always has been. Poor engine implementation, with a major CPU bottleneck, which is doubly sad considering that this game was in beta using this very engine back in 2012 and has done little to optimize these issues.  The Publisher, PGI, has engaged in a variety of shady, scummy business practices; serial overpromising leading to broken promises, a failed Kickstarter for a Star Citizen clone in 2014 while simutaneously pleading poverty and lack of manpower on MWO's promised feaures not being finished (aka "The Great Founders' Reunion"), solely focusing on producing more monetizable 'mechs, all while failing to actually optimize the core game as promised.Don't even get me started on balance, the generally terrible way PGI has interacted with the community, or the generally haphazard why this thing has been handled since beta.  It's abundantly clear that PGI just started throwing it all against a wall to see what stuck.  What was promised to be the definitive battletech expirence became little more than a microtransaction-laden esports-style arena shooter.BTW, this game is literally the reason I will NEVER purchase an early supporter pack from any developer, ever again.  Ever.

												Been playing MWO for years now. It is my favorite free to play game hands down. If you like fps,give this game a try. It can be a little daunting. It is fairly complex. There are endless variations for loadouts on mechs and play styles that go best with certain loadouts. You have to balance power, cooling,ammo,rate of fire,etc. You have to put in effort if you want to have fun. This means learning how to play your chosen mech and unlocking upgrades for mech to give you a bit more of an edge. Modules for mech also play a big roll. To give a couple of examples. These can be consumables in the form of coolant shots that greatly reduse heat in one shot or weapon modules that increase the rate of fire or range on a particular weapon. Your loadouts are fully customizable. This is a great game!

												quickie review:I'm really enjoying this game.A couple things:1) This game is a lot slower and more methodical then your standard FPS2) your mech can take a lot more punishment then your standard space marine/ww II soldier.  Its OK to take some hits.3) there is a rather steep learning curve with this game.  You will be killed.  Don't get discouraged.  You'll get better with practice. The tutorial and your first 25 matches give you extra in-game currency (C-bills) which can be used to buy a mech or two.5) join a faction and dip your toe into Community Warfare (youtube:

getting to level 2 in a faction nets you a free mech bay.6) Mechs that can only be purchased with real money will either be: A) not as good as mechs that can be purchased with in-game2 earnable currency, or B) will eventually be available for purchase with C-bills.7) This game has two currencies: C-bills and MC.
