content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												I've played this one since the open beta and really enjoy the combination of tinkering with the mech you bring into battle and the slightly slower pace of gameplay as a fairly tactical shooter (the mechanics mean you take quite a few hits to die in game which, in turn, slow things down a bit). There is a good range of different successful gameplay tactics and a huge range of customisable different mechs you can bring to a fight. After several teething issues (pre-steam, so don't worry) game balance is now pretty good between the two main factions ("inner sphere" and "clan") and the online population are fairly friendly in a wallaby-name-calling sort of fashion (see Gh1d0ra's review later!). The "storyline" part of the game, "community warfare", is fun with much more structured in-game challenges. However as it is pretty much "end game" content, it works best as part of a pre-organised team (lots of these accessible via the MWO website community links) and needs a top-line mech.It's main limitations are the initial learning curve and a limited number of maps and game types. Hopefully the developers will continue to respond to this in the next few months. Personally, I'm really hoping for some sort of intermediate gameplay between the random quickplay maps and the involved CW game (some sort of FFA deathmatch tournament would be great...)  All-in-all, it is good fun, especially as a free-to-play game, and I would recommend having a go through the initial cadet bonus stage, customing a bought mech until it is suitably bristling with lasers, ballistic weapons and missiles, blowing up the opposition team/going down in a blaze of glory and seeing if you enjoy it!

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												I started playing MWO back in Closed Beta and have played it consistently since that time. It has gone through a LOT of changes and is STILL undergoing changes (which isn't a bad thing). For me, it is still a lot of fun to play.Is it perfect? Of course not. Few, if any games are perfect. Is it Pay to Win? Not at all. There is nothing you can purchase for real money that gives you any advantage over those who use ingame currency. It may give you the opportunity to play new mechs early, but other than that, no advantages at all. All the Weapons available in the game work the same no matter on what Mech they are equipped (now, Clan weapons work differently from Inner Sphere but they work the same across all Clan mechs). There are no "Gold Weapons" or "Gold Ammunition".Why do mechs cost so much? That is indeed a good question and one I wish they would explain myself! Personally, I feel they would be better off selling them for less money to sell more but I guess they figure their price point currently maximizes their profits. And they are a company out to make a profit (who isn't)! That said, every mech (other than Hero and Champion Mechs) are available to purchase at some point using ingame currency that you can earn while playing the game.Hero Mechs? P2W!While it is true those mechs are only available for real money, they aren't P2W mechs. They are just mechs with a special paint/camo, and offer a Cbill % Bonus to your earnings. Hero mechs will have a weapon loadout that is not available on any other current variant usually but then suffer from some other disadvantage (perhaps it can't carry as many weapons as the others). But, the key point here ... all weapons perform the same, regardless of the Mech on which they are installed. So a Medium Laser is the same across all the Inner Sphere Mechs.Champion MechsChampion Mechs are exactly the same mech as their normal variant, just with a (C) designation and a boost to your Experience earnings. Trial MechsThese are what you will start with if you do not purchase any mechs with real money. They are free for you to use. You just cannot modify their loadouts whatsoever. You don't own them but you can play them to earn Cbills to purchase your own mechs. Learning CurveMWO is going to be wildly different from most other FPS type games. It is supposed to be a Mech Simulator, whatever they mean by that. Anyway, there will be a pretty steep learning curve for this game! To me, it was worth it and makes it so much more fun and involved. You have to learn how to Torso Twist to spread damage across your mech to increase your survivability. What this means is the upper half of your body can turn independently from your legs. You can be running one way and facing another (the degree of twist is dependent on the mech...some can turn more than others). Mastering the ability to Twist your Torso independent of your legs is a MUST.Aiming Reticles. You will likely have 2 sets of reticules. Your Arms can also move somewhat independently of your torso (depends on Mech) to some degree. The small Circle reticule is where your Arm mounted weapons will fire while the + reticule is where your torso mounted weapons will fire. Oh, the OTHER thing you have to keep in mind is WHERE on your mech these weapons are mounted as far as height goes. While your Reticule may not appear to be obstructed by terrain, low-mounted weapons may not fire over the hill you are standing behind (for example).Heat ManagementThis is going to be one of your MAJOR things to master in MWO. Every weapon you fire (with the exception of the Gauss Rifle) generates some measure of Heat. Your Mech can only handle a certain amount of heat before you risk shutting down and/or doing internal damage to your mech. Each mech has Heat Sinks that add to your heat capacity and also contribute to dissapating the heat you have accumulated. So, the greater the number of weapons you fire at once, the greater the amount of heat you build up. Also, the faster you fire, the more you generate heat. Heat is your biggest concern and the thing you HAVE to learn to manage.Ghost HeatThis is something the developers added as a "balance tool". It's not very well described in the game. What this means is they have set up a limit to the number of weapons of the same type that can be fired at the same time without incurring a "Ghost Heat Penalty". If you fire more than the allowed number at the same time, then you incur additional heat, hence the term "ghost". This penalty increases quickly based on how many more weapons past the limit you fire (so 3 more than the limit is penalized much more than 1 past the limit). You will get an indicator in the Mech Lab that warns you of the limit if you have more weapons of that type installed on the mech. For example, you can fire 4 SRM 4 missile packs without a penalty but if you fire 5 at the same time, you start incurring the Ghost Heat penalty. This is only if you fire them all at the same time. If you fire them one after the other (Chain Fire) you are fine or if you fire in smaller groups and pause at least .5 seconds between you are fine as well. So, it is a rather complicated game to learn but once you begin to understand and master the skills, it becomes second nature. The game still has some improving to do...matchmaking isn't the best in the land and the game really needs a Lobby available full time in my opinion, but they are slowly getting those things added. I find the core game a lot of fun to play.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Let me start by saying that I have played this game more or less continually since closed beta.Everyone asks if it is pay to win. No. It is NOT pay to win. Pay for convenience, absolutely. I spent the first year or so that I played without dropping a dime. It will take you time to build up a large reserve of cash and mechs if you don't invest anything but you absolutely can. Sure there are a few things that you can only buy with real world cash, about two dozen mechs, mech bays and paint. The mechs are nothing special, the bays can be won in some challenges/in-game achievements and the paint is purely aesthetics.The next problem I see people have is that there is a large learning curve. The game has become much more newbie friendly recently with the addition of a training academy tutorial and a tier system that will help to place you with similar skill level pilots. The issue many people have coming into the game is expecting a Hawken or CoD like shooter. This game is about tactics and attrition. You will need to hit your opponent more than once to bring him down at the same time avoiding as much damage as possible. My number one recommendation is to join a unit. Your peers are going to be a HUGE help with teaching tactics, mech building and the like.There is also a quickly growing competitive side to the game with PGI even hosting a tournament with a 100k cash purse. There are player driven leagues with cash prizes and a shout casts on twitch and with the new spectator tools allow for some really fun to watch battles.Overall I strongly recommend this game.

content:

												How i got to MWO? - SKIP it if you dont like personal introductory stories. Or else be my guest.I was looking through my games while moving and then i remembered I had a MW 4 - Vengeance CD somewhere. Didnt find it though but then I had an idea. Lets look it up on the interwebs. I found out no MW4 Vengeance around anymore so I read somewhere there was a MW ONLINE and then researched and did a very scientific survey - nah, just kidding - no survey but i really got excited and tried it out - Failed so badly that i tried more and more and after a couple of months MWO was my thing. I am in a very eligible unit but lawschool means sooooo much playtime while exams.Joined the battle February 2015.My Steam playtime doesnt represent my actual play time.I joined in on steam and do play on both the MWO Client and Steam Client.Have seen some changes til then and mostly they have been well received.*Mostly been playing quickplay and just got into community warfare - faction play lately so this review is quickplay originated.AND I am not going to talk about pug play because i am a pug myself. My experience is heavily positive but sometimes i encounter people that cause me to lose my temper.Because it has gone under changes various times i dont recall that much of em.*The ones i remember are the mechlab changes which now provide a good overview at everything. positive.*I definitely am a fan of the c-bill grinding but that only goes perfectly with premium time.So long i have been investing in the hero and champion mechs meaning i spent money in this f2p concept. - kinda negative.*I dont regret spending money on premium content but i figured it would be a little better if the game didnt have the mc thing going. This then would mean that without veterean founders the game might not even have made its release.So thank you veteran founders. You da real mvps out there.*if sales are going on - buy as much as possible especially if you get to win mc from events definitely spend em on mechbays. - definitely positive.*Also getting into faction play and achieving higher ranks will get you the MC and free Mechbays necessary. dont say no to free stuff ;)-BUT its very hard at the beginning even with the Cadet-bonus. At least that was my experience back in the day. - negative.THEREFORE definitely get to know other players and play together. We are a newbie friendly community and we'll help.-I am kinda upset that there arent any champions or hero mechs available for c-bills. There should have been just a couple heros/champs for c-bills at least. I am looking forward to every event and sale.You need to invest some serious amount of time and thereforeit gets really addicting - you ll spend your day playing and playing and playing.Remember to drink and eat and sleep enough.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Download and play if:-you played a MechWarrior game before-you like strategic shooters-you are a fan of simulation games-you like driving a tank but can't relate because it doesn't have legs like you-you are cool with losing a big portion of your time to reading strategies and thinking about this game-you can work together with 11 other people for ten minutes at a timeWe all know you have to "grind" your way through f2p titles, but there isn't another game that makes you forget instantly that you are "grinding" anything.  Playing Quick Play over and over again to work out your masteries on a chosen 'Mech is just fun.  Your first 20 matches gives you an insane amount of money to buy just about any 'Mech you want, and depending on what class and chassis you pick, you can even get your three variants to achieve mastery.Here's how not "grindy" the grind is: I played my first 17 hours and bought three heavy 'Mech variants, and achieved mastery of them without getting bored at all.  In fact, every match that I start, every time I click Quick Play, every time the oh-so-familiar 'Mech computer says "weapons online, sensors online, all systems nominal" I get goosebumps like I'm that kid I was back in 1995 when I first played MechWarrior 2, or when I saved my lunch money instead of buying lunch in middle school so that I could buy MechWarrior 4 in 2000.There is near limitless fun you can have just jumping in with Quick Play without ever giving PGI a dime.  Seriously there is not any reason someone who casually wants to shoot big robots in a walking tank would need to spend money.  But once you start finding yourself reading guides, learning strategies, working through your masteries on your first three 'Mechs, something will change.  You'll probably buy a 'Mech bundle, which somehow feels ok, it feels like an even trade, you won't look at your bank account and cringe at that impulse buy for a f2p title and you'll probably get more hours of enjoyment out of those three+ 'Mechs than you would from most $20 title on Steam.Play this game and:-you will become a MechWarrior, when you see the animation of your character booting up the 'Mechs systems and jiggling the controls, you will be transported to that cockpit and your chair is now the pilot's seat-you will call out contacts as they appear on the map, you will work together with your lancemates to flank and confuse and split up the enemy forces-you will turn your head and cringe when you hear "warning incoming missles"-you will cheer and sound crazy to the people around you when you kill an assault 'Mech while you are piloting a medium or light-you will be late to work and you will lose sleep-you will see lasers converging on a point when you close your eyes

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												I am not an old school mechwarrior, but I have played this game since 2013 and have enjoyed it immensely.  The community is great (although, there is quite a bit of disagreement between players about the game itself), and it is easy to find a friendly, mature group of people drop with.  People who say there is a learning curve are correct, don't be surprised if on your first drop you find yourself bouncing off walls and dying in a hail of fire.  Stick with it though, the controls are tight once you get a handle on them, and it gives you a sense of satisfaction when you finally get it down enough to effectively pilot a light mech.  I have enjoyed all of the game modes, although I wish there were a few more, and find customizing the mechs with the in game credits you earn to be endlessly enjoyable.  In short, this game is definitely worth a try for free.  (That said, saving up for mechs takes a good deal of time if you are going straight though in game credits and last I checked you do still need to buy mechbays to hold them.)

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												Great slow-paced shooter  (akin to a World of Tanks, etc) but still needs some work to really capitalize on the deep universe Battletech has to offer. The gameplay is solid with killer Mech designs and and combat that has a strong element of tactical positioning and smart management of various mechanics from heat buildup, one-shot artilleries or airstrikes, memorizing locations of enemy equipment to shoot it off, etc. Sadly, anyone looking to "exist" in a time and place in the BT universe will be sorely disappointed. There are A LOT of Mechs but only a small handful of roles that they all share so there really isn't much depth to the core gameplay. Again, the gameplay is solid so as long as you don't mind the "Warrior" part being underconstruction, you'll definitely dig the "Mechs."Great community (http://reddit.com/outreachhpg), patches like clockwork,  I've been playing it a few hours nearly every night since I started playing 4 years ago with friends and I play with them even today.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Writing the review from the POV of a mainly solo-queue player who has been around since the beta.Positives:Giant robot death machines.It's free-to-play.The game looks and sounds great, and the designs for the Mechs themselves have never been better.The core mechanics and "feel" of the game are fairly solid, with the team deathmatch and conquest game-modes being in a pretty good place right now.Mech customization leads to a particularly compelling meta-game.The weekend challenges can really spice things up a bit, if you are lucky enough to have the time to grind through them.Giant robot death machines.Negatives:The payment model is still far, far too expensive for what is on offer.Balance is still an ongoing issue, leading to a rotating roster of overly powerful "Meta-Builds" tending to dominate proceedings. Given the price of outright buying mechs, this can give players willing to pay over the odds a significant headstart in earning a strong gameplay advantage. (In PGI's favour, this aspect of the game has been steadily improving over time.)"Assault" mode is still a complete waste of time.The auto match-maker appears to take great joy in setting up hilariously lopsided matches.The weekend challenges, while spicing things up a bit, can quickly turn into a chore for those who aren't lucky enough to have a lot of free time to grind at weekends.TLDR:The game, while still having issues relating to balance and pricing, is fun, and it is possible, with a little research and pre-planning, to play successfully as a free player. Just be prepared for some frustrations along the way.

content:

												Terrific game, enjoying every moment of it. If you are familiar with the Mechwarrior franchise, battlestyle-wise the game feels very similar with big bad robots stomping each other. Most matches are done in 12v12s. Each match earns you C-bills, the in-game currency, which you use to buy new mechs or new equipment. There is a great deal of customization offered from the kind of weapons you can opt for, to the different variants of each chassis you can pick from and even down to what color or paint pattern you want on your mech to make it as visually distinguished as possible.One remarkable feature that I have to put out, the community is amazing so far. Most players I have came across are really helpful and patient, save for a few, but those a very small minority. Most players here are polite in response and will gladly help out new players in need. There are plenty of units (aka clans / guilds in layman terms) that are recruiting new players so if you have the time, you may want to check them out on the forums to help you get settled faster into the game.Overall experience: 8.5/10

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												I've played MechWarrior titles since 1995. It's my favorite genre and I've purchased every title in the series since. A few years ago I played this Open Beta for a couple weeks, and left very disappointed. I thought the title was doomed. But loyal fans spending lots of cash have kept the developers motivated. Improvements were made, so I decided to have another look. I've been back for 3 months now and while it's not the MechWarrior 5 I and many other fans hoped for, it is still quite enjoyable to play in its current state. Fortunately I picked a good time of the year to come back as multiple sales were going on both with in-game and premium currency. I was even motivated to spend some real cash for premium purchases which is out of character for me.So you're here to find out if this title is worth your time? If you love the series or the genre, I would say yes it certainly is worth installing and playing. There is a learning curve if your background is all Player versus A.I. of the previous titles. Humans are infinitely more unpredictable. (that's not saying they are always smarter) If your background is Player versus Player, especially First Person Shooter titles, this game's tactics will be familiar, yet different enough to be a new experience worth trying. You move much slower - depending on the chassis size, have multiple weapon groups to choose from - depending on range and heat levels, and must orient/steer your upper and lower torsos independantly.There is a strong focus on team logistics. You'll see it time and again: a lone wolf playstyle will get you killed as isolated mechs of any size can be overwhelmed with even just a pair of attackers. Then once you're gone, your team has a numbers disadvantage and the odds of them losing rise quickly. If you're the kind of person that likes team-chat, defined combat roles, and focused fire, you'll love this title.The in-game chat is 99.9% adult and respectful. Most are willing to give free advice and understand the challenges of playing the game well. Those that choose to swear/slur or team kill can be easily reported and seem to quickly disappear. The out-of-game community is alive and well. Searching the official forums, youtube, or the relevant reddit sites will give you links to many external resources for role-tactics, mech customization, chassis purchasing advice, social ladders, and just about anything you need to be successful except the actual in-game skill of keeping calm while 12 strangers (or possibly even friends once you've been around a while) are trying to melt your face off.I intend to play this game for quite a while, and I encourage anyone reading this to give the free install a shot. It might just be exactly what you're looking for. It doesn't take long for a new player to have several vehicles in the garage and feel like they can contribute or even turn the tides of a battle. Suit up!

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Few hundred hours played before Steam release.On to the game. Do you like the following: Big stompy mechs and sometimes smaller, faster, but less stompy mechs? Firing lazors? Big autocannons? Or perhaps you like being a scumbag who provides "support" fire with long range misiles? Creating the most awful awesome custom mech setup? Playing shooters that focus on thinking ahead rather than twitch reflex?If you answered yes to any of these, the game should suit you fairly well. It's a thinking man's shooter with a good ammount of customisation provided within a number of varied mech models. The weapons loadout boils down to four major groups with seemingly minor differences between them, but that still suffices to make for a number of opportunities to make something that feels, plays and is unique and hopefuly suited to how you like to play.Keep in mind though, this game is NOT the following: P2W - you can buy all mech variants for premium currency and there are premium exclusive mechs. That said, the only advantage the premium exclusive mechs really have is making more credits, you can put together a virtually identical mech and often enough a superior one if you like. Money gets you places faster, but given that it's not an easy game to master, going places faster may not be helpful... Easy to master - as mentioned, this isn't easy to master, but the community is relatively helpful and mature, so at least getting the hang of it isn't hard, there's ample tutorials around and plenty of people willing to advise. Developed fast - the game has changed a lot since I first dropped in four years ago, but given how long it's been, I'd say progress could definitely have been faster. Partially forgiven due to behind the scenes problems, but still rather slow.Now that I'm back following the Steam release, I expect to put in quite a few hours once again. Hopefully if you try it, you'll like it. Nothing to lose since it is F2P after all.

												This game is ridiculously fun. Giant robots blasting giant robots, not sure how that's bad? I would like to see some of the game modes refined, and the community warfare to have some more depth added, but this is a free game that lets you hop in a 100 ton battlemech and blast other battlemechs. The mech designs are awesome, the maps are pretty good for the most part, there are very real differences between how the different weight classes of mechs play, but all can be effective. I just finished a game in a 50 ton medium mech (CENTURION) with top damage for the match and won a free mech. Also, the laser sounds are soooooooo good. WUB WUB WUB. PEW PEW PEW.I usually play outside of steam (I started with the steam release, but the game works better outside of steam for some reason?) hence my low time played. I've got maybe 100 hrs at this point.Super fun.

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												First...I've only been playing for about 6 months. (We'll come back to that in a minute).This game is a "Stompy Robot Shooter" game. Basically an FPS but with robots of varying size and abilities. In some ways it's like Hawken but less of a 'video game' and more of a simulation. Which is what attracted me after getting burned out from COD (especially it's new Infinite Gymnastics release). So...if you're an FPS guy....this is a good FREE TO PLAY robot FPS. 3 out 5 stars right there with no othere considerations (see below) and it's free...you can spend a LOT of money in microtransactions but you don't have to if you just want to play it casually. Now...If you are a Lore-♥♥♥♥♥ then this game could be bad or good depending on how you want to view it. Yes, it does have some non-cannon parts. Yes, PGI can sometimes play fast and loose with mech design and weapons....but....you can't go from tabletop to video without some changes. I, personally, like the changes.....but those with OCD might not. (More on that in a minute).So...the game itself is pretty much like a lot of FPS games. You have teams. You have certain modes (TDM, Escort, Dom,o etc). Your weapons, while futuristic, break down into beam, ballistic, and missile. The mechs go from small to large. With the smallest being the fastest with the least armor and arms, while the Big Boys are slow but are walking bunkers.. The maps are, mostly, open so you can engage at range. (though there are some tight maps too).  If you are an FPS player its  an easy transition. You do have to watch your consumeables. You do have UAVs, System Cool Down Shots, Air/Artillary strikes...so it does have a more 'thinking' aspect to it than some of the other FPS games.  You can drop into random matches...or...join "Faction Play". Faction Play is currently a work in progress but has already, in my short playing time, gotten much better. You pick a side and either defend or attack to win all the planes in the games universe. You have the 'clan' (human descendents who are invading) or the "Houses" (star kingdoms ruled by a family or official who are defending from the clans). You'll need to read onlin and in game...LOT's of info.Now...let's talk about the community.I have met many awesome players and youtube posters who love the game. I've played with a few and had an absolute ball. One of the things (some) players talk about is how great the community is. For the most part it is....but....DO NOT GO INTO THE GENERAL FORUMS...STAYIN THE NEW PLAYER FORUMS!!! >>>> There are a large percentage of 'older' players who are NOT happy with the game. They're called "Bitter Vets" and they can be really mean and ugly. Most because of lore...some because they don't like the way it's morphed into more of a mainstream FPS game. but mostly because the tabletop lore is not the same as an online game. (NOTE: there were PC games in the MWO genre from the 80's and 90's and some can't understand why we can't have that kind of gameplay on MWO now...so still Lore ♥♥♥♥♥s but from a different generation of players).  Many of these "Bitter Vets" really really want this game to crash and burn  because they are so offended. Many of them have spent thousands of dollars to get every mech and they expect that the game should cater just to their needs. TLDR Rating?4 out of 5I play atleast 15 hours a week...so it does keep my interest. You CAN play this game and spend no money - There are many ways  to earn in game cash for anything you want to own.

												Arena combat shooter with stompy robot's that function similar to tanks. This game has a lot of content, and lots of customization. Fan's of classic MechWarrior will feel familiar, and new players have a great tutorial to study.Don't expect 360 no scope headshots, mech's take time and tactics to kill.Despite critisim from some battletech loyalists, the game is on par with most popular F2P titles like WarThunder and WoT. It recently become more balanced and less 'grindy' and you can unlock 95% of the games content for free (playing monthly events also rewards you with free swag).Investing in Hero mech's and premium time is well priced, and worth doing to keep the game alive.

												I have played this game since it was a boxed set for tabletop, saw the whole saga, decrepit inner sphere mechs half-patched together, very few new ones made, and suddenly there is this Merc Unit that has some peculiar weapons, seem to be Darn Good, and then left, bringing back Gen Kerensky alright, But NOT in the fashion they had in their wildest dreams imagined. Aside from the expense of the game (although that fits too since ONLY the Rich had mechs) this is a very well done creation of simulation to a fine degree. If I were not a disabled Vet on SSI I would be buying large numbers of mechs and packs etc... and playing them up to full levels.  Not much one can do once sedentary, yet this is something that helps with the cardio-vascular and mental alertness sides.  I am 54 and been going thru all the different versions of this game, but only heard about THIS a few months ago, and immediately found my old favorite, waiting patiently for me for me to return.Thank You for the Enjoyment!

												This is an awful game.The balance and gameplay changes have consistently taken a turn for the worse, and the equivalent of the star wars NGE experience is about to hit it.Most mechs that you use will be bad, or one particular variant of it will be good. If you love mechwarrior, go install one of the older games instead of playing this.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												I've played the game since founders beta so on and off since 2012. This game hasn't fixed its huge issues for years. Mech combat is poorly balanced, favouring clans, the more expensive faction, since they were released. The grind is rough, the first 25 matches gives you a large bonus so you can buy one IS mech and most of its upgrades. But that is only once and each new mech requires some basic upgrades like double heatsinks, a necessary update at 1.5 million for every mech, endo-steel, and new engines and weapons. After you get one mech you need to master 2 other variants of the same chassis to unlock the skills required to compete with veterans who have been playing for a long time.The queue times are probably the biggest killer, taking 5+ minutes to find a basic match for the game's most common game mode and that's the fastest it gets. Community Warfare queues can take up to 30 minutes.Game modes in this game are all really simplistic with the TDM and team conquest styles because really basic kill-all-enemies is fine but the community warfare mode is completely lacking on any deeper roles or meaning despite it being supposedly the final game mode for faction vs faction warfare. Factions are so empty that everyone jumps around to whatever faction has enough people and there's no meaning to planetary losses or gains.Overall, this game has been developed poorly for years, minimal viable product being an actual term used to describe it by the developers, and this is just an attempt to gain a few more people before the game goes under. The free to play game is usually described as having whales to make money and a large amount of people to fill the game so everyone's happy. MWO is a game that only has whales left and they're desperate for the game to appeal to people who don't want to spend hundreds of dollars on this game.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												As a veteran player, this game is a substantial letdown. Gone are the mechanics and thrill of piloting a mech that was present in Mechwarrior 2, Ghost Bear's Legacy, and so forth. The game itself is graphically beautiful and may take a recent graphics card to handle it at a good frame-rate. Sadly, this is the only real good thing going for it.Much of the control system has been entirely removed, opting for an extremely "streamlined" method of play. This is to such an extent that one wonders if a keyboard is really necessary anymore. The sheer amount of customisation that was in previous entries is vastly reduced. While the predecessors gave the feel of a simulator, this rendition feels more like an arcade game.Although the publisher claims the game to be free, it is instead paid through numerous, pricey "microtransactions". It would be far, far cheaper to just buy a game outright. There is no option for that here (it would be significantly cheaper).As a note to those who have played MechWarrior Online in the past, you will be forced to play through a tutorial before you can return to active multiplayer gaming.If one is completely new to the genre, they may enjoy it. For others, I strongly recommend running the older games or looking for an open-source game that competes with this.Requiescat in pace, FASA. It was a good run while it lasted.

number of helpful: 24 of 49 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Ok, so unlike alot of commentaries here I'm not going to discuss the progression of this game since Closed Beta, through Open Beta to today. Today is what matters, as the game goes to STEAM.  To be up front, I have about 11,500 matches under my belt and hundreds of hours of game play so I'm not new to the game, it's background or it's challenges.Video fx/Graphics (8): The artwork for the Mechs is fantastic imo. Even if you don't necessarily agree with the direction of the Art team or modeling of the Mechs, they still look well done and attractive. Intimidating and lethal, they look much as any fan of the intellectual property of BattleTech might imagine. I deducted points here due to some pixelated terrain that looks like a game from 2003 in places and some odd modeling/animation mistakes. Additionally, some of the mechs need a scaling overhaul, as some smaller tonnage mechs are larger than mechs in heavier weight classes. Overall tho, a great effort and all indications are this will get better. Audio (9): Again, barring some minor aesthitic disagreements, the sound effects are well done and the game sounds good during gameplay. Autocannons have a great bang/crunch mechanic, lasers sound vicious and explosions/getting hit add to the immersion. Immersion (6): This is where the video excellence and audio excellence fall short, in tandem with other things that are decidedly lacking. The musical backdrop is solid usually, but there are no immersive ingame sounds. While you are in the Mechlab/game join screens. If I'm in some giant bay somewhere modifying a 60-ton warmachine, shouldn't there at least be some air-wrenches screaming or the sounds of metal clanging or SOMETHING besides simple music? Missed opportunity there. Additionally, there's no tie to a back story within the game. If you're not already familiar with the IP, most of the game will mean nothing to you nor does the game give you much information in that respect. Backstory (0): PGI makes no effort to tie the grand-lore that sets this IP apart from any other "walking-tanks" battlesim and misses out hugely there. Hiring some writers or poaching directly from the novels/game books that are associated with the IP would make sense here, but there's no real history at all. Just some forum links to community based websites (such as sarna.net) that are great efforts, but in no way as reach, or as accurate as actually being source material. With the addition of "communit warfare" some of the planets have information about them, but no context really. Ultimately, you know this IP/background already or you're finding it from other sources, as PGI hasn't bothered.Gameplay (7.5): Purely from a gameplay mechanics and fun aspect, I enjoy playing it BUT I've been playing it for years now. The initial stings of playing through the learning curve are long past for me. I can enjoy the new Mechs as they are introduced immediately for their various strengths and weaknesses. This is not the same for new players.New Player Experience (2): I only grudgingly even give it a 2. The tutorial is a great (recent) addition to the game, but the game mechanics are not explained well anywhere, forcing new players to learn through pain or comb through dense forums. The occasional tip at the start of the match isn't enough, and usually have to do with reminding players about key-bindings to use. It has no centralized resource to explain how the Clan, Inner Sphere, Trial, Hero, or Champion mechs work differently, how certain weapons when "boated" in larger quantities cause ghost heat, etc to help people understand what the heck they are doing. The cadet bonuses to your first 25 matches are substantial but easily squandered by new players who are completely clueless on what does what. A PDF file attached to the game with all of the tips and key info, or a wesite framework with a similar design would be incredibly helpful to new players. The current website information is largely out of date.Balance (7.5): The weapons have some balance issues that are bound to be improved upon but are not intuitive to the player. The Mechs themselves as the platforms have some glaring optimal performers and some glaringly bad Mechs, with the majority in the comfortable middle. If all Mechs had useful roles, even if those roles were not purely combat related, that would improve their value immensely. Players who live primarily Clan, or Inner Sphere tend to accuse the other side of being "OP" based on Clan mechs having significant intrinsic advantages uniformly, while Inner Sphere mechs enjoy very niche, but powerful "quirks" to bring them up to par. Overall, balance has improved much over time and continues to balance the main systems to a reasonable degree. Room to improve here, but overall it's solid. Modes/Replayability (2): The game has three quick modes....assault, where teams can kill the enemy team or capture a objective on their opponents' side of the map, conquest where teams can the enemy team or earn points by owning up to 5 slow-ticking objectives scattered between the two teams, and skirmish which is team death match. Community warfare, involving larger maps (but still 12 on 12 matches) with 4 spawns per pilot is the "meta" level of the game, where players are fighting over planets. As much as I'd love to say they got this right....it's incredibly tough to enjoy at the moment for a variety of reasons you can read about on the forums. I'm very hopeful that Beta 3 will introduce some options that add more to that mode and help attract more players to it.EndGame/Why play factor (2): Once the fun wears off in playing the same three modes, you're left with grinding new Mech chassis for the sake of collecting them. Without a driving reason to fight and no value to community warfare outside of bragging rights (no politics, impact to resources, impact to your gaming experience for fighting etc), you're literally just playing because you enjoy the shootem up portion or to make your collection larger. F2P factors: There's no penalty to P4F, as the "hero Mechs" don't represent a real leg up in any true sense, but it does cut into the grind ALOT to pay for premium time. Grind:  This game does have a grind/leveling component that can be daunting for new players only because again, within the New Player Experience (NPE), they are likely to make mistakes in how they spend their initial funds.  Recently, PGI increased the rate of return on c-bills (ingame currency) that helps mitigate this facet of the grind, and players will learn quickly about the experience/mastery grind which really isn't something you can get around without spending MC ($ for game currency) to expedite.In 2013, I gave this game a 5 on metacritic.My overall opinion of the game would be to give it a 7 currently, but again I'm biased due to my love for the Battletech IP.  If you "scored" things with roughly equal weight as I laid them out above, you'd get a lower #. In the end though, the community is small but overall pretty good (ignore the toxic outliers), the game has a certain amount of fun factor that cannot be explained, the game continues to improve albeit at a slow pace AND it's F2P without any real penalty to do so.Well worth the serious stab at it if you're at all interested in tactical shooters, especially ones that are not pure twitch.

Posted: December 11, 2015
												Certainly a thinking person's shooter. With communication, teamwork and stratagy dictating the skill ceiling of pilots. mWo is not for those who expect to play the game for a week and assume completion and own everything in the game. You will need to work hard at mastering the in ingame mechanics; switching views, torso twisting and information processing. The free to play format is perfection, PGI are generious if you put the time in. And even more generious If you use real currency in the game. Solo queue and go it alone expect the longest possible grind to attain your C-bills and Mech's. Join the forums and community, fast track your training and ability and understanding of the universe. Find a unit, join a house, perhaps become a loyalist and reap the rewards offered. This is a game that will keep you on your toe's, last the ages and give you friendships that will last a lifetime.For those interested in making the most out of this game without spending money, each and everyday mechs have a x2 bonus on your first win for the day. So if you win a game on all the trail rotation mechs and play 1-2 community warfare games a day you make plenty of c-bills. There is also Cadet bonuses, faction rewards, tutorials and Achievements. Keep an eye out on your launch client as events that reward premium time and all sorts of goodies are a regular thing!We welcome you steam to our war harden universe, see you on the battlefield warriors.  o7

												Riding on the back of battered and neglected franchise was PGI: Offering promises to a desperate fanbase to take them for every penny they could get. MWO is a good example of a F2P game done wrong, absurdly overpriced founders packs paved the way for consistantly overpriced mechs that in some cases cost as much as a entire AAA game followed by even more expensive and gated mech packs that mean that even when a mech will be available for 'free' (by free I mean spending hours and hours and HOURS grinding for) they wont be available for SEVERAL months while the poor smucks that dished out buckets of cash will be using these fancy new but unavailable to you mechs to curbstomp you. (Unless they got one of the bad eggs, then they have a high priced turd you can demolish for free!)Now don't get me wrong, at its core the game is pretty fun, just grindy as hell and having buy buy buy constantly being thrown in your face by a dev team that has consistantly abused its playerbase (in some cases belittling them). Most of the original MWO fanbase either hates the amount of money and time they wasted on this game or they fanatically cling to a dying dream coasting on the sometimes thousands of dollars 'invested'.Do I recommend playing the game? Yes. Do I recommend spending a single penny? Hell, no.

number of helpful: 19 of 39 people (49%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Looking for the honest opinion of a veteran of big stompy robot goodness?  Someone with an intimate understanding of even the smallest game mechanics, and who can give an objective review for all of MWO's features without sugar-coating them?  Well sit back and read on potential mechwarrior.  I, the venerable Carchemish (in-game name) do kinda sorta fit that description.  Mostly.I'll break this down into what MWO is, and what it is not.  First the 'is':-  Mechwarrior Online is a player vs player, team arena style game set in the venerable Battletech universe.-  It is a beautifully rendered game, both in the landscapes and of course the mechs.  PGI has done a fantastic job making the mechs look amazing, especially given the awful source material. Anyone familiar with the old crappy Battletech "artwork" knows what I mean.  I really can’t say enough about this.  I’m always blown away by how they continue to make such gorgeous mechs from such bad original art-  It is a great blend of slow, build-up-to-the-fight, and then fast paced action.-  You’ll have a huge mech variety to explore.  Want to race across the map in a fast, agile scout?  Done.  Want to slowly lumber into the battle in a behemoth carrying a blistering array of guns?  Make it happen. -  MWO is well balanced across the two opposing factions, the Inner Sphere and the Clans.  Those familiar with the BT lore will know how insanely strong Clan tech was compared to the Inner Sphere.  PGI has done a very good job of balancing the two sides without entirely neutering the Clans.-  MWO has an appreciable learning curve, and will take some time to fully absorb.  The actual gameplay is essentially point and shoot, but the mech and weapon variety will take a while to get used to.Now for the 'is not':-  MWO has no PVE content (yet).  If you prefer a story-driven game with missions and NPCs and such, this may not be the game for you.-  MWO is not a ‘fast action all the time’ game.  Players will have to scout, find the enemy, set themselves up in the best positions they can, maneuver on the fly, and duke it out with the other team.  Planning and forethought will help you win games. Which brings me to my next point.-  Mechwarrior Online is NOT a single player game.  It is a team effort which rewards players for working with their cohorts.  Running off by yourself (with few exceptions) will likely get you and your team murdered.-  It is by no means a perfect game.  It has bugs, though they are few in number.  The mech balancing isn’t complete, though they continue to work on that.-  It is not “pay to win”.  This one deserves some attention.  Yes, there are some mechs (the so-called “hero” variants) which can only be purchased with real cash, but in most cases they are actually inferior to the standard variants!  So why would you buy them in the first place, you ask?  Hero mechs provide a c-bill (in game currency) boost when playing them, so they’re a good way to earn more money to buy more mechs!  And when I say “inferior”, I mean marginally so in most cases.  Sometimes they are just as good.   And yes you can purchase mech packages with real money, but they offer no advantage over other players who choose to grind out the in-game money!-  It is not World of Tanks!All in all, MWO is a solid game with a lot of playability and huge potential for even more features in the future.  If you enjoy the PvP experience, and are into the mech genre, this one won’t disappoint.  I fully recommend it, so long as you know what you’re getting into.  Last thing…getting a hold of a decent headset/mic and Teamspeak will make your mech life much easier.Hope to see you on the battlefield!  Carchemish the Wise and Powerful

number of helpful: 16 of 33 people (48%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												A thinking man's shooter, Mechwarrior Online takes the best part of tank battles and first person shooters and merges them together in Giant mechs ranging from 20-100 tons in weight and dwarfing other types of units on the battlefield.Let me start out by saying that this game does have a steep learning curve.  If you have not played this game before, you will need to go through the Academy first.  That will give you the basic tools to play the game.  After that, you will want to play your Cadet bonus matches in a variety of mechs to get the feel of the different weight classes.  Do NOT buy a mech until you have gotten a good feel for the different weight classes.  Once you have gotten an idea of what you want to play with, go ahead and head to the in game store to buy your first mech with C-bills, the in game currency.  You should have plenty for your first mech after those cadet bonus matches for even an Assault mech.Now that you have bought a mech of your own, you can customize it in the mechlab.  This is going to cost you more C-bills to buy the parts and weapons and upgrades that you want.  You will also find that you have various skills you need to earn experience to unlock and upgrade.After that, if you want to play casually, have fun and enjoy stomping around in your Battlemech.  If you are more competitive, check out the forums on the main game website and see who is recruiting.Overall, I have loved this game, is it perfect? No.  Is it a lot of fun?  You bet it is!  I'll see you out there, Mechwarriors!

number of helpful: 15 of 31 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												So here is the deal with MWO.  Its NOT a tabletop game.  Its more of a shooter at this point with a huge selection of chassis and loadouts.  Depending on the chasis and loadout depends on how you play.  Its a huge cooperative/teamwork game.  If you dont play with your teammates you die.  Your team dies and you all look like noobs.  Its very unforgiving in this regard.There is really no endgame at this point and as I am sure you have seen in some of the reviews it was promised to be much much more but it is not there yet.  They have been implementing new content at a higher pace recently and the balance and tweaks have been generally good.  The 3 different gameplays of Skirmish, Conquest, and Assault really do not vary much as it usually just turns into an all out brawl at the end.  Community Warfare is fun but intense and absolutly REQUIRES teamwork as you end up going against coordinated opposing teams that absolutly dominate uncoordinated teams.  However, some of the funnest, heart pounding, got the shakes gameplay has come from CW as it is very...well,,intense.So if you are wanting an RPG style shooter this is not it at the moment.  If you are looking for a good well rounded stompy robot game then this is it.  Literally endless options on how to tweak your mechs and customizations.  Serious fun team play and solo play.  Find yourself a good group of friends to play with or a friendly unit to drop with and you will enjoy this game.  btw I have been playing MWO with theskjaldborg.com (SoR) for 3 years now and we can help point you in the right direction if you want.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Great game, with a great community.Has a step learning curve, but after you got the basics it become even betterIch spiele MWO seit August 2012 und uns verbindet eine Art Hassliebe. Mit der Entwicklung geht es wie in jedem Onlinespiel rauf und runter und es wird mal besser, mal schlechter. In der Com kennt man sich doch inzwischen ganz gut und diese ist auch breit aufgestellt.Was wirklich der Plus Punkt schlecht hin ist.  Passionierte Spieler die aus dem Spiel mehr machen, als nur der Arena Shooter der es auf den ersten Blick zu sein scheint.Auch wenn viele auch den Waffenwerten herumhacken (und wir haben viele Waffen hier) gibt am Ende doch der Spieler, die Wahl des Geländes und wie er sich auf sein Team abstimmt den Ausschlag. Manche Gefechte gehen verloren, weil ein Mech irgendwann zu zeitig ausgefallen ist, andere werden gewonnen, weil ein scheinbar verwirrter Marodeur Pilot mitten im offenen Gelände mehr durch Zufall eine "brauchbar" Koordinierte Zangenbewegung aufhält. Es sind diese besonderen Momente, die das Spiel wirklich großartig machen können. man geht ohne Chance auf einen Sieg in ein 2 vs 1 Duell gegen 2 Mechs die zusammen doppelt so schwer sind.... und man siegt....oder man führt einen Angriff und auf einmal ist das Team verschwunden...und dann zerbricht man dennoch im Alleingang die Linie des Feindes.

number of helpful: 11 of 23 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												I have played MWO a lot in the last two years. I find the gameplay is good, the maps are fun, and the variety in the mechs adds a lot of flavor, strategy and planning that needs to be done before a match even starts.Is the game perfect? Definitely not. There is a steep initial learning curve, the matchmaker can sometimes take a while to find a match, and with all the customization it's easy to bring something to the battle that is very sub-optimal. On the flip side, I really enjoy the high skill ceiling, the high level of customization, the intense matches, and that good strategy/tactics pay off in the field.Would I recommend this to anyone? Absolutely. Is everyone going to find something to like about the game? Absolutely not. If the theme or style appeals to you at all, there is a lot of stompy robot goodness to love in the game. If you like shooters, I'd say give it a try and see if it's your thing. I'd still recommend anyone slightly interested give it a try, as the game is great for a free game. I continue to get a lot of enjoyment and entertainment from it.If you try it out and don't like it, then I wish you luck on finding your next game. If you try it out and do like it, you are in for a lot of fun! I'll look forward to dropping with you in the near future. :)Cheers!Malum

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												This game has so much potential, despite it being made by the same people who brought you duke nukem forever... First ill give the pros and cons of the game, and then ill go into depth explaining why I do not recommend this.Pros:1. gameplay is challenging and stupid players get destroyed quickly.2. Its highly skill oriented3. It requires tactical gameplay, poking your head out is a cause for destruction, and being a rambo is instant death4. It has a lot of customization and variants to suit the needs of the battle5. Puts more of an emphasis on team play than lone wolf play. You get more rewards for doing damage and assisting your team, than you do for getting a kill, typically/Cons:1. Very Long Range Missile (LRM) heavy skirmishes, meaning you wont be able to necessarly see them before they destroy you2. No Prevention of Bad players from participating in CW, leading to faction imbalance, players getting stuck at their spawn to instantly die3. Admins do not adhere to their own code of conduct and enforce the CW (community warfare) code of conduct... which would ban most bad players4. There is no learning curve, only a cliff with a bottomless pit that you will barely be able to crawl out of.Most players are going to suck at this game the moment they enter. You cannot go in thinking you will dominate the entire enemy team. Very few will and chances are you are going to die a lot before you learn.On top of this, there are no requirements to enter community warfare/faction play. This is a mistake, there is a special code of conduct reserved for it. If you suck you are dragging your team down. Their CoC follows the league of legends rules to where if you ♥♥♥♥ up in cw, you will be getting penalized... but the admins do not do their jobs.Players will bring in trial mechs, not have the skills or custom loadouts to get the job done. CW is end game and many players just dont care. You do not queue for CW if you dont know how to play, simply put the devs are just screwing around.In order to unlock skills, for mechs, you have to purchase the mechs, with cbills. Then if you want to go up to the elite/master tier of skills, you need to have 3 variants of the same mech, and max out all normal skills to get to elite, and all elite skills to get to master... on all 3 variants. It takes time to do this, and it really does matter, in the end... so if you dont like to grind, this is not the game for you.I will end this with one statement. Its not fun if you constantly lose because bad players dont care. Its not fun if you are trapped in spawn and cant even fire at the enemy before you are dead. I will not recommend this game until there are requirements to enter CW, and even then it will be an apprehensive reccomendation.It is very clear that pirhana games has no clue what they are doing in their game design, and it is fairly clear they will never know. Once again, this is made by the same morons who made duke nukem forever. This should be a clear indication of the incompitence you will find in the development of this game.

number of helpful: 77 of 156 people (49%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												There continues to be a dedicated community around this game. For better or worse, their love of what this game "could be" keeps them both playing and being positive about the game as a whole. As far as positives there are some great members of the MWO community, and early on that kept me playing this game. As a founder unfortunately I don't have similiar feelings about the developers but my feelings are less important then the facts.When advertising for the game began several promises were made about the type of game being delievered. Mech warrior online would be a "....the Mechwarrior you know. It's a fully first-person. It's not a new interpretation."  "Players will be able to band together in the format of a lance..... they'll be able to band together as a mercnary coporation for hire.... to customize the look and feel ..... how they enter battle, the lances, their names, ranks, and all kinds of things.""Anything that would affect or give you a tactical advantage, you can't purchase with real cash." I could continue quoting unrealized promises and quickly run over the character limit for reviews so I will sumarize.Of the "four pillars" of gameplay (mech, role, community, information) at best two are fully realized. You can both purchase mechs/items with real money and some of the meta (most useful in the current game) mechs can not be purchased without a cash purchase.The idea of community warfare and therefore the ability to act as a "mercenary" is completely non-existant even though it was heavily talked about. News/lore relevant to actual gameplay (arguably another part of community warfare, but still missing)A single player campaign, PVE, the explicit statement that there would be no 3rd person, coolant flush/shots, priority strikes (improved usuables only available with real money). The devs also had several at best insulting statements to large portions of the community on multiple occasions, claiming that same old "small vocal minority". There are multiple instances of employees acting out towards individuals in the mwo community, there are certainly claims on both sides, but several instances of them acting out without just cause, including the entire banning of huge groups of players, then later saying they would unban anyone who asked nicely. Theres no doubt they unjustly banned players to ever make such an offer.On top of this the game has only gotten more punishing for new players with hard to understand hidden mechanics, the worst example being "ghost heat".On all of these, simply google them, no need to take my word. Theres more to be found.tl:dr Game with potential and amazing community members ruined by the developer and employees.

number of helpful: 12 of 25 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												This is not the MechWarrior game we are looking for.In its current state, MWO is not going anywhere fast. It is painfully aparent that this Free-to-Play game is supporting itself on very expensive Mechpacks (new mech comes out, preorder commences, nostalgic players drop $80, rinse and repeat). Gameplay is very, very stale. The 'immersive' battlefield known as Faction Play is a barren wasteland that is simply a harder and less-popular clone of Quick Play.Here is what you will find if you play this game.You will get massive ammounts of C-bills (probably around 25-million) for your first 25 games. Then your recruitment bonus will end and funds will trickle in like icicles melting in a warm breeze. It becomes EXTREMELY time consuming and tedious grind for a single million C-bills.Mechs (the ones that are available for C-bills) cost MILLIONS of C-bills to purchase, and you only get 3 free slots for Mechs. So unless you win a Mechbay from an event, you will only be able to own 3 Mechs for free. That is, assuming you manage to earn enough C-bills to buy 3 Mechs.Quick Play (which is currently the ONLY viable game mode) is the same 12 vs. 12 man match over and over and  over and over again. You have different maps and slightly different objectives (if other players vote for them at the voting screen) but it is hardly enough to keep you engaged and interested for the lenghth of time it would take to afford an Assault Mech.Oh, and these 12 vs. 12 matches are PUG matches. Which means you will be trying to coordinate a 12-man team of random players. Use your imagination.All told, game looks great and the mechanics aren't terrible. Sadly it is one of the ever growing number of Free-to-Play titles that are going towards the Pay-to-Enjoy model. And heads up, even if you do pay, it won't make the matches more interesting.

number of helpful: 12 of 25 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												Welcome back to the Mechwarrior Universe, where you can bask in the glory of many different Mechs both Inner Sphere and Clan as they spew death upon one another in the beautifully crafted maps of MWO.The combat is highly tactical, the skill of a mechwarrior is not in their twich reacations but their choice of target and how they engage it, with the build they have entered the arena with. The game encorages players to work together & improve their teamwork and to be tactical with their shots managing their mechs heat levels not only when deployed in combat but when creating the loadouts for their purchased mechs. That large pulse laster puts out a lot of focused damage at good range, great for removing opponents limbs and components, but it also puts out a lot of heat and it is heavy!I have been playing MWO for about 2 years and i can honestly say that i have seen a continuous improvement in the game over that period (it has had some downs as well). There are not a lot of games i am still playing after such a long period which i consider testament to its quality.MWO caters well for casual play if you just want to stomp around in a big robot spraying laser death for an half an hour or so as well as more involved clan matches and alliances in clan warefare.The regular challenge weekends have been fun and provided insentives to get players using new features when they have been added, as well as giving players "hats" to adorn their mech cockpits with.edit:Just read a review which slammed the mwo community... clearly the reviewer had never attempted to join it. The PGI forums are very active and a lot of experienced players are willing to advise new ones, the team speak servers are also very active!The reviewer also mentioned that there is no guidance on how to build a loadout for a mech and that its easy to blow your hard earned cbills on something that, well isnt the most effective build. I will go back to the community bit here because the builder tool http://mwo.smurfy-net.de/mechlab lets you design your mech build and test its heat performance before you spend a stone. If you dont know enough to work out a good build on your own there are countless shared builds to choose from linked from the forums.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
 TLDR:  I cant recommend this game at this time. The developers prioritize money (overpriced mechpacks) over any real content, it's shown through the lack of finished content added to the game in the last two years. If you really want to give it a try, go for it, just set your standards low. It's not a AAA title nor is it even close to finished. In fact there's little this game does well. If you want to know more, please read below, and thank you for your time. LONG VERSION Let the player numbers speak for them selves.  Player Count [steamcharts.com]The monetization of the game is quite possibly one of the worst I've ever seen.  Mechs packs being sold from $30 bucks to an astonishing $220.  That's a  premium price for an unfinished game  that doesn't have a bright future in terms of content.Mechs may be bought with in-game money at an exorbitant price for each one. Then you have to buy weapons, a new engine, modules, for your mech. Let's do some math shall we? Let's pretend you are going full free to play, and want the best mech in the game Kodiak 3k. 16 Million C-bills      150,000 C-bills a match      15 mins for each       You need 16 Mill            16 Mill / 150.000 = 106.6 matchs * 15 mins = 1,600 mins / 60 mins for a hour = 26 straight hours.  26 hours, in a mech you may not like, for a SINGLE MECH and thats not the cost for the weapons. Granted their are cheaper mechs, but chances are they are♥♥♥♥♥♥and you will only have them to level them.Only "4" game modes. Skirmish(TDM), Assault (TDM), Domination(TDM), and Conquest.                       1.) Skirmish: Standard TDM                      2.) Assault: TDM with the option to capture the enemy base.                      3.) Domination: TDM with you being forced to fight in the center of the map.                       4.) Conquest: being the worst mode due to the maps not being designed for it and teammates not knowing what do to.   Graphic are just ok, and battle damage looks like something made in MSPaint. PGI cant stop the hackers. Seriously. You wont see many because the player base is low, but again PGI can't stop the ones that do without video proof.A small development team means VERY SLOW small releases if they aren't delayed for months.Global chat is NOT the game. It may be to limit people from knowing how many players are on.The UI for the mech bay is terrible, and that's after they revamped it.The UI for your friends/Unit/and LFG window is just a crappy block window. It doesn't even have ranks for your Unit.Few maps, made even fewer by the vote system. You'll constantly play same 5ish maps over and over because most of the maps are just that badly designed, and no one wants to play on them.Every match in any game mode will boil down to death balling.Cosmetics cost around 5-15 bucks to really make a SINGLE mech look unique.The sounds effects and motions of the mechs dont feel visceral. Giant 25-100 ton mechs walking around don't feel very large. The massive weapons don't sound like the 16inch cannon they are suppose to really feel/sound like. Even the more power weapons feel like their smaller counter parts.Community Warfare is the biggest joke in the game. If your Unit takes a planet from someone else...good job. That's all you get. C-bill reward is higher for each match, but you need 4 fully fleshed mechs to really be on par with the enemy, and if you don't do well you wont get a great reward. Also you will be mostly playing against a 12 man team. Thus making solo dropping pointless unless you want you be fighting a losing battle from the start.The community is torn into two groups those who are burned by the developers who not making the game the promised and those who spent too much money on the game to see it die and watch their money go to waste. Just check the message boards on Steam, Reddit, and don't bother on their main forum. They auto delete/downvote any criticism that isn't praising the game at the same time. Seriously I'll be surprise if you see this review.The small development team has a long history of lies to their player base about what content they are working on.

number of helpful: 11 of 23 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
												I've played this games for hundreds of hours before it came to steam and came back to it about a month ago so this is my opinion on the current iteration of this game.Pros:Well thought out mechanics.Skill is based on precision and teamwork in this game.Probably the best community I've seen in a game (youngest person I've met online was 16).Immersive gameplay.Great visual queues for everything that happens whether dealing damage or taking it.Teamwork focused gameplay.Extremely Customizable mechs and mech loadouts.There are no "bad mechs" as all have strengths and weaknesses.All weapons are fair and balanced.Beautiful scenery/models/animations.Great F2P system (you earn a ton of money early with the cadet bonus which allows you too basicly buy any mech).Little to no "trolls".Cons:Extremely high skill ceiling for new players.Clan wars (Comp.) can be dreadful and not worth your time if you aren't in a good faction/group.If you are new and past your cadet bonus you won't be making much money as you won't be getting many points.If you don't do well then earning c-bills (in game currency) can become a grind instead of a steady income.Game modes aren't different enough from one another.Queuing system needs reworking.Overall this game is its own unique experience as no other game is quite like it. It puts you into a cockpit of a huge 25-100 ton War machine and tells you to go out and destroy the enemy Pilots. The feeling you get when you peel apart enemy mechs and visualing see them being torn to ribbons is a feeling no other game can recapture.I can't recommend this game enough. It's fun, has a great community, and as of July the dev team has worked out some of the previous hinderances and problems that this game had (that plagued it long ago but no more!). Now is the best time to play this game so Pilots power up your mechs and head out to war!!9/10 please just try it you are missing out :)(Ps message me if you have questions I am happy to answer anything MWO related!)

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												I have played this game since closed beta, and a Legendary Founder for the game. I have seen this game change very much since those days. Ever since IGP went bankrupt and the license has been under PGI control, they have done a lot to make the game so much more. From Faction Warfare, to a robust tutorial system, to a future PVE campaign. This game is not Call of Duty, this is not Rambo rampage, this is MechWarrior. The combat is slower paced, and team oriented. Running around solo, trying to be superman will get you killed. Stick with your team, focus fire, provide cover fire and try to move from cover to cover. Don't be scared by the price of mechs and mech packs, every single mech (except for hero mechs) can be earned for free by simply playing the game and grinding cbills. There is no 'Pay to Win' mech, buying mechs with cash does not give you a mech thats superior to a standard mech bought with cbills. The only difference between a standard mechs, champion and Hero mechs is that champion mechs earn 30% mroe xp (that stacks with premium time), and Hero mechs {designated by parenthesis like (F), (L), (I), (S), etc} earn 30% more cbills (which stacks with premium time). But you can get standard versions of the same mechs without the bonuses. Not to mention that almost every month PGI has an event where you can usually earn free cbills, MC, mech bays and sometimes even mechs for free. And you can earn free mech bays for doing faction warfare. [Warning if you are a brand new player, I do not recommend doing faction warfare until you have 4 full mechs that are decently skilled)This game will give back to you what you put back into, whether its just a couple quick drops for after hard day, or you are binge-playing over the weekend to get event rewards, The more you play, the better your understanding of the maps and mechs will do you will. Torso twisting, focus firing, cover from LRM swarms, This game will take time to get good at, and putting skills into mechs will make your mechs play better, which will in turn make you play better.Dont be afraid to ask for help, the community thats been here for over 3 years has no problem helping out new players, but for more indepth answers to your questions, go to the MWO forums. There is only so much people can answer in the games chat.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Technically, this is free to play. Yeah, well, technically. In reality, if you want  to compete you'll be plunking down cash for one of the two in-game currencies you can only buy with cash. Works like this: To max out your pilot's abilities on a chassis, you need to level-up four different variants of that chassis, so you need to buy four different variants of that chassis. To compete in something other than skirmish play (random pubbies) you need to have leveled up four different chassis. So four variants times four chassies equals sixteen different variants. Problem: you only start out with space for four chassis. So if you want to avoid paying cash for more you'll be selling chassies for underwear-streaking losses to fit the next one. While you could *technically* do this, it's a giant waste of your resources, which means it's a giant waste of your time. And the very best variants of every chassis are only available if you pay IRL money. So, yeah, enjoy losing to whales who can drop $600 on in-game purchases. Free to play my♥♥♥♥♥ It's free to play until you hit the soft paywall and you're left feeling like your time's been wasted.

												Great game with a few caveats. First off, make sure you are in a unit. The solo play is great for awhile but due to the learning curve of the game you are going to have a tough time without someone, or group of someones, holding your hand for a bit. Second, the map selection is a bit weak, but I can't really tell if that is due to the amount of time I have been playing or if they all really are that repetative. (They are improving and building new maps though)All in all its a great team game with a really good community. Anything high teir and comp level you will have a pretty strict meta to follow, but low teir to mid there is a ton of customization and build experiment that keeps it fresh.Definitely the longest I have played a F2P title. Lots of good communication from the dev team.Learning curve is a cliff not a hill. Get in a group.

number of helpful: 10 of 21 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												I love Battletech, and MechWarrior games. That is the only reason I am playing this one. This is the only game of which I am aware that has had so many news stories about how out of touch developers are with their own fan base. They are out of touch with their own playerbase, as well. They are in Forbes magazine for having one of the dumbest business strategies in the gaming industry. Bottum line is that if you like Battletech/MechWarrior then you will like playing this. Thats how I feel. But if you aren't already a fan, you will not deal with the masochism of MWO. It is riddled with poor game play, bugs that have not been fixed after years of beta, game modes that are not compitently tested, and developers who so obviously don't know how to play their own product. It is mind boggling and entertainment in of itself how frequently they want to change random massive gameplay features/foundation of rules that make the game worse every month. But I foolishly play it. Because I love battletech.Russ Bullock is the owner of the license for this game. He is so bad at his job that it has become a comical event among the community to hear how incompitant he is in Town Hall podcasts at No Guts No Galexy. No joke, members of the community (from a panel that he cherry picked, no less) will literally straight up tell him how to improve his game in a consensus, and he will deflect by monopolize/demogague/mic hoging for 3/4+ of the interview time while everyone is struggling to find words to inform him that the community does not like the things that he wants to implement.I have not seen a monthly patch come out that was a positive improvement! I'm not exajurating. (Aside from adding mechs into the game, which is always cool if you can get over that they will charge up to $70 for one mech model each time). The game is buggy. New bugs get introduced at a rate of at least 2:1 every patch. It does not improve. The game changes will alter the entire base of the game (such as radically altering the foundation of heat consumption for all weapons, or quirking 50 mech chasis at a time to completely alter the meta -- as opposed to doing one thing at a time and seeing how it pans out).Its a painful time to be a MechWarrior fan. And I can't wait until Russ looses the license so that good games can be developed for this system by someone that doesn't seem to actively hate his own target audience.
