content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												Don't let my game time fool you. More than enough time was logged before this ported over to Steam for help.I only recommend this becuase it's the only decent "Mechwarrior-like" game I can play on my machine without a ton of extracirricular crap. It's free. Yeah. You can buy a lot of stuff which completely unbalances the game... and for a redonkulous amount of money at that.For someone who grew up playing the board games, and the archaic mechwarrior on windows 95/SNES, and upward, this is the only thing I've found to make me feel at home. .. ish. Though you do get a significant boost as a rookie starting off, that dies quickly, and so will your want to play this game if you are not wanting to looking at thousand upon thousands of hours of game time, still only to not make you feel like you've accomplished much of anything. Much like most MMO's. Except this one is lacking a lot that would make it perfect, and its not mechanics.Edit: Apparently my review Butthurt someone enough to make a level 0 private account just to comment and troll reviews. Lol Gotta love the kids on Steam.What I'm referring to about "Unbalancing" is that P2W kills Casual playing. Yes, money flow keeps games like this alive. However, there is a line. To get certain Mech builds, you MUST spend Money. They are not all readily available via c-bills.Personally, I don't like paying past the one time purchase fee when I buy a game. But.. It's free O_O so. Making one or two in game purchases(if you see fit) won't be a bad thing. Yes the game has bugs. Name one that doesn't. Wall hackers, rubberbanders, etc etc etc. Welcome to Online Gameplay.If you do want to spend money, i would suggest at, or at least Half the MSRP of a Brand New game. If you buy anything 30$ or under, buy the Steam LIGHT Mechpack. You get two variants that have a perm +30% to cbills, and 30 days premium time which is a flat 50% increase to xp and xbills across all variants. Plus, it's a good idea to master Light Mech fighting. Because for me, it's actually the hardest weight class. Easy for you? Bam. Money.If you buy MC for Mechs, don't spend them on anything else except premium time. As PT = $$$ and you need that to buy variants to unlock the Elite Skill Tree and Mech Modules. Everything else is really obtainable with Cbills.. except Mech Bays. They have random events where you can unlock them. Or you can purchase them in game.AVOID QUICKPLAY. If you are serious about Team Play Join a faction as a merc or a loyalist. Get a team so you can coordinate. If you don't team play, You will get slaughtered.Don't have a Mic/Headset? Don't wanna blow 30-40$ on a Headset? Teamspeak is VERY cheap on the Google Play and Apple App Stores. You can use your phone's headset(which have noise cancel on most) and/or bluetooth and set it to voice activate after a certain range level is met.7/10MWO lost 3 Points because they won't have a Steam Workshop and allow us to customize and design, which would bring in SO Much money for PGI, and they wont allow transferring of cbills between players, so Units can help each other :(

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												If you like arena shooters, but wish there was some more thinking and strategy involved, this is a game for you. The goal is the destroy the enemy, but whether or not you're successful depends not just on your accuracy with a mouse, but how well you can build your mech, and how well you can manage your systems mid-battle.There are a variety of mechs and weapons to choose from, and you can endlessly customize them with numerous paint schemes and colors. Decals are coming soon. You can choose from several factions, each on either side of a galactic war. There's a built-in VOIP, but many people have their own team speak servers. I would recommend getting on one or the other because team coordination is the most powerful tool in this game.Wait on trying the Community Warfare (Faction tab) until you're experienced and own your own customized mechs. It is absolutely a Hardcore mode, and you don't want to try it with the free trial mechs. Don't worry, you can buy everything you need with in-game currency. There is no P2W here, and the 1-2% of items locked behind a paywall do not confer any advantages, they are just unique items. I have been playing since before Steam, and I'd recommend this to any Steam players that want to think when they shoot and engage with a more mature community.

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												Been playing this game on-and-off since the early days of its development, so my actual playtime is well above 1000 hours. As both a battletech fan and quite active gamer with only a minor interest in competitive gaming my experience  with the game has been very fun.I recommend the game to anyone who likes battle simulations and/or battletech. If you are searching for a shooter you might take a look but this game is not a shooter. For the battletech fans: Careful, the game does not strictly follow lore. The mechs are all taken from the battletech universe (including some of the Unseen now!) and it follows table top rules in most of the core aspects. In order to balance the game however additional rules and changes have been made in order for Clan and IS mechs to be able to play side by side.Graphics: The game is based on the cry engine so the graphics are solid but not over the top. If you are looking to test out your newest gaming gear and want to see insanely realistic effects you will be disappointed. For everyone else both graphics and design are quite appealing and older parts of the game get reworked from time to time.Gameplay: This part is obviously somewhat subjective. You can probably compare the gameplay to games like World of Tanks. As stated in the beginning the game is more of a simulation than a shooter. This doesnt mean that it is devoid of action. But it requires less twitch reflexes and more patience. There are private, public and community warfare matches. Private and public matches can be played in three different game modes all of which can be won by shooting down all enemies. Public matches are always 12v12 players and last between 5 and 15 minutes, no respawn. Community Warfare matches also are played as 12v12 but allow you to drop several mechs (meaning you 'respawn' up to 3 times) and can last up to 30 minutes. At higher skill/experience tiers there is a strong metagaming aspect which however is softened by the non-competitive atmosphere of the public matches.Apart from the actual matches you can spend a lot of time changing your mech equipment in the mechlab. The game gives you a loot of room for customization and trying out your own playstyle.Community: The current community (pre Steam release) is quite mature and usually rather helpful and friendly. Newcomer questions are usually answered in detail on the official forums. Both official forums and reddit see their regular whining about whatever bugs the players and are subject to a lot of drama. These aspects however do not carry over to the ingame atmosphere or gameplay. I do recommend trying to find a unit (clan) for players who decide to stick with the game.Development: While being a full sized game and by no means half-finished the game is still being developed. Additional gamemodes, customization features and AI opponents have been teased and might be seen within the next year. There also is at least one (mostly two) patch per month for bugfixes, new mech releases, map changes or balance changes.Grind Factor: Getting new mechs and equipment requires a certain grind on your part. The game provides a set of trial mechs which you can play without buying them but those trial mechs do not change very often and are fixed in their equipment. People who play very casual might find this annoying and will not have the opportunity to afford new mechs very often. Compared with other free2play titles however the grind factor is not very high and people who play often should not encounter difficulties.Pay2Win?: The game is not pay2win. Real money can be spend to reduce the grind, buy new mechs and cosmetic stuff. New mechs are released earlier for people who preorder with real money and are sometimes considered really strong for the first week or two. Game breaking balance issues however are usually taken care of such that there is no actual need to preorder anything. All other content releases (maps, game modes) are free.E-Sport/Competitive Gaming: So far the game does not have any ranked matches. Competitive gaming is self-organized in private lobbies. The game relies on both teamwork and individual skill so there certainly is some basis for competitive gaming here. Just recently a tournament was announced by the developer but whether this will ever turn into an E-Sport game remains to be seen.

												The short of it: A free to play first person Robotic deathmatch game. Fun to play, though it requires some thinking and is not your typical run and gun game. They make their money off of in game purchases, which is true about most FTP games. Further development of different game modes and so forth has been great, and I look forward to seeing it grow.If you are a Mechwarrior fan, or even dabbled in it a little bit and enjoyed it, get this game. Give it a try. It is great and there is nothing to lose.If you are new to the series, come on in, join up, blow up some robots with us! Nothing like the smell of scrap metal in the morning! It is an FPS, but it is so far removed from the likes of COD and Battlefield it won't feel stale and old. And there are many players in the community willing to give you a helping hand.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Veteran pilot here, back from closed beta days until now.  My review of Mechwarrior Online is not going to be any polarized PGI aft kissing or hyperbolic salt dripping.  No, I'm going to be honest and as neutral as I can be.  I'm not going to overly delve into the history of the game.  I'll simply state what my thoughts on the game are.Mechwarrior Online offers some of the best arena shooting Mechwarrior combat that I have experienced.  The actual combat is good.  The map variety is solid.  Balance is... acceptable, and certainly more even between Clan and IS tech trees than its predecesors.  The attention to detail in the art department, the visual customization based on loadouts, is heads and tails above all others, with the possible exception of MWLL.  The degree of customization is positively immense!However, not everything is perfect, either.  Development is slow, rocky, and far too often follows illogical decision making.  There is a lack of transparency from the developers, and they do have a nasty habit of ignoring the experienced community's input.  The current, as of this writing, game modes are just variations of team deathmatch and absolutely need expansion in their mechanics as it can get stale playing the same thing over and over again.  Community Warfare matches, while soon(tm) due to have a significant update, currently is of questionable enjoyment and of zero consequence to the overall big picture.Yet it is a game I keep coming back to. Why?  Because the game is still loads of fun.  The core experience is just plain enjoyable (teams permitting), and I can play the game, get my top tier mech experience, eventually get burnt out or tired of the issues that still haunt the game, set it down, and return to it with fresh eyes a couple months later.  That PGI managed to avoid a P2W situation is a fantastic perk that should not be undervalued - nothing you can buy with money is any more competitive than anything you can (eventually) get out of playing the game.  It is pay for convenience, though without the grind can be a little excessive.  Also, while I often disagree with the developers' methods, they work hard.  Not necessarily working smart, but they do work hard at their product.Would I recommend the game?  Absolutely.  Would I recommend spending money on it?  Well... YMMV, and that's just something you'll need to decide on your own.Never a knight of black nor white, shades of gray is where reality lay,Pariah DevalisClan Nova Cat

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Been playing this game for years, now it is out on steam! Huge community, very active. Devs are greedy money ♥♥♥♥♥s, but that means new mechs to buy on a constant (every month or two) basis. This game can be pay-to-easymode but not pay to win. Constant updates, more maps, more modes, everything is getting slowly improved but it feels only 80% done right now. I highly recommend if you like giant stompy robots. Gameplay consists of you buying your mech chassis, outfitting it with the engine, weapons, ammo, heatsinks, armor, etc. You then que up for a match and wait to be paired with 24 people (12v12) in your skill catagory. You all vote on the map and mode (Skirmish, assault, conquest etc). Then you play as a team to smash your opponents in stategic and skill-based combat. There are "skills" to unlock as you gain XP in your played mech. This makes your mech a bit faster, more agile, etc. There are various (3-8) variant of each mech chassis, 3 need to be purchased and leveled up individually if you want maximum skill level, because there's a bonus if you max level 3 variants of 1 chassis.Some mech variants can only be bought with MC (Mechwarrior Credits) which you only get through events or buying with money. It is very fun to buy your favorite chassis and variants, then outfit them with just the loadout you like, then either brawl (close combat fighting) or long-range snipe. Missiles, lasers, guns, flamethrowers, PPCs, it's all there to play with! Try it out, but give it 5-10 hours to fully appreciate the fun this game offers!

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												I have been playing MWO off and on for about 3 years now. I highly reccommend it if you favor strategy and team play over a lone wolf, arcade style shooter. As far as Battletech fans from the table-top or past MechWarrior games, this is probably not for you, but as it is free-to-play, I would at least give it a try. It is a solid game with TONS of customization and it still feels great getting into those mechs and bringing the pain. It's very possible to have fun playing the game solo but the most fun I've ever had playing this game has been joining up with a full drop team and communicating strategy and tactics during tournaments and scheduled team vs team skirmishes.One thing I will say about the game as a negative, it has a rather large learning curve. The new in-game tutorial is great and a significant improvement for welcoming new players, but I would still definitely recommend trying to join a MWO clan or group that is willing to teach you the game or at least give you some tips. At the very least maybe watch a tutorial video guide about weapon systems and loadouts. As an example, overall, the premade load-outs for the mechs you use are decent but definitely not the most optimal. Learning which weapons, engines, armor, etc, work best in your mech of choice and which role you should be playing on the battlefield with that loadout, is imperative to your (and your team's) success and overall enjoyment in the game.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												Game is fun for a few hours, then you try faction play.  12 mechs rush your spawn point and kill you, and you have 0 retaliation.  0 options.  The developer shrugs its shoulders, realizes they can't code worth♥♥♥♥♥♥ and just have to accept it as a "valid tactic".  Then you have the Horrible UI, where you can't do anything once you try to find a game.  Screen goes black and locks up.  Can't look at your mechs, can't change other mechs.  You try to group up with friends to play, then you realize that each matchmaking system forces a different type of group.  So if you wanted to change to faction play, you have to kick everyone out and reform, only to wait 10 mins for someone to show up to fight against you.  If you have impatience friends, you then have to remove them from your group and reform yet again.The game is fun for the first 100-200 hours.  The in game ui and gameplay, for the most part, is spot on.  The out of game UI looks like it was designed and implemented by a 1st year CS major.TBH, this game is a cash grab for those nostalgic battletech/mechwarrior players.  Every 2ish weeks, they release another 'mech' pack, which is anywhere from $20-50 that hardcore fans just eat up like a kid on halloween.  For those that do this and read this, i'd be cautious.  There is no gaurantee that PGI's license will be renewed once it expires, which I belive could be as early as 2017 or late as 2020, depending on if they reach certain milestones.All in all, i cannot recommnd this game, which i have played more than 1000 hours in since the closed beta.  It was once good, then bad decisions have undermined what could have been amazing.  It still has potential, but with the current developers, I have no faith of that being realized.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												I am one of early beta players. Founder. And even if I have enjoyed this game, I can't recommend it to anyone.- Game constantly crashes. Let's say 1 in 4 matches will crash to desktop. It happens to everyone and it is not fixed as long as I have played this game. Most of the players don't return and with that handicap, your team is usually steamrolled.  Even if you return, there is a HIGH CHANCE that enemy light mech will be taking a free kill while you are loading a level. If you don't come back you will be penalized. This bug is not fixed for several years and there is no indication that it will ever be fixed. - Matchmaking is really terrible. 80% of the games finish in 12 kills for one side and maybe 3 for the others side. So, no matter how good you are, it all comes down to team and players. And believe me, there is a BUNCH of terrible players in game. But it's not their fault, game is hard to learn. It's not fun at all to play with this unbalanced matchmaking system. I have uninstalled this game after 10 lost games in a row. Took few hours to play after work and got additionaly frustrated after playing this. Highest damage and most kills in most terrible teams. This is frustrating, something that sucks all fun out of this game. - It is pointless to play this game with your friends, unless you are all equaly skilled and really good in this game, because you will be placed in a matchmaking where player tier plays no role. You will play against pros and will be killed as fast as you can say meta mech. This means that you can either find some awesome no-lifer guild and become a no-lifer yourself or you can play alone, for a slight chance of winning. There you have it. These 3 things completely ruin the game that has so much potential, but somehow owners don't seem to care as long as they get money from new mechs.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Read on, I've got the goods on this one: Ignore the time Steam says I have invested. My forum profile tells me I have over 6000 regular matches and I know I have a couple thousand at least before they put that counter in. I'm pretty sure that doesn't even include my community warfare drops either. I presently own 254 mechs (all mastered but the newest 4) and I had never heard of Battletech or MechWarrior before trying this game. I still don't know jack about the lore, I make my own stories up thank ya very much. Only thing you need to learn is how to point and shoot while running for your life.The good: This game is completely 100% free to play. No BS money sinks, you don't have to put in one single cent to play or be amongst the elite. The weekend (or weeklong) challenges will give you all the MC or mechbays you will need to keep growing your army (community warfare alone allows you to unlock a bunch of mechbays just for playing). Real money buys paint, cockpit items, warhorns and hero mechs (which are not as good as regular variants in nearly 100% of chassis). Even my $500 Gold Direwolf is only a fancy paint job; it's the same Direwolf Prime you can buy yourself with in-game currency. You can make an argument that premium time is essential - I am never without it or my glass of wine - as it cuts down on the grind a lot. I have never not had premium time up so I can't speak to the wasted sober hours some go through.Game play is addicting and can swing between exhilarating and infuriating because all your pug team mates are idiots, right? What you will eventually do is join a community. Then you will find out those guys are annoying and lose every second match and you will move on and find another one. They will be a little better but you'll still be bouncing around like Tigger at a swingers club until you find that sweet spot where those guys who know how to carry a team play. If you're lucky you will pick up a trick or two. I won't tell you who the elite groups are but you'll figure that out. The bad: Bad is a strong word. Work-in-progress is more apt. Community warfare is leaving beta 2 and beta 3 is right around the corner and this game is by no means finished as it is constantly evolving with an ever-changing meta but this is not an early access game. At least you'll be learning about the new features and game modes at the same time as all the vets and won't be at too much of a disadvantage there. Some of the maps are weak and we still need more. In my opinion map making is PGI's greatest weakness but a couple of them are great so that saved their goat. What on earth possessed them to make so many maps that require night vision and heat vision for targeting when you are trying to sell paint jobs to make all your mechs look cool is beyond me. My $500 (HUNDRED!!) Direwolf is Gold and you dummies can't see it cuz you are in heat vision. Look at me dammit, Im gold!!  You can now vote for maps and game modes so the terra-bad (pun!) ones hardly ever come up. I would be remiss without a little word about the griefers. Oh-my-god-some-kids-won't-take-it-like-a-man saga is alive and well. So many people can't handle FPS games and being shot in a pretend world. It's amazing how fragile they are. You will see people have complete public meltdowns. I find alcohol helps, maybe you like pills, I don't judge. Want my advice? Ignore the forums too. It's just a whine and rant-fest. Get TeamSpeak and join a team and ask your questions there. The community is huge. The PGI hate-train is always up and running but I have no issues with MechWarrior at all and I have given them well over a thousand bucks for paint and warhorns. And even though I have given them a ridiculous amount of money they have no issues telling me to go pound sand when I send in my own little rant. Money can't buy you love here, just paint. Lots of paint. Gotta wrap this up cuz the wife is wearing something hot. No-time-to-spell/grammar-check-this-hot, you feel me?. This game rocks. You will go on epic winning and losing streaks, theory craft until your 6am morning alarm goes off, and find a nemesis who you will go to the ends of the earth to kill (I'm looking at you H8Wine). It's run by a North American company so any money you spend here isn't going to some dodgy 3rd world country like some if it's competitors. Go find your fortune, I'll be waiting for you with guns loaded. And kill that H8Wine guy and tell him I sent you.Wine O

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												Perhaps one of the best ways you can go feed your nostalgia in the way of some old school shooting. As your pure mechanized machine goes to pound off the armor of another, whether it's by guns, lasers, or missiles. Unfortunately, despite it's release, it still can feel rather beta. If you carry knowledge of the game, they are trying to stay very close to the story of what Mechwarrior is. Here are some of the things are making this go so wrong.- The Inner sphere take on equal amounts of clanners, where as the clanners. still have their unmatched firepower.- They are desperately keeping clan weaponry to the clan. The Inner Sphere will most likely never see their integration into their systems. - There is an uneeded, visible, TIER system in the game to make you struggle and hate your skills to get to the top.- The maps that they carry are only about small/medium at most in comparison to what size older maps could have been, though this is reasonably required for a 15 minute match. - (Personal) Weapon customization is limited on mechs (But there are many "Types" to choose from), So.. take my opinion with a grain of sugar. :PI'm not about to go about this without a bit of things that I like...- Playing something such as a catapult is now pleasing, locking with missiles doesn't require you to literally hold line of sight on an enemy. - Clan have some very interesting way's to adapt. They can switch around ligaments, if you own other types. - Their updates always come with interesting promise. They often do their updates/events with public opinion. A petition was even able to get the urban mech into the game. <3- Buying a Premium mech holds the user no advantage. All mechs and their abilities come from the way you design your mech.  The pilot makes the mech, not the other way around.Despite what's going on, I still hold a lot for this game. Even if there may or may not be a lot of mechs to ever come see the fields, what you have to choose from at this time is still. It definitely scratches some nostalgia for me, it is a very pretty, and pretty much bugless.

												Played the game off and on for 3+ years. The game is fun and there's constant updates, as with a lot of MMOs though, you won't get the full experience or have nearly as much fun unless you find a unit and play with other people. The prices are still pretty stupidly high, but as you dont need to purchase mechs to play the game and can get what you need just from playing for free.It's a more tactical shooter, you can manipulate your loadouts to what suits you and your playstyle. Even though I have terrible hand-eye coordination, I can still perform well by using weapons that work well without good twitch/aiming skills like streaks or short range lasers. If fighting with mechs interests you (and if you ever watched Gundam or Macross it should) definitely give the game a try.

												Been playing MWO for the last 3 years. To be honest it's been a pretty rough ride but now all you steam people are getting the benefit of that time. The gameplay is fun, and there's no repair costs to force you into premium time like in WoT. High level play is limited largely to player organized events. If you like mechs, they push out mechs as fast as you can buy them, but when it comes to balance changes they'll leave something broken for months, years even. I do not recommend anyone buy the steam packs, they are VERY poor value for a new player.Overall I do recommend the game, it's in a good place now and looks to keep on getting better.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												Dabbled in this momentarily in the closed beta, and didn't touch it for 3 years until the middle of 2015. MAN has this game come a long way since then! It's a beautiful game with giant stompy robots, and combat is exciting and never the same in any two games. Sure, it's effectively 12v12 deathmatch for 80% of the quick play games. Noone complains about having only one map on DOTA. each different mech feels different, handles different, and the breadth of customization, while not fully open to anything under the sun, makes spending time in the mechlab sometimes more enjoyable than playing the game itself. You can effectively have fun without paying a single cent (and not be disadvantaged compared to those who pay). However, for those with the money and no time to work the grind, their system allows for a good time-vs-money tradeoff. I've paid for stuff in the game, and have not had any regrets (at all!). Highly recommend it, keep the improvements coming, great job to PGI!

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												This game isn't quite BattleTech and does have some balance issues. The Pay-2-Win crowd is also pretty fiece and playing a Quick Play match will drop you in a team that's a lot like the Keystone Cops. I have no interest in faction play (it gets way to Tribal in there) and without some sort of story line or AI combat; I can't justify the time I put into this title.The game heavily favors Clan Mech over Inner Sphere Mechs (The in game meta factions) as far as build options and for a perpetual tinkerer like me, it gets frustrating to try and balance a build.There's also a strong vein of elitism and anti-Steam user chatter that will put a lot of us on the outs. There is also no active monitoring of user age. Getting slagged by a kid is one thing, but having to listen to some 11 year old scream into the VOIP and Caps-rage about how no one will do what they're told needs to stop.There are also legal issues at play that will continue to slow or even alter game content. I don't know enough about FASA, the old pen and paper BattleTech IP or the various people involved to make a flow chart, but there is another MechWarrior game in developement and a lot of the old 'Jocks in the Forums are still bemoaning the lack of certain Iconic Mechs in MWO.Give this one another 2 years and another major update. If it's still up and running, go for it. For now, I'd recommend holding off.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												First review. I don't tend towards the hyperbolic, so I think all this is fair.Great-F2P done right. Fans of Planetside 2 will enjoy this model. You could grind for ages and still have the best equipment eventually. I ended up paying about $180 and it was all well spent. No regrets. Recommend budgeting at least $80.-Matchmaking. Going up in tiers really helps weed out poor players and griefers. Lunatics will always be present, but you can mute or block them.-Clans. You don't really have to join one. You can find a group of folks and they will always be happy to associate with you. They may be a clan or just other individuals (your friends list).-Mech combat. Well balanced (aside from typical forum bemoaning) that is ultimately gratifying. Go fast, go slow; go long range, go 120m brawler. Whatever you want.-Mechs. Customizable, skinable, and relatively true to lore. You can roleplay yourself as a hardcore pilot or just play casually. Fun fun.Good-Developers keep on developing. They are slow, promises tend to be 2-8 months after delivery date. It'll arrive eventually though.-Content continues to be released, along with rough timelines published each month. New pre-orders are always in the hopper. Enjoyable to watch the options grow.-Faction content/loyalty. I enjoy repping my faction but the differentiations are pretty slight in general play. Poor-The engine has some pretty crappy object hit detection. Not ballistic - think mechs running into each other (weird clipping) and terrain issues. It can't really be fixed without upgrading the software engine...which is probably never.-UI. A bit arduous to do relatively simple inventory management and accounting.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												Awesome that this game came to steam, huge influx of players which makes the games a ton funner and faster. i instant Queue now at non-peak hours where before steam-integration it may have taken a minute.one of the best sim games in the steam library, nothing can compare to the tactical play of a co-ordinated lance of four. having some mech's rock anti-missile systems to protect you and nearby team and lance members while another mech runs ECM's and UAV's, the team play is massive. the game can get pretty deep.the game looks beautiful and every mech has it's own personal cockpit, the more you use your mech's the more you master them, giving you small boosts (e.x. 2.5% mech turn speed) and you can customize all the internals, even more so with "clan mechs", including your engine size/model, how many heatsinks you install, your weapon platforms, your ammo storage depending on platforms, your Anti-missile-system what kind of metal your mech is contructed of, there's too much to say. when you finally take the time to custom-mod your mech you really feel like it's 'your' mech because you tuned it the way you want to play it.Pay-2-win? there are microtransactions in the game, but they are mostly for appearance (items that can be placed in the cockpit etc.). though you can buy mech's with real cash, you can earn mech platform's (except for 'hero mechs') with in-game cash won by using trial/loaner mechs for a while when you begin, very similar to league of legends. the trial mechs are built well so you wont be underperforming as well. if you are a fan of sim-warfare games, dont miss this one.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												I am a new player of this game in the past week and have already sunk about 60 hours into it. I'm enjoying every minute. I'm going to present some PROS and CONS that I've encountered in my first almost-week of playing, as well as some TIPS for enjoying yourself if you decide to give this game a try.PROS:-Tactical shooter/mech simulation with a surprisingly high "realism" factor which enhances gameplay; Is someone killing you with the lasers on their right arm? Simple: shoot their right arm off! Are you overheating? Simple: run in the water so the heatsinks you put in your mech's legs can be more efficient.-Community seems mostly friendly toward newbies. In team-versus-team games, rage and salt are usually everywhere. Especially when you are new and don't know how to play. I've had some mixed experiences, but for the most part the veterans seem willing to help the newbies learn the mechanics.-Different "weight classes" and varieties of mechs provide different playstyles. Want to dart in and out of enemy lines, drawing fire away from your allies? Play a Light mech. Want to lead a push and pack lots of firepower? Play an Assault mech.-Customization system for "bought" (in-game currency or premium currency) mechs adds to replayability, and allows a single mech to be played many different ways.-It is truly Free-to-Play. There are some mechs which you can only buy with premium currency, however the benefits they provide are being able to grind faster and having different weapon slots. Both of these are things F2P players can thrive without. I will provide a DISCLAIMER and say that Mech Bays (ability to buy and store more mechs), while something F2P players can absolutely live without, will be very very tempting to buy. You can buy and store 4 mechs (enough for Faction Play) without buying any additional Mech Bays.CONS-Steep learning curve, especially for FPS newbies.-It is a team-versus-team game. There are always going to be toxic people who will tell you "ur bad, git good, ur a♥♥♥♥♥ go back to the kitchen where u belong," etc. etc.-It's a Grind. Depending on what you want to do with your mechs, you might end up spending a lot of time grinding in-game currency and XP to upgrade them. This may or may not be a CON for you.-Mech Bays, while not necessary to play the game and not giving any gameplay benefits to players who own them, will be tempting to buy. (With premium currency.) They allow you to buy and store extra mechs, so if you get addicted to this game like I am and want ALL THE MECHS... you are going to have to buy some with premium currency.TIPS:-If at all possible, use VOIP! Your team will love you for it. You won't be expected to lead the team as a newbie; calling out enemy locations (using the military phonetic alphabet[en.wikipedia.org] to make sure you're understood) when they are first spotted and when a Light is skittering around the back line will earn you brownie points, and maybe help you win.-Don't spend your in-game currency right away. Most people recommend waiting until your Cadet Bonus (first 25 games) has expired until you buy your first custom mech from the Store; that way you can get an idea of what does what. Of course, if you see something out in the field and say "I want THAT one!," I wouldn't stop you.-Don't be intimidated by the tutorials! Your best tutorial is out in the field--in other words, your first few Quick Play matches getting exploded. You will get oriented, but not without dying horribly. Ask for advice on team chat (Y) or VOIP (CAPS Lock) if you need to.-Make friends with other newbies. You're most likely to get matched with your peers, so if someone friendly is on VOIP or team chat, don't be afraid to reach out. (Heck, make friends with veterans!)Give this game a try if you think it looks like your thing. Be patient with yourself if the mechanics are giving you trouble. Enjoy yourself.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												Pros;  You can satisfy the urge to run around in a stompy robot and shoot other stompy robots with a few basic types of weapons in what is typically deathmatch style combat.Cons;  As old as the game is, it does not feel complete, I have played it on and off for a few years now.  The company that runs it doesn't seem to have the resources to polish the product.  Camoflauge and colors on different mechs aren't free and that is sort of annoying.  The game itself seems to be keeping itself afloat on just repacking old content(old mechs) and selling them at a profit, and designing new mechs every month, while IMO not really having the time or resources to better the product.  The, soon to be reworked, pilot skill tree and module system has felt restrictive funwise by forcing you to enhance one style of play and sticking to it while you acquire XP and C-Bills to unlock other things.  Which feels like a big grind to me.  The Faction Warfare gamemode feels terrible to me, though I could probably get more out of it if I had the time to find a good group of active people, which I still feel would be 12 people farming PUG groups.  Some could argue the balance in the game needs work, some see mandatory upgrades on IS mechs as a neccassary grind to maintain immersion, to me it is annoying to have useless equipment.  Some could say the IS/Clan balance is bad, others might say it was that way in the lore, and neccassary for immersion.  There are lots of confusing aspects of the game to newwer players, like how heat and ghost heat work.Overall, I personally enjoy the game, but it seems to still have a long way to go to be attractive to a wider audience.  The snails pace development is a hinderance, coupled with unfinished and unfun game mechanics that continue to linger.  I have seen in the community forum many talk about the Cryengine needs an update.I don't write reviews, I did this review to get steam awards, feel free to take the opinions as nothing more than a butt hurt noob who needs to git gud and move on and ignore what I say.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												I have been playing this game on and off since the closed beta, it is true that its not the greatest game in the world and that there is a heafty price on some mechs if you dont want to grind and want everything now. The actual gameplay of the battles and customization of the mechs in the mechbay is where this game is great. The battles are fought as 3 4 mech lances (squads) so to get the best out of the game you need to work together and support your team (it only takes 1 mech to run off by themselves to turn a garanteed victory into a defeat) each mech class has its own advantages and uses that you will find out from playing.The grind in the game isn't to reach the biggest mechs as you can pretty much get these from the get go and each class plays verry differently suiting different people, if you like to run and gun darting from cover to cover in hit and run tactics then a light mech is your thing, if you like heavy firepower and the armour to stand your ground (because you are not moving very fast) then assault mechs might be your thing but remember even in the biggest baddest looking mech you can still be turned into a smoking wreck in a matter of seconds by light mechs without the support of your team.So I will leave with this, the game is f2p you have nothing to lose so give it ago, compleet the tutorial, use the trial mechs to get a feel for the different classes and find the class that suits you then once you have finished 25 matches and earned all the cadet bonus you should have a fair amount of credits to get a mech of your choice all without spending any real money. So have fun and I may see you on the field of battle mechwarrior.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												Highly recommended to anyone who enjoys first person shooters. A slower paced game, great if you want to get away from the twitchy, super competitive madness that is Halo/CoD.Customization in the mechlab is phenomenal. Spending time in the mechlab building and tweaking mechs and testing their effectiveness is half the fun. Anything from armor values on all 8 of your different components (11 of you count the rear armor), weapons, ammo, engine size and type, and equipment, can be relocated and swapped to suit your needs.Anyone who has played any other Mechwarrior title should feel right at home. If you haven't played/heard of Battletech before, I recommend reading up on some guides and strategies before you hop in. The learning curve is steep. You WILL lose a lot at first.Combat is slow and methodical. Engagements will often last several minutes. The feeling of brawling with an enemy mech and having parts blasted off, will keep you on the edge of your seat; especially if it comes down to a 1v1 situation. Being '1 shotted' is very rare and is often the result of bad positioning and multiple enemy mechs focusing you down.PROS:-Solid game play mechanics -The artwork and attention to detail behind the mechs and maps is visually stunning-Mechlab/building mechs is quite fun - Not P2W. More 'Pay to skip the grind'-Huge selection of mechs to buy- Encourages teamwork. Teamwork is often the deciding factor between winning and losing.-events usually every second weekend that hand out all kinds of free goodies-It has adhered well to the original Tabletop stats and rules, which makes balancing hard. But the game is in the best state of balance it has ever beenCONS-The meta game Is very strict-Development is rather slow-Balancing tweaks are few and far between. The same meta can reign supreme for months-The grind can feel overwhelming is you play only for Free.-Lack of tutorials/briefing for mechlab and Faction Play-Game mode variety is limited. Basically Team Death Match over and over again-No real feeling of 'end game' you need 3 variants of a mech to level it up past Basic skills, then Elite, then Master. Master unlocks a module slot, but modules are basically C-bill sinks to improve your mech. A new skill tree is in the works.All said and done, it's Free to Play, and if you enjoy the game it doesn't feel like a grind. Development has grown in leaps and bounds since the publisher broke off from the developers.Good luck and maybe you'll see me out thereo7

												If you played any of the older games you'll know what your getting into.Getting started:step 1 : Play some rental mechsstep 2 : Take a look at the store pagestep 3 : Save up for the mech chassis you like moststep 4 : Buy it and customize it into whatever you want it most to be.Intresting things are this game has no tiering system and yet it works great. If you don't want to go crazy you don't have to customize a mech at all, as there are variations on every single one in the store, along with a premium version that earns more exp.Only real con i can come up with is they don't have ALL the mechs I want. But they are still adding them it the order they were made... So if the mech you want isn't in game, it probably will be eventually.All in all I would highly recomend this game if you want to play a mech game that isn't to zippy like some of the ones are today.

												It's not a MMO, it's not a FPS. It's neither a turn-based nor a real-time tactics or strategy game, even though it's based on a tactical board game from the 1980s.It's flawed, eternally stuck somewhere in the middle of a glacial development cycle. You will lose badly, unless you gather some friends and work on you small unit tactics.But as long as shooting lasers at each other from a building-sized bipedal tank will be fun, I'll be playing MechWarrior Online.

content:
Posted: February 3
												It really is free to play.  The rate you earn C-bills (the in-game currency) is high enough that with some minor grinding you can get yourself some really decent 'mechs.  Your first twenty-five matches also pay out at a much higher rate, letting even beginners gather enough money to own at least one good 'mech.  It is monetized, so payng real money is a much faster way to get the 'mechs and accessories that you want - and some 'mechs and options are ONLY available for real money.  Still, it's totally possible to play free; those who spend money on their builds don't have any automatic adantage over pilots who don't.The gameplay revolves around a really outstanding player base - an older crowd, not the bunch you find on COD.  And the developers, three years later, are still heavily involved inupdates and making new maps, gamemodes, and balance adjustments.  All in all this is a great game; it could be improved with a single-player campaign mode, but that is a fairly minor complaint given how free and how enjoyable the game is overall.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												As someone who has supported and played this game from closed beta I can honestly say that this game is good.  Not amazing, not superb, but good.  It is by no means an easy game to jump into and pick up, but they are slowly improving and making steps in the right direction.  It has a lot of potential, and for a relatively small dev group it is a solid game.  The current biggest drawbacks for me are the long queue times, broken ELO/BR, and heavy-handed "balancing" that is doled out on the regular.  It should still be in beta with the amount of changes they make with each patch and their pricing is definitely not on the cheap side, but the content is good and if you can get a group of friends to play with you regularly this game can be very satisfying.  If you have the time and effort to really learn the game, research, make new friends who can help you learn the ins and outs, or even have a group of friends who are interested in playing, then by all means, pick this game up.  If you're a casual gamer who likes the idea of mech combat and isn't interested in team play, tactics, or focus firing then do us all a favor and skip this game.  Perhaps check out hawken or some other cod-style twitch shooter, MWO is definitely not all about 360 no scoping.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												If you are a fan of Battletech this is just about the only online fix you'll be able to get. After the shutdown of Mechwarrior:Living Legends that left this the last bastion.The actual mechanics are ok, the game is more stable nowadays and has a fairly flexible approach to gameplay and the devs (PGI) have stepped their game up a fair few notches. When you can get a good game, with good team mates it's a great game-you certainly can gain those "gaming memories2 that you never forget:)But, MWO has one HUGE issue and it's one that cannot be solved by the devs...the playerbase.Basically, I've played MMO games since the release of EQ1 and I have NEVER seen such a pro solo, anti group playerbase. a disturbing lack of teamplay in all game modes-even though the game has built in voip and text chat. It even got last year, a solo only queue-a solo mode in a multiplayer online game, that should tell you all you need to know already!It also has a more complex "clan wars" style mode simliar to WoT that is currently in 2nd phase of beta testing. Unless you are social and get onto each faction's TS hubs abd actually speak to other people, you will be stuck with the pug lottery. during EU primetime that lottery will mostly give you 11 utterly silent team mates who will make zero effort to teamwork. Shift that to US primetime and the amount of teamwork increases, with mostly Americans being the talkers-but the gameplay DOES improve and I have had some cracking CW matches like that. Best advice I can give you is GET INTO A UNIT AND PLAY WITH OTHERS, the game is great when with others.Last critique is you'll notice that the playerbase is VERY timid, especially in solo queue so if you like team focused, movement heavy games-you'll be VERY frustrated with the solo Q.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												PROS* Play for free, and after 25 matches you have enough money to buy 1 or 2 Mechs* Awesome custom options/weapons/color schemes/ for Mechs (that you own).* Playing with a faction of people you know, or friends, is very satisfying for co-op play.* Mech combat is intense and adrenaline pumping.* The game rewards patience and positioning, not twitch mechanics or picking up drops.* The mechlab is fun, for designing a mech with a weapon loadout suited to your playstyle.* Different mechs play differently, even from light mech to light mech, or Assault to Assault.* Follows the lore (to a certain extent).* Colors bought can be applied to any mech you own. Some can be bought with cbills.* In-game earned credits (cbills) can buy most things, so there are less mechanics that could be singled out as P2W  than in some online games. Hero/Champion mechs bought for MC are rarely the best among variants of a chassis, and so the powerful cbill variants can be had by anyone with cbills instead of real money, nice!* At some point in the future, there will be a PVE game mode or single player campaign (supposedly in development by PGI). Time will tell.* There are free mechs (Trial Mechs) one can use in the game until they figure out what they like, to a certain extent. But none of them can be customized.* Veteran players can now support the game by buying the new mechs that come out (20 dollars a pack, for three) which includes a month of cbill boosted earnings (valued 12 dollars). Yet this will not be great for new players since they will not know what to buy at first (see below in warnings and CONS)* Cool warhorns and hanging items you can put in your cockpits (which can be won for free during events, or paid for if you have money to burn)* If you are a fan of the lore you can join a house or clan of your choosing and fight for planets in the Inner Sphere. The game modes/maps for this are quite different from the PuG matches, and last longer.* Spend some money in the game and there are loyalty mechs/rewards at the end of the year, for various levels of support.* Eventually buying one steam pack here provides a lot of content (30% cbill boosted mechs, cbill boosted earnings for a month, cool paintjobs, cool colors (that cost money in the game), and give mc (mech credits) for buying hero mechs or colors/cockpit items in the game. Though it would be nice if they came with different colors or patterns from pack to pack.WARNINGS, and hopefully things that will change in time:* This game requires a fianacial advisor or tutorial in order to keep new players from spending their first cbills in the wrong way. New players may become frustrated and quit as a result.* New players might buy their first mech based on nostalgia or knowledge of the lore, only to find out neither have anything to do with how the mech plays in the current meta (gameplay). * In Tier 5 (lowest ranked players) Pug matches can seem very unbalanced, and rarely do matches seem even; your team is completely destroyed or dominates depending on how many veteran players from upper tiers were forced to play with you (due to few people being available for matchmaking).* PGI has spent the last couple years trying to balance weapons and mechs, but still a lot of tweaking is required. Often new mechs/patches injected into the game change the way the game is played, especially in faction warfare. * Bad positioning (or teams splitting up) often means you will lose, and unless you are playing in a group of 12 people on teamspeak there is always a chance this will happen.* People love lasers and long range combat, so rarely do groups push into the enemy right off the bat, so matches can seem dragged out to new players that want to face-tank opponents.* Mechs that have a 30% cbill earning boost require real money to buy, but may or may not be the best variant of a chassis. When it is the best, people complain it lies behind a paywall. When they suck, people complain that they wasted their money.* Game modes are somewhat different, but rarely feel different from each other. (supposedly more are in development, but we will see if and when that happens)* Fans of the lore might want to play an Assault Mech (the largest), but to do so well requires too much knowledge of the current gameplay and positioning on current maps. * Make one mistake in positioning and you will die, especially in the higher ranked tiers for PuG. Faster mechs on your team will abandon you when♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan, so expect to take one for the team again and again until your learn the maps and how to position.* Clan mechs are crazy expensive, while Inner Sphere mechs are cheap as chips. Newer players might then gravitate to IS mechs, but IS mechs will almost always require a better engine, new weapons, and so on, so the amount of cbills spent to optimize is actually similar.* To fully upgrade a mech with your mech xp you must play with and upgrade 2 other variants of the same chassis before higher level upgrades are available. This requires a lot of cbills, or real money to buy entire packs of mechs in one shot.* A lot of mechs have become obsolete, or were never very good. This will not be readily apparent to new players unless they do some research on google, or metamechs.com.* Positioning, twisting & shielding (to spread damage when being shot at), and weapon ranges are things that can't be picked up in a day, and require a lot of practice in-game. The learning curve can feel brutal at times.* Inner sphere mechs were given isane quirks in order for them to compete properly with the Clan mechs, which means they are specialized for one or two styles of gameplay usually and so new players really have to do their homework before buying one. CONS, and things that are unlikely to change: * Cbills are hard to get as a novice player. And to get a general boost to cbill earning requires about $12 a month, so often you will be tempted to pay for it to lessen the grind.* The "Trial mechs" are rarely outfitted to one's liking, and do not have any modules on them (which help veteran players stay alive longer, or kill more effectively). While a veteran player in a trial mech might still be dangerous, a newbie in a trial mech is cbills for the taking. Trial mechs are few in number and rarely change. You could wait months or years to see a mech you wanted to try in this list. As a result, players simply go in blind most of the time and buy the mechs before being able to try them out.* While new players are grinding cbills, veterans can spend theirs freely on optimizing their mechs with modules (that add efficiencies to various systems on a mech) and cooling abilities to reduce or eliminate heat from their mech when they get too hot. This means they can out DPS anyone who does not have these on their mech (because once your mech gets too hot, you must slow down or stop your rate of fire). Even some in the community call "pay to win" here, and so these elements can rub people the wrong way. *Unlocking modules not only takes a massive amount of GXP, but then they must be paid for with cbills (2 - 6 million) as well! New players want to spend money on new mechs, not grinding to optimize; this works against the best part of the game which is being able to try new mechs.* If you want to leave the module on a mech and never move it you have to pay cbills again to have a copy of said module.* XL Engines for IS mechs turn your mech into a fast moving glass canon (if you lose a torso section, you die), while Clan engines are fast and allow you to lose one torso section and stay in the game. Many argue that this causes balance issues in the game.* Long range missles make the game a hide behind cover and shoot simulator at times, and only in the higher tiers does this change, a little.* Faction play is very unforgiving for new players, and where many of the elite players join up to play.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												I came into this game with 0 hype and now I cant get enough of it!   The variable mechanics make this game very deep and leave you theorycrafting at work or at the house.  I found myself at work just thinking how to most efficiently gear out my mech.  Any game you start day dreaming about is a good sign that it's well made.  You have to manage heat or your mech shuts down in battle,  distance rating on the weapons you choose, weight of the gear on the mech, and slot management.  This game is 1000x deeper than any other shooter out there.  The gameplay is also very fun.  Do you want a fast mech that runs circles around the heavies but softer or a Heavy laser vomiting monster thats more powerful but slow?  Do you want to run lasers, missles, or ballistics?  How about a mix of those?  Close range or long range?  This game is amazing!

content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												There's a lot of♥♥♥♥♥♥that pisses me off about this game.  It's either expensive or pretty really grindy to keep a decent stable of mechs. The faction warfare is a chokepoint snoozefest and few play it.  The ranking system the match making uses is a glorified experience bar and is nearly worthless which causes bad matches for new and old players alike.  Some of the mechs are just ♥♥♥♥♥♥, and PGI has a really hard time avoiding power creep with new stuff.With all that honestly said, the gameplay is damn fun and it keeps me coming back.  There's really nothing else quite like it.  There's a nice high skill ceiling, and team play both casual and tournament is really satisfying.  The community is pretty cool and chill for a team based online game.I'd say it's probably worth trying out for most people.  You do get a nice amount of money to start with.  Join a like-minded team for the full experience and the most fun.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
Have you played War Thunder, World of Tanks/Warships, Robocraft, Hawken?If the answer is yes to those F2P titles, Mechwarrior is another entry to the genre of tatical, partial-simulator FPS. Slower than your average FPS, grindy as any other, with a skill curve sure to be steep.Have you played Arma or Operation Flashpoint?It is much simplier sim/combat than Arma or OF, harder than your average FPS. It is more Battlefield than COD, with the team depedancy of TF2. And even a good team can end a game in a crushing defeat.ContentIt is slow to release actual features but mechs are frequent, and I would consider maps release acceptable. Early access to mechs cost money like the recent trend of games. Weapons are tweaked like all good F2P games despite the whinge.MonniesThe most efficient use of money is mechbays. Or if you want to spend less time grinding then premium time and mechbays. No purchase will guarrentee you victory (although may increase your odds). Time spent learning the pace of the game, learning your mech, observing when your team mates are aggressive or hesitant; these are a few points of focus in the first 10 hours of gameplay (I'm a slow learner).It was my lifestyle game, I'd play it every day for 2 years. According to my madstats I have clocked 528 hours of in-match game time (tinkering not included). If you think it mech combat might tickle your fancy and don't mind F2P, you have nothing to lose. If you only have time for AAA games, you probably want to give it a miss.Currently on a break (picked up elite dangerous) and I'm waiting on something different changes before I return.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3
												I've been playing this for over 2 years.  The developers are continually adding new content and improving the game...sometimes its a step back before 2 steps forward.It's not an easy shooter.  It takes effort to get good (knowing the meta, learning different chasis and their weaknesses, positioning and targeting with different weapon systems, etc...).  One must also learn that working with ones team is vital.  Even the best players are easily taken down when isolated from their mates.  MWO is also about strategy: which mech you bring, how you build it, when & how you engage, which weapons you fire, etc...This game is already a first class shooter; It sets the standard for stompy robot shooter games.  It has a rich lore in the Battletech universe.  But, it has potential to be much better.However, it falls short in the meta game...the game really offers nothing beyond shooting opponents in different styles of mechs.  The community warfare mode needs a lot of work.  The war between the Inner Sphere and the Clans fails to engage.  Even to the extent that teams can make a minor impact, the fruit of these efforts are largely meaningless.  Individuals fail to reap any tangible impact from their efforts.  That combined with battles that are often one-sided as skilled teams drop against randomly grouped pugs...and the mode can quickly become discouraging...even for a top tier player.Overall, I enjoy the game.  I am critical because it could be great!

Product received for free
												Plain and simple, if you are looking for a run in and kill game, this is NOT for you.MechWarrior Online takes time and patience to learn all the aspects of the game. Highly custimizable Mechs, but a LOT of grinding to afford Skill Upgrades, Weapons, Modules, and other items needed to build to suit your playstyle. PUG (Pick Up Games, or running without friends) are usually chaotic, for people tend to run about without a plan. Playing with Friends does make things easier and more enjoyable (for most). MechWarrior Online is the only game that interests me enough to keep playing. Most of the players are like me, a bit older and like games with planning and strategy. Plan, Communicate, and work together then things work in your favor, even when PUGgingGood Hunting

Product received for free
												It looks decent, and it plays well. At least through the tutorial, but once I got through that, I found there was no content to speak of.  Just some 'practice missions' and matchmaking. I was expecting a MechWarrior RPG game, with characters and a story, but it turns out that it is essentially a MOBA, and I detest those. I like storylines with a world to explore, and characters to love or hate. Something to fight for. Not random skirmishes with strangers.It does seem stay true to the BattleTech lore, and how can piloting a giant death robot not be fun?I won't say it's bad just because it's not my thing, because I wouldn't know a good MOBA from a bad one, as I've only played enough of them to know I dislike that style of game.If you like those sort of games, then give it a try. If you like missions, with storylines and places to explore, then avoid it. Still it's free, and if you are a fan of the BattleTech universe, it's worth at least checking out.  You may find you like it. I wish there were more options than yes or no. Because I would recommend it to those who like these style games, but I wouldn't recommend it to someone who likes RPGs.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												MWO is possibly the best free to play game I've played, but then again, it's the only free to play game that has huge sod-off stompy robots in it (Hawken doesn't count because they're more Ballerinas than 'mechs). Oh and machine guns don't cost 10 quid like some F2P games do. *Looks at Planetside 2*Oh and I have played since closed beta in 2012. For whatever that's worth.But yeah, onto what makes MWO good and better than atleast 100% F2P launches on Steam in 2015.IT'S NOT P2WShock, horror a F2P game on Steam that isn't P2W? The humanity!Sure you can pay for 'mechs with the ingame MC and they can be rather expensive, so my advice? Don't, it's easy to rack up money with the cadet bonus which extends to 25 games netting you around 10mil, the tutorial gives you like 5 million to start and doesn't force you to purchase stupid things for the sake of a tutorial that 5 mil it gives you, is all yours. Speaking of money, let's talk in game money 'mech prices. The cheapest is currently the Locust, a 20 light 'mech, starting at around 1,388,241 and peak at  1,777,326 C-bills. This doesn't include upgrade costs like Double heat sinks or endo steel structures or even the paramont need for an XL engine, which can easily cost around 5/7,000,000 C-Bills on a light 'mech. The most expensive? The Executioner a 95 ton Clan 'mech that can 'sprint' for short durations, has jumpjets and some of the most tanky hitboxes seen in any Clan 'mech. Ranging from 17,505,967 to 18,142,422 C-bills (In lore it was far more expensive at around 36,000,000 C-Bills so thank God that isn't a thing.)Now looking on this game at the end of 2016;It's mostly in the same place as the same at 2015, co-op seems to be coming at some point in 2017 in theory, revamps for most of the old maps has really helped this game age, HPG is still boring and basically a boring arena map people like because...Brawlhalla. Been a bunch of new 'mechs in 2016, some for the positive, being unique such as the Cyclops, a dedicated Commander's battlemech as well as the soon to be released Linebacker, a 65 ton 'mech that pushes 100kph. Oh and there's a free 'mech up for grabs at the moment until Jan 1st, details are on the website, no strings, just a free code, boom, free 'mech with 30% C-Bill boost, extremely handy for the newer player.I rate this game, legit, 8.5/10, it's a Mechwarrior game, it's not the perfect Mechwarrior game, but they're taking it in a nice direction ever since they seperated from IGP.Play it, see if you can get into it.

												It has been a long journey from the table top version of this game. It incorporates the best parts of all of the digital counterparts as well... Especially if you like piloting a LRM boat. All kidding aside the game offers several ways to enjoy the MW universe. Faction warfare, and straight up team death match. The mechs are mostly balanced, especially during faction warfare where each side has its strong point and weak point to factor strategy around on any given map. PG has been thus far very receptive to player feedback. The game is still in development. Maps, mechs, and changes occur quite often and keeps things interesting. I've been playing since closed Alpha and I have spent almost as much on this as many people spend on Eve online plex.Give it a shot, you get access to trial mechs which grant a bonus to xp and earnings. These change from time to time to keep things fresh.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												Borderline recommendation, but only because it's an above average game that could be amazing if the developers shifted focus. I'd say there are two issues holding the game back:(1) It's currently a game that's torn between realism/adherence to tabletop Battletech versus focus on gameplay/fun in general. The upside is that they got the basic fighting forumla - the fragging in the basic quick match game mode - down well. It's fun, it rewards aim-based skill, and it rewards good mech loadouts. The downside is that PGI (the developers), have shown that they have trouble understanding the gameplay of their own game, with OP mechs, and then over-nerfs (although eventually they sort out mech balance). Similarly this extends to Community warfare (a special game mode), where realism/adherence to tabletop has made for boring community warefare maps. Case and point is further realism/tabletop mechanics poorly implemented like the CW auto-aim, long-tom artillery which basically fires off a mini-nuke every 2 mins, which kills most mechs in 1-2 hits and has a large radius. It's caused people to stop playing CW in the past - this is just one example. Similarly, PGI nerfed agility and speed of light mechs (a class of mechs) making them them basically underpowered in fights, because that's how they were in tabletop, eventhough lights were balanced before and a very fun class to play, even for the fragging. A third example is that community warfare has more then 8+ factions, making it a total mess with certain factions having too low pops, and others too high, once again imho, because of the focus on tabletop/lore/realism over gameplay.(2) The game is Pay2NotGrind. As a new player you get a huge starting bonus of c-bills that lets you get a couple lights, 2 mediums, or 1 heavy, so it's not immediately noticeable, but put it this way - an average starting player  might  average 100k c-bills per 10-15 min match if they are good (after starting bonus expires), but light mechs typically take 5-7 million deck out; assaults usually closer to 15-18mil. If you're good, you can probably average 150k c-bills/match, maybe higher, but it's still a grind. Thankfully, it's not really Pay2Win, although there are some very good mechs that can only be bought with hard cash; the free to play equivalents are generally just as good. There are also trial mechs (can always be played by anyone without buying them) that are decent as well, though you can't customize them. Overall, the Pay2NotGrind seems to be a purposeful decision by PGI to focus on whales (few players who put lots of money in the game), and this tends to hurt the size of the playerbase.Overall though, it's still a very fun game, and the quick match - individual or group queues - are very fun, even if community warfare isn't. And you can play private games for scrimmages, and there is a very active league quick match scene, so there is real depth to the game. Just a shame that the developers are holding the game back.p.s. I have another 100 hours on the non-steam version of the game, several years back. Also, I'm a pseudo-whale - I've played this game on and off three times (2014, 2015, 2016)  and each time I've spent around $50-60 for a total of about $150-180. That amount has bought me about 12 mechs, mostly heavies. In the same time period of time - or about 200 hours total - I've probably grinded enough money to buy 9 heavy mechs, but I definitely wasted some ingame money by selling weapons after buying them, and then needing them later and having to rebuy them.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2016
												I've always wanted to write a proper review for this game but I still can't be arsed to write a lengthy, detailed writeup over a video game; everything I'd want to say has already been said again and again anyways. So I'll just get down to the important stuff.This game has its pros and cons but the important thing to remember is that it -IS- free and if you play semi-regularly the grind doesn't really feel too hard. Everything performance-wise you can get with real money you can get with in-game money except for Hero mechs, which aren't even remotely P2W but do have unique playstyles and loadouts compared to their standard variants. Also, some of them look sexy as hell. (Most of the pay model in this game is cosmetic btw)There are a LOT of mechs you can pick from and decent variety between the individual models. You can customize the loadout and there's a fair bit of playstyle flexibility for MOST of the mechs. However, this game suffers from a terrible state of "forced" meta due to the way rebalancing is handled (or not handled), making things considered non-meta really hard to be competitive in. Still, if -you- like it and you can put in the performance, go for it and do you. All my clan mechs are ballistic-based and I love the unexpected facetime and carries I get against people expecting pulse vomit or streams or other meta Clan stuff.This game hates AMD FX processors!!! Full stop. It's a known and somewhat long-term issue and, while not incapacitating, can be really frustrating because it causes small, infrequent hiccups/bottlenecking during gameplay. For everyone else, this game has the optimization of a flint axe! Bear that in mind if you crank up the graphics settings. However, the mechs on higher settings look amazing, as do the particles and shaders. The LODs are terribad but I guess that's the price you pay for super-sexy giant stompy robots with full first-person cockpit views.Another big con for this game is that the developer doesn't always make the best or brightest decisions in regards to balance passes and content updates. But!!! Things have been way better in that department in the past few months/past year, and we actually got the new CW when they said they would put it out, so that's refreshing.TLDR: Should you play this game? Yes. It's free. It's fun. There's no P2W. At least give it a shot before you decide you hate it.

												Having Played the original Mechwarrior series years ago, i was absolutely thrilled to see this title on Steam.Despite being a very different game i still love MwO. This game has a solid learning curve and being F2P amassing wealth and exp to buy mechs and upgrades takes a good while if you choose not to Pay real money. However... that time is definately worth it. I have not been playing this for long and allready i like the community. I will most likely sub the game pretty soon if i continue to have as much fun playing it as i have now. This game needs support and i will do my part for sure.A little list of positive and negative things about the game...Positive:- Good and friendly community- Great potential for epic team battle provided you have a good strategic leader.- F2P. It is actually possible to build very deadly mechs without using real money- Some awesome maps with very good looking graphics despite still providing good strategic points.- High learning curve... Means you won't get bored soon if you have an ambition to matter in the game.- You Pilot Mech's ... Who wouldnt want to pilot a 100 ton Mech? Think Pacific Rim... Seriously... Mechwarfare!!!Negative:- F2P has its drawbacks... Hopefully Piranha Games wont pull the plug anytime soon and make enough cash to see the game as a financial success.- Steap learning curve means that you propably need to love the genre to stay in this universe for long.- Some maps are awesome while others are downright awfull. - F2P Speed at wich you can gather wealth is pretty slow so you really need patience here...- as far as i have seen no support for multi monitor... wich is sad if you have the system to carry it.i would give the game 8/10 points tilting towards 9/10 but there is still room for improovement. If you are into the Mech Genre... This game is a MUST HAVE!!! If you are not... you will still have lots of fun.

												There are few games that have the astounding range of customization with such a huge array of "charachters".  The rewards systems and your ability to purchase mechs, and build your ultimate "Deck" to battle with is a wonderful combination of forethought and all out brawling. If you ever played the board game or any of the previous mechwarrior games I think you will enjoy this rendition.  It takes some getting used to, you'll have to do some reading.. But it's worth it.
