												Have been playing this game since October 2012, pretty sure I'm well over 3k hours but I've downloaded the Steam client just some months ago.PROS:Not pay-to-winGood graphicsExcellent controls and gameplayLearning curve is decentNear infinite customization options, both for cosmetics and loadoutsHundreds of Mechs to choose and buy (with in-game or real money)Helpful communityVery active devs, one big update being released each monthGood game balanceGreat for E-SportHRS (Host Rewind State) makes is playable for people with bad connection or far from the serversNO HACKS (but lots of tinfoil hats who can't shoot straight or hold a laser on target calling "hackers!" the ones who does)CONS$$$ packs are expensive"Weekend" events giveaway premium stuff for free, but they can be time consuming and, sometimes, require you to login and play a couple matches for many days in a rowGame mode Faction Play is still not quite finished and lacking balance adjustment between factions.This is, for sure, one of the best games I've had the pleasure to play in my life. 10/10

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												Been playing on and off since beta and I highly recommend this game if you want a different kind of FPS experience. The gameplay is slower and more tactical than about any other FPS on the market, not only in the way you have to focus on team play but also how you have to fight. With the ability to destroy parts of the enemy mech you have to make choices in the heat of the battle, do you go for the kill by destroying the center torso or do you first destroy their ability to fight efficiently by destroying their weapons (arms and/or side torso)? The game gives you a lot of different possibilities on how you want to fight, just keep in mind, this game will punish you hard of you try to do the "Rambo".The game has its problems, game balance is a big one that has plagued the community for a long time. With 3 big weapon kinds (laser, ballistics, missiles) and with different weight classes and kinds of each of those makes getting everything equally  viable, very hard. And since the two factions both have their own variants of almost all the weapons with range, dmg etc differing between them, I imagine that its hell to make it all balanced. PGI do try and each patch has new tweaks to make it better. (Some times they do fail big time! ;) Graphics and sound are really good, all crankt up the game looks amazing, sadly turning the settings down gives you an edge since you will have better visibility due to less particles in the air, less effects from weapons etc. Seen some people saying that there is pay2win in MWO, but there isn't, there is no weapons, armour, "gold ammo" etc you can buy for real money. You can buy colours, skins, cockpit items, premium time (extra XP and cash rewards) and mechs. The newest mechs are only available for cash for a time after release, they will then come available for in-game currency. And since "new" mech doesn't equal "best" mech I fail to see the problem with that. F2P games need to make money and this is probably the best way they can do that with the player count they have. There is no content locked behind levels or any such nonsense (looking at you WoT, Warframe etc ). You can buy any mech in the game if you can afford them, want the first mech you buy to be a 100ton murder machine? No problem, with the in game currency you will make from completing the tutorial and your 25 first matches will reward you with extra cash (Cadet bonus, I believe that still in effect?) you will have lots of cash to spend on your first mech, I would recommend that you don't buy the most expensive one you can find, read the forums for great tips on what to go for depending on what weigh class you want to play.Try it and don't give up just because to die without killing any one your first match! Believe it took me 5 matches before I got my first kill and man was it rewarding after all the fail in previous matches! ;) I also recommend checking out the forums, MWO has a great community and will help new players with tips and tricks for getting started. Many will also drop in game with you and help you, great community of guys and gals!

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												   If you like Mobile Suit Gundam, Macross, Pacific Rim, or even played any of the BattleTech games (tabletop from the 80's or video games in the franchise) you'll want to give this one a go. It fills in that niche giant robot slot you've been craving.   The game appears like your poorly-interactive-MMORPG at first glance (it took me a couple days to figure out just WTF is going on in the Mechlab), but once you get the hang of the wealth of information presented, it becomes much more intuitive. Every piece on the screen, in-game or in-menu, serves a purpose and tells you something. It just takes a bit to get used to it.   The piloting segment of the game is very fun but is a challenge to do well. Many aspects are occuring at once, and it's up to you to manage them all effectively (ex. heat management, ammo, presenting armor, etc.). If you are a tanker (World of Tanks, War Thunder, Armored Warfare, etc.) you can apply your knowledge directly to this game and do pretty well. If you aren't, the learning curve is about the same. The idea is to play smarter, not harder. Coordinate with your team and you'll likely take home the big money.   My biggest credit to this game after playing more Pay2Win games is the free-to-play model. The game is very much playable for free; in fact, the game will help you grind for your first 'Mech, and even so, supplies you with "rental" Trial 'Mechs throughout the game. There also isn't a progression tree, so you choose what you want to play, grind it out, and get the one you want. Beyond that, the Mechlab will allow you to customize the components on your 'Mech to suit basically any playstyle (look up B33f's Direstar build: it's a riot!). All of this is free, you don't have to pay a dime to them. The cosmetics of your mech will be what they grab cash out of you on, but that is entirely optional.    After seeing so many dull, indless games come up, it's good to see a game that requires a good mind. I would definitely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												Been playing on and off since beta and I highly recommend this game if you want a different kind of FPS experience. The gameplay is slower and more tactical than about any other FPS on the market, not only in the way you have to focus on team play but also how you have to fight. With the ability to destroy parts of the enemy mech you have to make choices in the heat of the battle, do you go for the kill by destroying the center torso or do you first destroy their ability to fight efficiently by destroying their weapons (arms and/or side torso)? The game gives you a lot of different possibilities on how you want to fight, just keep in mind, this game will punish you hard of you try to do the "Rambo".The game has its problems, game balance is a big one that has plagued the community for a long time. With 3 big weapon kinds (laser, ballistics, missiles) and with different weight classes and kinds of each of those makes getting everything equally  viable, very hard. And since the two factions both have their own variants of almost all the weapons with range, dmg etc differing between them, I imagine that its hell to make it all balanced. PGI do try and each patch has new tweaks to make it better. (Some times they do fail big time! ;) Graphics and sound are really good, all crankt up the game looks amazing, sadly turning the settings down gives you an edge since you will have better visibility due to less particles in the air, less effects from weapons etc. Seen some people saying that there is pay2win in MWO, but there isn't, there is no weapons, armour, "gold ammo" etc you can buy for real money. You can buy colours, skins, cockpit items, premium time (extra XP and cash rewards) and mechs. The newest mechs are only available for cash for a time after release, they will then come available for in-game currency. And since "new" mech doesn't equal "best" mech I fail to see the problem with that. F2P games need to make money and this is probably the best way they can do that with the player count they have. There is no content locked behind levels or any such nonsense (looking at you WoT, Warframe etc ). You can buy any mech in the game if you can afford them, want the first mech you buy to be a 100ton murder machine? No problem, with the in game currency you will make from completing the tutorial and your 25 first matches will reward you with extra cash (Cadet bonus, I believe that still in effect?) you will have lots of cash to spend on your first mech, I would recommend that you don't buy the most expensive one you can find, read the forums for great tips on what to go for depending on what weigh class you want to play.Try it and don't give up just because to die without killing any one your first match! Believe it took me 5 matches before I got my first kill and man was it rewarding after all the fail in previous matches! ;) I also recommend checking out the forums, MWO has a great community and will help new players with tips and tricks for getting started. Many will also drop in game with you and help you, great community of guys and gals!

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												   If you like Mobile Suit Gundam, Macross, Pacific Rim, or even played any of the BattleTech games (tabletop from the 80's or video games in the franchise) you'll want to give this one a go. It fills in that niche giant robot slot you've been craving.   The game appears like your poorly-interactive-MMORPG at first glance (it took me a couple days to figure out just WTF is going on in the Mechlab), but once you get the hang of the wealth of information presented, it becomes much more intuitive. Every piece on the screen, in-game or in-menu, serves a purpose and tells you something. It just takes a bit to get used to it.   The piloting segment of the game is very fun but is a challenge to do well. Many aspects are occuring at once, and it's up to you to manage them all effectively (ex. heat management, ammo, presenting armor, etc.). If you are a tanker (World of Tanks, War Thunder, Armored Warfare, etc.) you can apply your knowledge directly to this game and do pretty well. If you aren't, the learning curve is about the same. The idea is to play smarter, not harder. Coordinate with your team and you'll likely take home the big money.   My biggest credit to this game after playing more Pay2Win games is the free-to-play model. The game is very much playable for free; in fact, the game will help you grind for your first 'Mech, and even so, supplies you with "rental" Trial 'Mechs throughout the game. There also isn't a progression tree, so you choose what you want to play, grind it out, and get the one you want. Beyond that, the Mechlab will allow you to customize the components on your 'Mech to suit basically any playstyle (look up B33f's Direstar build: it's a riot!). All of this is free, you don't have to pay a dime to them. The cosmetics of your mech will be what they grab cash out of you on, but that is entirely optional.    After seeing so many dull, indless games come up, it's good to see a game that requires a good mind. I would definitely recommend this game.

												Have been playing this game since October 2012, pretty sure I'm well over 3k hours but I've downloaded the Steam client just some months ago.PROS:Not pay-to-winGood graphicsExcellent controls and gameplayLearning curve is decentNear infinite customization options, both for cosmetics and loadoutsHundreds of Mechs to choose and buy (with in-game or real money)Helpful communityVery active devs, one big update being released each monthGood game balanceGreat for E-SportHRS (Host Rewind State) makes is playable for people with bad connection or far from the serversNO HACKS (but lots of tinfoil hats who can't shoot straight or hold a laser on target calling "hackers!" the ones who does)CONS$$$ packs are expensive"Weekend" events giveaway premium stuff for free, but they can be time consuming and, sometimes, require you to login and play a couple matches for many days in a rowGame mode Faction Play is still not quite finished and lacking balance adjustment between factions.This is, for sure, one of the best games I've had the pleasure to play in my life. 10/10

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												DEFINITELY WORTH A DOWNLOADI just started playing the game December 2015 and within a week I've put almost 80hrs in. This game is addictive and tons of fun if you play with a group. Its good alone, but I imagine it could get really frustrating once you understand whats going on. If you decide to go ahead and get into this, know that the first 20 mil or so C-Bills you make is much easier than the rest due to bonuses from leveling, and many of the factions have dedicated faction teamspeaks if you want to get into faction play. Also know that focused fire on particular components is always more lethal than things like rockets. So skilled shooting and knowing when to turn to take hits will make all the difference when brawling. 9.9/10 Best multiplayer game I've played this year. I only regret the population isnt higher in faction play for faster matchmaking (get in faction teamspeaks to accelerate the matchmaking).

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												As someone who came into this game with little to no prior expirience with Battletech/Battletech universe lore, ect i'll just run down the pros and cons of this game.Pros:-Free2Play setup- realistically, its hard to play this game without spending money. Much like all F2P games, theres the freemium curency, and without it, you dont get many "mech bays" for housing mechs you purchase. I dropped 20$ twice on this game in total, soley for more of these mech bays and ground for the in game curreny to buy more mechs and mechparts.-Simple mechanics- You join a match, move forward, shoot people with your weapons until one team is dead.-Limited Weapon types- you know what all 4 types of weapons do (Missle, laser, ballistic), they either just get bigger and do more damage or shoot faster/have a longer range-Flexible Loadouts- The mechs are totally customizable to your liking depending on what what the mech is specialized for and what you're looking for. You want a bigger engine for more speed? Cut down on the amount of ammo you want, or make the engine more exposed to critical hits. Take long ranged weapons that dont work in close range combat, or stack up on short ranged dumbfire missles. The choice is yours.-Mech Building- Honestly this is the most enjoyable part for myself. I'll build the most unothrodox mechs to just have fun and screw around with. I'll take a massive mech thats suppossed to be slower, and throw in a massive engine with only a couple weapons and zip around like im a light-scout mech. Theres alot of leeway with that kind of stuff and I have  ablast with it.-Decent Community: most people in this community are chill, and will even help you. There is a small group of toxic players, mostly pilots that flame their team mates because they die doing something stupid, but the vast majority are players that have been following mechwarrior for years. They helped me out alot, and I found a group to play with in and outside of mechwarrior because of it.Cons:-Meta or bust: The game revolves heavily around meta builds/playstyle, especially on the Community Warfare hub. If you arent playing the most optimal builds, you get thrashed match after match, even if your skill is on par (**** Kodiaks- end of story)-Group heavy: The game requires coordination, planning, and teamwork- solo que can be cancer. Find some friends to play with and this problem is easily fixed.-Strict F2P is rough: If you dont plan on spending money at all, then you might want to get used to the monthly free-prebuilt un-customisable mechs, because you only get 3 slots for customizable mechs.-Desire to learn more about the lore: This may just be me, but bein thrown into a world I knew nothing about just didnt suit me, so I found myself spending hours on the wiki learning more on the battletech wiki.-Skill tree- Skill tree grants bonuses to mechs based on expirience with it, but without the bonus's, the mechs dont operate at the peak, out of the box, efficiency, which really hurt some mechs. All and all, I'd give the game two different scores:Strictly Free to Play: 4/10Spend what you want to: 7/10

Posted: December 29, 2015
												This game is great. Played a lot of beta before it was on steam. My first ever PC gaming experience was Mech Warrior 2, and this consistantly reminds me of that. The nostalgia is real. Game is solid and fairly well balanced. Lots of maps and a few different game modes that creates some very interesting matches. Quick game play is fast paced and the que times are short. If you're looking for a solid mech game, this is the one. The F2P model is decent, and the wallet warriors don't really have much of an edge over new players as the game gives out large amounts of free currency for you to use. There is a HUGE amount of customization available for your mechs. With some skill and some time invested you can easily whomp on people. Great game. Super solid Mech Warrior experience.

												I've played MWO for going on a year and a half.  My experience is that this a playable game with a readily-mastered learning curve, some very friendly communities, steady growth in available product, and a lot of fun.  Although I am relatively new to online gaming I find it measures up well in entertainment value to every game I have looked at since. content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												This is a great addition to the MechWarrior franchise. I've been playing it for years and PGI (the developers) keep making improvements. I wish the real-world prices for some of their mechs was a bit lower, but otherwise they've done a very good job of keeping things balanced and not letting only those with real cash get an advantage.The key to success is patience. Stay with the group, concentrate on the same target(s) as everyone else and don't wander off alone or stand in the open. Don't play this like you're in a Gundam. I personally find this game a lot more enjoyable when I play with friends.Oh, and in case you were wondering, this game is PVP only (for now). No solo campaign yet.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												Ah, MechWarrior. Can you believe it's been 20 years since MechWarrior 2 hit shelves in all of its floppy disk glory? Upon entering MWO, despite how modernized this title is by comparison, I felt an instant rush of nostalgia -- a throwback to the days of other treasured mid-90s games like Descent. Obviously, the mechanics in MWO greatly differ from its old-school predecessor(s) but the tutorial was relatively quick and simple.I will say that the system requirements listed on the store page seem to be underqualified for this title, giving my GPU (Radeon R7 240 2GB DDR3) fits even on mid-low settings but gameplay is still surprisingly smooth. Unlike most of the MMOs available via Steam, the MWO community is seemingly overwhelmingly friendly. To be fair, I haven't even logged a full hour yet but in my three matches, interaction with friend and foe alike was peaceful and informative even.I'm looking forward to investing more time into this title going forward and give it a resounding 10/10 already.

												6/10The main thing this game has going for it is that there are no other mech combat games. If It wasn't for that I couldn't recommend this game. Only having 3 game modes is downright lazy. Pros:- Decent Graphics-You feel like a mech pilot-matchmaking doesn't take longCons:-If you play solo it is common to get put on teams with no communication or ability. This game is about teamwork far more than solo gameplay. So you get put on these terrible teams that kill themselves like lemmings and there is little you can do to win the game. This game really sucks to play solo. -Matchmaking as a group puts you up vs very good players even if you are a noob.-Many invisible barrirers on objects blocking shots-Have to grind a lot to get money and xp to unlock or buy stuff for your mech-The only game mode people want to play is skirmish (TDM) out of the 3 game modes. -Auto Locking missile spam-Graphical bugs with textures popping in and out-No melee combat mechs-Overpriced Mechs

I happily recommend it to anyone looking to play a fast-paced SF-themed MMO.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Its a pretty fun game. I really enjoy the concept of people able to modify your armor and weapons loadout. You have limitations, including a total ton limit and certain parts of the mech can only hold certain types of weapons, and you have "slots." But within these, you can do just about anything you want. You can stick a really big engine and a bunch of machine guns all over your mech to make him fun to play with but annoying to other people, but to do this you will probably have to sacrifice armor. Or you can load your mech down with lots and lots of missiles but you probably won't have much room for other upgrades. You can choose to protect your ammo, or risk it exploding. You can switch standard heat sinks with more efficient doubles, or ferro fibrous steel instead of the standard in order to make your mech a lot lighter.The main problem I have with this game is money. In the beginning, the game does give you a ton of money for your first 25 games, but you better use this very wisely. I am a mediocre gamer, not bad, not great, and I average 75,000 per battle. So I would expect a really good gamer to earn 150,000-200,000 at best. The cheapest that you can buy a new mech is around 1.5 MILLION but the good ones are going to cost you at least 6-8 million, and the best reach 15 million. Even just buying a new engine will cost you at least a half a million. And very simple, small weapons like machine guns and small lasers will cost you 10-25,000 and it only gets more expensive from there, with some getting close to a million. The point being...it takes FOREVER to make any real progress in the game. If it weren't for everything being expensive and it taking a long time to earn the money, this would definitely be one of my favorite games, but unfortunately things are expensive and the game has simply become tedious as I have only had 2 mechs since getting the game a couple months ago.Perhaps the game designers intended for you to have this problem though. They do give you trial mechs that you can play with for free and automatically change every so often so you can still have fun using those. All in all, not a bad game.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												A tentative thumb up.It's a fun game with a few caveats depending on what type of gamer you are. The 'stomping death machine' part is done well but the lack of alternative game modes (essentially just team death match atm) will wear thin quickly. The Community Warfare mode currently in beta is a step in the right direction but considering it's been dangling since 2013, it may or may not turn out for the better.The hook of the game is living the dream of piloting the dozens of mechs from the Battletech universe. Unfortunately, the F2P grinding required is one of the worst I've seen and even in real money terms, mechs and various cosmetics etc are very expensive. In the end, if you are a fan of Battletech like me and willing to plunk down at least $30, you'll have a good time. If you are looking for COD+Titan Fall then please step away.Edit: MWO shines in team work and does not reward individual heroics. As such, a mic will significantly increase your enjoyment of the game. Even as a noob, your paniced warnings will be appreciated by your team who usually are too busy to read text boxes. As an experienced player, calling out tactics, seeing them obeyed and turn the tide of battle is pure, fist pumping joy. Community is generally well behaved since the high skill requirement will deter teen Rambos quickly.

												Don't let the past MWO, it's earlier problems,upset users and IGP dissuade you, PGI has turned this into a very fine game & one of the last holdouts for lifelong Battletech/Mechwarrior fanatics while making it accessible to all.  It's current state has a good variety of machines, a good, mature community, and large scale persistent factional warfare.  There are genre and some playstyle/mechanic/cash store similarities to games like World of Tanks, and the purchasable machines do not (despite claims otherwise) possess godlike pay2win powers.  It's a slow, deliberate game, meta game, and progression.  If you miss Mechwarrior 1-4, Battletech: Solaris, Mechassault, or the legendary Battletech tabletop miniatures wargame & it's accompanying pen & paper rpg Mechwarrior, this is for you.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												Mechwarrior Online is an awesome game of (simulated) BattleMech combat. It takes some practice just to get your machine going in the direction you want it to, but fortunately they do offer a training academy that is slowly getting better as time moves on. I recommend running through the academy several times in order to get a feel for the machines.Another word of advice: Considder changing some of the option in the game. Turn on Torso Twist, for example. It's better to learn now, before you develop a bad habit. Secondly, set it to first-person mode. It just makes the experience that much better. I would couple this with nudging the "FOV" slider up, to you can see out all of your windows. If you're a battletech fan, this is a good Battletech game. Forget what the naysayers yammer about. I've been playing since 2012, loggin on averag over 40 hours a week. Yes, there is a bit of a grind, but nowhere near as bad as World of Tanks. Yes, there is premium content to purchase, but none of that will guarentee victory. Mostly, premium items and 'Mechs have a cosmetic value to them. Most of the actual builds can by built on standard, non-premium machines.If you like a multiplayer game with a bit more thought to it that the endless deaths of Call of Duty, consider this title. Not only do you get to lumber across the landscape of alien worlds in a machine massing between 20 and 100 tons, you will also be rewarded for utilizing proper team tactics. The only truly "overpowered" component to this game is teamwork. Everything else can be countered. There is also a very large number of 'Mechs to try out. Find the weight class that suits you best, and you will be left with plenty of options for play, further expanded by the ability to completely customize your Battlemech. I would avoid Faction Play until you've gotten comfortable both with your 'Mechs, and the fact that you tend to die a lot. Faction play is pretty brutal right now, and dropping in without a team can be very frustrating. The takeaway? This is Mechwarrior. If you've ever been a fan, whether it's from the tabletop game or MechAssualt, then this is the latest chance to imagine yourself in the cockpit, controlling 75 tons of heavy armor and even heavier weapons.An excellent game that is constantly improving. Highly recommended!

												This game is great. Played a lot of beta before it was on steam. My first ever PC gaming experience was Mech Warrior 2, and this consistantly reminds me of that. The nostalgia is real. Game is solid and fairly well balanced. Lots of maps and a few different game modes that creates some very interesting matches. Quick game play is fast paced and the que times are short. If you're looking for a solid mech game, this is the one. The F2P model is decent, and the wallet warriors don't really have much of an edge over new players as the game gives out large amounts of free currency for you to use. There is a HUGE amount of customization available for your mechs. With some skill and some time invested you can easily whomp on people. Great game. Super solid Mech Warrior experience.

												This is a great addition to the MechWarrior franchise. I've been playing it for years and PGI (the developers) keep making improvements. I wish the real-world prices for some of their mechs was a bit lower, but otherwise they've done a very good job of keeping things balanced and not letting only those with real cash get an advantage.The key to success is patience. Stay with the group, concentrate on the same target(s) as everyone else and don't wander off alone or stand in the open. Don't play this like you're in a Gundam. content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												Ah, MechWarrior. Can you believe it's been 20 years since MechWarrior 2 hit shelves in all of its floppy disk glory? Upon entering MWO, despite how modernized this title is by comparison, I felt an instant rush of nostalgia -- a throwback to the days of other treasured mid-90s games like Descent. Obviously, the mechanics in MWO greatly differ from its old-school predecessor(s) but the tutorial was relatively quick and simple.I will say that the system requirements listed on the store page seem to be underqualified for this title, giving my GPU (Radeon R7 240 2GB DDR3) fits even on mid-low settings but gameplay is still surprisingly smooth. Unlike most of the MMOs available via Steam, the MWO community is seemingly overwhelmingly friendly. To be fair, I haven't even logged a full hour yet but in my three matches, interaction with friend and foe alike was peaceful and informative even.I'm looking forward to investing more time into this title going forward and give it a resounding 10/10 already.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												EDIT: Review assessment changed to 9/10, simply because of the amount of content and reworks coming our way in the near future; looks like PGI is listening to the fans after all.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~About time I wrote a review for my most-played game as of late.I've been a fan of BattleTech for a little over a decade now, since I was 4 or 5 years old, and I have failed to find another franchise which comes close to the feel of it. I'm gonna have a major rant on the background of these games, so if you wanna avoid all that scroll way down until you see a nice big train of tildes. 0_0This series follows a unique dystopian science-fiction setting (which is actually very plausible) where man has overcome the limitations of Earth and settled across the stars. Yet our sinful nature has not been left behind, and a multitude of factions exist after the collapse of the Star League in the 28th century. Four succession wars have been fought since, and the persistence of the human traits of greed, betrayal, and need for war have perhaps never been more evident.These wars are fought on a number of fronts: among the stars through jumpships and warships, in the skies through aerotech, and on the ground through infantry and the tanks which have now been in use for over a millenia. However, a breakthrough happened which would permanently change the face of war.In 2439, the Terran Hegenomy developed the MSK-5S prototype, commonly known as the Mackie; this was the first true BattleMech. While primitive by 31st century BattleMech standards, the prototype was a complete success, practically obliterating its test targets consisting of four Merkava heavy tanks. This ushered in a near arms-race age while the Star League still reigned supreme, in which perhaps hundreds of BattleMech models were released by the different Great Houses and other factions united under the League, with the technology available for these walking tanks constantly improving along the way.Tensions rose, however, and with the Great Houses eventually waging war on each other in the First Succession war, the defeated Star League Defence Force retreated to beyond the Periphery and Inner Sphere space currently known to man, taking their knowledge of BattleMech technology with them. These forces, over the course of a few centuries, developed their own societies and militaries, and would return to the Sphere under the name of the Clans.Meanwhile, relentless, unfading war between the Great Houses caused the rate of technological progress to come to a halt, and with the loss of the most advanced BattleMechs in these wars, the Inner Sphere eventually degraded to a point of lesser technology by the 31st century, so much so that the BattleMechs that were in such number during the Star League age were now a rare commodity, only piloted by the nobility, the highest-ranking officers in each House, and the richest mercenaries.Then came the Clans to give the Inner Sphere a little bit of a wake-up call. Converging from the Periphery, the Clans initially steamrolled all resistance until the influential Battle of Tukayyid in 3052. The Great Houses, still hostile towards one another, realized that they would have to put aside their differences until this new threat was sent back to where it came from.And we've only scratched the surface of the lore this series has to offer.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~That's where MechWarrior Online comes in: the conflict between the Inner Sphere and Clan is at its peak, and individual factions within both sides aren't exactly the most friendly with one another. To top it off, mercenaries are profiting off of this turmoil all the while. The Faction Play aspect of this game captures this side of MechWarrior almost perfectly: you can choose to be a loyalist, mercenary, or even a freelancer, all with their own benefits.Of course if that's not your cup of tea, the rest of the game has plenty to offer. The MechWarrior series has always had plenty of customization potential, and never before has the series had THIS much customization potential. The plethora of 'Mech chassis and variants, weapons, equipment, upgrades, and modules provide for an impossibly high number of build options. If customization is your thing (and I know it's mine), I can confidently say you will be WOWED by this game.The gameplay itself is very tactical: IGN put it pretty much perfectly by calling it a "thinking person's shooter". But don't worry, there are guides on Steam that will give you a run-down on all the tips and tricks of this game. Joining a casual or competitive unit will further your game experience by providing you with a well-coordinated team, as opposed to dropping in with random people.Balance is not an issue for the mass majority of the time you'll be playing, so not really anything to point out there.The game also updates every month, though these patches usually consist of new mechs held through a paywall for a few months and minor gameplay changes. There are also events held semi-regularly which provide in-game currency (standard and premium) as well as both cosmetic and useful items.If you are a previous BattleTech fan, this is a must-have. It doesn't have the campaign, Solaris arena, or instant-action modes that the MechWarrior series is so well known for (bummer :/), but it excels in pretty much every other way.If you're new to the series, all the stuff this game has to offer can be a little hard to get used to, but it's pretty intuitive and there's a simple tutorial. Additionally, you can find a series veteran like myself; we'd be glad to help you learn the ropes.Overall I'm gonna put aside my BattleTech bias and give this game a 8.5/10, there's stuff to do for sure, just not as much as there coud be.

												It's tanks...that walk...and some even fly!!!! If any one of these three things work for you then this is a winner! number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												I've been trying to quit this game for 3 years now but it's the only thing out there that scratches that itch.  I've been drawn to the Battletech universe ever since my older brother started bringing home the Technical Readouts and miniatures back in the 80's, so nostalgia is indeed a factor for me.  That said, the lack of any single player content or story is actually a huge negative for me when considering a recommendation.  In fact, there have been plenty of negative aspects of this game over the years that is difficult to justify.  Game balance is slow to adjust, and when it does it's drastic (to be fair, it's actually in a decent spot at the moment).  Monetization is not for the feint of heart or wallet.  Game design is pretty uninspired, every game mode is essentially a variation of team deathmatch.But despite it's flaws, I keep coming back.  For 3 years I've been able to rely on this game to satisfy my mech piloting needs.  In all that time I've never had trouble finding one of those heated matches where all the maneuvering, skill and teamwork all come together to create a highly rewarding experience.

												The game has some very steep learning curve... and the archaic tutorial in game doesn't really help as well...But the game comunity is very helpful and there are loads of guide and tutorial online whether on youtube or the forum itself.It's a great mech combat shooter and especially if you're a battle tech fan, just don't expect it to follow the traditional battle tech lore for the sake of the game balance.Has been a great game for me so far, frustating early on but as you generally progress through the tiers and gained further experience the games feels more rewarding.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												If you're a fan of battletech this game is a must have. It's the long awaited continuation  of the Mechwarrior series with an amazing roster of mechs and a complete customization system. There is also unit play to conquer areas of the inner sphere. The community warfare system is still fairly young with a lot of growth ahead of it, despite it alone offers a lot of content.The packages like most free to play games are a bit pricey however nearly every mech in the game is avaible for in game currency (c-bills) with the exception of hero mechs (special variants with +30% c-bill earning) and staggered releases on new mechs (Pre-order Release, Premium Currency Release, In-game Currency Release).Highly recommended even if not a fan of battletech or simulators, it comes off as a great tactical shooter.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												I've been a Mechwarrior fan since the original PC game in 1989.  The bulk of my Mechwarrior experience has been with MW2: Mercs where I ran a unit called ComStar Mercenaries.  Ahhh those were the days....no easy multiplayer interfaces....limited options....however Mechwarrior has always been on top.  After Microsoft's mutilation in MW4 I had started to lose hope in the series.  Then, out of the blue MechWarrior Online appears and war had returned to the universe!  The graphics are very good, gameplay is a little imbalanced in favor of the Inner Sphere(IS).  Community Warfare is an awesome part of this game allowing players to play out the changes in the game universe.  It will be nice if they add an interface similar to MW2: Mercs where you can sign up for smaller contracts and gain loyalty with other factions or lose loyalty if working against a faction.  Choosing a path for loyalty is also a good way to make some friends and work together toward a common goal.  I've chosen my path with Clan Wolf, which path will you take?

												Been playing it since open Beta, sure lots of ppl complain about the added mechanics like Ghost Heat, Gold Collector Mechs etc. At the end of the day, i'm glad i still stuck through all the changes and this is the only online mech sim i play. Fully customizable, tons of regular events with the devs throwing out freebies even before Steam launch, and as a result, i do make purchases with real money, Forums though need to take things shared with a pinch of salt, they tend to complain a lot, but there are awesome ppl who do dish out helpful commentary and insights as well.End of the day, the only constant is change, so as long as they keep improving the mechanics, i don't see myself stopping ever to play MWO.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												I was an original Elite Founder of this game when the funding campaign launched in 2012...before Steam Greenlight and many other community funded games.  I eagerly backed at the Elite ($60) level and chomped at the bit for ever to get into the game and then I did.  I was elated with how fun the game was in it's early days and was enthralled with the promise of what was to come, so my friends and I waited eagerly for that content...and waited...and waited...eventually got frustrated and stopped playing feeling like we had wasted $60 on broken promises.  That's what things were.  We backed the game with that understanding but PGI's approach was not that same as what you see on Kickstarter or Greenlight today...they did it all independantly.  So in short, we kept up with what they were doing for a while hoping to come back one days and things just seemed like they were going down hill and the game was going to crash and burn.When we saw it launch on Steam, my initial thought was "Well, one last ditch effort to keep the game alive it seems."  Then one day we were talking about it and decided to pop in one last time to see if things had changed...and were very surprised.  So now I have over 70 hours in the game in less than two weeks and am eating crow.So, I may not agree with everything that PGI did when they got started but I think they've been trying to find a way to make it work and had to grow some thick skin in the process to keep things afloat.  I'm not defending them by any means but this was an early learning lesson in crowd funding a game.  Lots of things they promised came very late or are still not in the game today.  That's OK, I'd rather them get it right but they had issues communicating this to their backers.In short, mistakes were made and some people are still mad about it.  I'm happy now and hope to see more of the content come to fruition.Would I recommend this game?  Yes, so long as you know what it is and isn't.  There are plenty of reviews that details this info, but in short:-  This is not run'n'gun, you do you die, fight alone, die alone-  Teamwork is essential for victory as is communication-  It is a slow paced progress to improve your mechs, do not expect to buy your way to victory.  Even if you put hundreds of dollars into it, you still have to grind the XP for your mechs to improve them-  The controls are complex but intuitive once you learn them-  The game is for a mature audiance and by that I do not mean 17+ because of language and nudity but because the players are primarily veterans of the Mechwarrior games from the late 90's/early 2000's.  That doesn't mean you shouldn't play, just be aware that it's not a game for those of little patience-  Yes, they ask for money.  You can buy mechs outright or grind out money and items.  The game is NOT pay to win and you can play it completely free if you're willing to take the time to work through it.  The stuff you pay for is getting mechs/equipment early or for cosmeticsSo, if you're looking for a game that requires true tactical teamwork, has arguably fair pricing, looks amazing and can feel pretty rewarding then this game is something you should check out.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												Good F2P game, most of things you buy with real money (like camo patterns, camo colours, stuff like that) is  overpriced for what you get, but the F2P grind is easy and they give you a bunch of almost perfectly kitted out "trial" mechs you can use to grind money with to buy your own mech. The combat is almost entirely skill based apart from missiles, which do have a bit of a random spread, the balance is great and their ideas to add "quirks" to balance mechs that have bad hitboxes was a great way to make subpar mechs be competitive without changing the shapes of iconic designsThe CW is a letdown though, both with the gameplay you get out of it and the rewards you get out of it

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												I enjoy playing MWO and will recommend it but will also point out the positives and negatives of the game from my eyes as well.The positives.It is a very good mech "shoot em up" game. Perhaps one of the best i have played.There is a vast selection of mechs, most of which can be purchased through the in game currency. It is truly a Team Game, meaning that usually the team that communicates better most likely wins.The developers explain their plans with the community as well as answer questions from the community from time to time.The developers constantly run events during weekends and holidays that can net you extra mechs, ingame currency, and sometimes even Real money currency.The negatives.As a new player, the learning curve is very harsh. It will take some significant time to learn most of the nuances of the game.Additional Mech Bays cost Real currency (MC) which means after your first 4 free mech bays you will have to spend  MC to gain additional Mechs.The Community Warfare is a hollow shell of what it should be.  It is nothing more than Team Deathmatch to take over colored pixels which mean absolutley nothing. Hopefully this will be adressed in the future, but to this point it has not.These are my honest opinions of the game, if you like a " shoot em up "  mech game and are willing to spend time learning the game , like to work as part of a team, then this is probably the game for you.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												There is a lot to be said about MWO, and most of it is good. The graphics are nice. The customization of the mechs is nice. The handling of the mechs is great. It all feels "right." There are plenty of memorable and epic moments to be found even though the missions are typically fairly short. The maps are nice and varied, allowing for the different classes of mechs to have environments where they fair very well in one game and very poorly in another. This adds challenge and forces adaptation of play style. Updates are still occurring, including new mapes and, recently, a new play mode. The system by which mechs and skills can be upgraded is reasonable and does not always require actual money for the transactions. I have played over 100 hours without spending a dollar, though soon I plan to make some purchases - there are things worth buying, after all, you just don't HAVE to buy them. This is definitely not a pay to win game.Generally, if you like mechs and PvP on-line games, its pretty good. I spend some time with it almost every day. Now for my only gripe:The only thing wrong with this game is the number of trolls playing it. Sure, die first and then spend the entire rest of the round typing about how everyone else and their mech loadout sucks. Sure, pilot a light mech and then refuse to acquire targets so that the slower but more powerful long range mechs can use your scouting to rain hell down on your enemies. And let us not forget the necessity of having a mute button so that we don't have to listen to the constant nagging of the 5 different "commanders" in every company. This game is designed to be a team event - consistantly winning any of its various mission types requires team work and an understanding not only of your own mech's/ lance's capabilities and strengths, but also an understanding of and cooperation with the strengths and capabilites of the other lances you are fighting with. Never the less, almost every single mission ends up being a free for all skirmish followed by idiotic critiques by people who have too much time to type while everyone else is fighting. This is why I don't usually play on-line games. And more than likely, it is what will drive me away from this one.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												I recommend this game, with some caviats.The gameplay is generally pretty solid, the visuals are beautiful, and the audio is very satisfying. 'Mech customization is very thorough, and combat is supremely fun. It requires a lot of teamwork, and is slower-paced than a typical shooter.However, waiting for Community Warfare matches can be very frustrating. This area of the game seems particularly poorly designed. I frequently wait 10-30 minutes on a match, which for the most part renders this mode unplayable for me and a lot of other players.Because the game is entirely dependent on teamwork, whether you win or lose a match doesn't have as much to do with individual skill, and so when you wind up on a team full of noobs or uncooperative players, it's a landslide loss. That's usually how matches go. When your team works together and communicates, win or lose, it's incredibly fun, but the overwhelming majority of my matches involve silent, uncooperative, and/or seemingly bewildered players, which unfortunately has a dramatic effect on the quality and trajectory of the resulting gameplay.The ranking system isn't particularly fair. I'm a good player but remain stuck in the bottom-ranked "tier" 5 because my teams lose most of the time. You can have a great match, sticking with your team, doing lots of damage, pulling off great tactics, and your rank will still go down if your team loses. It can be frustrating when you are stuck playing with new and low-skill players because your success is overwhelmingly dependent on the team effort. I understand that wins and losses should play into your ranking but they need to adjust the formula to account more for match performance.Combat is far too focused on the use of Long Range Missiles (LRM's), the "noob tubes" of the game. Not only do they do quite a bit of damage, but they lock onto you and can hit you behind obstacles (except for tall buildings or geographical features). There is also a consumable item called a UAV that allows the enemy team to spot you without having line of sight, making the use of these LRM's even easier (granted, UAV's can be shot down but they don't show on your minimap). What this means is that the overwhelming majority of matches play exactly the same, regardless of game type (Assault, Domination, Skirmish, etc.)--you hide behind obstacles while people with LRM's slug it out, and this involves a lot of waiting because LRM's have double the range of smaller energy weapons. It's just a shame for the most boring and easy-to-use weapon to be so dominant in almost every single match, more so on some levels than others of course.The game has been out for several years and the updates pretty much focus on release of new mechs, so I doubt any of these issues will be resolved, and may or may not even be regarded as issues by the developer or the broader community, depending on who you ask.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Pros:- Immersive Battlemech Combat;- Galaxy Map and Faction War with real dropships and planet capture/control;- Player Owned Mechwarrior Units both mercenary and loyalist;- Solo Carreer possible as freelancer, contracted mercenary and loyalist;- Good hearted community;Cons:- Takes forever to make money in-game and thus acquiring mechs/gear is a terrible grind (you'll have loads of fun right away if you have a few hundred $US to spend on it);- Quick match has long wait queues, tonnage enforcement and map/mode votation mechanics;- Faction matches are almost exclusively tactically focused - only very well organized units have access to strategic gameplay;- In Facion play, you are limited to either Inner Sphere or Clan Mechs, according to which side you are fighting for;- Mech movement animations/realism is worse than Mechwarrior 3/4 and MWLL;- Timeline is based off the start of clan invasions but technology is not consistent with that period and many important mechs are missing;- Weapons and heat don't obey normal Battletech rules;- Mech customization is very limited;- Mechlab sucks;- Out-of-match GUI (menus) sucks;- Mechlab sucks in every possible way;- Almost no maps require thermal vision to be used now, rendering it a near-useless mechanic;- Did I mention the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Mechlab?It will also be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥if you're a purist, cos all of the gear, mech weapons and mech mechanics are 'tweaked' by the developers to stablish a meta that'll sell better.I play it and have loads of fun with friends from both real life and in-game, but so far have only three Cauldron Borns in my MechBays because when I started the game some people tricked me into playing Inner Sphere and I wasted all my begginer cred on useless Catapults, Locusts, Trebuchets.So, I do recommend this game but ONLY if you're ABSOLUTELY IN LOVE with Battlemech Combat. Otherwise, it'll be too much pain to bear and you're better off playing the MWLL mod for Crisis Warhead or any of the old games or EVEN Mech Commander 2.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Pros:- Immersive Battlemech Combat;- Galaxy Map and Faction War with real dropships and planet capture/control;- Player Owned Mechwarrior Units both mercenary and loyalist;- Solo Carreer possible as freelancer, contracted mercenary and loyalist;- Good hearted community;Cons:- Takes forever to make money in-game and thus acquiring mechs/gear is a terrible grind (you'll have loads of fun right away if you have a few hundred $US to spend on it);- Quick match has long wait queues, tonnage enforcement and map/mode votation mechanics;- Faction matches are almost exclusively tactically focused - only very well organized units have access to strategic gameplay;- In Facion play, you are limited to either Inner Sphere or Clan Mechs, according to which side you are fighting for;- Mech movement animations/realism is worse than Mechwarrior 3/4 and MWLL;- Timeline is based off the start of clan invasions but technology is not consistent with that period and many important mechs are missing;- Weapons and heat don't obey normal Battletech rules;- Mech customization is very limited;- Mechlab sucks;- Out-of-match GUI (menus) sucks;- Mechlab sucks in every possible way;- Almost no maps require thermal vision to be used now, rendering it a near-useless mechanic;- Did I mention the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Mechlab?It will also be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥if you're a purist, cos all of the gear, mech weapons and mech mechanics are 'tweaked' by the developers to stablish a meta that'll sell better.I play it and have loads of fun with friends from both real life and in-game, but so far have only three Cauldron Borns in my MechBays because when I started the game some people tricked me into playing Inner Sphere and I wasted all my begginer cred on useless Catapults, Locusts, Trebuchets.So, I do recommend this game but ONLY if you're ABSOLUTELY IN LOVE with Battlemech Combat. Otherwise, it'll be too much pain to bear and you're better off playing the MWLL mod for Crisis Warhead or any of the old games or EVEN Mech Commander 2.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												I was an original founder back in Closed Beta.  I bought in because I loved the original PvE games and was looking forward to how this panned out.  I didn't end up playing long back then because the Meta-gaming was just terrible.  Stacked builds like Dual Guass Cats, and 170Kph Jenners that you could just not hit because of hitbox and shocking bad latency issues.  It was like old school shooters where you had to lead/guess half a second ahead of where your target COULD be.  Also it was very easy to lose funds in anything but a poorly equipped mech.  The fancy geared ones you just could not afford to run.  8 man teams coming into PuGs and just squashing Newbs wasn't good for keeping players interested either.April 2016.  I decided to revisit, and it's changed.  You now can run whatever you can afford to build as most of the cost is in the initial purchase, and Repair/Rearm costs seems significantly lowered.  Possibly removed entirely.  Hit detection seems a lot better now even on 300ms ping to NA server.  There is an Oceanic server which is great for me.  The Metagaming BS has been trashed.  There doesn't seem to be any 'cheese' builds anymore.  However the more expensive Clan mechs still seem way better than any equivalent Inner Sphere design, and there is some serious inconsistency between model size/stature and actual tonnage.  Now there is Faction based warfare and rewards, and altough I haven't tried it yet  it does look interesting.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												The latest PC game incarnation of the classic BattleTech simulator series, MechWarrior Online offers a unique gameplay experience for a nominal F2P shooter game, slower paced and more tactical. There are few things greater than piloting a BattleMech stomping across the battlefield to slug it out with other 'Mechs.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Pros:A free to play first-person shooter. Some 'Mechs are for real cash only, but after sometime (?) these become avialable for in game currency.This is a slow paced shooter (Think World of Tanks). You're in a big stompy robot, and movement illustrates this in game. Customization is abound for each 'Mech. Don't like what weapons you start out with?NO PROBLEM! You really get to tweak each 'Mech to your own playstayle. However, my one problem with the customization is the requirement to have 3 Chasis of the same 'Mech to level pilot skills, this can be kind of grindy.New players will be glad to know that you are injected with what I consider to be a large amount of in game currency for playing 25 matches as a new player. This injection will allow you to get a few 'Mechs and totally fit them out, which is great.Cons:The game can feel grindy at times, especially if you "gotta catch'em all" or are a completionist.Some 'Mechs are only availble at their release for real cash (gotta make money somehow, right?) As such, early adopters can be penalized for purchasing underperforming 'Mechs. Solution for you? Don't buy the new 'Mechs right away.Limited number of maps. There are less than 10 for quick play at the time of this review. Community Warefare has different maps, but that is an entirely different gamemode and for more experienced players.You can screw yourself up and buy bad 'Mechs with in game currency and then be stuck with these 'Mechs until you earn more in game money, do research before you buy 'Mechs is my suggestion.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												I've been playing this game since closed alpha -- I had to fill out an application and be accepted to join closed alpha testing. That was early 2012 and this is still by far my most played video game of all time. You need to know what you are getting into with this so that your expectations are not let down.There still is no single player campaignThere is no story lineCommunity warfare is just another game mode with virtually zero additional depthThere is a very steep learning curve. You will have to play for many hours before you are really good. There is a lot to learn, many quirks and intricacies.  If you like the gameplay, though, this game may be for you. There are many different strategies you can take -- various mech classes and roles. For me, the game never gets stale because of the customization and different roles. If I get tired of playing the peek-and-poke strategy with a fast, light, agile mech running 2 large pulse lasers, I can switch to an assault brawler build with short range missiles and a large autocannon and have a completely different play experience. So for me, the game never gets stale, I just keep coming back for more. So just know going into it that it's almost like a porno -- the plot is just some thin BS, it's really about the action. If you like the action enough, this game wont get old.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												Ah, MechWarrior. I think MWO is great for what it is. The graphics are pleasing and the various 'Mechs handle just like they should. The game doesn't ask for much with system specs either, most half decent potatoes can run this game at low with at least 30 frames. I've been a long time supporter for MWO and they've added a lot. Things like new game modes, 'Mechs, maps, modules, weapons, different physics, you name it. The game isn't pay to win either (like a lot of people say) more of pay to get your stuff faster because you're lazy type of game. The two main currencies in the game are the C-bills and MC. You earn C-bills how you would expect, playing matches and are rewarded with more if you did well and less if you didn't do well. You earn MC by paying real money for it (something like $14 or $15 for 1,500 MC). With C-bills, you can buy everything with except cosmetics (EX: Christmas lights for your cockpit and such). With MC, you can also buy everything, including cosmetics.If you're a long time MechWarrior fan, I would give it a try. But, if you arent, I would consider this:- 'Mechs handle like tanks do. Your mech will walk in the direction it's legs are pointing, not the direction you're looking.- 'Mechs are also multi-ton war machines the size of a building, they're slow and have a heavy feeling to them- MechWarrior is a slow paced game, you can't just run around the map getting kills left and right. It requires you to actually think before you do, and stratagize with your team. (No respawns during matches)For a guy like me, this game is awesome. It's great graphics and low specs means i can play it on my laptop when on the go, and it's multi-player based gameplay is perfect for fun matches with my friends. Addictive and action packed.8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												Probably the best entry of all the Mechwarrior games and mods. The graphics, the gameplay, and the community (except the asshats on facebook) are all top notch. Whether you're a Classic BattleTech fan, competitive player, casual shooter, or sim-nut, there's a place for you in MWO. There is a bit of a learning curve, though it is nothing like Eve Online. The best way I could describe it is that it is complex, difficult, but accessable. It is an all around enjoyable game with the variety and depth needed to satiate the needs of most niche-gamers, adrenaline junkies, and strategists alike.People who complain that it is pay to win are ♥♥♥♥ing morons. Everyone has access to the same mechs and and weapons. It's pay to look cool, or pay for the convenience of not having to grind for money to buy the next mech you want. It pays their bills (albeit barely), and keeps the game fair. I honestly could not think of a better f2p model.The game runs surprisingly well on dated computers; I ran it on an AMD athlon 2 x2 with a radeon hd 6670 for years without issue. Granted, it was on low settings DX9, but I could still play competitive and record with fraps. Now with an i5dk and radeon 380x, it easily runs maxed out DX11 at 90fps average, meaning that an 800$ computer today can run it maxed out in competitive play.My *only* complaint about the game is that it lacks some of my favorite mechs from the BattleTech/MechWarrior IP, like the Annihilator, Bushwacker, Champion, and the like, but that will change as the in game timeline progresses.

												As a kid, i was in a Battletech club after school that was ran by a couple teachers and the level of nostalgia this game brings back is uncanny.  I absolutely love this game.  It is NOT perfect.  I think the cost for real money items can be a bit high, when you're paying 30.00 real money and the currency you get in game doesn't yield you enough for more than 1 mech that seems excessive.  However, you can play the game without dropping a single dime and have a great time doing it.  I have only played quick matches because i'm still feeling the game out but I do absolutely think this is my personal favorite FPS style game.  Mech Customization is a bit fixed.  You can not put clan weaponry on inner sphere mechs and I find that to be a draw back but I think they're doing it because the game is set in 3051 which predates the 3055 sourcebook that was the introduction of Clan tech on innersphere mechs with the exctensive list of IIC mechs that came out such as the Rifleman IIC and so forth.  There are some clan versions of popular innersphere mechs and i feel the game is going to get better.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												This game has been around for a few years in development off of Steam and it's grown a lot in the last year or so. It does a really good job of portraying the extensive Battletech/Mechwarrior lore that's been developed over the last 25-30 years by FASA, Microsoft, and other gaming companies. The learning curve can be a little steep as it's a very team oriented game and going lone wolf usually won't turn out well against vetern players.There's plenty of good advice to be had on the games official forums where you can find tactics and Mech builds.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												This game is amazing. The combat gets my heart racing so fast. Exhilarating combat experiences await when you have a good team leader and team mates.However, if you are flying solo, it can turn into a complete slaughterfest very quickly and very often. This game needs to be played with a group of people who are willing to march as one coherent group.Then we have the game store. This completely kills it for me. if you have the money you can buy everything you want. No need to grind in-game credits when you can avoid it entirely with $20-50. This makes the grind a wall setup to impede free players.What my biggest gripe of all is there is no way to expand your mech capacity for free. You have to spend hundreds in order to collect these mechs. And collecting is fun! It's not fun selling your hard grind just to make room for another mech. This one shot the score down for me. I would be willing to forgive most of the shop, but not this one.Pros:Beautiful graphics.The world and the mech models are amazing.Amazing combat. This combat is action packed when it heats up and you can feal the heat! Some feel the fights are too slow paced. I however like it. Big hulking machines pounding each other as if there is no tomorrow.Completely team oriented. You need team work or you fall apart fast! This is kind of a con at the same time if you don't find a team to play with. You wont have as much fun if you solo queue.VOIP built in.It doesn't sound bad and mostly works well. Still recommend using your own VOIP with the team you play with. Communication is key in this game and this was well needed to be built in.Cons:Too few free mech slots.You end up having to buy additional space for your mechs with real money. If you dont have space for another, you have to sell it. That's terrible!MicroTransation store can purchase anything and has exclusives mechs.This store is completely anti-free player. It has the essential Mech garages (needed to increase mech slots), exclusive mechs and every mech available. There is nothing you can't buy with this store.No free way to obtain this pay currency on a regular basis.Needless Grind.The games grind is 100% setup to hold free players back. The store is a shortcut to buy your way out of it.Match Making.It will put you up against a complete pre-made. You will get slaughtered and you will get this often if you fight alone.Overall Rating:76/100PC Specs  Hardware Type   CPU Intel i7-3770k @ 4GHz   GPU EVGA Nvidia 680GTX   RAM 16GB DDR3 2133   OS Windows 10 Pro

content:

												'This game is ACE'I downloaded MWO in late 2012 after looking to see if there had been any further releases to the Mechwarrior series, a game i loved so much as a kid . Now with well over a 1000 hours of gameplay can safely say MWO is an equal and perhaps perfect multiplayer advancement that can true test your skill as a mech pilot and battlefield commander. MWO will definatly give to a top gamming rush!When your trying to survive battling head to head as the last mech standing, most likely Piloting and assualt mech with half its side shredded off with your opponent equally damaged its hard not to feel some sort of adrenaline.Or if you manage to sprint across the map just avoiding enemy fire from crippling a leg in a nimble light mech and just manage to Capture the enemy base just as you 5 enemy mechs appearing from behind a hill start laying in to you.It might take some investment of time to reach your peak mech piloting ability but its definatly worth it.I highly advise joining a good Unit that uses VOIP such as teamspeak as this will take your gamming experience to the next level!see you on the battlefield.80C

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												There are Mechwarrior fans, and there are Battletech fans. If you are looking for a game that that is like Mechwarrior 4... this game is not that. You probably won't even like it. If you are fundamentally incapable of playing on an impromptu team... you will not like it. If you are not capable of ever adjusting tactics to new situations and the strengths/weaknesses of other random players... you will not like it. If you think of yourself as being an invincible Rambo who should, through your own sheer awesomeness and force of will, be able to carry a team single-handlely, or at least get a rush of endorphins at how super-duper-awesome you are (i.e. you throw a tantrum every time you are humbled)... you will absolutely hate this game. This game is not CounterStrike. This game is not Call of duty. This game is not a hum-dee-dum casual game like World of [Whatever]. This game is difficult. You will lose. A lot. You will play against people much better than you while on a team much worse than you. And that's tough, but life isn't fair. You want grittiness? That's it. You want challenge? That's it. You will grind. You must grind. And you will get batter for it. You will be frustrated sometimes. Good. That makes the next victory all the sweeter. And for all of those things I listed above, this game is totally awesome. There are plenty of whining people who give this game negative reviews. I strongly suggest you read them and evaluate if that sounds like the kind of stuff you would complain about. But if you see negative reviews about the "poisonous" community, consider that the reviewer is probably the griefer who hogs up the battle comms with that stuff during a match and how obnoxious that is. If you see a review complaining about the mere existence of "support" mechs... consider how that person must react to being on a team. If you see reviews that say "X weapon is the best and Y weapon is the worst", and especially when you see that from different people about literally every combination of weapons in the game, consider how knowledgable these people must actually be about the system they are complaining about. And ignore them all. Try the game. If you don't like it; well, it was free and you can come back here to complain. But, on the other hand... you might just find it to be the best damned real-time approach to BattleTech that has ever been realized.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												If your a fan of the original mechwarrior games than you will love MWO.  It has tons of customisable mechs and the combat is top notch.  Faction wars kind of sucks though and is bassicaly for hardcore players only unless you want to lose 9 out of 10 matches grouped up with "steam noobs"  that are just playing the game for the first time....  My other complaint is how much the mechs cost, they are WAY overpriced and trying to grind c-bills for them takes a very long time unless you have no job, school or life.  My advice to you is do some research before spending your cadet bonus money on a mech you might not want later on and check out all the trial mechs (they change every now and then) to find a mech you like.  nothing feels worse than spending a whole ton of c-bills on a mech only to find out you dont like it.  they are adding new content all the time and if your patient you can get some decent mechs and items for free when challenges come up.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												A truly outstanding mech game. If you're looking for a simulation experience with tactical gameplay, solid cooperation in every match and a positive and friendly community then look no further. Given that there is very few mech/mecha type games out there of this calibre, luckily MWO really has nailed most of what you want. The maps are big and detailed. The mechs are very customisable. This is a simulation where skill is required - but forgiving enough for a novice. When you relay coordinates and see people actively respond it shows you the community understand teamwork. When you spend the time and effort tagging opponents and people thank you for it - it's worth it. You can play a ranged game, a stealth game or get amongst it and brawl. As a final bonus, there are paid elements but you can do everything in game and there is no pay to win - David can always beat Goliath!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												To the future players.This game brings back old memories of the tabletop game and is a lot of fun. Enjoy a wide variety of mechs that specialise in different ways of play. They range from your up close an personal brawler, to your sniper, missle battery, support class and many others that are too many to name. Pretty much what what ever your play sytle is, MWO has something for you. and enough variety that you don't get easily bored. The number of maps are growing steadily which is nice to see. Also the maps them selves can be either balanced, or favored to one side or to a certain type of play. this makes teamwork extremely crucial for victory and gives something for everyone to do and be happy with. all in all this is a great product as long as you have the time to spend.The game is a bit grindy so to speak. it will take a lot of effort to get everything you would want in the game. there is also a premium pack that you can pay for with real life money if that is your thing. I personally don't mind spending $5-$10 on a free game since it helps developement of the game. however if you want things like paint jobs or accessories or to buy mech flat out with cash it is so expensive it will make your wallet snap shut. it would cost you $30-$40 to buy a mech flat out with cash which is kinda stupidly expensive.Advise to new players,Int he beginning do the turorial it gives you ingame money also save all your turotrial money and your new cadet bonus money until you figure out what type of mech you want. You can have anything from light to medium, even heavy and assault classes. when you figure out a chassis that you like and your play style buy a mech and outfit it to what you want out of it. until then, again save your ingame money because it can be difficult to reaquire. ________________________________________________________________________________To the developers,the prices of your consumables and other items are what you would expect. However the cost of mechs are stupidly expenensive. making them $10-$15 would bring in more sales. since you have the softcores and the hardcores buying mechs instead of only the hard cores. Also the price of unlocked paint/camos/cockpit accessories is also extremely high.The MWO product is self is a great product, runs smooth even on an old computer or a high end new one, so you have a very wide player base in terms of pc budget. The graphicsa are nice, although it would be nice to see the pilot breath during boot up and shut downn modes for a little extra eye candy. also please make a setting for depth of field because the game can get kinda grainy when your sniping 1250m+ away.Innersphere/Clan mechsthe innesphere mechs are stupidly unbalanced to clan mechs and have a but ton of useful quirks while a clan mech may only receive a slight exp bonus at the end of a round. Clan mechs are suppost to be drastically more high tech in comparisson to innersphere mechs according to game lore. because of the advantage of innerphere with both mech costs and quirks the clan mechs are severely at a disadvantage. if the balance is not going to be fixed at least make clan mechs relatively the same cost as innerphere instead of them often being 50%-100% more expensive

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												This game takes a lot to get into, but it is totally worth it. Mechwarrior is a shooter that doesn't reward reflexes rather than it rewards careful strategy and knowledge. Understanding the game is your key to winning, but unfortunately it can be a bit difficult to get into.There is lots of things to juggle and pay attention to at one time while you play. Heat, Armor, Ammo, Movement speed, Limb Strength, current torso direction, current leg direction, radar. Its a lot. When you first play it is a bewildering amount of information that confuses you and makes it hard for you to really know what you are doing. But once you get it, it becomes second nature. You find yourself calling out enemy locations while getting missile lockons, targetting air strikes, and keeping your heat/armor carefully managed. This is the game's strength. When you finally master the game you really feel like you are piloting a 100 ton battlemech. It feels good to fire autocannons and break the leg of an enemy mech and see him limp away in fear. It feels dire when you run as a light mech, dodging enemy fire and attempting to sabatoge the support units of the enemy team. Sure the game is complex as all get out, but that makes it all the more *real*. Nothing gives you such grim satisfaction as turning off your heat protection and blowing out your engine in order to suicide kill an enemy mech. Feeling the loud slam as Particle cannon tears off your left arm and you retaliate with your remaining right. Never before has any game but the Mechwarrior series made me feel like I'm actually driving something. You feel connected to your Atlas or Timber Wolf as you would your car or truck. They even made it to the point where you can hear your engine malfunctioning if you are on low health, and you can listen to the hissing of your failing heat sinks if they are destroyed.Make no mistake. This game is in beta. It still has a long way to go before it is perfect. There's also a lot of skill involved, and it isn't the kind of game that you can learn in just a few hours. But once you do, it is great fun and it is also free!So join me, and maybe I'll see you on the battlefield mechwarrior.
