content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												TL;DR - Devs really care and want the game to be great. They listen to feedback and try to do what the community wants without ruining the game. Gotta use your noggin' to do well and think over your actions ingame to assure victory. Definitely a great game. Good devs are good. And nice. Except for Paul.Don't let my Steam hours dissuade you; I've been playing since Closed Beta. The developers listen to the community and love the game. Mose of the developers play it, and do almost daily streams of the game where they're either sponsoring an event and giving awards, or actively playing with the player base. PGI really does care.That aside, things were rough at the start, but as the game stands now it is a very well cared for rendition of Mechwarrior and Battletech. Sure there are things that are not canon, such as mech releases, some weapons, and quirks, but these are to overall influence the gameplay. Sometimes you have to go against canon the make the game fun. PGI knows this, and does it, but very carefully.There is a learning curve to the game, but honestly after 5 matches you should understand most of it, roughly. There are nuances to every weight class, mech, faction, weapon selection/loadout. The more thought you put into it, often times, the better you'll be at the game ergo the more fun you'll have. Nothing is more satisfying then making a killer loadout that absolutely shreds mechs, or making something that seems impossible but works. I'm looking at you, 7 ER PPC Black Knight >:l

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Primer: If you play this, finish the Mech Academy and your first 25 games to get your cadet bonus C-Bills, save those and play the freebie mechs until you find a frame to your liking then spend your money. Mechs can take a while to grind out if you're not stacking premium time or buying them outright. Just a PSA8/10Good:-Fun (no I mean that give that some thought)-Mech game-Quality Mechanics-Quick Play isn't terrible-VOIP (organize when in game and most people arent toxic from what I've seen)-Connection is consistent (i average around 80-130 ping in NA servers where i usually play, its higher than some games for me, compared to Overwatch where the highest i see regularly is 60-70 but its a different game and you don't notice. Take that from a guy who's played twitch shooters for nearly 20 years.)Bad:-Not "Armored Core" (playful joke for those who know)-Mech balance can be amazing to terrible depending on what just happened with the "most recent patch" www.metamechs.com for more on that.-Can soak up money like a sponge if you don't have good wallet control. (How many WoT premiums / time did you buy? yeah same thing here)-UI is a mess, but its useable if you trudge through it for a day or so. Its not terrible, just not great.-Has the same Meta shift most games like it do (again WoT) where whats good in one patch may be unuseable in the next or overpowered, the dice roll is real.-Faction Play has no point (if that's the entire reason you're here, just don't)*Extended commentary:If you're looking for a Mech game this is about the best one I've played on PC if you enjoy even the most remote idea of tactics and teamwork, granted you're going to have to talk to other people and go out of your way to co-ordinate with them both verbally and with mech selection (makes the game better IMO) so know that going in.You can solo que this up pretty good but the game shines when working with a team (of any number really 2 man squads all the way up to full 12's are fun when you can get them. The more people in each team that are organized the more fun the Quick play que is.Mechs have strengths and weaknesses which should be obvious based on class / weapon location / speed / armor etc:I'll say this as well MWO gets a lot of flack for PGI seeming to be a greedy company rolling out mech packs for sale / pre-order (just look over at MWOMercs.com for examples) and i'm sure that can be easily seen as such. However to be fair they do produce consistent products on a semi regular basis for those looking to get more new stuff and they do, all be it sometimes ham fistedly, try to take care of the game.*Faction play is not to be trusted, some enjoy it but I'm willing to bet they are a minority and it requires good teamwork and already having a decent stock of mechs in the garage, so it wont be where you start out. In conclusion I have fun with this game and play a lot of genres that sometimes don't treat me so well recently, MWO hasn't done that to me. I've purchased a mech that turned out to be bad, sure, but it's still fun to build and take into the Solo que with different weapons and configurations trying to make something work. Afterall thats how you improve as a builder and pilot.Not as boring as Chromehounds, not nearly as bleeding edge as Armored Core. MWO sits very comfortably in the middle as a tactical-esque arcade mech shooter that treats its players alright as long as they arent looking for hand outs.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												It's definitely pay2win but it's more forgiving than other f2p games cause you can have roles. It's okay to use a trial (good) mech and jump in with friends. And you can perform better than others in better mechs by playing your role and staying in a group.However, if you want to choose this game and be serious about it, I don't recommend it. It's a serious serious grind. Tons upon tons of items to buy. And the inventory/management has to be one of the most confusing I've ever seen. The only reason I can survive is cause my friend who has spent $1200 ingame manages stuff for me.There's 4 different kids of currency: C-bills, mech XP and general XP and MC. Yes it's that confusing. To use one you must convert another, which requires MC in order to convert as a conversion fee. Confusing as all hell. And all the mechs they release are just restated old mechs, and they charge like $40 per mech. In order to "upgrade" your mech/pilot trees, you must actually buy 2 other variants of that mech. This means a casual player like me who just wants to play one type of mech/playstyle is forced to buy other mechs to fully upgrade the mech I want to main. Again, it's another obvious f2p mechanic.If you can get past this, then it's a fun game. Has that CS:GO feel but u survive longer and thus can have more fun.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25
												I love Mechwarrior in general. Most of the games have been great, and it annoys me deeply that you can't get the earlier games very easily anymore. If they had earlier mechwarrior games on Steam, I'd likely own them all.Mechwarrior Online isn't quite the same. It's a player vs player game. Think World of Tanks, with Battle Mechs.  This is mostly a good thing.  The interface is a bit clunky, but the game seems to run well, and it looks pretty.  I've played this game for hundreds of hours before it hit Steam, right through the early Betas.There are many, many mechs to choose from, both clan and inner sphere designs, and a reasonable number of maps. The wait times are comfortably tolerable, and the match-maker's not too bad either.  Unfortunately, you have to vote on maps and game styles upon queuing up, and without fail the majority seems to choose the same damn maps... so while they have a good selection, in practice you don't get to play on all that many.Also, many of the mechs are behind a pay-wall. Not all by any means, but a lot of the really nice ones. It doesn't quite get to the level of Pay To Win, but it runs close. Patch after patch they bring out new monetisation in the form of new mechs, but not a lot of other content.  This can be deeply frustrating.Equipping your mech is fun. Lots of fun. There are a great deal of options available - though unlike many of the earlier Mechwarrior games you can't just throw what you like on your mech up to the wieght limit. Certain slots are limited to projectile weapons, or missiles, or energy weapons, etc.  I can understand why, but it does cut down on the configurability a bit. You can get different variants of the same basic mech, which does help mitigate this a bit.There are down-sides however, and a lot of that is to do with how the game has ultimately developed.Back in the earlier days, the matches felt a lot more epic. Mechs seemed slower and heavier, and each could take a real pounding. You could almost feel the tonnes of metal lurching around, being blown off, etc.  More recent updates seem to have put the emphasis on action. Everything is a lot faster than it was, and I think this is a shame.  You don't quite get that visceral *thump* of steel hitting steel anymore, and everything feels a bit more cartoony as a result.  Also, your mechs come apart a lot faster. There are no missions, it's all arena play. The arenas themselves are various sizes, but generally quite big, with lots of room to maneuver. However, unless you have your own "platoon", you'll find the random matches tend to involve people not really working together... which is a real shame.In short, it's not bad, but it's not great. If you don't want to send money on it, it's also free. Got to recommend it just for the big robots.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
												If you play games like Warthunder *cough* terrible customer service *cough*, or games like World of Tanks *cough* too arcade-ish with harsh negative community *cough* you will fit right in with MWO.  First and foremost, the community in MWO is so great that they offer voice chat with your team unlike other games of similar play type.  MWO is all about skill and teamwork. There are some fantastic armchair field commanders in this game that lead your team to huge victories. Again with the community, I usually hate to play along side kids as they tend to screw around, but nearly every kid I have ever been teamed up with in this game takes it just as serious as the adult players.  There are constant contests that are reasonable to achieve and are not based on pure luck randomness like Warthunder wanting you to destroy 4 or more anti air vehicles in a single match at tier 3 or higher. Nor do these contests require you to have premium time to achieve like in World of tanks where you have a time limit in days to earn X amount of XP in a tank tree to "win" the event, and if you did the math on non premium time would take way too much time to "win" and may not even get it with constant play.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												I have been playing for a couple years now, and I gotta say, this has been my favorite game for most of that time.  It does take some time to learn the game and the play style (you can't play this game like Call of Duty) and to build a collection of useful mechs, but it has been extremely rewarding.I have found a variety of different playstyles that I enjoy, the mechs look great, the customization aspect has a learning curve (there are many guides available) but is very enjoyable.  There are some great teams to join too if you like playing with other people.I definitely recommend giving this game a try (it is free to play after all), just don't expect to drop in and figure it out in 20 minutes!  Also, try to take advantage of some of the guides that are available here on steam and on the official website of the game, it will help a alot!  There are many factors to consider, which is a lot for new players who are just trying to figure it out.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												An oldie title, but a goodie, I remember jumping into the game simulaters at the local Dave and Busters. It's about the same.   With 100s of mechs to choose from, 100s equipment to choose from, 100s mods and skill points to choose from.....With a quick tuturial with Capt. Adams and some time in the MechWarrior Acadamy, learn how to do the basics in your Mech, and become a MechWarrior of the 31 millinium. SCIFI and future battles involving mercenaries, freelancers and houses of MechWarriors battleing out as ''norm'' at the time for supremecy of the Inner Sphere. So choose between a Light, Medium, Heavy and Assualt Mech. Each Mech does have a specific playing style according to their size...AKA how many weapons they can blast you with . The bigger the more weapons/sensors/armor. Level up your Mech by playing it more to get skills and level your pilot skills up by just playing any Mechs. Skills give slight edges in battle with range, cooldowns and sensor perks. Nothing beats tactics in this game though. You will die alone. The learning curve is steep. VERY. So after chooseing a Mech , choose to be a mercenary or freelancer or join up with a house to combat together for the highest rewards. Matches are usual capture points or hold points or just kill them all with lots of weapons. Your mech you can custamize with specific skins and cockpit goodies or straight up pay money for the best of the best. Yes, pay to win does help here to the grinder free to play MechWarriors. Custamizing your Mechs armor and weapons and skills load out is VERY much up to you. Lasers? Flamethrower? Pulse-Lasers? All, is up to you, but you have to watch how much you can equip ,that depends on your Mechs tonage. The size does matter, again the bigger = more tonage = the more weapons. Lots of acheivments and titles/badges to show off and joining a unit or friends group is strongly suggested for fun, tactics and rewards. Or just hide behind the bigger Mechs and pot shot into a fight that surely your going to win and stay alive.'' I played the Myst Lynx Light Mech''...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												The game is absolutely horrible. You drive a big stompy mech and shootz people in the eyes with lazors and rain on them with the missiles. You have to use this thing called teamwork and even talk to people once in awhile to tell your team enemy locations or let thim know that they are pushing hard on a specific flank. Itz so hard and lik the legs don't move in de same direction as your face sometimes and it's all confuzabibble. And there is this magical button that you press, has this thing, oh, here it is..the R button, lets you lock on to a mech and it lets you know where you should shoot. This gaem is soo ard and so long that at the end of the day...you sleep and dream, of the big stompy mechs.But on the serious note, It is a very fun game if you can actually leave your shell and communicate with your team. Do yourself  a favor and before dropping money buying all of the mechs in the game(which is alot), buy a damn mic. That thur adds at least 100 more damage to your ending score. Do not start out and spend your c-bills on the first mech you see in the store, use the trial mechs, they are decent builds, I have pulled top damage many times using them, so use them and get a feel for the type of mech you enjoy playing. And it isn't always about the size of your mech, in this game, it is how you use it. I personally like the graphics and the game as of right now, feels pretty balanced. Game had a wonky past, but things have been getting alot better and the company has made leaps and bounds in the right direction in my opinion...which is why you are reading this review. Game is free, and worth every penny! Disclaimer: I played this game before it hit steam, so I have a hell of alot more hours than it shows on here.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												This is a great game if you remember one thing. Community Warfare isn't the place to go to learn how to play. It's the equivalent of end game content. It's MWO's version of open world PvP. That said, there is no pay to win. Yes there are a few Mech variants that are cash only, but note the word "variant". They're different versions of regular mechs, and aren't more powerful, don't have special abilities etc. Often based on characters from the BattleTech universe, they have a different hardpoints (determines where and how many weapons of a given type can be mounted).  As I said, it's not pay to win, so it isn't a matter of adding more. Various factors such as space and weight limits apply. Sometimes its a Mech that is mostly Ballistics based (ie "guns") and the Hero version mostly Energy (lasers etc) based. Toss in a unique camouflage scheme, some colors, and that's one way they keep the lights on. New mechs are introduced regularly, and spend a few months as cash only, then opened up for in-game money. No the new ones aren't more powerful etc. Weight and space limits remember? An AC/20 still weighs 14 tons no matter what Mech you pilot.It's a fun game, if you're willing to admit there is a learning curve. LRMs (Long Range Missiles) are deadly until you learn how to avoid them. as a common example. The official forums have a very active new player section, and the community is overwhelmingly friendly and helpful. I've spent over $100 on this game and I don't spend money on F2P games. One big purchase early on for some mechs, then bought some additional mech bays (this was in the days before you could earn free ones in CW and special events.)  The only way to "screw up" is to spend your Cadet bonus unwisely (you get bonus cash your first 25 missions to help you along). Even then you can pilot "trial" mechs for variety as you save up to buy new mechs. Bottom line? Visit the official forums and read over the New Player section while you download MWO. Ask questions, don't be a jerk, and you'll have lots of fun. :)

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												   TLDR: This game is not newbie friendly, it's shallow and has pretty repeative gameplay, the Devs are as greedy as EA, Content comes out at a glacial pace and in small quantites for very high prices ( 4 mechs for 60+ USD) And it's only really fun to play in a player clan because if you go lone wolf and play random battles you'll get bored fast.So, I've been a Mechwarrior fan since i was 5 playing Mechwarrior 2 Mercs on Windows 95 and i've played every Mechwarrior since and this game is probably my least favorite and  the most shallow It's hard to keep playing at a consistant pace. It kinda a bit in common with Battlefront and the developer is almost as greedy as EA. Great graphics with zero depth. it even has it's own version of EA style DLC  , you see, every time they add a new mechpack (at a glacial pace) they are first sold for real currency (for the price of a triple A game mind you 60+ USD) , then in game premium currency then you can finally buy it with regular credits after half a year.) this game is lucky it's the only Mechwarrior sim at the moment and they're squeezing us for every penny. Queue times are long for random battles and MM sometimes has a brainfart and gives one team a significant tonnage advantage. there also aren't many maps and the level of content you get for your money is very low. Playing random battles can be confusing for new players and can get stale fast , the tutorial only covers the very basics and the game has a steep learning curve so new players will not know how to make the best builds and will get outgunned by players running metabuilds. the only thing that keeps me playing is Community Warfare which is a competative mode where player clans join factions from the lore and fight against each other for planets and ultimately control of the Inner Sphere.  to sum this up i would not say this is a good game, with about 3 years of being online the amount this game developed is pretty pathetic especially when you see what kind of prices they charge for content. I'd only recommend this game if you're a diehard fan who can join a clan and i would urge you to seriously consider if you want to shell out the price of a triple A game for a couple of mechs.

number of helpful: 39 of 80 people (49%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												The core gameplay is sort of a mix between a Tank game and a Shooter. The game is slower paced than a number of other shooters, but this does not mean that it is easier. In fact, the learning curve for a brand new player can be relatively steep. The gameplay itself can be deep and rewarding though, which keeps many players playing despite the other issues they have with the game.For one thing, the game is very much a team-dependant game closer to a MoBA than a typical FPS in that regard. With no respawns (or limited respawns in faction warfare) it s essential for players to stay and fight cohesively. Players that run off attempting to grab kills for themselves can be quickly focused down by many other mechs and accomplish very ittle.The game features pretty in-depth customization of mechs that goes beyond just switching out weapons. You are able to adjust armor, change engines, replace parts, and add and remove weapons and equipment depending on the sometimes complex Mechlab rules. When you start you will be using a Trial mech at first, but you gain in-game currency fast enough to be able to buy your own custom mech within a few hours at most.There is also no tier system in regards to the mechs. There is no unlocking of better mech chassis as you play. The choice for what you want to buy is open to you from the start.Despite the sometimes high real-world prices of items in the game and the fact that it is F2P, the game does a very good job of not being Pay to Win. All of the best mechs (determined by the community) in the game are either available for in-game currency or are timed exclusives for those who buy them (the closest thing to P2W that the game has). There are Hero mechs that are available for purchase only but they tend to not be good, but rather unique. Paid consumables are 100% identical to in-game currency consumables once the in-game currency consumables are upgraded with XP. The most useful things in the game available for real-money purchase are mech bays to store more mechs in, but they are given out in Faction Play and in relatively frequent events.There are certainly some hiccups with the game. It is not particularly well-optimized and the developers have not always consistently been on top of things. Some actions have generated quite a bit of animosity among past players. They have been getting better about it though and in my impression few of the issues come from anything approaching malice but rather from inexperience. They are at least still actively working on and adding to the game in significant ways (although maybe slower than many like).In the end though I find the game quite fun which has kept me coming back to it.I've played this game for quite some time before it was released on Steam (you should be able to look up Krivvan if you doubt that for whatever reason).

number of helpful: 35 of 72 people (49%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
Of Mice, 'Mechs, and Star Lords: Threads of AmbitionOnce upon a time in the late 20th Century, in an era of vintage classics, the great Lords of Gaming bestowed upon their subjects a series called MechWarrior. Those were good times indeed.In those days I had happened upon a copy of MechWarrior 2, after being an obsessive fan of sci-fi simulation games like X-Wing, and strapped in to my first Mech Simulator and powered up - "All Systems Nominal." Everything got better from there that is until the Golden Century of Gaming had ended and the Great League of Publishers fell into dissarray (or were destroyed by the Word of EA and Microsoft).After a decade or so of players keeping MW alive, with the franchise having fallen into the dusbtin of history, and MW5 being destroyed by the evil of publishers a kickstarter-like (but not really a kickstarter) declared MW was back in 2012, and with promises that it would be "awesome."Was it in fact awesome? Let's see.The Space Lords of "Freemium" - Latin for Not ReallyAs most people may be aware, the first games in this unique series were made with a quality standard for premium type games. However, MW had been reborn, as a Freemium in 2012, made by developer Piranha known for classic games like Duke Nukem Forever Multiplayer and Bass Fish Gaming? Where is Jordan Weisman? No clue. The Nostalgia Was Strong and I threw my money into the 5 million dollar pile and be a glorified Beta Tester for 2 years.For those that know me, I have a love-hate relationship and low tolerance for plenty of OTHER F2P type games and approached this game with trepidation. I gave it my best shot. A series, once based on the old BattleTech franchise, and doing the bidding of Space Lords from your Cockpit with detailed, branching Single-Player with an addictive, bonus Multiplayer - became this. I'll get to that at the end, but firstly what to expect out of this review:  My honest take on the game and what you can expect, either as someone brand new to this series or those who were aware of the original franchise.The Basics - Is this the review now?You shoot at Walking Tanks with an assortment of space magic weapons like lasers, huge ballistic cannons, and missilesYou move around a battlefield to destroy the other team's Mechs, earning in-game currency to buy more Mechs, parts, or modulesYou can tinker with a Mech and experiment with different designs, not unlike previous games, but problems arise (weapons, how fast you move, armor levels, etc.) + base/weapon stats can be upgraded via modules and 'pilot tree' (recommended)Mechs are layered into pieces that you can shoot off individually (if the enemy has a laser in their right arm, you can shoot off that arm)'Twitch' based shooter that plays well enough with the keyboard/mouse, joystick, or a combinationMatched against random Robots with (when it works) similar skill in 'Solo' on random mapsThere is no story, only LARPingIf you want all the Robots prepare to hunker down for many days at a time, perhaps months, otherwise you can follow the whispers of PGI to open up your wallet (kind of like zealot ComStar hoarders)A tutorial is available, but there is somewhat of a learning curve if you are not used to quasi-simulations like MWDetractorsPricing - this isn't like MechWarrior you may have remembered paying 60 bucks for and being able to pilot hundreds of Mechs to your hearts content.Time commitment - if you don't have a lot of time to play games like me like an hour or two a day here and there, advancing in-game will feel like it takes ages, which will then make you feel like you need to spend cash as you fall behind everyone else and the vicious cycle repeatsGame still has optimization issues - I can run Witcher 3 on Ultra, but this game hiccups quite a bit for me; there are also default eye-sores like film-grain and reduced/smudgy view distance (some of these things can be turned off in the menu, some can not and require editing of config files outside the game)Wasted Potential: Or why I'm not recommending thisLack of unique or challenging Game Modes from previous games such as: Stock Mode, King of The Hill, Convoy, Co-op Missions, Terrain Control (true Conquest), or a better objective-based, etc.Customization while fun to a point in this game has its own inherent problems coupled with lack of cohesion with certain mechanics, which has caused imbalances that PGI will never be able to resolve truly in a Random Matchmaker. Balance in the previous games was better handled by Admins, Lobby or bidding systems, and generally the players themselves. In both BT and MW, players decided how and what level of customization was allowed.Lack of true variety; here Mechs at the top are sporting similar builds meant to kill an opponent as quickly as possible, with similar speeds and weapons, truckloads of endless ammo, and the only difference is how they look for nostalgia purposes. (BT and previous games have more variety with setup/rules)No innovation from holdover issues of old MW games using 'pin-point' damage in Multiplay (just go for the center torso, its all that matters and its easy to do)The pilot trees are the same for every Mech, so if you're looking for some depth and nuance to it there is noneYour first Mech includes a default build, these are canon builds from the original Battletech that are meant to be used/balanced against other similarly non-customized Mechs, BUT you will never actually be matched 100% against an entire team of non-custom and rather forced into the cauldron of Super Nascars.No ability to save your loadout into an in-game list for easy switching back and forthThe UI is clunky, laggy, and less intuitive compared to games a decade old, seriouslyLack of robust Multiplayer features on how you wish to play (no choosing of a specific map, match length preference, kill limits, whether you want sim aspects on or off such as spawning or third person, or you want to join a 2v2 4v4 8v8, IS vs IS, Clan vs Clan, etc.)Interesting tactical depth and sim-like aspects from past games are non-existent: Active/Passive radar, Jettison Ammo, Rear/Side internal cameras, true uncoupled free roam aim, and more - replaced by more ArcadeMaps are smallish, usually laned or nonsensically built; the largest maps have tons of unused space.Community Warfare is somehow worse than the better MW MMO from the late 90sThe 'custom' servers actually require you to pay real cash to fully utilize unlike most other f2p games, and over all is unintuitive (its not like a custom DOTA2 lobby for instance)The grind, for people like me who really don't have time for f2ps, was ultimately frustrating to no end; in previous games I loved using and trying EVERY Mech in the game but it takes too much time and/or money in this game.Summary: The Milking of Resurrected AmbitionsThe game overall left me simply wanting MORE out of it. Sort of 'ok' for a time until it set in how much it lacks in true content, depth, and a boatload of features compared with even the tacked on Multiplayer of previous games alone, let alone SP. If you DO play various F2Ps, you may tolerate it if you're not concerned about what all was in the previous games, but if you're like me where certain F2Ps just rub you wrong way with aggressive grinds and pay2notgrind nonsense or want a TRUE MechWarrior5, this just doesn't cut it. Frankly it saddens me that THIS is all that's left of the rich MW series. This is it? A shallow husk that feels 'average.'  It would be great if someone just makes MW5, but frankly perhaps MechWarrior should just be drug out back and buried.  All in all the type of f2p design decisions in this game holds it back from being truly great.

number of helpful: 34 of 70 people (49%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												Played this for about a year and a half before the glaring issues eventually forced myself and my friends to quit. To start expect a heavy pay to win experience or at best a pay to not grind three weeks for a standard mech. Also expect to be charged ridiculous amounts of cash to obtain hero mechs or even just mechbays or colors/patterns. Seriously it's in the neighborhood of $30+ PER MECH. Don't even think about the bundles and such as you'll get very little for $100+. Just standard mechs you can buy in game a little faster and MAYBE a bonus mech with a slight cbill boost.Once you get into the game expect two things. Fun stompy mech action and complete and utter bs metabuilds. In my time it went from LRMs for a brief period to PPC/Gauss builds. The PPC/Gauss was the worst because it was instant pinpoint HIGH damage. You'd wait 5-10 minutes for a match and die in seconds if you weren't in a light or assault class. Unless you got lucky matchmaking wise and the other team wasn't loaded with 5-6 metabuilds and you'd get a decent match. After the forced mech setup for matchmaking requiring x of each class it got a little more even in matches but the wait times went skyhigh. Eventually the high alpha BS and long wait times drove myself and my friends to stop playing.The company also has issues. One of the WORST I've ever dealt with. I understand Niko left a bit ago but still damn. They also can't balance their way out of a paper bag. Things get buffed WAY too far or not remotely enough and stay that way for months if not years. It took them six months or so to even start to nerf the high alpha metagame and even then it was weak nerfs that did very little curb it. Not even the bizarre ghost heat changes ever successfully killed it. The highest alpha to a side torso or center torso is the only real way to fight with any real success.I will admit before the issues started piling up and things with the company got worse it was a blast. It really captures the stompy mech action quite well. However the magic is long gone so if you play do it without wasting money like I did. Get in, do a couple rounds for some fun, and get out when the lopsided matches get to be too much. The trial/standard mechs work well enough for light play. As long as you don't invest too much time or money it's a perfectly fine game to play a match or two on occassion.EDIT - It seems they fixed up the wait times at some point. So it's faster to get into a game. The rest still stands.

number of helpful: 116 of 236 people (49%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Its a decent stompy robot game, but its got alot of problems.  the biggest is the low turnaround to fixing issues with the game.  Weapon balance has been outta whack for some time with some weapons being unusable for years.  There is generally only one major "balance pass" a year rather than iterative changes, so if the weapon is useless after the pass its probably gonna be that way for a year or more.  It dosent help things when it seems that half the balance is made with dice rolls.The new mechlab came out 1.5 years ago and was total crap, it took them over a year to get it decently useful (at least better than the old one) and there are still features that the community wants put in, like a way to strip all the modules off all your mechs, that have been basically ignored.There are issues with map and gamemode design.  For gamemodes, the problem is that theres only 3 modes, and most of the time theres no real difference between the 3 of them.  Map design has a tendency to funnel everyone to the same spots every game, due to a combo of defensive terrain in select areas and both teams starting spread out rather than togeather.  By the time you grouped with ur team you are under attack or about to be.  This makes most maps seem very small and cramped no matter how large they are because ur fighting in the same small defensive areas.The time to kill (TTK) is very low as well.  There has been alot of power creep in this game to the point where a game which involves huge stompy mechs of doom that are supposed to dominate the battlefield instead plays more like COD with mechs hunkering down behind cover and popping out to fire and duck back in.  The TTK has been shinking for years  with no end or solution in sight.There is a part of the game called "Community Warfare" (or CW) which allows you to pick one of 10 factions and fight each other for control of the galaxy.  In reality the population is too low and most of the time its the Innsershere vs the Clans which gets real old after awhile.  In addition the issues with map design and gamemodes are even worse in CW, to the point where its alot like playing a tower defence game (not even joking)To top it all off while the game is free to play pretty much any ingame items are incredably overpriced, just look at the "Steam performace packs".  The grind is real so be prepared to either shell out alot of cash or time to get a decent mech.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												The 91% approval rating on this game is proposterous.This is a game with no redeeming qualities, this is coming from someone who has spent hundreds of dollars on this game over the course of years, hoping, and praying it would become what PGI promised it would, I have played this game much longer than 45 hours.  It is an atrochious game relative to the standards it set for itself all those years ago on that kickstarter, and it is atrochious relative to the standards of game design.MWO is a ♥♥♥♥♥ier World of Tanks, that is it.  The 20-100 ton mechs handle like you are playing call of duty, the balance is apalling and made worse each time the developers touch it.  There are many mechs that are outright useless, and you have no way of knowing that till you grind for them, and find out firsthand.  Did I mention it is a grindfest?  Unless you're willing to pay a monthly stipend of course, even then it's still pretty bad.  Worst of all it runs like absolute dog♥♥♥♥♥♥  I have a $1500 that cant run it above 30FPS in most situations (This is after they removed Inverse Kinematics, Ammo Explosions, and several other basic features.) And this is AFTER I'd been able to run it at 60+ fps for years on a worse computer!If there is one thing I must tell you in this review, it is that the developers;DONOTCAREThey have never cared, they do not care the optomize their game, they do not care to balance it, they do not care to add any new weapons. (They have maybe 10 types of weapons in the game, in the battletech franchise, and older MW games, there are exponetialy more.)  You must pay 20-80 USD for new mechs when they are released as well, often times these mechs are broken, as they are nostalgia cash grabs that don't have the weapons, or equipment needed from the rest of the lore to function.  They have relased mechs that are based around single weapons, or strategies, that in NO WAY fits into this game, and charged up to 80 USD for them. MWO has been mired in a♥♥♥♥♥♥show of controversy and consumer♥♥♥♥♥♥ they have done nothing but make the game ACTUALLY worse as time has progressed, remaking maps that the community loved, and churning out garbage that runs worse than anyone could have imagined.  With all this money they have milked they have done nothing to devolope this game, or fix their mistakes.SUMMARY:  I have always hated PGI for making the first terrible title of an absolutley amazing series, but I played the game for years, because it was better than nothing.  I even liked the game if I could look at it as a non-Mechwarrior game.  But in the last year, the game has become nearly unplayable for me, between worsening UI, degrading visuals (Which is all this game had a leg to stand on in the first place) And a crippling framerate, I can no long say this game is even worth the time it takes to download, let alone the time it takes to grind a mech bigger than a Raven.  P.S. Lights are almost unplayable given the lag, and the massive nerfs by making them bigger than some ♥♥♥♥ing HEAVY mechs. That and they added ♥♥♥♥ing CS:GO style crates, crates that are absurdly lazey, no UI changes, just click a button and get an abhorent item or consumable.Edit: Removed an uncessary spur of the moment insult to people who liked it.  Sorry about that.

number of helpful: 89 of 182 people (49%) found this review helpful10 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												TLDR:  Don't get burned like I did.  PGI is a dishonest, inept developer that drove away many who bought into the Founders Program.  They *consistently* overpromise and under-deliver.  The game, as it exists, still does not have what was promised to Founders at launch two years ago.  This is a minimum viable product that continues to have little depth, is poorly balanced and is only a shell of what a game worthy of the "Mechwarrior" title means if you know the IP.  By all means, play it for what it is, but don't give PGI money.  Let the game die so that another company can get the IP and do it right.If this game had just been released in the state it is in and you only intend to play it for free, I could recommend it as a fun stompy robot arena shooter, but the history and the company that made this game matter if you consider putting money into it.  When viewed through that lens...don't spend your money.  I started in closed beta and spent a good bit of money on this game before I realized PGI could not be trusted and would outright lie to the player base.  I still play now just because I love the IP and this is all we have right now, but I won't put another thin dime in PGI's pocket.Many have already pointed out many things that PGI got wrong and continues to get wrong in other reviews.  I won't belabor all of those here.  My key points:1.  Lied to Founders about ECM implementation, Third Person View, Ghost Heat, and consumables.  To give you an idea of how PGI treats its players, PGI banned players on their own forums for things people posted on reddit.  Really.2.  All items are overpriced in real money and it is a pretty steep grind for a F2P.3.  Player balance system is better, but still broken.  One-sided matches way too common.  This is because there is a small player base.4.  Game has no depth...just different arena battles.  Clan and IS mechs on same side in single player que is a clear example to anyone who knows the MW IP.5.  Wait times for games can be long due to small player base.5.  CW is NOT what you think it is.  It is a shallow layer on top of the shallow arena combat game with stompy robots.6.  Expect balance to swing wildly with each patch.7.  Don't expect first time quality from anything PGI promises. I will say the game looks and sounds pretty good (although infuriatingly, 100 ton mechs still get caught by small rocks on maps)...so it can be fun.  I stopped playing for two years and the progress made was only incremental when I came back.  I came back simply because MWO is the only MW game in town and I figured I should get my money's worth.  Did I mention you should play it for free, but don't pay PGI anything? ;)If you want to read about some of PGI's missteps...start here:http://www.forbes.com/sites/insertcoin/2013/12/15/free-to-play-mechwarrior-online-offends-players-with-500-golden-mechs/http://www.pcgamer.com/piranha-games-speaks-out-on-transverse-crowdfunding-and-the-future-of-mechwarrior-online/  - check the comments on this one.http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/mechwarrior-online   - Peruse some of the user reviews...https://www.themittani.com/features/mwo-failure-communicatehttps://www.themittani.com/features/mwo-pgi-community-manager-ignites-reddit-controversyI realize the last two are goon site posts (and i do NOT endorse goons...but those articles are the truth)

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												My experience with this game over the last three years has been akin to watching a car crash in slow motion. At first you see a pristine, great concept, and original design, then gradtually watch in horror as it is torn to crumpled shreds by the oaf at the wheel, reducing it to a mangled ruin bereft of any former glory.This is not a good game for many reasons, the first being that the developers have burned every bridge imaginable. PGI is infmaous for throwing community managers under the proverbial bus to shirk responsibility for unpopular additions, censorship is rampant on their forums, the community is ignored or shunned at every turn, players are repeatedly outright lied to by the developers and balance is a joke. Over the years we have seen massive knee jerk reactions over and over again by the PGI, going for the quick and easy solutions to problems over retaining actual balance. This resulted in nightmares like the Jenner being an unstoppable god-slaying machine for the early months of the closed beta. With every new patch there was some new horror which stripped away at the game’s integrity, from the disastrous implementation of ECM and the poor handling of ghost heat, to the mishandled inclusion clan mechs and the developer’s sheer inability to pay even the vaguest hint of attention to BattleTech lore.If you want a good tactical combat game in this style, look into World of Tanks or War Thunder. Sure, they might not have big stomping mechs, but they're well-rounded in terms of balance and have a developer who sees their game as a product rather than a glorified premium milking machine.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Mechwarior Online (MWO).Just typing these words will inspire emotion in several of us older "kids" who may well be pusing our 40's. I have been playing and collecting stuff from this universe since the 1980's when I was in grade school. To put it lightly PGI has an oppurtunity to cash in on my nostalgia and sell a piece of my childhood back to me.Many of you are younger. You may never have heard of this title, or the previous games. The idea of little me sitting with a friend and nervously moving cardboard cut outs on a hex map could be hilarious. The question is, is there something here for both of us? I say yes. PGI has made several choices that take the game away from a direct port of the old table top rules. This is good, those rules were not well balanced and the mechs there were not able to face each other with anything like parity. In table top bigger was better.Here in MWO each weight class, there are four, is played by a single individual. Unlike previous titles all are viable in the battlefield. The little mechs can take on the big ones and win. Similatly Clan versus Inner Sphere balance is better on this platform than in any other location. In table top the balance was performed with points and Clans got fewer mechs. That does not work in an online enviroment. In MWO Clan mechs are situationally better than Inner Sphere mechs, and IS mechs are situationally better in others. In any situation pilot skill and teamwork are more important than loadout.Pilot Skill and Teamwork. These are the hallmarks of this game. Battles can be as deep or shallow as your interaction with the other players. If you are looking to be a lone rambo, try light mechs, but this is probably not the game for you.If you like working with others for a common goal, and you like big robots killing each other, this is definately the game for you.If you are a new player looking for a group many of us will gladly welcome new players. I run with House Steiner. Killing clanners as often as I can.I'm Stelar 7. I've been playing since open beta, I heartily endorse this game.Find me on TS at House Steinerts1.housesteiner.comLegion of Phoboslegionofphobos.teamspeakservers.com

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Ignore the time played. I have logged many hours in this game and have been playing since 2013.  I highly recommend trying this game! At it's core, it's a team based tactical shooter featuring giant war machines that are adequately referenced from the impressive lore/universe known as BattleTech.  It may not be for everyone, but it definitely has a type of player it attracts. If thinking-based tactical shooters are your cup of tea, then this will be a game for you. If you enjoy customizing things across a wide variety of platforms and creating your own unique builds, then this will be a game for you. If you love games that require attention to detail, then this will be a game for you. If you enjoy playing as a team and being part of a dedicated community, then this may be a game for you! Competitive or casual, this game seems to have something for different types of gamers. I won't lie, MechWarrior Online has had it's rough moments. There was a time where I left for a while because I felt the game back in 2013 was a bit too grindy and was missing some key elements. I returned a few months back and there have been MASSIVE improvements to this game. It's no where near grindy as it was and it actually has one of the best free to play models out there. This is by no means a pay to win game. In the hundreds of hours I have logged into this game, I have spent a grand total of $20. It wasn't necessary but I felt like getting a set of Mechs early. In reality, some of my best Mechs were purchased via the in-game currency. As a new player, you will have a cadet bonus for your first 25 matches and completing the tutorial along with that will net you quite a substantial amount of C-bills (the in game currency). You can choose to pay for premium time if you want, but it isn't necessary by any means. Plus, there are a lot of in game events that take place every once in a while that give players a wide array of bonuses. Bottom line, you can be competitive and have fun without spending any money. The developers have been listening to the community more and the game has a good roadmap for future improvements. This game is in good hands and there is a huge community behind it. There are tons of resources to help you along the way. A short list of these resources include: The MWO official forums, specifically the guides/new player sectionsMechspecs.comMetamechs.comThe Outreach HPG subredditI highly recommend that you give this game a shot and do your best to find a unit or community that has a TS server or it's equivalent! Being part of a unit has several bonuses and it's a total gamechanger in terms of finding reliable teamwork and assistance. This game punishes the lonewolf types. Trust me, in order to get the best experience you should try to find a unit/open to the public teamspeak. This is not to say you can't have fun just dropping in public groups queue or just going solo, you certainly can, it's just that being part of a community can enhance the experience of this game tenfold.  There are tons of units recruiting on the steam forums and the MWO forums. Go check it out!

												While the basic Mech on Mch play is ok, that's all there is to the game. There's pretty much nothing here from the lore other than PGI trying to cash in on nostalgia. This isn't the game you are looking for in a MW/BT game, unless you're just here for a repetitive arena shooter with mech skins. All the time in development and post release and all the game really has to offer is 3 mostly similiar game modes and lots of mechs to buy. The prices are high. You can survive on the initial trials and the Cadet bonus and such before you really should spend any real money if you so decide. I'm a Legendary Founder so let my mistakes help save you the time and most importantly the cash. When the best most positive reviews can manage is to point out it's free so you've got nothing to lose ( if you don't value your time) it's not the most ringing endorsement.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												Wow, what a refreshing shooter.I enjoy the fact that you win by trading damage over the duration of the match, as opposed to the twitchy reflexes required in CSGO or CoD.  Positioning accounts for so much here, and random headhots are SO MUCH rarer than in CSGO (yeah, I meant to hit you in the head with my P90 spray from 50 yards away...).  I played a bit before MWO went to steam, and I like the virtually unlimited customizability for your mechs.  Take some long range missiles to soften up enemies from a safe distance, or pack on the lasers and autocannons to shred your enemies from closer in.Seems pretty grindy to start up though.  Either put in some cash to get some starter mechs or mech bays, or be prepared for a moderate grind to get up to speed.  Also, it's more expensive than other micro-transaction-based games, but I think that's because Battletech is an old universe, so many of the players are older and have jobs, thus are willing to fork out some cash.  If you enjoy the game though, then it's worth it.Oh, FYI, NEVER SELL AN ENGINE!  You're probably just going to rebuy it when you finally figure out what's going on later, but you'll be down a few million CBills.I absolutely recommend this game.  Very different pacing from other shooters. It rewards patience and good decisions.  Win over several minutes, not in a frantic 10-second shootout.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												I can recommend this game if you meet these two reasons:1. You love Battletech.2. You don't mind a Free to Play setup for your Battletech game. (Free to Play being Pay to Win)Now with that being said I downloaded this for free realizing it was Free to Play from the description. No harm there since I want to look things over. I tried it out and the test range tutorals and it feels like a mix between Mechwarrior 2, 3, and 4. The mechs handle nicely and the graphics are very nice during game play.The interface for creating custom mechs is there but it's somewhat limited to the hard point concept setup I'm guessing in started in Mechwarrior 4. That's the first time I remember seeing something like that which limited choices on mech/omni-mech designs. I hate that part of the game since I used to be a big time pen and papper battletech player and loved creating mech designs just to try out. So in that respect the game is limiting for me and puts a dampener on my interest in playing. The other aspect that contributes to this is the Free to Play model limitations.Personally I wish this wasn't an MMO Free to Play setup. The game is good but I think it would have been better if it were more like the Mechwarrior series before it in that there's a single player campaign but with a more robust multiplayer setup. This is basically a big cash grab using Battletech. Nice if you have the cash to blow on it but not so much if you want more then just that.Update 01/14/2016 - I put some time in to this and some money. The barrier for entry in to this game is dependant by the choice of grinding out tons of C-Bills for mech and equipment purchases which is perfectly fine. The other aspect is the fast track to buying mechs with real money. That being said the prices for some of those add-ons is really high when you look at the mech bundles.In game mech purchases provide a wide variety of choices but there are some limited to the Pay to Play credits or Mech Credits which you buy for real cash. Also expanding your garage for more mechs requires you to put real cash in which seems fine to me really for a pay to play system as well as the certain mechs requiring paying cash to get. A big downer I've had playing however is that in order to get better mastery of a mech you like you must purchase other variants of that mech and pilot those. So basically to level up your favorite mech you have to pilot other mechs to unlock the higher progression trees. I think that stinks in that if you are going to master something you don't practice with something else to master it. I feel this was put in to push people towards paying to buy mechs more frequently. The game itself isn't fun when you have to pilot something else to level and play the one mech you enjoy most.There is an instant messaging system in the game for when you aren't in matches so don't expect to find many social areas in the game itself like chat rooms or something. I've yet to find them myself in there. Really it's like paying WoW's BG system with Battletech and not having any place to socialize afterwards. I'm guessing you are limited to game forums and steam forums for that.Final thoughts: Don't spend any money till after your first 25 bonus matches are completed. Stick with the trial mechs and use them to get your initial C-Bill boost. It'll go a long way to saving up for a mech you find fun to pilot unless the trial mech is a Mech Credit only mech where you have to pay real money for.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Playing this game since beginning of open beta, but let's get straight to the interesting part, shall we? The Pros     + Almost 0 pay to win    + Rewards twitchy skills AND strategic thinking in combat    + Sophisticated hitzone system    + Rewards experimenting through customization (half the battle is fought, before it even began)    + Customization is HUGE (for combat and aesthetics)    + Many, very different, mechs and designs to choose from     + No negative incomes -> never worry about losing money for bad matches    + Rewards Teamplay    + Pretty unique experience    + It's big stompy robots! The Cons	    - Ingame earnings aren't very high (recently buffed, so its better now)    - Some optional, but helpful stuff takes rather long to get    - Balance could absolutely be better (though not horrible)    - Learning curve is steep and acquired skill vanishes quickly when not played for a while    - There could be more maps    - Too many "spend your money on this" events, which distracts even if optional Overall a very unique game among all those twitch heavy shooters and hectic arena games out there. I especially love how it combines these elements with a very tactical, slower paced environment. The mechs and their designs are really cool and add a lot to the game, even more so for mechwarrior fans. Take into account the steep learning curve though and don't give up if piloting seems hard at first.If you love experimenting with many different builds and having a lot of options, this is also a game for you.

number of helpful: 11 of 24 people (46%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 17
												(Update: Review edited after the initial excitement wore off a bit.)TL:DR - one of the best F2P games here. You get your own mech and are not forced to pay real money if you don't want to. You'll hate the constant long range guided missile sniping (or love it, if you'll be one of the people doing it).Good and active community, maps, everything. Runs on CryEngine.But above all... The mechs.The game creates a very good sense of ownership. When you buy your first mech, it can remind you a bit of Star Citizen. Beautiful cockpits, detailed design. You have to carefully choose the loadout for whatever you plan to do, and you will most likely get it very wrong at first. And die a lot. When you get into it a bit, it'll get more fun. See that giant assault mech? Grab a ligt mech, run around it and just shoot it legs off to kill it. Or walk into the wrong corner of the map and get caught in the cross-fire of 8 enemy mechs.Stragety first. Fighting second. You'll probably like your mech a lot and won't rush into sensless battles. You go alone, you die. You go with your group, you won't die as quickly.What costs actual money: Color customizations, special mechs (which generate more XP and in-game currency, meaning they ain't worth it) and other useless stuff. It's better to just look at the pretty red and blue mechs of other paying players ;).As for optimization,  I've seen some complaints here. I mean okay, it's not perfect, but it runs smoothly without crashes on a i3 6157u with Iris 550 on mid-to-high settings. Just turn off the shadow effects and you're fine.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												  First off it is a free to play model game.  Knowing that if you are patient you can quite feasably never spend real money on anything in this game and be competitive and slowly grow your stable of mechs.  There are always events going on that have various rewards: in game currency(CBills), mechbays (which you need to stable more mechs), cosmetics and even small amounts of MC( purchased currency used to buy hero mechs, mech bays camo patterns etc etc.)  The game has a pretty steep learning curve, learning maps, heat, weapon ranges etc all while staying alive, but the community is friendly, the forums are a great resource for any questions and plenty of helpful people to ask questions.  Now this being a f2p game if you want to play more than the 4 mechs your initial 4 bays alllow the best place to drop some money on the game is for mechbays. a few dollars will get you a good number of bays.    The important thing to note about this game is buying a "hero" mech does not give you a competitive advantage and in most cases the "hero" mech is no better and sometimes has a worse layout over a standard mech varient.  The only big thing a "hero" mech will give you is a 30% bonus to CBills when you complete a match which cuts the grind for in game currency before you can purchase that next mech, weapon, module.  Other thing of note is that unlike call of duty type game there is no respawn, your mech has a set amount of armor and structure it can use to absorb incoming damage before you are destroyed, and friendly fire isn't very friendly in MWO.  Watch you fire lines, stay with the team and manage your heat.

content:
Posted: March 29
												Well, where to start.Even if i play this Game more and more and sometimes really, really enjoying it, I cant recommend it.And here is why:First:The Tier-rating, by which matchmaking is done, is utterly and totally broken. Why? because your matchrating is more or less totally dependend on your team.  Lets give You an example: today I did two matches with the same Mech to farm a little XP. I am by no means "good" in this machine, im just farming XP so I become "Master" in my favorite MECH. But thats not the point. In one of the Games I did about 500 Damage, destroyed multiple components (but made no Kills), did multiple scoutings and earned a hell of lot of "flanking"-bonuses. But - we lost. The Game after that I did about 130 Damage and have been killed without being any real use for my team but they did win anyway. Guess what game did cost me points in my ranking and wich one gained me the same? (for those, who didnt get it: it was not the 500 damage game that gained) Yeah, right. Not only that, I got 3 to 5 times the amount of XP and Ingamecredits. Yeah - I got it, not because I was good, but my team did alright. Fair? I guess not.Well You could say: learn teamplay so You can influence Your teamperformance. But I dont believe one person would make a differnce, because you will see time and again and again and again other players ramming and even shooting You just to get the killshotbonus. GreatSecond: deleted due to edit (see below)Third: For me the most important reason, but totally subjective. Im an old man (for a computergamer), and im not so fast any more, so guess what I kind of mechs im playing - Yeah big, slow, artillery mechs with lots of missiles raining death from afar. But, to be effective with this kind of mechs, You NEED scouts, and in the low tiers I am playing, fast scouting mechs run around trying to do kills, and do not mark anybody for their teammates, who could kill faster (by far!). (btw.: the mech i was playing to farm xp (the one i mentioned at the beginning) is a "snipermech" with longrangelasers and ac2s. For an artillerymech 500 damage is not so much at all.) Killshotbonus gives more points than "narc"-ing, and of course everybody is only thinking about his own advantage. So I try to do the scouting all by myself. Its just WoT all over again. No tactics, only positioning, if you are not playing in a team. Otherwise its a pretty slowplaying shooter.edit:Well, after reading all the comments about "Pay to win".:Well, Maybe, this is the wrong wording. But its not "Free to play" either, and that is, what my problem is all about.MWo is, in this regard, exactly like nearly all of the so called "free to play"-titles I ever played. It is totally like WoT in this regard, a game where I also fell into the trap of free playing and paying for it, because i had a clan and wanted to reach a goal. Later I left the Game and the Clan because I just added all the little purchasses I tock to a sum and realized, what I was doing - spending 100s of bucks for a game, that, frankly, as a "normal game" wouldnt even score 30 bucks and I would never have bought for more than 20.MWo is not "amazing". It is a slow playing shooter with a little bit of tactics (that gets ignored quite a lot from most players, who just want to score maxdam and maxkills) that reminds me of days past, when i played my first tabletopgame back in the 80s with my work buddies (Yes, i am that old).Hell, the game doesnt even have a real community-function where you can chat and meet new people, You can only chat with your "friends" or during matches. A set of Battlemechs cost about 30 dollars(!) and yes, while i dont "need" them to win the odd qickplay, it gives me a definite advantage. Again it is like WoT in this regard - you werent "forced" to buy a premium tank in this game, but... Yeah, it gave You an advantage.Most of the quickplay-games have become boring like hell, because they are always the same. Faction play is out of discussion because I need to form my own Unit or become a loyalist to earn anything. And if I find some people who play with me, I would need to break my contract and get punished. What kind of stupid gamemechanics is this? While i understand the fluff behind it, it is overly restrictive for new players who want to find a group.The Matchmaking is absolutly broken and playerranking as well - hell i did a game with nearly 900 damage, two solokills and about 5 kmdd and we lost - but i didnt gained any rankingpoints for this game, i just managed to not loose any points in my ranking. When i do 30 damage and my team will win, i will earn points in the ranking - WTF!? In 90% of the games it isnt a close game anyways: one side will steamroll the other and all you do is trying to do as much damage as possible. Because damage and kills seem to be everything after matchwinning in playerranking.So, the best stragtegie to get higher in rank is: be egoistic, DONT play together, steal the killshot and hide in corners while your team gets wrecked, so you can do your solokill. Because thats the only way to do good damge if Your team is steamrolled. and if Your team is the steamrolling one, one mech doenst makes a differnce.Those are NOT gamemechanics why I play a teambased game.(and so i dont do it, try to narc and scout and give protection fire for my teammates, even run between a heavily wounded TM and the enemy to shield it, so he can shoot a little bit longer)Im not narrowminded. I am just not Pippi Longstockings and chance the world like i want in seeing only the positive things.plz notice: English is not my natural language, so I will make mistakes.

												If you like the idea of piloting a giant walking war machine, you've come to the right place.  There is a learning curve, but it's worth it.  Is it really free to play?  Is it pay to win?  It IS free to play.  If you want to speed the grind along faster, you can pay.  You do not gain any measurable play advantage by using real money.  The best mechs in the game are FREE(using in game currency, not real $).You will read some negative reviews.  IMHO, they fit into the following:  1) Crusty MWO veterans who are bitter about something from 3 years ago.  2) Short attention span players who aren't willing to put in more than 10 minutes to learn the game.  3)  People that don't like the idea of  big stompy robots fighting other big stompy robots.I have played this game extensively for over 2 years, and I keep coming back.  It's addicting and a ton of fun.  See you on the battlefield!

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												My original review can be seen here: 


YouTube™ Video: #MWO - Mechwarrior Online 2015 Review 

			Views: 6,760		

			Game: Mechwarrior Online (PC) Here is the review of a very unique styled F2P thinking fps. It's a lot to take but certainly worth a look. Don't forget to rate comment or subscribe!		

I gave it a 7.9 back then and thing have changed quite a bit since.So, for my personnal satisfaction and to help people around steam here is a new look at the game. Several months later.I want to start by saying that F2P games are usualy a gamble.Some games will go out and shine and others will die a few seasons after it's initial release.I've supported MWO since the alpha and beta by purchasingthe Legendary Founder pack for a roughly 120$I've since invested around 650$ more in Pirhana's game and so far, I haven't been desapointed.Mechwarrior Online is first and foremost a thinking shooter.It relies heavily on situation awareness and chassis build rather than quick reflexes and headshot.You still need to be quite good at aiming to hit the important and damaged componenet of your enemy but overall it's not as big of a factor as for say Counter Strike, Hawken or Battlefield.That being said, since MWO is a f2p game, you will start with 4 mech bays for you to fill with your own mech you will purchase and 20 matches of "recruit" that will give you around 10 000 000 cbills that you can invest in chassis and customizing them. So far so good. However, some of the heavier mechs are worth up to 33 000 000 cbills. Calculate that matches give you around 80 000 to 200 000 per match without premium, you will have to play a lot before getting you hand on them. That being said, investing on a 33 000 000 cbill mech doesnt give you an instant victory machine. Since mechs are seperated in 3 classes, light, medium, heavy and assault. They all have purpose and are fairly balanced. I'm saying fairly because some mechs are obviously better than others. Depending on their loadout, profile size, armor, speed and weapon mounting point. Overall thou, it's quite balance and once you know the chassis strength and weakness you will know what battle is worth fighting.The game sets two teams of 12 players against each other. Quickplay allows you to jump directly on the battlefield and gives the players a quick vote on which map and playstyle to fight for. It works well and makes the game a lot more viable than the old imposing system. There is also 3 main server around the world so you shouldn't have problems of connectivity as well. Community Warfare is the second part of the game, you can choose a faction and fight for them on a galactic space map. It works well and gives you 4 mechs to bring on a single battlefield. It's intense, relies heavily on teamplay for success. A victory will give you reputation points toward the chosen faction as well as a considerable amount of cash. The game will however average 25 to 30 minutes.Mechs are fun to play with and works mainly like tanks. Which means the legs and torso can turn seperatly from one another. Arms also have free movement compared to the mounted weapons. It gives MWO a special type of gameplay that ask for more thoughtfull movement. Weapons varies from small machine guns, lasers, long range missiles and automatic AC 20. They all have different type of attacks, heat displacement and damage output. Half of the game is centered around cusotmizing the mech and fortunately it's very enjoyable. Experimenting around and just going all gooffing around gives the game deep possibilities and management that is rare for any other game.Graphics have nice textures but overall effects are OKAY at best. The cryengine is demanding but models are sweet looking. Better yet is the animation and the waight of the mechs that gives the immersive sense of huge humanoid robot combat pleasant.Sound is again, adequate but the music is boring and some gun sounds cheap. Some great moment arrives thou when in space and the echoes of explosion on the cockpit shakes about and ♥♥♥♥♥ing betty is telling you that you are about to die in agony.MWO is fun, but it's more a love or hate relationship. Try it, you have nothing to lose. It's best played in team and there is no pay 2 win mentality. If you play for a while, buy yourself some pack and help Pirhana invest back in the community.Board a nice Timber Wolft, Equip some LRM's and Medium Pulser laser and deliver death and destruction.Take care!  Category Score   Graphics 7   Sound Design 7.5   Gameplay 8.5   Replayability 10   Fun factor 8   Price for Content 10

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												Been playing MWO off and on since release.  Spent more than I probably should but honestly I have gotten/am getting enough hours of enjoyment out of it.  It is a difficult game to get into because of the learning curve coupled with the sometimes questionable matchmaking.  I find the solo queue matchmaking does a pretty good job, but as soon as you drop as a group it feels like you get thrown to the wolves a bit.  Those of you with the ability to accept that you need to improve to be competitive will do fine but if you are the type to look for hand holding and easy wins then you will be in for a short stint with the game.  If you can get to the point where you are proficient with the game and better still invest yourself enough to join up with ta unit to gain the advantages that proper group play allow then you will have a really enjoyable time with the game.  The devs are balancing and adding content fairly regularly as well as events going on in game pretty often as well.  So good luck to new players, keep an open mind and don't be afraid to ask for help on the official forums.  www.mwomercs.com

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												The game has come a long way from Open Beta DaysPro's - There is now a good tutorial that rewards players with currency to purchase their first BattleMech when completing training. In addition there is New Player Bonus's to assit in affording first purchase's - Seperate testing grounds to learn the maps and test new weapon loadouts on stationary targets. - Large number of maps with dynamic environments and temperature effects. - 3 basic game modes in addition to the Community Warfare mode with additional maps and game modes. - A large number of BattleMech's to choose from to then build and customise to suit your own game styles on the battlefield. - Large number of promotions that can reward players with free Mech's, MechBays, in game pretty's, in game currency and in game version of real currency etc - Competitive play led by community groups - Team focused play where a single player relys on his team for victory.Con's - High initial learning curve - Cost to purchase MechBays to increase your number of Mech's over an initial 4. - Poor development history due to company IGP. Since IGP has been removed from this project things have rapidly improved leaps and bounds. - Some times over customisation and grinding to optimise Mech's - Team and skill balancing issues still pursist due to small community. - Ocianic Server providing the same ping to North American Servers for Australian players.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												Edit: While I still would recommend the game to anyone with a passing interest in mech combat the lethargic pace of development has just got me really down on actually wanting to play this continuously. A mech is announced months before it comes out, and then it goes out to the pre-orderers, then a month later it comes out for cbills. It just fosters this environment of staleness, perhaps this will be fixed this coming summer with the addition of new weapons and tech, but until then me picking the game up since i stopped playing months ago feels exactly the same.I feel PGI could learn a lot about improving their model from other games such as WarFrame, I understand there's limitations for a niche game like MWO that wouldn't necessarily work like that, but the annoyance I get out of not wanting to get new mechs outweighs that heavily.=========I've been playing since the closed beta, i'm also a fan of battletech, so that means i'm pretty biased.This game is fun, I enjoy it off and on, and would like to see its continued support from its developers, PGI.1. How to deal with the grind, the problem is when you're playing to buy something, playing to level up something, playing to unlock something, the trick is to play with a unit, go find one, make friends with people who are generally nice in the game, if they are part of a unit, ask if you can join them, they'll hook you up.2. If you find someone calling orders in game, and their orders changed the tide of battle, add that sucker to your friends list

So good luck to new players, keep an open mind and don't be afraid to ask for help on the official forums.  www.mwomercs.com

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
												Put simply, MWO is the most balanced MechWarrior, one of the most balanced Free to Play games I've played, and one of the most fair Free to Play models I've seen. I've come from very pay to win, grindy, unbalanced games like Need For Speed World, and from previous MechWarrior games. The fact that every mech chassis has at least 3 variants available for all players, just months after release, is great. Hero mechs should only be thought of as another mech variant for its chassis, as they only come with a C-Bill earnings boost, unique hardpoints, and are derived from a specific pilot in the battletech lore. C-Bills can purchase everything you need to be competitive, things like camo will cost real momey, but it's not too expensive. This defeats the argument that this game is pay to win (those who dispute I'd like to hear your reasoning.) As I stated earlier, it's the most balanced MechWarrior, and in comparison to other Free to Play games, it's balanced enough to the point that saying a mech sucks means that another mech chassis can run a build better. Gameplay is all about teamwork and knowing how to get the most performance out of your mech. Those who play CSGO know the drill, communicate and work with your team. On a final note, I want to talk about the dev team. For a franchise like MechWarrior, the playerbase has gone down since the last release over a decade ago. They have taken a risk with the additions of the "unseen" mechs like the Marauder and Warhammer, the Warhammer being the reason why MechWarrior 5 had to be cancelled. They have done great work with the designs and games balance, as well as how they handle the business. The fact that people shame them, call them worst dev team ever, and say they should lose their license to the MechWarrior franchise sickens me. When there's corrupt dev teams like Gaijin barely getting any backlash from their actions, it makes me wonder why PGI does from the majority of the community. They're by no means perfect, things were rough earlier on, but now they are a much better dev team than they were 3 years ago. For a community like the MechWarrior community, It makes me upset that one of the nicest game communities is so hostile to a very nice dev team. But to wrap it all up, MWO is a balanced Free to Play game that is not Pay to Win, and is more skill based than some other popular vehicular MMO's (World of Tanks in particular).
