content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												I've been playing MWO since Feb 2012, and I can't say that I've come across another game that's kept me that engaged. Now, to be fair, I'm a BT/MW self confessed fanboy, so PGI had a big head start in gaining a seal of approval! That being said, I highly recommend giving MWO a look. On condition that you don't want a game where you're instantly godlike in terms of skill. There's a bit of a learning curve, but if you put a bit of time in and accept initially you may well have terrible matches initially whilst you learn the basics, you'll be well rewarded. My suggestion - watch streams, I learnt a huge amnount when I first started (twitch is a good place to start), and ask questions of the streamers and the viewers. 99% of the MWO community are great guys and girls who will be more than happy to help.MWO is a true free to play game. You can be successful and have fun without spending a single penny. At most you used to have to admit, well, you do need to buy mechbays at a buck or two a pop, but PGI give so many away these days (via Faction Play achievements for example) that even this isn't necessary any more. Mechs come out in packages for real world monies with some extra swag (if you pre-order early enough) several months before they're available for in game currency. But that extra swag is mainly cosmetic, nothing in there gives you an ingame advantage. However, those exact mechs will be available for free eventually. There are no 'you must buy this to win' mechs. Hero and special mechs come with a boost to the earnings you can make in in game currency per match, at 30%. However, those mechs don't garauntee you will have a good match, they're no better than the standard variants available. Champion mechs give a boost in a similar way but to XP earned. In all honesty, champion versions of the standard variants aren't something that's ever appealed to me. When you have a mech, you need to 'level it up' through basic, elite and master skills. This slightly improves things such as it's heat efficiency, maneuverability, speed etc. Which is where the XP comes in. XP is earned in matches along with CBills (currency). You have to have 3 variants of a mech at full basic level before you can work on elite skills. Once elite skills are done, you can then complete the master skills. Once one mech is mastered for a weight class, you only have to basic three variants of a new mech, from there you can if you choose elite and master a single variant. This levelling of mechs is where some folks say it's a bit of a grind, along with earning cbills to buy new mechs, but I've never found it to be too big of an issue personally.There are also mastery packs available which give you several variants of a mech chassis that are available for cash, at big savings if you bought them separately (plus some extras I think but I'm not too sure on that). I'm not going to comment on the value of the mastery packs, after 3 years and 150 or so mechs in the garage, they're not something I've had a need to look at, so I'll just make you aware they're there if you want to take a look at them. But at a glance, to me they seem good value if you want to spend real money on something which largely (but not everything) consists of content available for in game currency. Value is subjective, if you have the cash avaialble, it's your choice!Anyway, personally I love the game, when balance issues arise PGI are usually pretty quick to change things, content is free flowing, and quite simply the game is a hell of a lot of fun! And the great thing is, there's much more content to come from PGI and MWO!

												To the new players for this game:The people who have been giving this game negative reviews are mostly salty players who expected an AAA game almost four years ago when the game was under the name of a completely different company. The game was run under IGP and they were horrible and stunded this game's growth.Now with that said, the game has been under to control of a new company, PGI for a while now. PGI has made GREAT strides in providing balance, reducing grind, and avoiding a pay-to-win game. The game is rather simplistic in game-modes but is not tiring as each map can be VERY different from the next with the simplest changes to a tactic. Tactics and team-work are huge in this game and makes everything so much more interesting. It is has a nice balance between teamplay and first person shooter that makes the game so much fun. Get a few friends to play the game with you, form a group, be aggressive, work together, and use the MIC and you will have a lot of fun. The game has made great strides this year alone and I high recommend it to anyone as it is one of the few games that truly changes and just has something that not even HAWKEN could provide. There's a huge learning curve but getting past it is SOOO satisfying!!!Anyway, in conclusion:Big-stompy-robots/10 would play again.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												General points:- The game is not Pay-To-Win in any way, shape, or form.  Everything can be purchased with Cbills, which are rewarded at the end of games.- The game has a very rough learning curve.  Those who do not know how to look one way while moving another are going to have problems here.- No, seriously, learning curve.  Additionally you have two crosshairs - one for your arms, the other for all torso-mounted weapons.  They will not necessarily be pointing at the same thing at any given point in time.- Most customization of a giant robot outside of the Armored Core series of games.- A-symmetrical warfare.  There are two sides to every conflict.  In this game it's the Inner Sphere vs the Clan.  Inner Sphere pilot mechs that are centuries old - clan mechs are the latest and greatest.  PGI has done a very good job keeping these concepts without overpowering one side or the other.- About that learning curve... There are mechanics that are not readily apparent.  When constructing your mech, look for a red 'yield' sign and mouse over it for further information.- The game really is free, and there's literally no reason not to try it.General review:  In no other game on the market can you play as a robot the size of a building, slinging shells the size of volkswagens to shear off plates of titanium, ceramic, steel, AND DIAMOND from other robots the size of buildings.  Mechwarrior Online is a Moba in the truest sense of the acronym - Multiplayer Online Battle Arena.  Select and customize your mech to take part in a 12 on 12 battle royales against other players and their unique snowflake mechs to see who will come out on top.  Ultimately, Mechwarrior Online is a very challenging slow-paced first person shooter that plays a lot like a simulation.  Moving your mech is increasing the throttle, and you accelerate to your top speed which not only varies from mech class to mech class (Light, Medium, Heavy, Assault) but from mech to mech (depending on the engine that you choose to bring).  Mechwarrior Online definitely isn't for everyone, but with a Free to Play model that isn't pay to win - you lose nothing for giving it a try.  6/10.Review for those who have played Mechwarrior Online since Beta (Founders):  The game has come a long way from when there were four mechs.  All told, the game still isn't everything that was asked for, but despite that, it's a game that after YEARS of play, we keep coming back to it.  Giving PGI credit where it's due 7/10.Review for those who have played other Mechwarrior Titles (MW 2,3,4):  Mechwarrior Online plays a lot different from the game you remember.  This is mostly because the game is a multiplayer experience only based on the World of Tanks gameplay and monitization system.  Matches were desinged to be played in 15 minutes or less, so there is definitely an arcade feel here.  As the most recent Mechwarrior title, its looks are far better than the previous titles (as it should), and the redesigns of the mech models are quite superb.  Mechbay is much different from what you would be used to - instead of swapping out weapons of a type to fill the slots available, mech customization is deeper, while similarly limited.  MWO has a steep learning curve, but as a Mechwarrior veteran you should be able to catch up quick.  7/10Review for those who play fast-paced mech titles (Armored Core series):  You aren't going to be impressed with this title as the gameplay is not what you are looking for.  Armored Core, while similar in the level of customization, also is far more fast paced.  Control over an Normal or Next is far less like operating a machine of war, and far more like playing a FPS where you look like a mech.  In AC, your mech has a total hitpoint value based on your  components, while in MWO your mech's health is determined by component.  This means you can be killed when your mech is at 65% simply by taking damage to your center torso and losing it, or having your cockpit destroyed (headshots), wheras AC doesn't have these distinctions.  AC's gameplay is a fast-paced gundam style while MWO is more like if you were trying to drive a World War 2 tank.  It's a free game so give it a shot, but you will be better served by playing Hawken.  4/10

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												I welcome those who are new to this game and I recommend them to fully read this to both understand what to expect and what to do.A little background on my self with this game, I've been on this game non-stop 3-5 times weekly for teh past 2 years since the founding times so I know what I'm taking about. Also I'm playing all the way from Malaysia in Asia with my buddies/unit based in the US/UK regions and I have like over 120 mechs of both IS and Clan. I'm a Corporal rank in my unit, 1st Crucis Recon and previously we were from Head Hunters of Davion (Davion Faction's largest unit).What to expect:1) Light/Medium mechs are fast while Heavy/Assault mechs are slow but powerful (slow as in, you can time and see em turn like how an elephant turns it's body, so basically Light mechs run circles around the bigger guys literally).2) Mechs are expensive since it's Free To Play, but not impossible to achieve (when I started; with 0 mech of my own, I used the free trail version Hunchback for a week).3) Don't expect head shots every time, it's super hard to do and very rare (to date I've done less than 50).4) Grinding/making cash is faster with certain methods (I'll explain later).Very Important:For those starting, the first thing I recommend is to go setup your VOIP setting in game to ecnable radio communications.This game is all about teamwork with your teammates in every match.Read the guides/manuals/FAQ of the game when you progress further.And most important, play the tutorials to get a hang of things.Gameplay:For starters, there are 2 types of game; quickplay and Faction-play.Quickplay is a 12vs12 match in either Assault/Conquest/Skirmish mode.Faction-play is choosing a Faction to support by taking a contract (you can select how long; weeks/months/permanent), and playing either defense/attack of planets in a big war of 12vs12 (with each warrior respawn of 4 times/ 4 mechs each).Faction-play although slow and hard for beginners, is quite rewarding in it's faction rewards; some being in game c-bills, free mech bay, gxp, xp and more.I suggest doing some faction games done when you can to at least reach tier 3 of a faction's loyalty rewards programme, you need those free mech bays.So How Make C-Bills/More Mechs Fast?Play quickplay a lot. As a newbie/PUG, select trail mechs, run in groups with other veteran mechs (mechs with lots of custom paint jobs is a very clear sign) and help them in game. Don't run out alone to just die fast tot eh enemy, it has very little rewards given as c-bills. Doing more of teamwork during games gives you more rewards when you either win/lose the match.Keeping this in mind, it's best to stay alive with the team and if you die, just quit match, reselect another trail mech and find another match. Doing this method could easily see you making about 1million C-Bills within 1 hour. I got my first Hunchback (50 ton medium mech) within a day, so yeah, it's not that tough a grind.Keep playing this way to amke more money and soon you will pick up things like cutomization of your mech weapons, skills and how to use GXP, don't worry; the learning curve is not as hard as some might say, you just need to do some reading like I did.Gameplay Pros:1) Awesome graphics, details and effects2) Cutomizable mechs galore3) Nice flow of game play and one of the best times I had playing in groups/with teammates4) Rewards progression of skills, c-bills, game performance per matchCons:1) Like all Free To Play, you need to pay some to get to some more mechbays or cumization options like color and patterns.2) If your teammates don't know what they are doing, the match ends very quickly.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												So here we go.MechWarrior Online is an MMO sequel to the rather well known MechWarrior series set in the BattleTech universe created by FASA in 1984.While most of the MechWarrior games were good (sans MechAssault 1, 2, and Phantom War), this one started out... horrible. So I have been around this game since basically it came out, but I didn't play it until December of 2012. Since then I have watched it at its peaks, and at its worst. The game started out little more than Hawken, just slower paced. It was generic and not worth a dime. Now however it is really good.The game features very good mechanics to improve the experience (such as arms move separate of the torso which moves separate of the legs), and the maps are exponentially better. The game is still working on balance though. If you are familiar with the BT universe you know that the Clans were like... over powered gorillas in a house full of chimpanzees (kind of how they viewed the Inner Sphere philosophically too haha). They are like that here too. The weapons are extremely good, and just way better than anything the Inner Sphere can match. But in Community Warfare there is one thing that the Inner Sphere has on their side. Higher Tonnage rates which gives them the advantage of having more large mechs than the Clans. Now straight Clan mechs can't upgrade engines either. So there is some balance but unfortunately the Clans still are severely over powered at times.Overall the game is pretty decent. This community is newbie friendly (look up the B33f on the forums if you want training videos, or find me on occasion under the name Marack Drock), the game plays nicely, and there is a lot of content now. If this was 1.5 years ago I wouldn't have suggested this, but I do now.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Let me say first that I started playing MWO about a year or so ago, and so far I got roughly 80 hourse playtime.Let's start with the two most common points of criticism for the game:1. MWO get's much hate because the developers did some really bad things in the past and were inconsistent about their development.2. MWO is based on the "BattleTech" book series. Many people expected (as was initially promised as far as I know) a game that is very similar to the mech battles in the books. That didn't completely work out though.So let's address these points:1. That was the past. Nowadays the developers are very open about the development, posting a kind of status report and roadmap monthly on the forums. They are listening more to what the players want now too. The development as it is now is quite good. As said, it's consistent, the devs aren't acting too much against the players desires and we get two patches, one a bit lighter and one more content-heavy, each month, steadily improving the game. PGI, the developers, are also not afraid to revisit and redo many ingame mechanics. 2. If you don't expect this game to be like the books or didn't even knew about the franchise before, you won't have any problems with this. I actually can't tell how different this is to the books as I simply don't think about it. I recognize BattleTech in this game, but there are also some differences to be noticed.In conclusion, development is fine today, and if you don't care about the books that's not a point of criticism either.Free to play, but is it pay to win?No. You can only use the premium currency MC to buy cosmetics, mechs and garage slots to have more mechs at the same time. Regarding the mech buying:You can buy every mech that is availabe for C-Bills, the ingame currency, with MC too to skip the grind.When new mechs are released, the first month or so they are available for MC only, after that for C-Bills too.But then, there are also hero mechs. Hero mechs can only ever be bought for MC. They are specially colored and maybe uniquely equipped variants of "regular" mechs. They have unique names and are well known from the books, but they aren't in any way OP. If you want to play an OP mech (lol) you will definitely find one available for C-Bills too. The grindIn the beginning you only have the trial mechs, which change every few weeks or months or so. Trial mechs are regular mechs which you can play without buying, but can't customize, so you're stuck with the standard loadout. As you don't own a mech yet, you have to play some trial-mech matches. The game will support you financially in the beginning by giving you extra money for every battle fought, for the first 25 battles or so. This will make you able to buy your own mech quickly. With the money earned in your next matches you will buy and try different kinds of equipment for your mech. After said first 25 matches though, money earning slows down a lot. You will get up to 200k C-Bills for very good matches and roughly 20k from bad ones. The cheapest mechs cost 1,5 mil, the most expensive ones cost 16 mil. Note that this is not just the chassis, but also motor, weapons, ammo, armor etc. so you can reuse most of the stuff you buy, but it still takes quite some time to make enough money to afford a new mech. Additionally, you will probably spend some millions on buying upgrades and equipment for your new mech. If you're like me, you will feel a bit shocked when you used up all of the initial money boost and begin to realize how much you actually need to buy a mech. This feeling will however go away after some time and it will feel really rewarding when you can finally buy a new mech or an expensive upgrade. Also, cheap mechs aren't bad. The price of a mech is just the sum of all of the equipment included in the initial loadout plus a bit extra for the chassis. Cheap mechs are light mechs. Light mechs can be just as enjoyable as the huge, hard-hitting but slow assault mechs, it's just personal preference and playstyle.Graphics are good, not staggering but a sudden laser cutting through the darkness looks really neat. Also, you really feel like in a mechpilots cockpit because of screen shake, red alarm lights and stuff.Sound is very good, each weapon type has it's own sounds and you can really feel the impacts of attacks on your armor. There's even a map without atmosphere where you can only hear your own movement and impacts on your armor, but nothing else from outside.All in all.. most of the criticism can be ignored, that really depends on yourself. As always with F2P games, just try it out. If you can get behind the initial confusion about the quite complex MWO and behind the trial mechs, get a mech you like and equip it how you want, you will have a really good time.

												I bought a founder pack for this game when it first came out and, while fun, I never really got into that much. I kept coming back to it every now and again to see what progress they made but never stuck around for long.Now that the game has come out on Steam I've come back again and this time I think I can honestly say the game is in a state where it is thoroughly enjoyable. It still has problems though, and if you're a diehard fan of BattleTech and the old MechWarrior games there are a few changes that might annoy you.As for the business model, I personally think it's quite fair. You can buy every mech for in-game earned money (C-Bills), although new mechs are only available for real money for a while after their release. Honestly you never have to spend a dime in this game to enjoy it. When you first start you get a huge boost to your income for the first 30 games or so, so you can buy whatever mech you like pretty fast (at least I think that's still a thing, it was when I played a year or so ago). Once your starter bonus is up you still make money at a very fair rate, and since playing the game is actually very fun, time will fly so fast you'll suddenly realise you have heaps of cash to buy a new mech or new weapons or whatever you want.So yeah, I heartily recommend this game! :D

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												-Was a founder and played a little bit early on but the game did not hold my attention alot then. I really wanted to like the game but something was holding me back. Once it came on steam though I have started getting into it more and sure the learning curve is steep (so prepare for watching many tutorials and reading many forum post) but once you start getting the hang of it and things click there are not many games that have you think about so many variable at once and I actually really like that.- Prepare your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for the first little bit as you learn the ins and outs and learn how and when to engage other pilots. -The trial mech system is a really great way for people to try out mech before they buy them. Even though you can't customize the Trial Mechs I like that you still earn xp on them so there is always something to gain from them.- As long as your doing at least something during the battle such as keeping missle locks on enemies or even staying in formation the game shall reward thee. The indicators for rewards is nice too and I think it helps foster better teamwork and there are many incentives to help even though lone wolfing is possible but deffinetly in a more anachronistic format that many of the other online battle game out there.- Most of your C-bills (earned in game currency) iss spent more on the equipment and module for mechs as apposed on the mechs themselves so getting lots of mech is pretty easier to do until you get to some of the later Assault mechs that can cost quite a bit.- Pretty fair buisiness model the main way they make money is similar to alot of other battle games such as Worl of Tanks or even Warframe where you do have to buy mech slots to house your mechs witrh realy money but have seen events and faction warfare rewards where they can be aquired which is always nice. But this leads to another pro and con about the game...- There are tons of mechs in this game and more get added pretty regularly so its alot of information to take in on alot of machines and they all need homes to stay in so that where your mech bays come in handy.- Unlike WOT or Warframe though you are not super rewared for selling your mechs since each are an asset on their own and all of them are very well crafted so you can develop quite the connection with some of them since they all look and play very differently.Thats all I got for now but for a Free to Play it  scratches many itches for me currently and I think there are many people who would enjoy the quality and variety this game offers.                         PEACE

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												MWO is simply a great game that has improved tremendously over the years.  I've been playing MWO since its closed beta, and it has always had great combat and customization.  In the beginning there were a very limited amount of mechs to play, but over the last few years they have increased it to the point where there is a huge selection of mechs available for every role and tonnage.  If you have ever wanted to play a game where you controlled a walking tank with huge firepower in PvP, this is your game.  Regardless of your play style, whether it be fast twitch or slow tanky, this game has you covered.A few small tips for new players:1. Use the new tutorial!  Seriously, this game has a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of buttons and complexity.  HIGHLY recommended!  PGI has outdone themselves making it as well.2. If you ignored No. 1, use R to spot targets for your team.  If the triangle is full, you are sharing that info with your team.  Hollow triangles mean nobody has them locked!3. TORSO TWIST.  Seriously, try to spread the damage you are taking as much as possible.  Not only does it keep you alive, but it also stops you from having parts of your mech blown off.4. If playing a light mech, NEVER STOP MOVING.  The only exception is if you are behind an enemy mech lining up a shot and NOBODY knows you are there.  Seriously, your armor is made of paper, so speed is your only defense.  That being said, light mechs are still ridiculously good.  5. For the first 25 games you play or so, you will earn a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of cbills.  I highly suggest that you try to figure out what your play style is with the trial mechs before you buy anything.  As far as your first purchase, I personally feel that the clan "omni-mechs" are the best investment.  You can outfit a single omni-mech for pretty much any type of weapon mix because you can change their weapon hardpoints by swapping torso pieces.   I  suggest the Arctic Chetah, Stormcrow, Timberwolf, or Dire Wolf as a beginner omni-mech for those respective classes.  For non-omni mechs I suggest the Jenner / Raven, Hunchback / Crab, Grasshopper / Cataphract, or King Crab / Atlas.Keep up the great work PGI,Phantom LeaderLegendary FounderP.S. I have hundreds of hours in this game, hell maybe thousands by now.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												You'll see alot of people whining about this game saying it's not like mechwarrior, or it's a cash grab. It is indeed Mechwarrior and it's alot of fun. The game can be a bit grindy especially if you don't put a small amount of money into it,Premium time is where it's at to get credits. The hero/champion mechs aren't broken or OP you just get more money/xp and hard points ooo wippity doooo. The game itself is great there are alot of mechs to use, not to mention a decent chunk on trial. You should only buy a mech when you think you like it and want to customize the loudout and camos and paint. The faction play is also pretty awesome it's a unique way to get into a team based shooter. I'd say the main probelms with this game are the intense amount of time it takes to grind if you're a free player, Sometimes you will get mercilessly stomped by a clan in faction play while you're with a bunch of randoms, and the lack of costumization options without using real money as well. But paying to look pretty isn't pay to win, or a reason to stay away from this game. Like come on people do you expect every f2p game to just give you a full game experience? The people who make games need to make money too. I'm tired of people whining and complaining because you can buy this or that in f2p games . This game has a great community and decent VOIP built into it as well. 90% of the people who use it are very nice and helpful, you'll run into a toxic player here and there but that's the internet fo you. Out of all of the f2p games on steam I'd reccomend this one to anyone who likes giant robots or games where teamwork and coordination are required. 9/10 Big Robot Peneee

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												Pro: Free, fun gameplay that is tactical and varied, with lots of customisations. If you act before you think, you end up badly hurt or chosing the next drop. Let us not forget that, to quote some, GIANT STOMPY ROBOTS!Con: Still has some bugs and developement is not fast compared to some games due to lack of manpower, needs more maps as well and more game modes. Needs better documentation for new players. The grind could be a bit steep for some (though those that play LoL and the likes are used to the grind)I play MWO casually due to real-life obligations, and it has been the case since closed beta. I tried it, liked it, got the base founder package (all I could budget). Since then I got some MC, and felt compelled to get the Marrauder package. I am not great skill-wize, but I still find enjoyment. A lot of things you buy can be had from events, especially if you spend a lot of time and become skilled. The cons list might be bigger then the pros, but it is still FUN, and most cons will be progressively ironed out eventualy.There are some that will say this is the worse game ever (but still play) and those that say it is the best game ever and defend it al all cost. The truth is always in the middle; I just take it as it is and enjoy it for what it is: a game fun at its core ever progressing and getting better. It is not perfect, but no one or nothing on this planet is.Enjoy.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												I won't really be able to add a lot that hasn't already been said in other reviews, but here's my 2 cents...I've been playing MWO since early 2013. I know there are many players who've played from the start, but this is the only "MMO" game I've stuck with. EVE online is the only other one that compelled me to really gave it a chance with, but after a month I was done for several reasons. Mostly, I just wasn't having fun.MWO on the other hand has been my go to game since I started playing it. I don't play daily(except during my vacations), but I do play several hours a day on my weekends. and more importantly, I look forward to playing every single week. The only other game that can say that for me is XCOM(and hopefully XCOM 2). I can either sit down and play 3 hours of matches without a break, or play 1-2, take a break/eat/deal with the kids/etc.. the play some more. Or, I can just spend time in the mech lab trying out different configs and builds.voice/text chat during matches is, for the vast majority of the time, pleasant and good natured. Of course there is always "that guy" on occasion, but that's the exception, not the rule. forum wise, the community is VERY passionate. the can and will debate over what to an outsider seems like a very trivial matter to someone outside the community. size of hit boxes, XL vs standard engines in certain mechs, scale, the merit of weapon types, and on and on and on... Is there toxic players/posters? yes. just like in all games. and unfortunately that passion the community has can make for some very disgruntled players who are upset over things that happened long ago. sometimes they have a valid point. too often a minor thing is turned into a conspiracy theory based on nothing but their feels.which brings me to PGI. stellar company? no. to be frank, they REALLY messed up and tripped coming out of the gate at the start of development. VERY bad balance choices that took them far too long to correct. poor communication. poor feed back. over promising. unrealistic  release dates. poor marketing choices. rushed clan mechs. and so on. having said that, ditching IGP really helped clear up a lot of those problems. and in the last year and a half VAST improvements in those categories have been made. My only real issue at the moment is that it still feels like new features are talking too long to implement(looking at you CW phase 3).But having said all that, the important thing is gameplay. gameplay trumps all else in my opinion, and as I said, this is the game I keep coming back to week after week. and that's all that matters to me.so to sum up my opinion on MWO...It's a F2P game, that's not pay to win, has a pretty decent community barring a few individuals, is still being developed(even if I wish it was quicker about that) good graphics for what it is, immersive, and most importantly...it's fun. I recommend you give it a shot and see if you like it. after all, it's free.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Let me say first that I started playing MWO about a year or so ago, and so far I got roughly 80 hourse playtime.Let's start with the two most common points of criticism for the game:1. MWO get's much hate because the developers did some really bad things in the past and were inconsistent about their development.2. MWO is based on the "BattleTech" book series. Many people expected (as was initially promised as far as I know) a game that is very similar to the mech battles in the books. That didn't completely work out though.So let's address these points:1. That was the past. Nowadays the developers are very open about the development, posting a kind of status report and roadmap monthly on the forums. They are listening more to what the players want now too. The development as it is now is quite good. As said, it's consistent, the devs aren't acting too much against the players desires and we get two patches, one a bit lighter and one more content-heavy, each month, steadily improving the game. PGI, the developers, are also not afraid to revisit and redo many ingame mechanics. 2. If you don't expect this game to be like the books or didn't even knew about the franchise before, you won't have any problems with this. I actually can't tell how different this is to the books as I simply don't think about it. I recognize BattleTech in this game, but there are also some differences to be noticed.In conclusion, development is fine today, and if you don't care about the books that's not a point of criticism either.Free to play, but is it pay to win?No. You can only use the premium currency MC to buy cosmetics, mechs and garage slots to have more mechs at the same time. Regarding the mech buying:You can buy every mech that is availabe for C-Bills, the ingame currency, with MC too to skip the grind.When new mechs are released, the first month or so they are available for MC only, after that for C-Bills too.But then, there are also hero mechs. Hero mechs can only ever be bought for MC. They are specially colored and maybe uniquely equipped variants of "regular" mechs. They have unique names and are well known from the books, but they aren't in any way OP. If you want to play an OP mech (lol) you will definitely find one available for C-Bills too. The grindIn the beginning you only have the trial mechs, which change every few weeks or months or so. Trial mechs are regular mechs which you can play without buying, but can't customize, so you're stuck with the standard loadout. As you don't own a mech yet, you have to play some trial-mech matches. The game will support you financially in the beginning by giving you extra money for every battle fought, for the first 25 battles or so. This will make you able to buy your own mech quickly. With the money earned in your next matches you will buy and try different kinds of equipment for your mech. After said first 25 matches though, money earning slows down a lot. You will get up to 200k C-Bills for very good matches and roughly 20k from bad ones. The cheapest mechs cost 1,5 mil, the most expensive ones cost 16 mil. Note that this is not just the chassis, but also motor, weapons, ammo, armor etc. so you can reuse most of the stuff you buy, but it still takes quite some time to make enough money to afford a new mech. Additionally, you will probably spend some millions on buying upgrades and equipment for your new mech. If you're like me, you will feel a bit shocked when you used up all of the initial money boost and begin to realize how much you actually need to buy a mech. This feeling will however go away after some time and it will feel really rewarding when you can finally buy a new mech or an expensive upgrade. Also, cheap mechs aren't bad. The price of a mech is just the sum of all of the equipment included in the initial loadout plus a bit extra for the chassis. Cheap mechs are light mechs. Light mechs can be just as enjoyable as the huge, hard-hitting but slow assault mechs, it's just personal preference and playstyle.Graphics are good, not staggering but a sudden laser cutting through the darkness looks really neat. Also, you really feel like in a mechpilots cockpit because of screen shake, red alarm lights and stuff.Sound is very good, each weapon type has it's own sounds and you can really feel the impacts of attacks on your armor. There's even a map without atmosphere where you can only hear your own movement and impacts on your armor, but nothing else from outside.All in all.. most of the criticism can be ignored, that really depends on yourself. As always with F2P games, just try it out. If you can get behind the initial confusion about the quite complex MWO and behind the trial mechs, get a mech you like and equip it how you want, you will have a really good time.

												Great game, you can buy experience point boost, but you can't buy experience.  There have been regular events in beta where you can win/earn MC (the points you buy with real moneys), and you can't buy an advantage.  Beginner players without a group can expect their life to be "nasty, brutish, and short", but it's all about the team play.  Stick together and you increase your chances of survival immensely.  It takes time to accumulate enough to buy a decent set of mechs, and even longer to get them tweaked to the point of usefullness.  There is a wealth of information in the forums to give more than adequate guidance as your play style develops.  The community is vast, diverse, and deep.My wife HATES this game: 10/10

												I've recently started playing and am finding the game to have a lot more depth than similar titles (like world of tanks, world of warships etc.), with just as much if not more room for progression. Certainly mastering every mech chassis and finding optimal builds that work for you on all of them would take a long time. From what I've seen the c-bill (currency earned in game) variants of mechs are at least competitive with, if not better than the mechs you can only buy with real money. As such the only thing you ever 'need' to buy are mech bays, though if you're putting in enough time to get the c-bills for that many mechs (and equiprment) then putting a little money in is fairly reasonable. If you are going to spend real money then the steam dlc 'mech performance packs' aren't the best idea - you only get one mech chassis variant of each type so you'd need to spend quite a lot of time getting the money for two more variants as you need to own three in order to master a chassis, which you'd definitely want to be doing. For my money I'd get a mastery pack for MC (the premium currency) which you can see in-game.Certainly the game is worth downloading and trying; there's a whole lot of content on offer, most of which you can get without spending anything if you're willing to put in the time.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												Have you played Call of Duty, or Battlefield and had a great time?  Are you prone to lone wolf tactics?  Can you take down the entire enemy team on your own armed with nothing but a knife?  Then this is not the game for you.  Mechwarrior is for thinkers, not twich gamers.  Gamers who need to consider everything around them, and take decisive action.  Mistakes are very costly, losing armor, or weapons systems can break you.  You have to consider your role, and work well with a team in order to succeed.The team at Pirhana Games has created a wonderful interpretation of the Battletech universe.  No, it's not much like the tabletop, but it's certainly no HAWKEN.  MWO is closer to a mech sim than a FPS, with localized damage, tonnage and ammo requirements, no respawning, and slow paced tactical combat.  Driving these mechs makes you feel the weight of a multi ton killing machine.  The impact of missiles and autocannon rounds is visceral and makes you seek cover when they hit.  The victories are sweet, just as the defeats can be crushing, but always satisfying and fun.  If you like World of Tanks, you'll like MWO.  If you like COD, go play HAWKEN or Titanfall for some sweet mech action.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												I don't know how to write a review.Pros:Quite funFreeEasy to pick up, and put downYou can try out virtually every mech via 'trial' periodVery solid hit detectionOptional 3rd personLook pretty goodCons:Sometimes matches take a few minutes to find/startNo map in 3rd personSpecial mech variants can only be purchased through microtransactions (which honestly isn't even a big deal. You can customize the base models enough to probably match them)Slightly repetitive (It's a shooter. If you don't like shooters, this isn't for you)All in all, this game is a great game to play when you're bored, or don't know what to do. Between matches you can spend currency to upgrade or tweak your mech. Each mech gets a certain weight cap, and from there you can install weapons, alter your armor on each individual part (Front AND back armor), and install different modules like heat sinks. The tutorial gives you quite a decent amount of money, giving you the ability to get a decent selection of mechs. The game even lets you test out almost every mech to see what you like, and what your play style is. Be it a heavy laser sniper mech, or a light mech that can run circles around the heavies should you be able to get close enough. People seem to say it's pay to win, but I don't really see that. I've played about.. 15+ matches, some lost, some won. I can't give a completely fair opinion on this, due to me not being out of 'noob' stage. There also seems to be a lot of people saying there's a huge learning curve. I don't see that either. Your legs don't face the way you're aiming, but that took a whole 5 minutes to get used to. You don't stop on a dime, and turning takes a second, but once you get past that it's a shooter. You can either try to be precise and aim for specific parts on the enemy mech, or just go all out and fire untill they die. Be warned, you get one life per match. If you die, and quit the match, you'll still get credit. If you quit, you will be unable to use the mech you had in the match untill it's over, though you can still use other mechs in the mean time.TL;DRGame good. Game free. Good for boredom fixes.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												I am a founder.  I bought the mid-tier founders pack and have not regretted it.  The first year was a bit rocky, but through it all, PGI has done all it can to bring the best sim game the Mechwarrior franchise has seen.  I loved all the other titles, but this is the closest to balanced as any Mechwarrior has been.  PGI has not taken all the suggestions they have received and implemented them (the other founders that are crying and putting up negative reviews are doing so because of this.  Entitlement at it's finest lol), but they have implemented many of them, and even improved on some of those recommendations.  Overall, the game has been good enough for me to buy well over $1000 on mech packs and MC, and there are many many others out there that are like me.  Though you may see many negative reviews from some of the founders, understand they are truly the vocal minority.  They just happen to be the loudest, and worst part of this community.There is no PTW, 99.9% of all mechs are purchasable with in game funds, the hero mechs only truly supply you with a faster way to earn those funds, and level the mech slightly faster.  The only pay is for convenience.  You pay to get more money and xp faster, or like me, you pay to help the Devs continue on their recent successful path.  There truly is no end game mech, every mech is viable until you get to tier 1 where you do have to know the meta to compete with some of the best this game has to offer, but for those of us who play for fun, we can build some really wonky mechs that still win. The devs have continued with the development of this game, and with the upcoming release of community warfare 3, and little perks like decals, and updated mechlab, it looks to only get better. If you enjoy stompy robot games, FPS' that are slower and more thought out than CoD, and even better, enjoy joining clans, MWO is a great game to try.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12
												Let me start this review by saying that I have never played a Mech Warrior game before, so I am writing this as someone who does not know any of the lore or design choices and i'm just a filthy casual after some enjoyable gameplay.Pros * Free to play game* The only multiplayer mech game out there for mech fans right now(?)* The community generally seems pretty friendly & a lot of people use voice comms* Different game modes depending on how seriously you want to take it* A lot of customisation of mechs & their loadouts* Battles can be intense & rewarding if you do well / work as a team* A high skill capCons * Extremely sloooow paced game.  Want to play a quick casual with a friend?  Depending on the day & time you're playing (and if the Americans are awake yet) you could be in a queue for 3+ minutes. Then you need to wait for the loading screen to vote on the map & gameplay mode... Then you need to wait for another loading screen to go into a lobby with 24 other people who have inevitably gone off to make a cup of tea / finish the washing up / do the weekly shop while they wait to get into a game - and you have to wait for every single one of those 24 players to press ready or wait for the timer to run down...  Then you get another loading screen to watch essentially another loading screen where your mech is dropped onto the planet...  Then you get to walk across the map for 2 to 3 minutes in your mech (or wait for the other larger & slower mechs to move into position).  All this for probably about 5 to 10 minutes of gameplay if you are lucky* Not being able to access any other part of the game while searching for a game is frustrating, you are forced to sit looking at a searching message rather than being able to check out possible upgrades in the shop or mech loadouts etc* The menu layouts, sub options etc are all extremely confusing & poorly laid out.  I realise that part of this is due to the sheer amount of options the game has, but I can't help but feel a lot of this is down to poor choice & design on the developers part as well* And the real killer is the grind.  The game does a good job at the start of rewarding new players with a lot of in-game currency for completing certain achievements - this then allows them to purchase a mech or two and get a few of the upgrades for that ship.  Great!  Now you'll want to start levelling the skills up for that mech, no no no, you need to purchase & level up another 2 slightly different variants of the same mech you've already purchased!  This inevitably means you'll need to spend a lot more of those precious space bucks & that you will also need to use another two of your very limited spaces garages to hold the ships (and guess what garage spaces cost space bucks).  You also then need to play the two weaker (or less interesting) variants of that ship to the same level as the one you are interested in to unlock the next skill trees, and then repeat the same process of grinding up more experience on all three mechs. You'll also want to upgrade that ship with better engine parts or modules - some more space bucks needed, which are now being earnt extremely slowly since you completed all the starting objectives.  Well you better dedicate your life to this game or be willing to spend some serious real-cash money if you want to play more than a couple of different variants of mechs, which bring me onto the next point* The cost of the in-game purchases is ridiculous for what you actually get, they do put special deals on for certain mechs which change regularly, but wow, it really does seem expensive for what you getConclusion This isn't a bad game, in fact it can be quite intense & enjoyable in the right company & when you finally get into a game and do well, but it's pretty clear after a while that the developers are trying to fleece people who enjopy it / are interested in Mech games & have no other real options.I realise it is free to play, and I purchased a mech or two at the start of the game as I wanted to contribute towards the game that I was enjoying (as I have done for other F2P games such as League of Legends), but you could sink literally 1000s of pounds into this game, and I have a feeling that they prey on people who are willing to do this due to their personality traits & previosuly stated lack of options for Mech games elsewhere.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												I've been playing from alpha.If you are looking for great team based mech combat based in the battletech franchise - this IS it.If you are looking for the above coupled within the battletech social/political space - this is NOT it. I had a much longer review typed out and accidentaly hit the back key on my mouse button, so I'll summarize...The game is fun, and only a few of your L337 FPS skills are going to transfer over. Its going to take a great deal of time to master your piloting and build your arsenal al la carte.Have fun, but remember that the game will be pretty stagnant within a years time if the developers don't pull yon head from dark hole and make faction/house/clan/merc warfare a MEANINGFUL part of the game. Right now its just a short lobby-drop grind for c-bills and xp (quick match) or a little longer grind for c-bills and xp (faction warfare) and thats absolutely it. The social aspect of the game is completely non-existant except for calling out spotting intel and coordination while in combat. Yes you can group with friends - no you can't do anything meaningful within a company or within the faction warfare system. Again, there are no in-game tools or perks to promote anything within this games socio-political space.There are no tools in game that would support a player driven company be it mercs/clans or house military. There is no trading of mechs or c-bills. There are no decisions on repair costs. Your only decision is how to outfit your mech, who to group up with, and how to click the ready button.Now thats not to say the devs have not been working on improving the game beyond what we have now. Hopefully we'll get some perks for faction warfare as it relates to taking defending and holding territory at the faction level (including merc allegiances). Hopefully we get some social tools to promote clan/guild/merc/house military development. Hopefully at some point I can promote or demote someone within my company and set their weekly pay accordingly, which is not tied to some silly rank/achievment system. hopefully we get an ARENA with some commentator tools along with prizes and ladders.However I won't hold my breath on that last block of text. I will however pony up 25k in real hard cash for the first mechwarrior 12 vs 12 tournament in the Solaris arena and get my buddy Deman to commentate the ladder match during a live stream. We need commentator spectator tools/cameras though.Now go read the second sentence of this review.

												There is a lot of potential in this game, but it's pretty inaccessable to new players. I'd be interested in spending some money on this game but the content is so shallow yet complicated. Pros: -Great Mech designs. -great fundamental concepts like the "information warfare" and the different uses for each mech weight class.-Potential for awesome cooperation between players,-Free to pay but not pay to win. (a rare treat)Cons:-Inaccessable. Its so difficult to know some of the basics and meta unless you dig around the internet.-There is a lot of grinding to do just to aquire fundamental features. Supposedly I can only enjoy the game after aquiring these time consuming features, but why would I bother if spending the time to get them is so booring and long.-The turning mechanics are suprisingly amateurish in how they are animated. -Mech customization is supposed to be a fundamental and fun feature of the game, but it too takes too much time and money to be fun.No fluff! No lore! In a Mechwarrior game!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												This is the most immersive game I've ever played and that's why it's my favorite.  It's true that the learning curve is huge, but if the idea of combat from the cockpit of a giant walking tank sounds fun, you should try it.  Give it 2 weeks, because it takes a long time to learn how to be successful.  Do the tutorial until you get the movement and targeting down.  Don't play with real opponents until you've done that.  Join a unit like DHB (deathshandbrigade.net) or the BeerWarriors (beerwarriors.net), get on their TeamSpeak server and ask any questions you may have.  Both groups have nice guys to help you be successful.  Don't be discouraged.  It IS a pretty hard game to learn but can be completely free, if you want it to be.  You can win free mechbays during contests, but it might be worth buying the smallest MC pack for $8 and using it on mechbays.  I hope you keep playing and that I see you in-game.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												Pros:- this really is free-to-play and definitely NOT pay-to-win. Most mechs are purchasable with c-bills which you can earn in-game, and the few 'premium-only mechs are not necessarily 'better' than the non-premium ones (but they do offer a bonus to in-game currency earned in matches). Most of the premium-only items in the game are either cosmetic or boost the rate at which you can earn in-game currency; additional mechbays are an exception, but the 4 you start with are plenty until you want to start building a large mech collection.- the game is very generous for new players. Just completing the tutorials gives you a load of c-bills, while the cadet bonuses from your 1st 25 matches should get you enough to buy any mech in the game (apart from the premium variants mentioned above).- huge range of customisable mechs to buy (in 4 classes light,medium, heavy and assault). The game also has a selection of trial mechs in each class that you can use for free (but you can't customise these) - this allows new players to get a feel for the different weight classes before buying their 1st mech (tip: don't do what I did and spend your cadet bonus before being absolutely sure what type of mech suits you).- lots of mech customisation options (but these may seem complex/baffling for anyone not familiar with mechwarrior games).- the visuals and audio do a great job in making the mechs feel authentic- the matchmaking system attempts to match newer players with other players of the same level of experience- fairly friendly community overallCons:- huge learning curve for anyone not familiar with the mechwarrior universe.- the basic tutorials are not really sufficient to prepare new players for the online battlefields, so new players may get frustrated at having to learn to play the hard way.- there is no option to practice against AI mechs, which would help to alleviate the point above. There is an option to wander around empty battlefields to familiarise yourself with the maps, but I suspect that a lot of new players will quickly get get bored with this, if they choose to do it at all.- despite the attempt to match new players with others of similar experience, a lot of matches seem to be quite unbalanced and I can see that this could put off many new players.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												The base of this game is too much for any mechanical fanatic to pass up, I mean really; Mechs in an unyielding grudgematch to the death( or until an objective is met) but mostly death.Pros: For starters, it fulfilled my childhood dreams of crushing enemies with mechs, but more than that it allows a variety of mechs to be used.  Trial mechs are offered in the beginning under each different class to give the player a chance at the magnitude of styles for all areas of the game.  Making money for an owned mech is easy in the beginning, and I had myself 15,000,000 in-game money before I knew it.  Its combat system is also a quick breeze to understand, and you can adjust you weapons to fire in unison or diversify the artillery under different buttons.  The wisest move behind it all is the tutorial, seeing as it states everything you need to know to jump into the game after its completion.Cons: As figured from a game like this, there is another sort of in-game money that costs real money to earn, but the matches aren't any better behind a mech bought with only that money.  The game does its best to keep a balance for new and older players all in a while making sure the bought money is only a shortcut, not just an enhancer.  As I said earlier, makingmoney is easy AT FIRST, but consequentally after so much your income after each match drops to you putting alot of effort just to afford another mech.  I can't say that the premium in this game gives much moe, but a 50% bonus isn't too bad.  The mech-anics(see that there) are like controlling any other rust bucket, but I do Wonder why there wasn't any tread-legs added( just a personal hope).

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												After growing tired of the CoD games I found MechWarrior Online. It is so much more than just your average MMO FPS style of game. Unlike FPS games, the fastest reflexes do not win in MechWarrior Online. It is a game of strategy. There are so many customizations available. It is a very in-depth game and enjoyable! No reason you haven't tried it yet. The community is positive and helpful (check reddit OutreachHPG). Customizing your mech and going into battle is very satisfying and provides hours of choices and options to entertain. It is challenging to play but once you learn it becomes very rewarding.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												-What's interesting about this game?-It's an FPS game with technological stuff like lasers, long range guided missiles, huge cannons etc... but its certainly not like other FPS games. First, it's not really easy to destroy mechs so, you can lose your leg, arm, or side torso and you can still keep fighting. Then, there is lots of customization stuff so you can find the playstyle that fits you, for example if you like fast-paced playing or scout style playing you can try lighter mechs or if you prefer slow but powerful stuff, you can try heavier mechs. Lastly, if you played any other Mechwarrior game and liked it, you should definitely try this.-Is it p2w? are there any imba stuff?-Although there are things that cause imbalanced gameplay, p2w ain't one of them. and they are making (nearly) every effort to minimize these differences. So, feel free to count this game as one of the fully f2p games. Note, that you might say that they restrict the starting mech bays which you can buy mechs in to 4 but you can gain new mechbays for playing in "faction play" mode or in most weekend events. and even those pretty looking mech designs aren't too far away, they are giving colors and mc away in those events too, so you can customize your battlemechs.-how about community?-I played MWO for years (before steam) and i rarely stumbled open people who curse, swear, etc... plus if you need any help, people really are very eager to help you. (even if they don't help you out in game, you can try forums http://mwomercs.com/forums/ )-Lastly, things that new players should be careful about:*Weapon Ranges: Always check your weapon ranges at the start of a match (lower right corner). And you can find distance of your targer just right of your targeting reticle, so if it shows 400 meter, don't shoot your 200 meter short lasers, they will do reduced damage beyond their max range (0 at double range).Note: normal PPCs have minimimum range of 90, they don't do damage below that range. Note: LRMs have 180 minimum range, c-LRMs do reduced damage below 180*Servers: Between "Faction Play" and "Quick Play" button there's an arrow that lets you choose the server to play the game, choose the one with the lowest ping *Teamplay: Stick with your team, you'll live longer and do more damage.*Buying Mechs: Before you buy mechs, build your mech in this site http://mwo.smurfy-net.de , and then if it fits you, buy it.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												I've put hundreds of hours into Battlefield 3 and 4... and I quit them for this game :-)played MWO since it came out moar than 3 years ago and I'm still at it almost every night. as an Elite Founder of this game, I've seen it go through a lot of ups and downs and I'm really happy about the present state and where the game is headed. spending a small amount is enough to get you all set for the first year or so. the Mastery Packs yield tremendous value for money. you should pick up MechBay deals when they become available and dont waste your precious MCs on buying mech chassis. spend real money only on mastery packs, mech bays, and a few camo and color schemes. forget the rest of the bling. you can get by with the grind, its not that hard. I hated WOT grinds, this is far sensible. TLDR: this is not pay to win. its pay a little, pay what you want, grind for the rest. the GAME BALANCE is excellent!As a battletech nut since 1988, I've played it all on the PC, SNES, Virtual Worlds, Clix, CCG, and Tabletop. this is how I visualize mech combat!

Posted: June 11, 2016
												Simply the best mech sim out there! There is nothing close to it. It captures all of the mechanics of the board game as well as all of it's predecessors since the first VGA came out in 1985. Mechwarrior is the cumilation of decades of perfection, like a samurai sword it has been folded hundreds of times, it is razor sharp and eternal, never rusting, never giving ground to noobs and neophytes. This game is amazing, easy to learn, difficult to master. Many people with low IQ will find this game frustrating since it requires intelligence as well as skill and tactical teamwork. If you are stupid, then stay away from this game because it is beyond your abilities. However, if you are intelligent, then welcome to the thinking man's shooter!

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												Disregard my time played: I've been with this game since launch about 2 years ago, and have sunk hundreds of hours into it.Right, so, where to begin...As soon as the game came out, I was instantaneously disappointed. I, and a lot of other fans of the BattleTek and MW franchise wanted Mechwarrior 5.This is, by no means, Mechwarrior 5.Go google Mechwarrior: Living Legends. THAT, is what MW5 should have been like.*Ahem*Anywho, so, yes, this is not the game we wanted, however it is a pretty decent game in it's own rights.Prior to the steam release, the game was much, much more P2W.You used to make 20-30k cbills a match, maybe 50k if you were good. That meant it took eons to save up for mechs you could "easily" just buy with cash. There were also a lot of mech variants that were marginally better, that were only available for cash. I played it anyway cause, hey, Mechwarrior.Now that it's on steam, it's roughly 200% better in my opinion. I get minimum 100k cbills a match (even if I lose), and up to 400k if I have a good run. That's quite a bit more, and allows me to play around with my loadouts, and get more mechs sooner. Makes the game much less of a grind.So, would I recommend?6 months ago: No.Now: YES.Here's some tips for new players:DO NOT WASTE YOUR STARTING CBILLS ON AN 11MIL ASSAULT MECH. Go for something cheaper, so you still have room to mess with the loadout. People always choose the assault mechs, such as the Atlas, because they look bada$$, are freakin huge, and look like they could just tank and destroy everyone.If you believe that, prepare to be let down. Even the mighty Atlas or Direwolf are not tanks. Go with a light mech if you prefer a faster, hit and run/bugger the heck out of the enemy playstyle, or a medium or possibly heavy if you prefer more of a DPS/somewhat-tanking role.DO YOUR RESEARCHThe first mech I bought was a Banshee variant. Was about 8mil cbills if I recall. Thing looked like it could pack quite a bit of power in and seemed well armoured.After purchasing, I realized it only had Laser hardpoints. Not  bad thing in of itself, but for a tanking mech like that, all-laser builds do not fare very well. No matter what build I tried, I never found one that i was satisfyed with. So I sold it.SELLING A MECH GETS YOU ROUGHLY 1/4-1/2 THE CBILLS BACK. So make sure you research the mech you're interested in, look up builds, because choosing the wrong mech can be costly.DON'T EVERYONE BE AN LRM BOAT. An LRM boat is a mech that holds only, or mostly LRM's (long-range missiles). Yes, they're fantastic for surpressing the enemy or providing extra support to the front line mechs, but I've been seeing more and more matches recently with 6-7 (out of 12 total teammates) Maddogs or Catapults (clan and IS lrm boats). As you can imagine, having the majority of your team be artillary does not work very well. PICK A MECH AND STICK WITH IT. This goes along with what I said earlier, but it adds more. Staying with one mech will benefit you much more than having a load of them. Once you learn how to play a mech, and play it well, and create your perfect loadout, the game gets 1000% more fun. Seriously. Once you get your insanely fast light mech and start running around the enemies shredding the armour and destroying them, or once you get your beefy assault/heavy mech and partake in glorious close-mid range all out brawls? That's where this game shines. I found my perfect mech a couple weeks ago, the Arctic Cheeta ACH-B.Got my perfect loadout, and I've maxed out it's efficiencies. Even though I've now nothing to work towards with it (nothing to unlock for it), just messing about with different loadouts is fun. And playing the thing? It's fantastic, I love the hit and run style it allows for.GAME DOESN'T RUN WELL? You see those minimum specs down there? Disregard them. You see those recommended specs down there? Disregard them too. I run an FX-6300, 6 core, OC'd to 4.1ghz, R9 270x 2gb (slightly better than a GTX 750ti), 16 gb 1600mhz ram, and an SSD, displaying to a 1920x1080 monitor. I average 50-60 fps, drop down to 30-40 when it hits the fan. On low graphics. Now, imo, the game looks the same on all graphic settings, so I highly suggest you just go with minimal graphics. This is one of those games where 30 and sometimes even sub 30 FPS is playable, however, if you play a light mech, you need the fastest response time you can get, so 60 FPS would be best.USE VOICE COMMS. AGAIN, USE. VOICE. COMMS.Play a match where your team just communicates with text chat, or not at all, to a game where your team talks with VOIP, and you'll see a large difference. When VOIP comes in to play, that's when the real fun happens. Tactics, strategy, mid-game banter with your 'mates. The community is quite friendly from what I've seen too, I've never had a bad 'mate on VOIP. Even if only to say "Assault lance advanding delta 6" or such every so often, use voice comms. It makes the match so, so much better.I hope this review and some of these tips helped you, and I'm glad to see new players to this game from steam!Have a good one, and happy hunting.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												This game has come a LONG way since it's humble beta back in ~2013, when I last played. There's still work to be done, but the developers continually endeavor to squash bugs, improve balancing (an endless battle in and of itself) and add new content. As a "new" player coming into a game that's been out for a while, I didn't feel hamstrung by my lack of kit versus the more established players. I was able to drop right in and make a difference. As a "free to play" game, there are of course microtransactions - but I feel it is very well balanced and not at all pay to win. While you can skip ahead to the best mechs and fitments by throwing money around, winning will always come down to player experience and teamwork in the field. You don't have to spend a single dime to be effective. If you like it, you can always throw them a few bucks towards "premium" game time, which grants bigger rewards at the end of each battle, similar to how World of Tanks handles it. If you're a fan of BattleTech or have played any of the previous MechWarrior games, much of the gameplay will be familiar to you. You purchase BattleMechs ('Mechs for short), outfit them in the MechLab, and go to battle. You control the torso with the mouse, much like any shooter, but you control the legs independently from the torso with the keyboard (you can also use a joystick, gamepad, etc. for both). This allows you to shoot on the move, as well as dance around your target while continually pouring hellfire into them. If you've ever played World of Tanks, or used vehicles in Battlefield, you'll be familiar with the feel of this already. The developers have recently included a galaxy-spanning metagame, where the outcome of your battles have real consequences. Groups of players can fight for control of individual planets in the name of their faction (of which there are several to choose from), and the map is updated to reflect the ebb and flow of the battle lines as the campaign progresses. The closest existing example for this that comes to mind is WW2Online (Battleground Europe). Anyway, the game has a lot to offer and it gets my recommendation!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Comfort is a warm center torso Charlie Brown.Pros:-Looks pretty good for an mmo that's a couple years old.-Overall gameplay is fun and doesn't get boring.-Not pay to win. Mechs that can only be purchased for real cash like hero mechs are just unique variants, they don't provide an actual advantage (they do still provide a bonus in how much cash you earn). Similarily, champion mechs are just the most popular variant of a non hero mech with a better stock loadout and an xp bonus. There are plenty of trial mechs to use for free that are switched every once in a while, and you earn a very large casy bonus in your first 25 games. Grinding also doesn't get boring because, well, your job consists of blasting apart other mechs.-Though development was previously hellish (and there are many, many stories that attest to this), that is no longer the case. They have been doing a much better job since they split from the publisher.-You can customize mechs in many, many ways. You can add or remove armor, equipment and weapons of your choice. Inner sphere mechs can also swap engines, and clan mechs can swap arms and side torsos.Cons:-Gameplay can sometimes be rough. The learning curve is a big one here, and even though I previously played mechwarrior 3 quite a bit I still mostly suck :). Mechs are piloted like walking tanks in mechwarrior (seperately moving arms, torsos and legs), so if you played WOT you may have an advantage.-Some balance issues, especially between clan and inner sphere mechs, but the devs are always working to improve on this.Though this game isn't perfect, it is still very fun overall. As a previous player of Mechwarrior 3, I was inially somewhat skeptical about how fun mechwarrior could be without a campaign, but I think it's pretty fine as it is.See you on the battlefield!

If you make a small mistake in this game it will get you killed, Team work is key if your team do not work with each other then you will more than likely be looking at a loss. Any one can free fall 360 NoScope in most other games but not this one, this game widdles out those type of cheap shot players and finds players with real skills, players who know when to shild and when to shoot, when to take cover and when to trade, when to defend and when to push, players that use infomation to their advantage, to weaken their opponent. No game here this is a Battletech sim and its a WAR!!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												I can't stop  playing this game. If all you're looking for is Armored Core-levels of mech customization and stomping around in a legit mech-simulator, THIS IS FOR YOU. Don't think of it as anything else other than what it is...a slow, strategic team-based FPS.F2P turns off most people, but I played for nearly three years (pre-Steam, obv) without spending a cent. Your first 25 matches net you a TON of in-game credits and you have lots of trial mechs of all different types to get a feel of what you want before you spend your credits for it.There's an amazing community at www.reddit.com/r/OutreachHPG, or /r/OutreachHPG in case my URL gets deleted. Ask your questions, but realize this game punishes newbies and the learning curve is great. BUT, it's SO worth it! Don't jump into a new game expecting to know how to play it and to be an expert, put yourself out of your comfort zone and HELP BRING BACK THE MECHWARRIOR/BATTLEMECH FRANCHISE!

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												If you've played and enjoyed Mechwarrior titles in the past, definitely try this out. Don't let the negative reviews out there stop you. There are a lot of them out there, but if you look closely you'll find many were written a few years ago (when the concerns, now fixed, may have actually been valid) or are written by those obviously so attached to the idea of what the game "could be" if it were designed by themselves. Think of them like the crazy neighbours crying about government conspiracy because the garbage pickup wasn't on time, and "something should be done because by God, I've lived on this block for 20 years!"I'm writing this a few weeks after picking up the game and can say PGI has done a great job. The devs have captured the original feeling of Mechwarrior that made me fall in love with the series decades ago. PGI has also been unfairly accused of being greedy. But remember, this is a free game. Any money you choose to spend on this game is a choice. And having played against some wallet warriors, I can say the mechs/upgrades that can be bought with cash do not generally provide players with an unfair advantage.They generally only speed things up, marginally. And really, please don't shame private companies for trying to make a buck, especially when you don't have to pay anything at all -- these guys gotta eat!Please be ready for a complex game: this ain't no Call of Duty. Mechs are slow, they're big targets, have long cool downs between shots (for some weapons), and generally depend on having support mechs around to survive. You'll have to do things like watch out for overheating, tagging targets for team mates, taking cover from sniper fire, turning your mech so damage is evenly distributed around your armour, etc, etc. For me, the complexity is what makes the game exciting -- things such as the dread of having my mech shut down in a fight because I forgot to override the engine overheat safety shut off (yes, you can do that), or remembering to turn on infrared vision in a foggy map to see the heat signatures of enemy mechs through the mist.Because of the complexity, skill at playing this game will come more with time rather than with reflex. You will rightfully feel like other players are better at first, simply because they've learned to use the control buttons not taught in the tutorial. Press F1 for the button layout. Other than that, enjoy and hopefully I'll see you in game!

												I must say I have been obsessed with this game for almost 3 years now. It is not your typical FPS. It is a game that requires intense situational awareness and is also very unforgiving. This is a 'Mech Simulator' and is known to stick to the Tabletop gameplay as much as possible while being a thrilling FPS all at the same time. I have been a fan of Mechwarrior/Battletech since Mechwarrior 2 and Battletech (sega genesis) so that might have a lot to do with my infatuation with this game. No it is not perfect, far from it. But having some good teamwork and patience makes this game incredibely rewarding!Highly Recomend to anyone.If youre looking for something a little more faster pace and nearly equal amount of customization, try Hawken.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												I have been playing this game for the last couple of years. I have spent a lot of money on it. I continue to play, and have pre-purchased a number of things yet to come out.I do recommend this game, but not for many people.Since going on Steam, I have noticed a definet lowering of skill in the player base. Namely in the Community Warfare games. I have witnessed many people shooting the gates themselves, rather than the power generator. I have seen them run off to do their own thing and get killed for it. The old problem of being shot in the back by teammates at the start of a match is back because people want to test fire.If you want to play this game then I suggest you read the forums first. There is a wonderful section for new players. If you cannot be arsed to do that much, there is an in game tutorial about handling your mech, firing weapons and generally how to not get popped shortly after your mech is dropped on the planet. It rewards you with in game currency for doing the tutorial. Sadly, there is no tutorial covering Community Warfare, but is it really so difficult to watch what all of the other pilots are doing before rushing off to do your own thing? More importantly, is it really so important that you ignore what other pilots are telling you? Many times I have attempted to direct my team, or even just make a suggestion like "stick together, fire on the same target." I get it, I am a veteran and therefore exude some kind of aura that says "do the opposite, ignore them, blame them if it goes wrong and argue with them about their expeirence." I would think that it would not be so hard to fight against that aura, but recent evidence is proving me wrong.Are there problems with this game? Sure, it has glitches. Namely, I find that I crash when I play it through Steam. Sometimes there are problems with the maps and I get stuck with certain chassis in particular spots, or I get stuck rubber banding. These things happen. But worse than any glitches, is the new player base. Learn to pilot your multi-ton death machine to the benefit of your team, or take off the neuro-helm and find something else.
