content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												I've been a fan of MechWarrior since I was a kid. This game seriously delivers and feels like a true expansion on the universe. Although I recommend the game, I would like to point out some weakpoints.1. The tutorial falls short. It takes you through the basics but the customization in MechWarrior Online is immense and the sheer number of buttons that work in game is on par with a good flight simulator. There is a learning curve and you will have to figure out the intricacies yourself.2. The in-game currency is earned slowly and the purchased currency is expensive. This is the case with most free to play games, but MechWarrior Online is a little steep even by these standards. A single assault mech can cost upwards of $30. You'll need to earn experience on 3 variants of the same mech to maximize your perks, do the math.3. Waiting. You only get one life in a normal game and four lives in a Faction based game. After your lives are expended, you have to wait for the match to expire before you can begin again. I normally enjoy this style of play but I have found myself in a match with an AFK player that forces everyone to wait for the 15 minuite match timer to expire before play can begin again (the maps can get pretty big, and AFK/disconnected players are not always found).

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												As a long time veteran player, fan of the mechwarrior series and a general lover of big stompy robots. I would seriously recommend giving the game a try.Unlike most shooters a mech has legs and a torso that you have to control seperately.  A mech plays like a giant walking tank. However unlike a tank the mech consists of independent body parts. You can lose arms, a leg or shoulders and still keep on going. When you lose a body part, you also lose the weapons in that body part. This adds an extra layer of tactics on top of normal shooter gameplay. By twisting away you can choose which body part will take the damage. Also unlike most shooters a mech also has two cross-hairs, one for the weapons in the torso and one for the weapons in the arms (you do need to turn arm lock off). You control both with the mouse at the same time, one just moves a bit slower then the other. The weapons located in the arms can aim much higher and lower and move faster. They are however less protected then the weapons in the torso. This means that you have to think about your position on the battlefield. You want to move so all your weapons can shoot while your opponent won't be able to shoot back at all or atleast with all his weapons.You are also able to customize your mech. Change the weapons, the speed at which the mech moves and a few other things. Because you're able to control which body part will take most of the damage and because the location of the weapons in the body matters this allows for allot of interesting choices and gameplay.That said. Buying mechs and upgrading mechs is expensive. As new player you won't notice right away. Completing the tutorial, mechwarrior academy and the first two dozen of games will shower you with C-Bills. After that it takes some serious grinding. Pick your first purcachse wisely.The gameplay is still that of an Arena shooter, two teams of 12 players face off one of 13 maps. In quick play there is no respawn and fight last usually about 7-8 minutes. After that it is mopping up for the victor. In quickplay there are three game modes. Though on most maps the winner is usually decided by which side wins the big fight in the middle. The objectives don't matter much here. There are other strategies but those require a coordinated team which you won't find in quick play.For coordinated teams there is faction warefare. Two teams of 12 players either try to asault or defend a base. Each team has 4 respawns. A good game usually last between 30 and 45 minutes. This game mode can be allot of fun but I would not recomment this to new players or people looking to shoot stuff. The veteran players are extremly well coordinated and highly skilled. If you don't know what you're doing, you will lose horribly and generally not enjoy it.The game is free to play and you won't be locked out of anything essential. However if you want to have more then 4 mechs (and you will!) you will need to buy mechbays. These are cheap, about 2$ each and often given away for free during an event. There are also some upgrades that are extremly expensive and cost more then a mech. As a new player you can ignore these quite easilly though they do become important later on. At that point you'll have to either decide to grind it all out or use one of the premium options to speed it all up.

												I beta tested this game.Pros: The staff are friendly, care about the community and want bugs fixed.The game engine is very fluid.The mechs are well designed and true to cannon.Cons:There are 'variants' of mechs which use 'hard points'. content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												one of the best F2P action titles ive ever played. as a long standing fan of the series, i can say this holds up to what they've always aimed for; a realistic take on giant mechanized war machines. the game looks beautiful, the mechs feel as they should, and if you know of any previous titles, you'll instantly recognize some of your favorites from the past, and even some new models that all offer many variants and customization options that will leave you with literally 1000's of hours of play time! this game allows you to play like a lone wolf, but your influence on the battle field with be negligable to non-existant, so if you wanna have a strong effect on the game, make sure you work together, and think before you step around the next corner, or you could be a pile of twisted metal before you can say 'Sweet tooth' (see what i did there?).i will say this, if you end up falling in love with the game, your going to want to spend about 5-10 dollars once your 'new player bonuses' wear off so you can expand your mech bay, allowing you to own more mechs, otherwise your limited to 6. but they also always have a rotating roster of free to play mechs as well, that are all usable even if youre short on bays. (this paragraph is null and void as literally right after i wrote this, i found you can earn mechbays through faction warfare)all in all, an amazing game that i'd happily spend 10 dollars on for the time ive put into this game. (i played before it was on steam)  i would recommend this to any giant robot fans, fans of the series, or people who enjoy driving tanks (as the controlls closely resemble tank controls from other games).

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2
												3 out of 5 stars A satisfying MechWarrior experience that takes as much teamwork and discipline as it does skill to best your opponent. This is a chess like tactical shooter that requires you to purchase and setup a mech to fit your play style, and then challenges you to master that play style. Mics are required as much as a mouse is, and you aren't going to get very far without one.If you are looking for a game to get your MechWarrior fix in with then this will do the trick. This game has enough stragety and skill based elements in it to balance out the "pay to win" aspects of an "online version" of a game. That being said, this game could be light years better if it weren't for the pay to win mechanic that does exist. If you take this game seriously in any way you are going to want to purchase a few mechs which will end up costing you about the same price that they could charge if they made you pay to play the game in the first place. It only feels like a pay to win game in the mech lab mode, as there aren't alot of over powered things that you can add to your setup, as long as your team plays with good fundamentals.Each match, outside of faction play, consists of a 12 versus 12 setup with a max time format, having a kill limit or score limit end the game early. You get 1 life and no health regeneration. There are 4 game modes consisting of Skirmish, Domination, Assualt, and Conquest. Assault being a VIP escort mode, Domination is king of the hill, and Conquest is like territories from halo 2. And yes If you own at territories you are still a noob.There is a leveling system in this game and I will explain it the best I can in a flow chart style, with a little humor.-play pick up games with trial mechs.-grind for money to buy a mech that you might like-realize that you hate the mech you bought and scrap it for a different one-grind-in the meantime, learn how weapon systems work and how different builds have different roles on the field-realize its going to take months to grind to have the mechs that you want-pay money for the mechs so you dont waste your time-realize that you didn't understand the mechanics and re-buy the mech that you scrapped earlier-level up a few different mechs to mastery efficiency via grinding in pugs-grind to load said mechs with mods-build a drop deck for faction play-group up and que with other players that you like playing with-play faction mode, shoot face, reck the enemy, and conquer planets.If I won the lottery there would be a much better MechWarrior game and possibly a movie in production, but for now, as Mechwarrior fans, are just going to have to settle for this.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												MWO is one of the few really good and very fair F2P games, it's a really fun mech combat game proto-simulator with excellent meaningful complexity for an FPS in terms of customisation and personal preference.This game is definitely a keeper for anyone who likes giant stompy robots, and if you don't like giant stompy robots then you should try it and you'll end up liking giant stompy robots, there is no need to be a MechWarrior franchise or lore fan to like it, also it's very casual friendly if you stick to the normal queue.Is it perfect? No, it has some weapon balance concerns, suffers from a noticeably low time to kill(TTK) and a problematic Community Warfare model are some annoyances, but they keep developing it and it gets better so eventually those things will get ironed out hopefully as well.Do note however, while it's casual friendly, it has a much higher learning curve much due to the customisation options and various weapons and utility options available, so don't be afraid to ask for advice here or on the forums on www.mwomercs.com and www.reddit.com/r/outreachhpg/ or /mwoHappy stomping, and may your armour stay intact and your guns remain cool o7

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												I can't stop  playing this game. If all you're looking for is Armored Core-levels of mech customization and stomping around in a legit mech-simulator, THIS IS FOR YOU. Don't think of it as anything else other than what it is...a slow, strategic team-based FPS.F2P turns off most people, but I played for nearly three years (pre-Steam, obv) without spending a cent. Your first 25 matches net you a TON of in-game credits and you have lots of trial mechs of all different types to get a feel of what you want before you spend your credits for it.There's an amazing community at www.reddit.com/r/OutreachHPG, or /r/OutreachHPG in case my URL gets deleted. Ask your questions, but realize this game punishes newbies and the learning curve is great. BUT, it's SO worth it! Don't jump into a new game expecting to know how to play it and to be an expert, put yourself out of your comfort zone and HELP BRING BACK THE MECHWARRIOR/BATTLEMECH FRANCHISE!

												I love this game.  It's rough around the edges.  It's not the prettiest game.  It has some definite grind issues like pretty much all F2P games.  Real money prices for things are definitely rather ridiculous.  All that said, this game does the mech combat and customization thing as well as any game in decades.  If you are into that sort of thing this game is pure awesome, and I'm definitely into that sort of thing.  And hey, it's free to play so why not give it a whirl?

content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
												Back in 2013 this game left much to be desired.Having returned in 2016 it is quite possibly one of the best free to play experiences out there.There's an Intro/training area, then your straight into matches with a LFG system, ingame VOIP, and a helpful community.There's no requirement to spend money (unless you wish to support the game).My only gripe after sinking the better part of a week into the game, is that once searching for a match you cant fiddle with your other mechs' setups.8/10 easy, more so if you like mechs. :)

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												one of the best F2P action titles ive ever played. as a long standing fan of the series, i can say this holds up to what they've always aimed for; a realistic take on giant mechanized war machines. the game looks beautiful, the mechs feel as they should, and if you know of any previous titles, you'll instantly recognize some of your favorites from the past, and even some new models that all offer many variants and customization options that will leave you with literally 1000's of hours of play time! this game allows you to play like a lone wolf, but your influence on the battle field with be negligable to non-existant, so if you wanna have a strong effect on the game, make sure you work together, and think before you step around the next corner, or you could be a pile of twisted metal before you can say 'Sweet tooth' (see what i did there?).i will say this, if you end up falling in love with the game, your going to want to spend about 5-10 dollars once your 'new player bonuses' wear off so you can expand your mech bay, allowing you to own more mechs, otherwise your limited to 6. but they also always have a rotating roster of free to play mechs as well, that are all usable even if youre short on bays. (this paragraph is null and void as literally right after i wrote this, i found you can earn mechbays through faction warfare)all in all, an amazing game that i'd happily spend 10 dollars on for the time ive put into this game. (i played before it was on steam)  i would recommend this to any giant robot fans, fans of the series, or people who enjoy driving tanks (as the controlls closely resemble tank controls from other games).

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												This game is a one of a kind and it's amazing. Don't let other people tell you otherwise. While it has its flaws, it's an absolute marvel to play when you are in the upper tiers where people aren't noobs.As a tier 1 player with well over 700 hours (I played a lot when it wasn't on Steam), I can give you new players tips.For starters, this game is not your run of the mill CoD clone ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, nor is it like Battlefield. This is a vehicular mech fighting game, and not the gundam type where everything can dash and sidestep willynilly.Rather, you control like a tank, as in your torso and legs are seperate. You "Strafe" by lining your torso to the side of your legs. I would recommend getting used to playing with your arms unlocked at all times, it makes no sense to use a slower aim point that is locked arms, there is no benefit to it.By keeping your arms unlocked, you can be sure that your arm mounted weapons can travel faster/further up and down as well as left and right. Keep in mind some mechs do not have arms, only shoulders which can only go up and down.In terms of mechanics, this game feels great to be good at. Make sure to look up guides on torso twisting, mech parts tagetting and which weapon dooes what.Also make sure to look up guides on buying your first mech because you will not always be given cbills for free, your first purchase matter in how you will enjoy the game. Make sure you buy what fits you.I have not felt any game quite like MWO that drives my enjoyment of working as a team. Play with a friend, it's worth it.If you ever see anyone say "This game is broken with pay to win♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; you can instantly know they are talking♥♥♥♥♥♥ you cannot buy power in any way whatsoever. You can only be good at the game, that's it.If you need help with the game, feel free to visit MWO's forums, people will gladly answer your questions.Have fun and good luck, pilots.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												MWO is one of the few really good and very fair F2P games, it's a really fun mech combat game proto-simulator with excellent meaningful complexity for an FPS in terms of customisation and personal preference.This game is definitely a keeper for anyone who likes giant stompy robots, and if you don't like giant stompy robots then you should try it and you'll end up liking giant stompy robots, there is no need to be a MechWarrior franchise or lore fan to like it, also it's very casual friendly if you stick to the normal queue.Is it perfect? No, it has some weapon balance concerns, suffers from a noticeably low time to kill(TTK) and a problematic Community Warfare model are some annoyances, but they keep developing it and it gets better so eventually those things will get ironed out hopefully as well.Do note however, while it's casual friendly, it has a much higher learning curve much due to the customisation options and various weapons and utility options available, so don't be afraid to ask for advice here or on the forums on www.mwomercs.com and www.reddit.com/r/outreachhpg/ or /mwoHappy stomping, and may your armour stay intact and your guns remain cool o7

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
Product received for free
												Fun game that is essentially a tank arena game.  I wish there was a co-op mission option for fans of the old-school Mechwarrior games, but I won't knock it for being something it's not.  I'm generally not crazy about F2P games, becuase they are generally really grindy like MMOs, and this one is too to an extent, but it's well-balanced.  After playing for a day I had enough credits to afford a servicable mech with a customized loadout.  Paying real world money gets you the ability to have more than one personal mech at a time, 'premium time' where you get exp and such faster, visual florishes and mechs without the grind.  Generally these things are just a couple of bucks but some of the high-end mechs can go for as much as 20 bucks.'Twenty bucks for an in-game mech?' you ask.  Well, yeah, such things are available for the turbo-nutters who want them.  But for the most part they just grant a permenent exp increase; they have some other perks too but the game is so team-centric that it doesn't seem very unbalancing.  Two mechs working together will still beat one on it's own, platinum-plated or not.  So, good game.  Definitely worth a download to try it out.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												This is the original, real deal, Battletech (TM) universe. This is not Hawken, folks. This is a tactical shooter where you can't go in guns blazing. This is where teamwork counts and knowing your mech counts. This is not Titanfall, folks.This is a learning curve greater than a Bezier Parametric (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%A9zier_curve). This is not Call of Duty, folks.Does it crash? Yes. Is it balanced? Not quite. Is it a big, grindy, grindfest? Yes.Is it P2W? Not really. Is it fun? Yes. More than the other knockoffs? Yes.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												I was going to rant about this game for a few reasons:-Poorly optimized to the Cry Engine(still is),-Slow progress from devs when it comes to well-needed patches(they are a very small company),-Stuff is BADLY needed in the gameI'm a 3-year vet of MWO; been playing as "Zephonarch II" since early Beta, I've seen the transitions from LRMMania, GaussMania, MetaLaserMania, The Clan Mech-introduction, The InnerSphere Mech Quirk introduction, and now the removal of Quirks as PGI has seen it as a dumb idiotic directionless mistake. It was a band-aid plan to patch terrible balancing from the beginning. That's right. This game has a history of annoying nerfs and OP-boosts.It used to be manageable when it was just coming onto the market; it was simpler. AC2Os were frightening up close. Still are, but people complained then. Then the Clans came which BY LORE they're supposed to be OP opposed to IS(Inner Sphere) mechs. Quirks were awful. These new boosts and hybrid-mechs were the reason why maps had to be made larger(The mechs were too fast!)(TOO FAST). PGI's been "fixing" their mistakes for the whole time I've known of them. And I uninstalled due to overloading stress building over the years just around March or April.I had no hope going into reinstalling the game simply cause my gaming laptop suddenly couldn't handle the new larger, refined old maps. It ticked me off so badly, I resorted to zombie builds only. I barely moved, but I still could deal good amounts of damage at 8 FPS. ...And then I checked it out once the download finished. It's fine. I don't know what PGI did, but I suddenly can play this again. ... I get so irritated by PGI though, they never advertise Optimization improvements they make. I wouldv'e came back a while ago if they had included it in the emails! The game USED to perform practically at 20 FPS(At it's old best). Now I get 40-50 FPS. WHAT DID YOU DO PGI? HUH? YOU'RE NOT GOING TO AT LEAST BOAST THAT THE GAME'S BETTER FOR MID-SPEC RANGE PCS NOW??? I'M HAPPY AGAIN. I CAN PLAY. I GOT A KILL FOR 5 MATCHES STRAIGHT SINCE I STARTED PLAYING + I HELPED MY TEAM. NO DE-SYNCS. NO RANDOM LAG SPIKES FROM 3 RANDOM LRM-BOATS OR HUGE CQC-FIGHTS. JUST GOOD FIGHTS. THANK YOU PGI.MechWarrior:Online is worth it. Just plan for the right mechs for yourself, and you'll start planning tactics like a pro in no time. Just mind the bump that is PGI. The game may fall apart again with its history. It's sad but hey if you can handle a long grind with a good mech with good builds,... hey MechWarrior is great then.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
 -- A bit lacking in gameplay options. No matter what the mode, it plays out like a skirmish. - Pricing seems off. Not very tempted to spend money as the packs are unnappealing and the stuff you can buy is  expensive. The F2P grind isnt so bad for the very patient. You get decent money at start, If you spend it wisely you will have a competitive mech in about 25 matches. +++ lots of Mechs. lots of variety. classics are there locust, jenner, battlemaster, marauder and company. + The Mechlab is well done. Customizing yours is easy and the options are vast.++ Mech combat is fun. Mech handling and operation is pretty much like it was in the old games. - The maps, though nice, are stale and lack any sort of life. The scale of some of the set pieces seems off but whatever.. Destructable set props like buildings and such wouldve been very nice.If your a fan of the mechwarrior series, go for it.If you want to customize a Big battle mech and fight in the arena 12 vs 12, go for it.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10
												Please understand this is a first impression review. Now what should we start with first? The Pros of the Cons, eh? Don’t worry I will flip a coin. Tails! Cons it is.1: The Academy aka the tutorialAt first it looks like your really going to be educated on what it takes to be a MechWarrior but in reality you are given the bare bone necessities even some of their more advanced education can barely cover what you will encounter in live combat. BattleMechs do not stand still. In live combat if you are standing still you may as well paint a giant bullseye on you. In short the tutorial does not prepare you for the riggers of war in a Mech.2: Mech BuildsWithin my limited knowledge never have I seen in Battletech, MechWarrior and MechCommander has anyone ever decided for you how you will build or set up your Mech. Before M.W.O. your only limitations were Tonnage, Heat, Defense, Offense and Utilitarian. Now with M.W.O. you have to deal with what you are allowed to put where on YOUR MECH!!!3: Pay wallsWhere as I follow the philosophy that nothing is truly free and few people can truly be trusted MechWarrior Online is the absolute epitome of pay to play. You can’t get a mech that does what you want it to, you can’t open a cache, you cant have items in your cockpit, you can not change the color or pattern on your Mech, you can not run a Unit successfully without cold hard cash and for some of us that is just not a possibility.4: Be it BattleTech, MechWarrior or MechCommander there has always been a story to tell. In MechWarrior Online there is no story to tell and that bothers me. Pros1: FunOMG this game will leave you panting and wanting more. It will run you ragged and wanting more. This game will♥♥♥♥♥♥you off and make you want it even more.2: CommunityMWO has an amazing community that will help you every step of the way. Litteraly people from every walk of life that will advise you as you need it. Listen carefully and learn when to ask for help.Yeah thats it for now more to come as I learn more about the game.

												The grind at the beggining is real. You have to pick a good first Mech; good as in one that is fun for you to play, as it will be a while before you can afford another one (cadet bonus + academy rewards only last for so long). Fortunately, if you made a mistake in your purchase you can simply start a new account :)Once you get yourself few Mechs, and found your favourite playstyle - this is where the game shines. Unfortunately, if you don't want to spend any money, in order to get more Mechs you will need to rely on Faction Play and events to rack up some Mech bays.Still, would recommend for any Mechwarrior fans out there. Beware though, it's not your typical MW game...

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												I've got about 22 hours in, and so far it's been a lot of fun, for the most part. The aspects of the BattleTech universe have been rather well-balanced with the necessities of good gameplay. Graphics are good (to me at least, lol) and it runs well on my PC. Controls take some getting used to, but with practice and tinkering of the key list, it works. A player dedicated to mastering the concepts and tactics of the game can contribute regardless of 'Mech, and while it takes time to build up one's inventory, it can be done without throwing much if any money at the product (so far I haven't spent a dime).That said the price points for some of the pay-content seem rather high to me. There's no real option to purchase gear, etc. in any amount *without* basically 'subscribing' for a month of premium. This agitates me because I'd like to pitch some money at the game, but for now the cost for such limited return is rather high for a casual gamer like myself.That's a rather minor criticism from me though, as most other points of the game are solid. Very happy with my play time so far, and find myself constantly coming back for more. As close to a 'Mech 'simulation' that's still enjoyable that I've played in quite some time.Last piece of advice: as a new player, play through the tutorial, and finish all the 'cadet' achievements for a hefty number of free C-Bills. Take your time thinking before you spend it, do some reading, then spend and modify cautiously.

content:
Posted: February 1
												A great F2P game that isn't pay to win.   Griant robots in 12v12 combat that never gets old.  4 weight classes and multiple play styles so there is someting for everyone.   If you ever played Battletech or Mechwarrior in either the table top or video game forms you have to try this.  If not you need to discover this universe.  I have played this since closed beta and 4 years later, i'm still playing with over 600hours of game time.  Tryit, play it for a few weeks, but be sure and do the tutoials, the rewards are WELL worthi t and you will have a much better idea of how to play.  Sniping, scouting, brawling, indirect fire, this game has it all and it just doesn't get old.  There is always a new mech coming out and while they cost $ at first after a few months they go for ingame currency  They even do monthly rewards/contest that let you get free paid currency or items that can only be purchased with the paid currency.   After you get used to the game, fnd a group to play with and it only gets better.  Has PGI messed up over the years, oh yeah, big time, but the game is still great and a lot of the old issues are fixed.  Don't get me wrong, there is still a lot of improvements/expansion that could be made, but i still play this at least a few times a week if not daily.  IT's just that good.  did I mention it's FREE, download it and take a shot

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												I've been playing since the last days of open Beta, and the game is in the best state it's ever been.That said, there's still a LOT of room for improvement. The Good: With a coordinated team that knows what they're doing, the game is fun as hell. The mech models look pretty great. For a few brief, shining moments the game can occasionally be the "mech simulator/Thinking Man's Shooter" that its hyped up to be, but those moments are few and far between.The Bad: The meta is heavily skewed towards massive burst damage that turns the "thinking man's shooter" into "is that an enem- where'd all my armor and components go?". The gamemodes available are Team Deathmatch, Team Deathmach with lights running around to capture zones, Team Deathmatch that sometimes ends in before anyone gets any kills because lights with capture modules ran to the otherside of the map, and Queue Warrior Online, also called "How I learned to hate the Clans and get stomped by 12-mans". The weapon balance is constantly in flux, but rarely in ways that make sense. Rather than simply tweaking values, the devs prefer to add in "ghost" features that are never adequately explained and usually just make the balance issues worse. The Worse: Know this before you start investing time and money: The developers have a long history of being out of touch with the reality of the game. They've blatantly lied to players more times than I can count and see the player base as little more than wallets to be sucked dry. The game's pricing system may well go down in history as the worst ever. All that said, the game is currently the best Mechwarrior game in the market (because development on the Living Legends mod for Crysis "conveniently" stopped around the time this game started up)

number of helpful: 26 of 55 people (47%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												Pros: Free Big Stompy RobotsCons: Everything Else1/10 Would not trust shills again.>>>>>>**CAUTIONARY WARNING** <<<<<<This is a casual Team Death Match game VERY LOOSELY based on the Battletech Universe, and that's in the Mech Models only. If all you want is to kill some time and blow stuff up, its not bad. If you enjoy Battletech LORE, the Table Top game(s) then understand it does NOT exist here.Mechwarrior: Online is a Swiss Army Knife... it tries to please everyone and pull in as big of a crowd as it can, promising the world, but never really delivers or does anything well... just "good enough" and the main focus of development is primarily centered around pushing out new Mech models.The game as a casual “just stomp around and blow stuff up” is fun, but that’s the thin candy-coated shell that covers the bland, uninspiring empty center of the game. And this is the major reason why there are so many mixed reviews… there are many people who enjoy the casual lack of depth this game has, but there are just as many people who really wanted the depth that was promised and believed that depth to be delivered in a TIMELY fashion instead of accepting years of “Glacial Progression” about everything (such as MW:O finally got working monitors JUST in time for steam launch after years of staring at multiple “AUTO DETECT: NO” screens)Also, it helps to understand how the upper management developers of this game work before new players consider investing into the game. Here are some examples I’d suggest reading or looking up the following issues and coming to your own conclusions:- PGI and Transverse game- First Developer blog and intentions of addressing issues yet still exist 4 years later:   •	Urban Combat to address circle strafing and long range sniping.   •	Dynamic Battlefield further expanded on the concepts of Urban Combat and mechs having roles.   •	Dynamic pacing, introduced an early version of one of the final pillars, Information Warfare.(ref:  http://mwomercs.com/news/2011/10/2-dev-blog-0  )-Most recent admission of balance issues by a lead developer, suggestion of change and implementation of another system, termed “Infotech”:(ref: http://mwomercs.com/forums/topic/208441-mech-rebalance-and-pts/ )Russ Bullock’s reaction on Twitter to the player base regarding people heavily commenting on and rejecting the proposed “Infotech” issue, telling people “it’s turfed already, so you can all sleep again.”( ref: https://twitter.com/russ_bullock/status/662804251668692992 )As of this writing, the new “IIC” clan battlemechs have been introduced. New players will obviously be able to follow how the community and PGI reacts to these new mechs but will be a great indicator of how things eventually work out in MW:O and what to expect from there on… so read the forums and both reddits to see and understand the kind of community you’re getting involved with.I’m not saying you should or shouldn’t play this game or put money into it, you should be old enough to make up your own mind about playing a game and what you consider “worth it.” Just don’t expect a lot of depth beyond what you get your first few games, and as far as PGI fixing things, if you stick around, get used to the word "Soon."

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
Intro/Cons:I know it says i only have about 68 hrs on record at the time of writing this review but i have been playing since closed beta and trust me this game has come a long way since then. One of the main issues however still persists and that is the outdated engine the game runs on. The cryengine is a very pretty engine however PGI don't quite know how to use it well. Don't let that stop you from picking up the game even if you have never heard of Battletech or Mechwarrior before you could still have some fun. The learning curve is a very steep one although not as steep as it was in the past, early on there was no tutorial to teach new players the basics.Pros:On to some of the good things about the game, the first being the incredibly generous F2P model this game has. You can play every single mech in the game for completely free kind of. The game operates under a "Chassis" system where every chassis is available for free, there are some exceptions such as newly released mechs those will be released for free shortly after however. There are special versions that offer C-Bill bonuses (the free currency, MC being the premium currency) as well as bonus to xp, those being Hero and Champion mechs. I won't get into too much detail because i am sure someone has explained it. Another great thing about this game is the fact that it get's updated every month at the very least as that is when they release new mech chassis into the game. This year they are also releasing a bunch of new weapons so this year is probably the best time to get into the game as everyone will be learning the new weapons and the meta will get shaken up quite a bit.All in all I would say pick it up try it out and if you don't like it feel free to right a negative review because even the community knows this game isn't perfect. However it's all we have right now until the next mechwarrior game comes out later this year in the form of Battletech.

												Been playing MWO since February 2013 so I've logged more hours into this game than anything else I've ever played. Despite what you might hear, the game has a come a long way and nails the feel of piloting giant walking tanks from the Battletech universe. Gameplay is both varied due to the different mech classes but can get repetitive because of the limited gamemodes. At times balance between items/mechs can be very frustrating but it is generally better than it has been in the past and it seems like they are making progress (despite it being slow). Evidently, despite my criticism and my hope for more content/features I enjoy the experience. My advice, find a unit, make some ingame friends and have some fun. The game really does come together when you start seeing teams working together.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												I have an Inner shere account, and a clan account, been playing 3 years spent 130 bucks, in an always online server side game.. Not bad ehh...Giant robots with tons of customization are the big plus in this game. When it comes to the Mech warrior games, as far as the pvp goes, this one has the best balance between the weight classes. Any class can take out any other which is a nice change from previous titles. The Balance between mechs though is a bit off, at least at this time so some mechs are just stronger than others. But the flip side of that with balance changes from time to time, the best mechs can and will change. The game like all PvP games has a pretty steep learning curve, but the people on the Offical MWO new player forums are very helpful so it is a good idea to ask questions, even if it's to say hi before ya even start.  The game like all online games, especially those that have not been around long. (to me 3 years is just a baby) It needs time to grow. I do find the game lots of fun, but will admit it does get repetitive due to limited game modes. But take a break for a week or month, and it feels fresh again for me.At this point in time there is  no single player which is unfortunate, but that is coming in the future, or so they say. We can only hope.It's free, nothing wrong with trying and seeing for yourself if it is for you.  One last thing, while the game does have micro transactions that seam pretty high, you can easily get by with spending 7-15 and buying mech bays, annd you can play a wide varriety at that point with just time played, and earning things in game. You can also earn tons of stuff durring events, and sales happen about twice a month on the weekends.  I spent about 100 bucks over the last 3 years and put a ton of time into it. Not a bad deal for an online game.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												So, Mechwarrior Online... is it great ? Is it Fun ?I have played all mechwarrior games released for PC (Mechwarrior series, MechCommander Series) and I must say, YES, it is FUN and YES it is great to play it, but I do recognize that it is not a game for everyone. Since it is a mix of first person shooter and a kind of simulation game, the leaning curve is quite high. It takes a while to ge use to it.Controls in MWO are, in my opinion, better than in the previous games. Much more fast and smooth to play. If you don´t know what Battletech is and never played anything from Mechwarrior, I still believe you should give it a try. You might like it. Do not enter this game expecting to have an opinion in a couple of hours. You got to play it for a while to really undesrtand if MWO is a game for you. Also, the matches have a flow, starts slow, get real frenzy by the midle and may stay like it till the end or slow down again. That is the game experience. One of the MWO videos says: a thinker man shooter. I do agree with that very much. It is not the king of game you run towards your enemy shooting. You got to understand  who is your enemy, whats his position and direction, how his mech is damaged, what weapons he got. All this makes a difference. You have to analise, think, than shoot. Also, team work is essential in this game. Play alone, die alone. A side note, when your mech gets destroyed in a match, you are down. No respawns. If you like huge mechs shooting each other, destructable parts (you can loose your arms, a leg and still be in the battle - how cool is that ?), have a more tactical experience, really... give it a try.There are two game modes (the second one called Faction play is best played when you join a UNIT).Also, the community is great, truly great.The only thing that is missing is a single player mode. Maybe in the future...

												This is by far, the best mech game in the MW series/BT Universe.  And aside from that, who doesn't like amazing graphics with even better gameplay?  For new players, it's definitely not a Pay-to-Win Game. (Never spent a dime on it)  It's easy to adapt to everything, because you customize virtually anything that you want.  This game has a great community and easy-to-learn controls, and the guides are there for you if you're a new player seeking for help.  Overall, this is a great game, and I recommend it to all of those people out there who like complete control over what they want to use (with weapons, mechs, extra modules, and etc.) and people who just enjoy hardcore realistic simulators or even FPS players.  It's quite challenging to get tired of a game that includes endless combinations for skins, weapons, and mechs.  I can guarantee you that you'll love it as much as I did the moment you've completed the tutorial and when you finish your first match.  (By the way, I also recommend to spend money on the game after you're used to the system and have a basic understanding of the game)

content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												I've never really followed Mechwarrior so I don't have an initial opinion on the series, but I am greatly enjoying this game. It's pretty easy to get the hang of with the great tutorial. You start with some free mechs that are really good. As you win matches you earn cash to purchase mechs that you can customize with different weapons depending on your playstyle. Buying a mech with real money is a shortcut, but doesn't provide any REAL benefits - just different mechs with different configurations (more lasers and less armor, jump jets vs rockets, etc). It's really fun, give it a try.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												I have an Inner shere account, and a clan account, been playing 3 years spent 130 bucks, in an always online server side game.. Not bad ehh...Giant robots with tons of customization are the big plus in this game. When it comes to the Mech warrior games, as far as the pvp goes, this one has the best balance between the weight classes. Any class can take out any other which is a nice change from previous titles. The Balance between mechs though is a bit off, at least at this time so some mechs are just stronger than others. But the flip side of that with balance changes from time to time, the best mechs can and will change. The game like all PvP games has a pretty steep learning curve, but the people on the Offical MWO new player forums are very helpful so it is a good idea to ask questions, even if it's to say hi before ya even start.  The game like all online games, especially those that have not been around long. (to me 3 years is just a baby) It needs time to grow. I do find the game lots of fun, but will admit it does get repetitive due to limited game modes. But take a break for a week or month, and it feels fresh again for me.At this point in time there is  no single player which is unfortunate, but that is coming in the future, or so they say. We can only hope.It's free, nothing wrong with trying and seeing for yourself if it is for you.  One last thing, while the game does have micro transactions that seam pretty high, you can easily get by with spending 7-15 and buying mech bays, annd you can play a wide varriety at that point with just time played, and earning things in game. You can also earn tons of stuff durring events, and sales happen about twice a month on the weekends.  I spent about 100 bucks over the last 3 years and put a ton of time into it. Not a bad deal for an online game.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23
												Mechwarrior Online should bring some really great feelings to those of you who grew up with the previous iterations or have a love for the Battletech universe. I believe that if you were looking for a giant robot simulator with competitive gameplay, this would be one that most closely feels like you are piloting a mech. There are some other games out there in this genre but they each bring something different to the table. I will really only talk about this one and I'll try keep it concise as possible. PROGRESSION: Mechwarrior Online provides you an entry into battle and allows you to earn in game credits in order to purchase new 'Mechs, or new Variants of the same mech. The current system at time of writing has 3 different tiers of Skill levels that you can unlock Passive bonuses to that 'Mech chassis. When you have unlocked all Tier 1 skills on 3 Variants of the same 'Mech, you unlock an Elite section of further bonuses. Unlocking all of those Elite bonuses on all 3 mechs will unlock an additional Module slot which allows you to add extra passive bonuses that can be earned, bought, or discovered from Supply Crates that are won during playing. The better you play, the more XP and Currency you earn. This enables you to unlock Module passives through the Pilot skill trees, as well as purchasing new weapons, new 'Mechs, and new Modules to equip. There are also several rotating "Trial" 'Mechs that you can pilot to get a feel for, but are unable to modify them in the Mechlab until you purchase one.MOVEMENT:The controls are not twitch based, though it is not slow, and depending on the size and weight of your 'Mech it will control much differently. Light 'Mechs are often lightly armored and speedy, built for scouting the front lines and providing target locks to the back line, and Assault 'Mechs are the heaviest, slowest, and largest with the most possible armor and weapon capacities. In between are Medium and Heavy respectively. Each has their own strengths, weaknesses, styles, and there are an incredible number of 'Mechs to choose from. You pilot the 'Mech like a tank where the top half can pivot and look around while you control the legs separately. This is all easily done with the WASD keys and a mouse, or you can play with the keyboard just like the old games.WEAPONS: 'Mechs come with specific hardpoints which limits the types of weapons and such that they can carry. These range from Ballistic to Missile to Energy weapons. You could have Variants of one 'Mech that offer different configurations and #'s of each of these or all one type. This allows different styles of gameplay while still using your favorite 'Mech. Missiles require a lock on target either by your own line of site, or another teammate "Locking On" for you. As long as a teammate has them targeted and visible, you and your team should be able to fire Long Range Missiles (LRM's) from the back line to whittle them down before engaging. Short Range Missiles will launch at much closer range, but do not require distance to become "Armed". Long Range Missiles will do little to no damage at close range in most situations.  Energy weapons consist of Lasers of Small, Medium, and Large variety. Within them are regular and Pulse as well as special Extended Range versions. Each of them has different damage, heat production, and cooldown time allowing for different playstyles. Ballistic weapons are often different types of cannons, or long range rifles. PPC's are a mix of Ballistic and Energy producing massive heat, but also high damage. SUMMARY: There is so much to talk about this game, but really if you want a giant robot fighting game with tons of customization, progression, teamwork, strategy, built in voice chat, and tons of fun please feel free to check it out! If you tell your team that you are just starting, they should give helpful pointers on how to stay alive, or which 'Mechs to shadow. At the very least, do what you can to support your Assault 'Mechs and make sure they can continue laying on damage to the enemy. There is also now a really great Tutorial and "Academy" missions you can access at anytime you think you need to brush up on Mechanics.I also encourage you to visit the No Guts No Galaxy podcast who streams from Twitch, has tons of Youtube videos of all the various 'Mechs, and also has it's own Discord server where people talk and group up for sessions of 'Mech warfare. Visit them @ www.twitch.tv/ngngtv and all their other social media links are there. See you on the Battlefield!

Quick rundown;If you like stompy mech vs mech combat, get this game. If you like customising things to fit your own playstyle, get this game.If you like fast battles where you can just jump in and play, don't get this game. If you are a die-hard fan of the Battletech Universe and think the best Mechwarrior title is MW:2 or MW:4 Mercs, then you probably don't want to play this game.The Good:Hot mech on mech actionVariety of maps, with more being added and old ones updatedCustomization (If you want to have a hot pink 100 ton mech that fires a rainbow of lasers, you can)ProgressionUpdates every monthThe matchmaking systemGrand scale community warefare featuring a persistant galaxyThe playerbaseThe Bad:The PlayerbaseThe Matchmaking systemLopsided balance (will be somewhat fixed reletively soon)Slower gameplayThe Ugly:The Playerbase"Meta"Prepare yourself for happiness, rage, and confustion.New player experience; "Warning, Incoming Missiles"Mid level experience; "Center-Torso Critical Damage"High level experience; "Target Destroyed"

												I remember back when MWO was in early beta, for me it was crap back then, but now I really enjoy myself. Let me just say there are not enought mech vs. mech fighting games that put you into mock battles against players so when I decided to try this game out again as an avid AC fan I had to adjust to the slow more tactical movements and gameplay that make this game really enjoyable. Though I still have one issue with the game and that is that besides faction and quickplay there is litterally no other way to play the game  (that I know of so far) and the wait to find a match is bloody long! They need to use the matchmaking system that 90% of fps games use (I.e. The pick a game type then when in game lobby pick map etc.) because half the time after waitng for 4 minutes to find a game in quickplay I got bored and signed out to play some other game. But if they fix this feature IMO the game would be 100x better.P.s. Hunchback for the win!

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												The game borders between fun and rage-inducing. It hits so many elements of the mechwarrior universe on point but lacks some of the most important things that makes mechwarrior stand out from any other deathmatch game. Bases aren't bases. They aren't massive round dropships surrounded by a perimeter of turret defenses, repair bays, and vital facilities/objectives. No, your base is just a martian rover with a capture zone. Clan Wars, an attack/defense game mode, is so horribly broken that practically no one plays it. The recent updates to it just made it worse. Limitations on mech selection AND the obliterate-the-entire-team artillary aside, much of it can be attributed to bad map layout.I credit this game for being balanced. It has a massive selection of weapons, mechs, and equipment - free mechs, and mechs that cost over $50. Yet, you can still gain an edge over the cash-flush players with skills and the right loadout.But you can also BLATANTLY CHEAT with macros. Somehow this is still allowed! Exploit the game and alter your weapon firing rates using outside, third-party software to input commands into the game. Defenders of this say "it doesn't affect dps" or the advantage is negligable. It's still an attempt to gain an advantage and it alters the way the game was originally intended to be played. Make whatever excuses you want, you're cheating. I'm not too worried about these people because they're terrible and that's why they use macros in the first place.So is the game still fun? Yes, but only in QuickMatch mode. And only if you're lucky enough to not get stuck on a team full of complete pansies who hide behind rocks, fail to recognize enemy tactics, or offer strategy suggestions long after the opportunity to act has passed.The game looks and sounds good, is in continuous development - with new content frequently coming out, and can be fun with the right group of players. So, it's a love/hate thing.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												2 years experienced player, MechWarrior Online was the first title I came to on PC after being a five year long console gamer and it soon became the one single game I play on a regular basis. After my first year of casual play, I started to become a more competetive player and I became a spender on this title. I didn't feel like I needed to spend money on Mechs to be able to enjoy the game, I just decided I wanted to support the devs since this game felt like a major step up from the direction console gaming has been going in. As far as pay-to-win goes, you can pay to speed up progression with premium time, but that's about as far as it goes, everything else is mostly cosmetic or timed (exclusive with the exception of Hero Mechs), it's up to you wether that crosses the line or not.The dev team is very open with community feedback and does a fair job of keeping players up to date with their plans to improve the game, so there's almost always some new features to look forward to in the regular updates/patches. Gameplay wise, this is a very competetive title and a lot of information to take in and learn about. If you enjoy having long term thinking and strategic decision making in your shooters, this is for you. The learning curve is steep, but very enjoyable when you start to apply your knowledge in game as you fight your battles and even more fun is when you play with a group of friends and communicate information between one another.Overall, a unique and in-depth shooter experience and a nice change of pace from the usual fast paced run and gun type shooters most of us are used to from Triple A titles. Definitely recommended to give it a try and at the cost of free, all you have to lose is a couple hours you spend trying it out.

number of helpful: 87 of 180 people (48%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Oh, I forgot to mention this but it's important, the game has no aimbot detection. At all.Mechwarrior Online is a game plagued with problems. I backed and founded the game based on the strength of the franchise, but I'm going to bring up any of my personal disappointments and the only mention of the Transverse fiasco will be right here. I'm giving this game a negative review for a few reasons, but if current trends continue I may choose to recommend the game instead.PGI, when's the Flea coming out? It's been nearly two years since you announced it and MASC exists now. To whoever has the job of moderating the negative reviews, at least pass this question along when you moderate my review into oblivion.With this review I mostly wanted to point out that the game typically goes months without anything resembling a balance update. MWO also features a few HIDDEN mechanics specifically designed to punish new players who don't know about it. That mechanic is colloquially known 'Ghost Heat,' which causes your BattleMech to gain additional (and often excessive) amounts of heat if you fire more than an arbitrary number of one type of weapon. This is never explained anywhere in game, and while the game does have a 'heat warning' that pops up in the mechlab if you've taken too many of one type of weapon that warning is small and easy to miss.Up until about a month ago (over a year after MWO's launch) MWO was also completely without a tutorial, and the typical 'new player experience' was 'pick a trial `Mech at random, die three or four times without really understanding why, and uninstall the game.' If you didn't have a friend to show you the ropes or warn you about Ghost Heat or several of the other 'traps' (like LRMs currently being absolutely terrible weapons due to their slow speed, scattered damage, and tendency to ram into the nearest wall) you weren't going to make it very far.This has changed, the tutorial is actually pretty nice, and there are some bonuses to help new players buy a BattleMech quickly so they can start customizing and using actually good weapons and the latest balance patch (the first one in MONTHS) has brought back a close-range brawling playstyle that's actually quite fun, but that doesn't change the fact that all of this was done immediately before the Steam launch and that the buffs to close-range weapons will almost certainly be reverted.The real-money cost of BattleMechs is also completely absurd. They could cost a quarter what they do now and they'd still be expensive for a free-to-play game. An Assault BattleMech in MWO costs  Coupled with the fact that new releases often aren't balance-tested and aren't available for in-game currency for months after release means that new `Mechs are often pay-to-win, and due to the high prices (often approaching the cost of a AAA game for a `Mech pack or even a single Assault-weight BattleMech) this means that players who aren't shoveling their money directly into the furnace often become the punching bags of the players who are.You also, and this is a real killer for me, have to spend real money on Mechbays (at around $1.38 per bay) to even buy a `Mech at all. Now, the MC cost of a Mechbay ultimately isn't that high, but it's another 'hidden' cost slowly nickel-and-diming the userbase to death.MWO is a game best played with friends, and individual matches can be enjoyable once you get a handle on things. But the learning curve is steep even with a tutorial and you'll often waste tons of in-game C-Bills just trying things out. If you do play, my only advice is to save the 'Cadet Bonus' you earn over the course of your first 25 matches and buy a 55-ton Stormcrow. It's one of the most efficient `Mechs in the game and has access to the more powerful Clan versions of all the weapons, and will probably always be a good workhorse for grinding C-Bills in since it's fast enough to get to the fight and fast enough to get itself out of trouble.Once you've learned what 'trouble' actually looks like.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												I backed this game in 2012 due to my love of battletech. A love that this game has poisoned.As a gamer, is this a terrible game? No. It sorta works, there is some fun to be had here. The F2P model is terrible, its grindy and expensive. Worse than wargaming games. But if you throw away some money and grind forever, it can be fun. Sadly, the whole 'outfit your mech' doesnt work well here. You generally have to set your mech up with whatever flavor of the month builds are working to be competitive. If you end up wasting your hard earned cash on the wrong part and/or mech, you're in for a bad time. Even some of the paid stuff is garbage.As a battletech game, it is blasphemy. Nothing is right about this game, the devs know nothing about battletech. They just jumped on the license, hired someone else to make this game.. then fired those guys and went on to milk battletech fans for their money. Now they are here to milk you for your money. Seriously, go watch some of their videos. They are canadian car salesmen, not programmers or gamers. Ultimately, I hate this game, I hate the devs, and I hate the spineless legion of white knights who hold this turd up in the spotlight. Most positive reviews will come from these guys, they are all 500+ dollars in and they desperately do not want the game to die. They want you to play and will say anything to get you to play. They are sad broken people, and if you do get sucked into scam warrior online you will end up sad and broke as well.UPDATE: Just to be sure i tried the steam version. Some things are better than i remember, some things are worse. The most dissapointing issue is that groups of 2 are still put against groups of up to 9+. So if you want to play with just one friend, you are doomed to constant and quick defeats. And no, the devs will not fix this. This is INTENTIONAL. They are feeding you to their whales who have dropped $1000's into this game.Also the time to kill is way too low. You spend 90% of the time loading, and walking to the spot where you will die. This is not a "thinking mans" shooter.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												When I think of mechwarrior or battletech in general, I think of MechWarrior 4 Mercenaries. In my opinion and in the opinion of many others, the best mechwarrior game made period. This is not that. First of all it is F2P and P2W, I mean, you can earn the mechs and weapons the old fashioned way but this is going to mean a lot of work and grinding with and against people you do not like. This I think spoiles the point. The next major problem for me is that this is multiplayer. Multiplayer for me is a hinderance beacause 9 times out of 10, you are stuck playing against either the screaming 12 year old or that guy who sunk $100+ into the game to get everything and roflestomps everyone with one shot. Then there are the cheaters. This has all three which make the gameplay well, suck. The other problem with this is that there is no blasted story! In a universe that is as story rich as battletech, why can't the devs find or make up an epic story for this? All of the other games had a kick♥♥♥♥♥story, I referance you to all three mechwarior 4 games and mechwarrior 3 and the mechcommander games, and so on and so on. So much material that was not used, what a shame. And this brings me to the final hammerblow for me on this game. Take in the following characteristics, pay to win, glamorous graphics, and lazy or even non existant story writing and a lack of SP. What this game is, is  a money grab that is trying to pan-handle to the Call of Duty and Battlefield crowds to just make a quick buck. Whether or not this money is actually put into a future game that is worth playing or not is unknown but rather unlikely unfortunatly.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												I have been playing this game for over 3 years and decided to write this short review to warn people who are not into Battletech about this game.Before you start playing, mind the following:- the game is still in a beta stage in some ways (bugs, unfinished features, core features missing or badly implemented)- PGI (the developer) is more interested in your money than in delivering a good game (although the permanently claim the opposite)- PGI does not do much against cheaters and even does not react when they are presented proof (and there are too many cheaters)- the overall frustration level in MWO is quite high, especially if you are new to the game- since the player base is quite small for an MMO, the match-finding times can be very high (> 15min) for the main game mode- balance in match-making and concerning the BattleMechs and their weapons is not nearly as good as it could beSo why am I still playing this game and why did I give it a positive rating?- I am a Battletech fan and there simply is no other recent MechWarrior game- It's a good team-based game that favors working together over playing as a lone-wolf - It's NOT pay-to-win and to be an outstanding player, you need many skills (being a good shot is not enough!)Long story short: play if you are a Battletech fan, try if you like team-based games with substance, ignore it if you're expecting a mainstream game à la Call of Duty or Star Wars Battlefront.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												I'm gonna write this negative review, and then not reply to ANYONE that whishes to whiteknight this turd for no reason other than the fact that, in their hearts, they wish that they were space nazis with no parents.Look, I was there.  I played this game on a table top, where company-level games between two players took an hour for one turn, and I loved it.  I played many incarnations of Mechwarrior on the PC, from Cresent Hawks Inception the Mechwarrrior 4, and I loved it.  I was there in the early days of closed beta, when we still had all the goodies that Cryengine 3 could deliver, like inverse kinematics and all that, and I loved it.Now, like three years later, after launching a beta product as a general release, after not having more than two game modes between pick up death match and community warfare (and don't come back and say that there are three game modes in public death match, they all boil down to skirmish in the end), I have absolutely no reason to believe that this product is anything more than a shameless cash grab aimed at the absolute bottom of the gamer community, one that thought that the previous games were too "hard" or too "niche", as made by a developer that has a track record of making bare-bones minimum viable products, or as we like to call it for short, SHOVELWARE.This guy Russ, whom I hope I can run into in real life on the streets of Seattle one day just so I can cry in his face about how he♥♥♥♥♥♥♥one of my favorite IPs and got away with it, is so desperate for good reviews he has to beg players to start Steam accounts just so they can thumbs up this crap even if they have no intention of playing it on Steam, is nothing more than a craven raider of popular titles, and he figured he hit some real pay dirt with the Battle Tech license, didn't you Russ?TLDR; This is a beloved robot combat simulator dumbed down into a mediocre arcade shooter, play if you want, but try not to spend any money on it.  That is the one good point, you don't have to spend money on it if you are patient and have very little life outside videogames.

number of helpful: 10 of 23 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												The basic problems of the game is the same as with almost every free to play game on the steam marketplace: You might have some fun, but you're at a competitive disadvantage to anyone with a credit card powerup. You could have the best reflexes, great internet, great computer, intelligence and deep skill... but one swipe of the card and it's meaningless. This is a pay to win game, like all the others. Below, I'll explain the particulars of how this game executes the model. .Your first 25 matches give you huge amounts of 'c-bills', the main in-game currency. But after that, regardless of how good you are, you won't make more than 200k per match. Realistically, you can expect to make 50-130k, depending on skillset and build choices for your mech.  Most of the mechs you will want cost about 8-16mil for the chassis. Triple that to fit it up decently. A match will run you about 18 minutes a pop, assuming you are doing it during peak hours -- the queue times can be in the minutes range outside of that window, and 85% of the player base is N. American.  So the breakdown is, you can blow 5 hours a night and get in about 15 matches during that. That'll give you about 1.5mil. So basically, once a week you can afford to get another mech. There are about a hundred. And there are an average of about 4 variations for each. To use them well, you need to buy 3 of each chassis, and skill them up. The goal here is to get a set of 4 mechs that you can use to bring to community warfare; So you will need to grind a minimum of 12 mechs, selling 8 of them, to accomplish this. That's about 3 months of grinding every night, 5 hours a night, to be competitive in community warfare..Which brings me to our next problem: Community warfare without a dozen friends is like going to a sausage party. Those few who do this make millions of c-bills an hour grinding out maps. Everyone else is just scrubs -- no matter how good you are, you're going to lose. And that's the main selling point of the game over previous mechwarrior games. So you either spend 3 months grinding so you can have a *chance* at winning -- and the load out that one of those aforementioned groups will take you in on -- or you whip out your credit card and take the express lane to the desert of community warfare..By desert, I mean... there are a couple matches every hour during peak times. If you just want to play with random strangers who have no idea what they're doing, and will often suicide themselves just to get to the next match faster... you can skip community warfare. But if that kind of playstyle is aggravating to you, and teamwork is what you really want to be a part of, this is the best mechwarrior online has to offer. .And it ain't much.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												I played this a bunch when it was new. It recently arrived on Steam and I elected to pick it up again to see if it had changed any over the years. On a technical level, the game is pretty decent. It's visually pleasing, plays smooth, has excellent balance and controls that can be picked up quickly. THere are a few bugs that pop up from time to time, but mostly they are contained to the tutorials and control mapping. Joystick support seems like a cruelly halfwitted afterthought due to how much more simplified and twitch-response oriented the game has become over the years, but the game otherwise plays like a slightly clumsy FPS with a usual mouse and keyboard. But there's something significant that it's missing. I can't quite put my finger on it, but allow me to try to explain. The whole thing consists of nothing but an endless series of pick-up fights lasting less than 10 minutes each on average, with exactly zero control over the scenario beyond "Which chassis do I want to use (which you pick before you know where and what you're going to play) and do I want to be a commander or not".  Game types are semi-randomized, as are maps. You play for hours on end and the only thing you feel is fatigue; you don't really feel like you've accomplished anything. The devs have done an acceptable job of keeping the game off of a pay-to-win scale, which has really become more of a pay-to-not-grind system. WHile this is an improvement, to be certain, it still feels hollow. I used to play MechWarrior 4 competitively. This was obviously a long time ago, and the game feels less like a simulator now and more like a MOBA with robots. If youy are among the multitudes who love MOBAs, you should give it a try. It's free, it's easy and quick to pick up, and certainly offers a huge number of possibilities. It's just that, like DotA, like Smite, like LoL, there's no story to speak of and none of those possibilities really feels even remotely meaningful.

number of helpful: 9 of 21 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												A good deathmatch game for those who enjoyed the mech combat side of previous mechwarrior titles. It offers the best online mech vs. mech combat of any game so far but it is not without its flaws. If you are looking for a deep campaign system with role-playing and long-term strategic planning then you should probably look elsewhere. However if you enjoy good old giant stompy robots blowing the %#!@ out of each other in arena settings then this  probably a good game to try for free, especially if you have played other similar titles such as World of Tanks or Armored Warfare.Pros• The most deep and detailed mech combat system of any online mech game.  It is very fun once you understand what you are doing and it's the primary reason so many players stayed through the bugs and flaws of the original game. • There is a huge range of mechs and a very deep customization system that offers a lot of options for tinkerers and collectors.• The game should feel familiar and easy to pick up for those who have played games like World of Tanks.  In addition the grind and financial aspects of the game are considerably less. • The game rewards skill. Paying money can save you time and give you more mechbays, but it will not give you any significant advantage over other players.  • The first mechwarrior title since 1989 that has actually included the original 3025 battlemechs. • Despite considerable changes from the tabletop, it is the closest any mechwarrior title (to this date) has been to replicating its feel and tactics. • In comparison with other online games, the community tends to be more mature and friendly on average.   • You can play on any of the worldwide servers (North America, Europe, Southeast Asia / Oceania) with the same account. Cons• Despite the grind being considerably less than other similar titles, it is still present.• The game runs on cryengine3  which is not the most stable or efficient of online platforms. • The game still has a number of minor bugs and balance issues to be fixed and the developers are often slow to react to this.• Outside of arena battles the game doesn't offer much of a campaign mode. The community warfare mode (still in beta at the time of this review) is fun for short periods but it hasn't been developed nearly enough to be considered a fully functional feature. • Because it is a heavily skill focused game, the game also punishes making bad decisions. This can make it more difficult for people who just want to play casually and not worry about using their best mechs all the time. • The game uses an inefficient matchmaking system that results in longer wait times than necessary.

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												Review from someone playing since Open Beta:In its current state: 7.5 / 10This game is good and fun, not balls-to-the-wall astonishingly amazing, but it has the potential to reach those levels.Fact is, at the moment, this is the only Battletech game we've got, and It's a damn decent one. ** A word of warning about the bad reviews: Many of these are salty old players who have not taken ANY time to re-examine the current state of the game** /end warning----Visual/Audio------Audio - 8/10  Sound design could be a bit beefier, I'm actually a fan of the audio that USED to be in the game (weapon SFX and stuff). I've always been hoping for dynamic music that changes based upon your situation, but that's a pipedream. What we have now is pretty good nonetheless.Visuals - 7/10 I'm not someone who cares about the highest quality textures, details, etc... BUT they could be better, plus the game is poorly optimized. I find it hard to believe the reccommended specs on the Store Page. The game used to look much better, search for screenshots, but performance was worse.------Gameplay------Teamwork is key in this game, afterall, there is no FFA. If you lonewolf expexting to kill lots of things, you'll be dissappointed. Use voip, use chat, move with your team. This is slower than Hawken, and certainly much different from your average resoawn-die-respawn-die twitch shooters. It really is a "thinking man's shooter" You have to think who to shoot, when to shoot, where to shoot on them, IF you even SHOULD shoot, have situational awareness, be aware of heat, weapon mounts, target locks, friendly location...the list goes on. Teamwork is key in this game, afterall, there is no FFA. If you lonewolf expexting to kill lots of things, you'll be dissappointed. Use voip, use chat, move with your team. All in all: blasting mechs feels fun.------The Grind--------Certainly not a grindy as other F2P games out there, but there is still a grind. That being said, it is now MUCH better than it used to be, with increased ingame rewards, and Faction Play paying out much more than it used to. Grinding for mechs becomes addicting (for me anyway). ------Pricing--------Yes, DLC, MC, and mech packs (for real money) are expensive. They have been, and I don't think that will change. The main reason people spend money on this game is because they have cash to burn, or people like me, who want to see the Battletech IP survive to fight another day. It is good to know that Steam DLC can go on sale. All in all, if you are a fan of Battletech, or big stompy robots, you owe it to yourself to give this game a try. I like it, you might too.
