content:
Posted: December 14, 2015
												An awesome continuation of the famouse Mech Warrior francise.The game feels good, a mid-level gaming laptop can handle it on almost highest settings at a solid 60fps, and it seems to be free to play with some microtransactions for visual change.The developers are constantly doing events that give a lot of rewards, including some that you can get only using real money. New mechs are added every month or so, with the huge patches that improve, or fix issues in the game(performance or otherwise).There are also some other small flaws, like alt-tabbing and when getting back to the game and press shift it opens the steam cloud window(aparently it saves keys pressed), and some of the mechs from my favorite MW3 are not here(yet) *cry*.Overall a great game that you should give it at least a few days of play!

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 2
												As one of the original 'Founders' I wish I could recommend this game, but it should be avoided in its current state.The major problems that I face with this game is that after 4 years of development it feels like its in Early Access/Beta. Where the devs dont fully seem to grasp the I.P they have. Changes made to the game usually seem ill thought out and never fully implemented. It's common to buy a new Mech Pack but for it's stats to be nerfed a few months later, community feedback is often ignored.This game does not have a Campaign, and lacks any decent missions. At present you have two mods, a quick play mode and a Faction Warfare mode where you can bring four mechs to Battle. However, the game lacks substance.And worst of all, there is a growing toxic community to this game. Although a team based game you will feel the urge to turn off VOIP due to some of the more toxic elements of the community.This game has great potential, and maybe in 4 years time that potential could be realised, but until then stay clear and find something else to enjoy.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												I've played this game a couple hundred hours since it was in beta.  I'm glad this is on Steam now because I've had problems with the standalone client when trying to move between hard drives or updating operating system.I would describe it like a cross between an FPS and tank battle sims.  You can shoot and destroy individual components on enemy mechs which destroys any weapons or loadout items stored in them. There are a few things you can buy which give advantage like special consumables or specific mechs which let you earn currency faster (but they mostly aren't top tier mechs), but honestly it doesn't make enough of a difference to detract from gameplay and doing well without them is no issue if you have a good loadoutHeavy mechs have the best balance of firepower and mobility and are the most popular.  Assault mechs have the most firepower and armor but have awful mobility. For new players medium mechs might be best to get used to the controls (my personal fav mech is a specific medium mech with a ton of hardpoints that makes it like a glass cannon). Light mechs are the hardest to use but can be gamechanging in the hands of a veteran for component sniping, taking down damaged or overextended mechs and point capturing.Different weapons include hitscan lasers of various range and type, ballistic cannons, railguns for sniping, close and long range missiles, electronic warfare.If you're new google the smurfy mechlab to play test loadouts and look up Meta Mechs for mech tier lists and some good loadouts to get you started. Also look up theB33f on youtube for some funny MWO vids

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												This is an arena shooter/semi-simulation in the style of the mechwarrior games of old, I've played mechwarrior games since the first one in the 1990's and if you're thinking of trying it, try it for 25 matches for real its worth that for sureLikes:Tons of Mechs to choose from with ingame currency you earn from matches, the dollar bill mechs just gain more exp or ingame currency, similar to WoT without being stronger than what you can buy(in many cases weaker lol)Tons of personal customization in the Mechlab, where you outfit your walking tanks with weapons and equipment of your choiceFirst 25 matches you earn enough to buy a few decent mechs with the tutorial because of a starter bonusDislikes:I was a founder of this game 3 years ago and the original company that handled the developers was horrible, luckily a year ago that relationship ended and things have gotten better and betterCan be hard for new players to learn how to move a walking tank around, its not hawken/counterstrike FPS, more elements of a flight simulator come to mindIts a Arena shooter, a great fallback free to play game imo, but it makes you want the experience that mechwarrior 4 had

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												I have played this game since open  Beta in 2012, over 5000 matches.  It has slowly evolved over that time and continues to evolve.  I appreciate the fact that I can play the game and have fun despite my lack of twitch skills.  It is a bit daunting for new players, especially if you don't have and background in the Battletech universe, but there is a good community behind this and lots of help to be found online.I have spent more time in this game than any other, probably by a factor of 10 in 30 years of gaming.  I have never felt the need to spend money on this game.  I have spent money because I wanted to pay back the devs for the hours of entertainment I have gotten out of the game.  The devs have also been generous with free content over the last 3 years.Play this game if you want a deep tactical experience which allows for many different play styles and ability levels.

content:
Posted: February 27
												831 Hours, 60 FPS, 110ms ping in game. 24ms by my ISPTrashy hit scanning (Damaging front of mech from behind and Vis Versa) not even close. Biggest issue and still current.The ignored key presses, or GUI button clicks is the worst. It's like it just didnt "go through". Second biggest issue and still current.Powerful teleportation, I see mechs jump jetting then fall three times through the air only to be rubberbanded back up into the air and fall again. Still current.Lasers sometimes go through things. (Mountains, mechs, whatever.)Lasers sometimes DONT go through things. (Empty spaces near any post, mountain, or building.) *A little bit fixed but still exists heavily in some areas*Very often just how twisted your upper body is will not be server side. So players still damage vital exposed parts even though on your screen they are hidden. *all the time now*Microstutters from poor server performance/communication makes full damage lasers impossible.Good con = full damage lasers, more spread out damage from accurate torso twistingBad con = be a superior player, memorize map spots, and be psychic.Loading in to garage takes forever!Everything here is true and accurate as of 2/27/17

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												I've been playing off and on since closed beta as a top level founder. I've been a fan of the PC games for decades and honestly, this game partially scratched that itch for me. The game has some amazing shining moments, and some glaring problems, and from it's inception each of those things have changed. In it's current state, I can't imagine starting this game without investing money into it. As a FTP it is a very hard game to find yourself immersed in. Unforgiving play, steep learning curve, and pug play doesnt have the networking required for people to garner skill.As someone who would want to invest actual money into the game, play FTP first, and talk to people who have been playing for a long time before sinking money in to particular mechs.I would only recommend this game to hardcore fans of the PC games (and would want to point out that it plays different, and better than them). Possibly hardcore fans of the battletech game and universe.

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												Pros: Good Fun & Simple Stupid Shooter people pretend to have tactics in to make them feel like like they are strategic.Cons: Completley Garbage UI, jumbled assets with no order, randomly ordered set of skills, unmannagable menu, bad music, limited and completely crap hardpoints made by people that never played Mech Warrior, Confusing Interface Menu, Bad Garrage, Bad optimisation, Aim Bots, No Anti-Cheat, Pay-to-Win for sure, Mechs not based on Tons just Hardpoints, Goofy "Skills" that are really just equipment, Bad Weapon Sounds, Overly Grinding if you dont buy a Premium, Terrible Looking Cockpits, Bad Graphics Overall, Everything is Death Match. No cheat protection either so tons of people hack and cheat all day.Note: This game has the stupidest people on the planet playing in it. This is ment in the most litteral sense one can imagine. Every third person suffers from Aspergers, torrets, or some form of fetal alcohol syndrome in MWO. Cowards are abundant. Cowards hide in clusters behind one building and NEVER win a match. Its a fact that if you are agressive in an FPS game, and want to destroy a team of people hiding in a cluster behind a building that are sharing stories about their toenail polish, that you will win. (If you see people acting like they are digga-digga, talking like a Hue-Hue from Texas, or hiding in one tight group behind the same building or hill, you should instantly charge out into the enemy and kill yourself. You should do this with 100% certainty that the match is not in your favor from the start and your team will fail. Die, leave the match, select another mech, and play again. It will save you time and fustration in the long run, I assure you.)The only real problem I see is how slow this game is and how many aim botters there are. It takes a long bit of time to find a match in Faction type settings. In quick play, you dont really do much besides shoot and kill. There are objective missions, but they dont really end up being more than brawls anyhow which is EXACTLY what I like about Mech Warrior. I hated escort missions so anything other than those is a welcomed presence in the Mech Warrior Universe.Mech combat feels fine like mech combat. I will say the weapons are all VERY low damage in this game VS weapons from the 'actual' Mech Warrior games. Ever crit with an Gauss or ER-PPC to someones head in a game? They die. In MWO, that wont really happen. Its impossible, in fact, to one shot even light mechs with a million cred weapon. Which makes everytihing a fun little fight, albeit dragged out extensively. The game is mostly timesink but it doesnt really destroy the fun too much.The layout is a confusing b1tch. I dont really think these guys worked too hard on menus or directions/hints of where everything was located. You have (if you are new to the game) a long long time ahead of you sorting through how to navigate the menus and where everything is. Id say about an hour, and even then I suspect you will be sorting through it long after that as you discover this and that. The menu almost feels like a game itself...choose your own adventure?Im very critical about games. I can say that if you dont like death match, Mech Brawling, and non-escort type combat, then this is better suited for shelfing or avoiding.If you like such games, then this is for you. Works great with track IR and Mech-Joystick configs. Also works with VR.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												Hello MechWarriors!I decided to share my expirience from playing MWO for almost 3 years. This game isn't easy one and it was even harder back then. It's learnig curve is steep. For 1st week I was able to play for 30 minutes a day and rage quit after being wasted so quick in 100 ton Atlas. But I love Battletech so next day I was coming back to learn how to pilot trial 'mechs (3 years ago trials were stock 'mechs without good equipment, very very frustrating expirience. Now you have Champion trials that are almost meta equiped). After 25 metches with Cadet Bonus I had enougt C-Bills to buy my first own 'Mech. I decided to go for Stalker 85 ton assault 'mech and it was good decision because I still play Stalkers today and totaly love this chasis. This is how my adventure with this game started.Soon I realized I like this game so much I woudl like to suport developers with $$$ and boost my c-bills account so I decided to buy my first hero 'mech with 30% earning bonus. I found Flame (heavy Dragon 'mech) to be intresting back then but I don't recomend it now ;).Then I met nice people by killing them first and than teaming with them next drop and real fun started. This game teastes better when played with funy/crazy people and voice chat. So see you on the battlefield!

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												The game is fun, buying with RL money can get expensive quickly if you let yourself go. I have 2 different mechs. 3 Variants of each and im having plenty of fun though. You get to run about 3 different trial mechs of each weight class to see what you like running. Light, medium, and heavy play very differently. I felt a bit underpowered in a trial mech but most of that was not knowing my ranges and how i needed to approach enemies. I could do fine in one now. The biggest thing about starting with a free trial mech is you cant change the build and that to me is where a lot of the fun lies. Most startup builds on a mech are garbage. I ended up buying one of the steam packs and it was ok. I wish I would have just bought a mastery pack for like 28 bucks instead from the Mechwarrior website. My drawback comes from the pricing of all the content. The game should be one of the best games on the market if people are paying those prices for everything. There is a page like others have said with a 500 dollar gold mech. If you charge 500 bucks for basically a look on a character, bot, whatever, the bottom line is you are most definitely a money grabbing SOB. Soooo I say if you like mechs and big♥♥♥♥♥lasers and feeling like a badass pilot every time your rig fires up go for it. If you have trouble controlling your spending on extra content and you have that itch when you see something on a market that looks cool as hell and you have to have it and you can't force down that wallet hand stay away... as far away as you can possibly get.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7
												As a Battletech board game player I was curious to see the FPS online version and in 2 weeks I was negatively impressed by this game. I have 30 hours on record of which 1, maybe 2 were played and 28 wasted between loading times, watching others play, and trying to find a match. I've mistakenly bought a Clan Mech with the light mech package but then picked an Inner Sphere Career and I could never use it... Piranha refused to reimburse me for a mech I can't use and can't sell. They didn't even give me the credits back to buy a different mech with. It's totally absurd.Out of a hundred matches, my team (inner sphere) may have won 10 at best... index of a poor conversion in balancing between the IS and Clan pros/cons. I have possibly experienced the worst netcode in the world (beats Battlefield 4 and says it all) and on top of that, there's apparently no anticheating protection (Punkbuster). I cannot explain in any other way the impossible things that take place in combat... where a medium mech can take dozens of hits from me and my teammates then kill me in an assault mech with just 2 hits. ... and it happens all the time.The system is apparently evolving around credits (split in 3 different components) with which you buy modules, weapons and other goodies. This means the new player is at complete disadvantage against more experienced players not for a matter of skill, tactics and experience but by sheer mech quality difference: It means to be at disadvantage for MONTHS against your opponents, no matter how well you play or which mech you're using.I am not going to waste my time to get on par with other players in a game that starts with these premises, especially after Piranha behaved like that with me. Saying my evaluation is below negative is an understatement.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												Let's just get this out of the way right here, right now: this game is *hard.* Hard to understand for most folks, hard to play by the same, and most definitely hard to fully and truly master. If you love giant freakin' robots with lasers, giant guns, and rockets pouring out the ears, this'll be your cup of tea for sure.But if you're going the free-to-play route, you're going to have an uphill slog ahead.See, buying any pack of 'mechs whatsoever gives you a leg-up on getting the purchased 'mechs mastered. If you've read the reviews of some other players, you'll know what this means: getting three variants of the same 'mech chassis, just to grind experience on them so you can unlock all their upgrades on the skill tree in order to up their performance in the field. And MWO is going to be one hell of a grindfest; you'll be grinding for C-Bills to purchase new 'mechs, grinding those 'mechs in the field so you can get their performance upped, and grinding General XP so you can unlock beneficial modules that'll keep you on the game and competitive.Trust me when I say that just cause' my record *says* so many hours, it's oh so much more than that. And let's just say that I was on well before they introduced Trial 'mechs that were "optimized" (read: upgraded and given a weapons loadout that compliments them).All in all you really should go in loving giant stompy war machines in order to get any mileage out of this game. And start learning to be sociable too: you'll want to be in a group of players you trust and play beside frequently in order to pierce the heavy metal veil that is Community Warfare. To those of you interested and playing; keep at it and don't give up. Bite the bullet and keep at the controls. Oh, and hit the academy, the lessons'll help a lot. Because after all this struggle, the first time you core an enemy Assault 'mech after a hard fight against it? It's likely gonna feel like an accomplishment, like you yourself managed to bring down a titanic 80+ ton bipedal war machine of death and destruction. Yes, even if you had help from your teammates!Now for the record: I recommend you *try* MWO at least before you judge it, as in *really* try it. Don't just struggle through a few matches, give up, and delete it from your Steam library either; like I said, it takes time to get used to this circus and the troupe of monkeys (BattleMechs) you need to train.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												When the game first showed up couple of years ago, I tried it out with high expectations as a big BattleTech fan, and fan of massive robots in general. It didn't work out. Game was removed within few weeks.Then, about two months ago, I saw someone streaming it on Twitch (thanks Gimpy21!), and decided to give it one more shot - it's been a long time. And oh boy, did things change (for the better). TL;DR - This is as much fun with 'mechs as one could have at the moment, and that says a lot. Mind you, this game does require you to think more than rely on your reflexes and mouse DPI, and is most definitely not your regular FPS. Each mech is special, and it might take a long time to get accustomed to various options, loadouts - even before digging into what's meta. Experiment, have fun with stompy mechs, and know that your mechs WILL get killed MANY times. However, each time you get to learn what went wrong, and you can't wait to begin firing alphas again (no, seriously, don't do that as a newbie ;)).I encourage new players to visit official forums for incredibly helpful guides, and aside from written stuff there are plenty of embedded YouTube tutorials to help anyone and everyone - if you decide to dive in. Ignore the toxic comments, and enjoy many mature players who are there to help you out and have fun with mechs.Highly recommended title - feel free to ask for any details I might be able to answer. Tip: As a newbie and without a group of teammates, avoid playing Faction portion of the game (Community Warfare) at the very start. Also avoid buying mechs/mech packs with real money until you've gotten a good grip of what style and chassis you like to play. Also bear in mind that you really don't have to pay a single cent of the real money to progress in this game and buy mechs, nor does paying real money for mechs make you play better in any way.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												Played the Game from Closed Beta. This is one of those game you will have a Love / Hate relationship with. It had Lots of Lore to it. By Lore I'm it started out as a Pen and Paper Table top game back in the Mid 1980's, Tons of Rules book, Novels, a Cartoon. All based  in BattleTech, Mechwarrior is a Very small Part of a Much Bigger Universe game wise. There are two Tech Faction to the game Inner Sphere (I.S.) and the Clans. (You will want to Learn the Differences  in them) There are 6 I.S. factions in game, And 4 Clans Factions. So it a 10 Way war. Solo queues you only have other Solo Player with in 2 Tiers of you. (Tier 5 being the Lowest, Tier 1 being the highest)PGI has been working very hard to keep the game Balanced. So there are always Minor changes happen to gear & Mechs to help bring them inline if Over Powered or Under Powered. Many People will claim it pay to win every time a New Mech is add to the game this is False. Here how they do it.1. About 3months out they will put a Mech or Mechs Packages up for sell. Real Cash outside the game store normal with some modules or Paint pattern for free or more add it for Buying Early2. The Mech get patch in to the game for those with the Package.3. About 3 weeks after the Mech getting it game it go up for MC (Real Cash in game store)4. About 3 weeks after MC patch it go on sell for C-Bills the in game Cash you earn every game you play. PGI also put on Event almost every Month where you can Earn Free Mechs, MC, Modules, Color and Patterns. No Weapon are behind Pay walls, (they are divided between the Two Tech Faction) Clan stuff can only go on Clan Mechs, and I.S. Stuff can only go on I.S. Stuff.There is in game Voice so ask questions if you need help. So go to the MWOMercs website to learn Much more about the game.The Learning Curve for this Game is VERY HIGH so it will take time to learn.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6
												It's the MechWarrior IP. if you grew up in the 90's you probably played these and there's nothing quite like it out there. Lots and lots of depth and strategy for what is essentially a FPS, and the learning curve is very challenging. Teamwork and patience is the key to rewarding gameplay. It's purportedly Free to Play, but the grind is really like any other game of this type, so getting some DLC for $20 or more is usually worth it, as long as you do your research.Developer is active but doesn't have the resources of having a big publishing house behind it, so fixes come slowly but it's pretty well polished for now. If you are 30 years old and want to relive your youth this game is just perfect. If you are younger, come on in, the water is fine!

number of helpful: 21 of 46 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												Thought I'd simplify my review because nobody likes a block of text. Still has the same points. Firstly- this is not a review on the developer. Just a review on the game itself. If you want dev drama, look elsewhere. The simplest way to put MechWarrior: Online is... it delivers some but not all of what you want in a MechWarrior game. And so much of it is subjective. It delivers enough to be a fun, relatively high quality mech shooter using fairly refined yet arguably simplified MechWarrior mechanics. It caters more towards the modern F2P competitive shooter crowd than previous MW games, and is more of a shooter than it is a sim. On those grounds alone, then yes, I recommend the game. Especially if you're a BT fan in any way- it's free, you're not losing anything by giving it a shot. It isn't all that you want in a MechWarrior game... but it's enough for now.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												I was a fan of Mechwarrior "back in the day," and played a lot of Mechwarrior 2: Mercenaries. Honestly, this game captured a lot of that feeling for me. It's not as deep, but at the same time the learning curve is a little bit easier, too. If you're on the fence about whether or not you should pick this game up, I challenge you to beat the price. Even if you only play it for two hours and put it down, you paid exactly $0.00.New players have access to trial mechs so you don't have to worry too much about being overmatched right out the gate. Things can get a little grindy after you've played your first 25 matches (and gotten a huge bonus for each one), but it doesn't feel terribly unfair. Even if you're consistently on the losing side and a terrible player, you'll usually make some C-Bills.There are only three things I don't like about this game, and they're pretty minor:1. Absolutely no cosmetic customization options are currently available (15December2015) without paying some real money. You can't so much as change your paint job without spending real money. Not a big deal to me, but not something I feel like spending real dough on, you know?2. The pricing is a little predatory. You don't get a lot of virtual currency for your real cash - it's like Zynga designed their pricing scheme.3. I don't feel like this is a pay to win game. I've won plenty without spending a dime! However, the people who are willing to dish out real money can get a definite advantage if they want it, loading themselves out with premier mechs and equipment. Skill is still a huge factor, and a good "free" player will still usually do fine, but it can be a little annoying watching a Hero-level Timber Wolf walking around the map... it's like watching that guy who got into a prestigious college because his dad bought them a new library.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												A friend got me into this game quite some time ago, and I had a blast with it.  Don't let the time on steam fool you since I've been playing for 50 to 100hrs of game time, potentially more.  In short, MechWarrior Online (MWO) is an interesting game where you get to pilot your own X ton robot to blow the crap out of other people piloting their own X ton robot.  The game can be fast or slow, depending upon what type of team you get into.  Members of the community can be a mixed bag where you'll get some helpful veteran players or jerks.  What drew me into MWO wasn't the aspect of it being free, but the depth to which you can customize your playthrough.  Mechs that have light tonnage can be extremly fast and agile.  This lends itself to a quick playthrough, but you're a walking target since armor is quite limited.  On the other end of the spectrum would be Heavy/Assault.  Do NOT confuse the two as Assault mechs are the heaviest class of mechs (the Atlas being a primary example), and these boys do some serious damage with heavier firepower.  Overall, I would give the game a shot, however, I will give some word of caution.  This isn't an FPS game where you run in guns blazing to take down every single enemy in sight.  It's a more tactical approach where you have to isolate targets and attack as a coordinated group.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												First off, I have around 500+ hours on this game and have played since beta(I wrote this review a few weeks before this game was released on steam but most almost everything is still true)This game is super underrated, especially in the state it's in. There are no real advantages to paying except for the fact that you can get hero mechs that just have different hard-points than the 3-5 variants of that specific mech... as if there wasn't enough varietyThey've added new game modes, a much better tutorial that actually rewards you, and a ton of new mechs with tons more to come.I have to admit, the game is extremely difficult to learn, it can take 3+ matches just to properly work the move mechanics and up to 100+ hours just to master aiming, movement, heat, weapon groups, builds, ect and keeping it all in line while in a fight.The game has a huge penalty for those who stray off in heavier mechs, which I love because it forces you to use some sort of teamwork and co-ordination.With the addition of voice chat it makes it much easier to co-ordinate flanks and other tactical plans.But I can guarantee this game is not pay to win, paying can give you a larger variety of mechs but will not make you better than anyone else.This game is NOT pay to winCons: Metas are developingClan mechs ALMOST always outgun inner spheres (But it seems to be getting work done on it)Learning the game takes a whileGame is not very popular leading to long queue times that can take 5+ minutes some times and you often times see the same people from previous games.Game is really fun, it constantly updated, and has many events and the customization is absolutely remarkable. There are also achievements that reward you with in game currency, exp, titles, and other things when completed giving you some sort of drive to go for them.I've spent around 10 dollars on the game just to get a hero mech that I was really interested in and a few cockpit items that are purely for appearance. I actually don't use that hero mech anymore because I am absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥in it but I do give it a go here and there.Definitely a game everyone should check out. Be patient when learning though, or you might find yourself getting quite frustrated.﻿Also, I noticed that almost everybody who is posting a review is a hardcore veteran. This is the first mechwarrior game I've ever played and I have to say, it's amazing. I started playing with a friend of mine who has played tons of mech warrior games and he taught me a bit about the game which lightened the extreme learning curve but now there is a very helpful tutorial that can really help new players understand movement, shooting, heat, etc.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												Oh Mechwarrior Online... What can I say, I've had a love hate relationship with this game for quite sometime. Playing as far back as open beta, this game never lived up to what Mechwarrior 5 could have been (at least in my opinion). However, playing on and off all these years, it slowly but surely did get a place in my heart and hopefully I can persuade you into playing this rather unique multiplayer game.Pros:-Giant, beautifully detailed, engines of destruction, Alex Iglesias has done a superbe job revitalising these old mech designs.-Exillerating combat, when you engage in a so called death circle where both pilots are moving in a circle shooting at critical points until one of you is left standing-Slow paced, now this is subjective, but to me its nice to play a slower multiplayer game when most multiplayer shooters are fast paced and twichy.-Decent maps and design-Customization has always been a strong point of Mechwarrior or any battletech game and MWO does not fail to deliver on that front-Regular content influx by the devs with tons of content on the way- Reworked old maps with time of day added-Reworked Tutorial that goes much more indepth-Two main factions with their own unique mechs that work differently-A ♥♥♥♥ton of mechs to choose from, all with unique cockpits (however, it's worth mentioning that mechs have chassis and variants i.e. the Raven mech is the chassis but it had 3 variants of it which look exactly the same but have different potential loadouts, basically, even though there are a lot of mechs, some are "repeats" of the same mech)-Private lobbies -Good matchmaking done by rank and also by weight type i.e. the matchmaker will alwasys try to creat matches with 3 assaults, 3 heavies, 3 mediums and 3 lights-F2P model that is pretty fair, you can't buy power, only mechs with unique skins and extra income potential.-Servers on NA, EU and OceanicCons:-Sound assets could really use some work, Autocannons, lasers, missles don't sound pleasant-Multiple gamemodes that all boil down to Deathmatch in a huge deathball formation (i.e. all mechs just cluster together and slug it out)-Community Warfare (this is the one gamemode that doesn't always degenerate into deathmatch, but even then counterattacks are essentially deathmatches, it's only attack/defend where you have to option to destroy the generators and the huge orbital gun to win instead of killing everyone) that has been in beta for eons, it has tons of promise but the development for it should have started way back in open beta imho, not 1 year into the release. As it currently stands it's alright, but nothing to write home about.-Killing a mech isn't satisfiying, no huge explosion sounds or a fireball exploding from the cockpit as the pilot ejects, just a puff of black smoke with the mech slowly falling down to the ground, ragdoll style, the explosion sounding more like a television frying out, not particularly impressive-Mech immersion isn't the greatest, you can run over trees on certain maps, but buildings, vehicles and terrain are all indestructable-The leveling up of mechs isn't really the best as it is very time consuming (ofc it's probably due to it being F2P), basically you have to buy 3 variants of the same mech(which is long in it of itself) and unlock basic skills, etlie skills and master skills for each of the 3 mech variants. However, it is worth mentioning that the skills themselves aren't game breaking, they make your mech handle better and move slightly faster than it otherwise would.-Preordering mechs is an alright way for PGI to make money, but the in-game rewards you get for prepurchase generally aren't worth the price they ask for. -Speaking of prices, the price for buying mechs with irl cash is pretty crazy going anywhere from 20-100+$ granted those 100+$ ones usually come with multiple mechs, but still, one mech costing 20$ is pretty expensive.In the end MWO is one of those games you have to try for yourself, it's F2P so there's not much to lose, and all things considered, it's a pretty good one at that.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												Let me start off by saying that I don't write reviews.MechWarrior Online, though, I am writing one for.I really, really love this game. It really allows you to cater to nearly every playstyle with a high level of customization (with the right mech chassis, of course, which will likely be your hardest choice). The game is NOT pay to win, you can only pay for cosmetic items and shortcut items so you don't have to grind so hard. However, I find buying it discouraging to buy anything in the store, because the price points are much higher than the majority of other games I've played involving in-game transactions. For example, a premium assault mech (heaviest and hardest-hitting class) Stalker Misery (top of my wishlist) is roughly $40 - for ONE mech. You don't find many people in this game who just throw that kind of money at one item just to win. Even then, it's more skill and team-based than anything, and those who do pay for primo features are often targeted and taken down first. Big thumbs up to the devs, this game is a breath of fresh air in every way. Keep doing what you're doing.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												I'm not going to discuss the entire lengthy history of Mechwarrior Online it's highs and lows it's troubles and the lot. If you want that I'm sure there is a review that will or a google search. I am going to talk about the game as it is today, the 25th of December 2015. This is a solid title faithful to Battletech/Mechwarrior franchise. There is a learning curve, some may find it steep but the first time you take down an enemy battlemech is a wonderful feeling and well worth the effort involved to get good at the game. Mech balance is overall fairly good with 30 ton light mechs able to compete against 100 ton Assaults. Weapons are actually pretty balanced and while balance is ongoing for such things the majority of mechs in the game are viable and actively used. The F2P model is expensive but not required to have an acceptable fun time. It does speed things along but no more so then any other game title offering a "premium time" earnings. You are however limited to 4 mechbays, while more can be earned with frequent events and Community Warfare you may eventually find yourself doing the math and paying 1.50$ for a mechbay. My biggest complaint would be Community Warfare not being in an acceptable state. The game mode is supposed to be the idea of factions facing off for galactic conquest but the way the matches play out doesn't capture that feeling at all at the moment.Mostly you'll be hitting quick join and playing in one of the three game modes with several maps. It's fun and enjoyable if you like a sim like game vs other players. In the end I'd suggest you try it if you have any interest at all in giant robots. It's free, the new player experience is pretty good and you can rapidly find yourself having fun if you are at all a fan of vertical tanks.

												This game has two sides.The mechlaband the battlingThe mechlab is an ingenius design that will make you think about the different weaponery and devices placed on the mech. Will it overheat quickly, will it move fast enough, does it have the firepower to cause a dent in the enemies armour. Also your choice of mechs is vital, as there may not be enough "tonnage", to be able to completely kit up the mech. This alone, is part of the challenge that this game has to offer.Then the combat. This video should sum it up 


YouTube™ Video: War always changes - Mech Warrior Online 

			Views: 29		

			Contradicting what fallout 4 said. This took very long to edit. mainly because of syncing the music to the mech. Feedback is wanted on every video. Post it in the comments		

The combat does have some remarkably good mechanics in play. For  example, turning the mech off makes you invisible to radar(and i think thermal imagining). Great for hiding in a corner, then shooting the enemy in the back.my only issue, is that the game offers a locational damage engine, but still feels like the mechs have a base health system. This may be because there isn't alot of critical points, or that the armour negates the locational damage, but it just doesn't feel as impressive as war thunders damage engine.also, the game is very generous to new players, giving  currency boosts in the space of 12 hours of game play to get a decent mech in the game(or weaponary,etc).But overall, a well made game. Play it, see what you think. don't like it? uninstall it.:)

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												So, I'll say this: I've been playing MWO since closed beta, and I've played Mechwarrior since I was 3. I'm somewhat of a fanboy of the series, and still play MW4 and MW3 regularly.MWO is not those games. MWO has a completely different atmoshpere. The 'mechs feel lighter, they're not the slow to respond, big, heavy feeling behemoths they were before. They're not the up close brawlers that are hard to even aim with that they were in 4, and they're not the insane boat builds you'd get in 3.MWO is not a classic Mechwarrior game. It doesn't have the campaign, the scale, the intensity, or the character. Mechwarrior 4 is a prime example with people like Duncan Fisher, Bird Dog, Aisha Thastus, and all the Lancemates you'd see.MWO is a jump in, jump out, queue based first person shooter with robots. It is not a simulator, it doesn't feel as heavy as the old games, and, yes, Living Legends feels more like a Mechwarrior game if we're talking purely about controls and mobility. I personally love the fact that 4 has weird aiming controls, and that you really have to have timing and positioning to hit something, it just immerses you more that way.And that's where I come to my main point: Mechwarrior Online is a fun as absolute heck game. I've spent many hours playing my Locust LCT-1E and Wolverine WVR-6K. I haven't even played 80% of the 'mechs in the game. I could have built up a Dire Wolf or two, along with several Mediums and Lights by this point, but I've had too much fun just piloting a Locust and wiping the floor with 'mechs several times my size.And, yes, you can do that. People will tell you that light 'mechs are useless, and that Assaults being more expensive is just a way to make you buy MC so you can get actual good 'mechs faster.Those people, however, are absolute morons. I've carried many games in my Locust, many of which I would have lost in a bigger, slower 'mech. I've torn apart entire lances of assault 'mechs, dealt more damage than half of my team combined, and won matches more or less single handedly.And I'm bad at this game compared to a lot of people I knowMWO is very much a game where the team as a whole matters massively, but one 'mech can easily be the difference between winning and losing."It's always helpful to have teammates; it gives the enemy something else to shoot at."That is Mechwarrior Online's teamplay in a nutshell. Stay near your teammates (Without blocking them or shooting them in the back, please.), and focus on dealing as much damage and killing as many enemies as possible while staying alive.You may carry the team alone in a light 'mech, but you still need them there to absorb damage and keep the enemy team's attention. No 'mech, no matter the weight and class, will be able to survive an entire enemy team. Even if that entire team is stock Urbanmechs.So, my verdict of MWO? If you liked the old 'mechwarrior games, at least give it a shot. If you haven't tried one before, this is the easiest one to get into, and will at least give you an impression of the universe. Joining a unit is a really effective way to learn about the game and the lore, and having friends makes everything more fun.I reccomend this game wholeheartedly, personally- but it's certainly not for everyone.Also, no, the Trial 'Mechs aren't bad, you just suck. No, you shouldn't use a joystick, they suck. No, Clans are not overpowered. No, you will not carry the team alone. No, you may not be on my team, shoot me in the back, and expect to be alive for more than 3 seconds afterwards.That is all.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												The most ballanced Mechwarrior/Battletech game yet, lacking the insane legging issues of Mechwarrior 3 (where losing one leg would take you out of the match) and the poptarting meta-game of Mechwarrior 4 (hiding behind a hill then jumping up for fire and letting the hill protect you as your weapons reloaded)The ever changing nature of an MMO, and Free-to-play games in general however, does mean that today's best mechs, can be tomorrow's garbage - and then back again.Case in point, since open beta, I have watched the Hunchback chassis travel from "Best medium chassis in the game, and nothing can change that" to "worthless garbage, and nothing can change that" and back at least twice.Now for a comparison of sorts...As far as most free-to-play issues (IE, is it REALLY free?)Absolutely no money needs to be spent to do well, or to do ANYTHING in the game.What mechs there are that cost real-world money to buy, can be bought with patience and timing.MC (The real-world-money equivalent) is given for playing the Faction Warfare mode (also known as Community Warfare) as are Mechbays - arguably the one thing you would need to actually buy.In the end, knowing your mech, and how to play, is far more important than anything else.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												My hours are low in Steam, but I have played this game a fair amount from the main client it self downlaoding it from their main website.This game will teach you patience, and that is not a bad thing. You will learn to lean on your team mates for the weaknesses you have. May it be speed, ECM, AMS, or lacking fire power. You will get more out of this game if you play with a small team so you can coordinate with them.Some people say this game is pay to win, I personally think it's kind of true, but it isn't bad compared to other games. Theres only so much you can pay for in this game, you just have to counter their weapon setup. If you play this game a fair amount you'll know what kind of weapons a mech is packing just looking at them. Think first, map awareness, position, and fire.You can enjoy this game solo, but team voice chat, socializing, planning, having the leader mark the map, is where this game shines.

												Mechwarrior Online has made great strides since splitting from its original publisher (IGP). If you can get past its expensive pricing structure, the core gameplay is enjoyable and often times exhilerating. Unlike many Free to Play games, MWO does not fall prey to pay to win. Instead their mech packs give early access to new mech chasis.I would recommend this title to anyone who enjoys piloting stompy robots, shooting lasers, and working as a team. This is not an FPS, and going rambo won't get you very far. While there is a steep learning curve, the new tutorial system and helpful community are great assets.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2016
												Although I'd say that it leans a little more towards the action game side of things than the classic MechWarrior sims, I think it still captures the feeling of being a mech pilot pretty well. I was apprehensive due to admittedly being a bit of a sim snob when it comes to this sort of game, but I'm finding it to be a lot of fun. Sure, they made a few changes from the board game, but even as a fan, I can deal with them. I think it still does a pretty good job of giving each type of mech a job, and not turning it into a simple shooter. You can take a missile boat and provide long-range support from cover, or a fast & light recon machine with electronic warfare equipment, or brawler, etc., and I think they did a pretty good job of making each one feel like what it is.Regarding the "freemium" thing, the one thing that kind of annoys me is that you have to use MC (the currency you have to pay for, as opposed to C-Bills, which you can earn by playing) to pay for changing the colors on your mech, and it's not exactly cheap. That's pretty minor though, and so far I'm having plenty of fun with the mechs I've purchased using the C-Bills I got from matches (there are "special" ones you can't buy with CB). They give you a bonus amount of CB for each of your first 25 matches, so even if you suck as bad as I did, you can afford to get something cool by the end of that.Overall, it's better than I expected, and while it's not perfect, it is a lot of fun.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												I've been playing this game for a long time, and though I do like the game, it isn't without flaws. In general, matches can range from awesome to a complete waste of time. Faction warfare is meant to be the defining mode of the game, but it's just not very good. Every map revolves around choke points which leads to no tactics and every match feels the same. Hardpoint bloating, weapon boating, and the insanely high pinpoint damage this causes are my main issues. Players will put no thought into builds and just slap on as many of one type of weapon as they can, and since many mechs have a ridiculous amount of hardpoints, they're able to put out so much damage, time to kill becomes non existant.Despite these problems I have, I still can't get myself to leave this game. In my opinion, those fantastic matches, though increasingly rare these days, make the game still worth playing. It is free to play, so if you're into mechs I still think this game is worth a try.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												This game is an awesome online team game, that allows you to purchase mechs that can be fully customizable.  Pick your favorite mech type and then build it the way you want, with the weapons you want.  The maps allow for all types of play styles and the game types keep everything interesting.  You can build a fast, close-range attacker or go heavy long-range assault.  If you like piloting your own robotic warmachine and coordinating with friends, then this is definitely the game for you.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												I really like the game and enjoy playing it.  That being said this game has a steep learning curve.   1. Balancing a mech and playing as an organized unit are hard, especially organizing in PUG matches.  While your mech build is important, the team play and communication are most important.  2. Most mechs are playable and can do well; you just have to find the right heat/firepower/range ratio for that mech model and build. There are usually several and they can be personalized.  3. Pay to Win?  The new mech releases are only available to purchase with real money, but most of the models become available in a few months for in game money.  There are a few obsolete models from the game launch, and a few small bonues on the newer released mechs.  4. Overall, this does not matter much.  I.E. The mech and model that I do best with has been there since launch, cost in game money, and has been nerfed a few times.  Your skill is what matters.5.  Spending real money, allows you access to the newer mechs, special mechs (The real difference is a paint job), cockpit items, and customizable paint jobs.  6. Grind:  The game has lots of bonus challanges, going on almost every day, that allow you to win in game money, in game cash credits, mechs, and cockpit items.  You can always use trial mechs from the start to earn these bonuses.  7.  Mech and skill advancement; Buy a medium or heavy mech to start with.  They are the most versatile and do well when together.  Save your in game money and buy 2 variants of your first mech so you can master that mech.  You should earn close to enough in game currency to buy the next model once you have skilled up the basic tier of a medium or heavy mech.  8.  Talk; It is a team combat simulation.  The keys are to focus fire, stay together, and communicate.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												Hands down this is the best free-to-play game out there.  It grants no advantage to those who pay, just greater variety.  I've played penniless for about 70 hours and had a blast!  Any old Mechwarrior fan would be most proud of this build, and any tank-game player would be an easy convert.  Very dedicated community, religious updates from devs, and great art direction.  I can't say enough about how well-made this game is, top to bottom.
